column2: SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Einar Mohn, president of the Western Conference of Teamsters, said today that organized labor had a job of public relations to develop more membership interest in union affairs.

SOMETHING must be happening to the women of New York State and the League of Women Voters, or somebody, ought to look into it. No fewer than twenty-five women were convicted of game-law violations in one month.
The J. C. Penney Company, which operate a chain of 1,684 department stores, showed a decline in sales and earnings in the first six months of this year from those of a year ago.
A thorough reorganization of the city's Bureau of Real Estate culminating in its conversion into a department directly responsible to Mayor Wagner was recommended yesterday.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 7 -- A royal proclamation tonight named six new Ministers and announced other changes in two Ministries, in a reshuffle of Premier Thanom Kittikachorn's Cabinet.
Following is the text of the statement yesterday by Thomas E. Murray on entering the race for the Democratic nomination for Senator:

The Federal Reserve System reduced its holdings of 91-day Treasury bills by $648,850,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the largest drop in system bill holdings since Sept. 30, 1950.
HAVANA, Aug. 7 -- The Cuban Red Cross will again take over from the rebels wounded Cuban soldiers in Oriente Province, it was learned today.
The twenty Republican legislators seeking re-election in New York City pledged yesterday to move to repeal six unused city nuisance taxes at the next session of the Legislature.

HONG KONG, Aug. 7 -- The Chinese Communist party organ, the People's Daily, provided today an indication that the Soviet Union and China had not seen eye to eye on what steps should be taken to solve the Middle East crisis.
ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- A 31-year-old mother was stabbed to death in her home here today by an escaped inmate of Rockland State Hospital while three women neighbors fought to save her.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- A recommendation that E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and its associated companies be permitted to retain ownership of 63.000,000 shares of General Motors Corporation stock was submitted in the United States District Court here today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- American scientists said today they had failed completely in their week-long attempt to get assurance here of the automatic publication of all data gathered in space by Soviet satellites.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Gov. Abraham Ribicoff may be called upon to resolve a controversy that involves one of this town's most popular lovers' lanes, a barricade on it and some local fishermen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The House of Representatives approved the compromise reciprocal trade bill today by a standing vote of 161 to 56. The Senate is expected to complete Congressional action Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Unemployment dropped slightly in July from the seventeen-year high recorded in June, but apparently still held above 5,000,000, Government economists said today.
The Rhein-Main airport in Frankfurt has been designated Germany's first commercial jet airport by the Government of the Federal Republic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Arthur Miller's conviction for contempt of Congress was reversed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 7 -- The Atlantic Fleet has resumed "normal operations" after a three-week readiness alert put into effect July 15 following the landing of United States Marines in Lebanon.
The account of the tragic death of the soldier at Fort Jackson reported in The Times of Aug. 2 prompts the following comment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The House approved by voice vote today legislation under which penalty taxes would be assessed against American importers under the so-called anti-dumping act whenever the Tariff Commission was evenly split on the issue.

Record sales and earnings for any of its first half-year periods were established by the National Dairy Products Corporation in the first six months of this year, E. E. Stewart, board chairman and president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Secretary of State Dulles returned from Brazil this afternoon and tossed a jest in the direction of Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Premier. Then he hurried to the White House to plan strategy for a United Nations General Assembly meeting.
PARIS, Aug. 7 -- It was reliably reported here today that Premier Charles de Gaulle had no intention of attending a special session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
Thomas E. Murray, a former Atomic Energy Commissioner, entered the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. (UPI) -- The United States has demanded that the Soviet Union grant the United States Embassy in Moscow the same right to distribute press releases that the Soviet Embassy has here, the State Department disclosed today.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 7 -- The paradise of chalk players and noncapitalist harness racing drivers, little Freehold Raceway, opened its 107th season of racing in its refurbished plant this afternoon.
Six British yachtsmen arrived yesterday to begin final preparations here for the America's Cup races to be held off Newport, R. I., starting Sept. 20.

SEATTLE, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Miss Supertest, with Bob Hayward at the wheel, led six qualifiers today for the Gold Cup hydroplane race on Sunday. A total of twelve craft are now in the fleet with two days of trials remaining. As many as eighteen are expected to start.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 7 (Reuters) -- The Associated Press of Pakistan reported today that Indian armed forces had opened fire on Pakistani territory all along the disputed Burma River sector.

Playbill, Inc., publisher of playbills for major theatres here, has leased a floor at 240 Madison Avenue near Thirty-eighth Street. The concern will move from 108 Wooster Street where it has been for most of the seventy-five years of its existence, E. G. Roos of William Co., agent for the building, negotiated the lease.
CROSBY, Minn., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The nation's biggest balloon carried some animal life on a brief space journey today, but it ripped and came down before accomplishing its mission.
Your "People and Stamps" editorial on Aug. 3 makes the interesting observation that "most private citizens are far more concerned about good mail service than mail service at a bargain."

Directors of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 25 cents from the 50 cents distributed in previous quarters. It is payable Sept. 10. The company had maintained the $2 annual rate on the common stock since the merger of Olin Industries and Mathieson Chemical in 1954.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 7 -- Senator Albert Gore was assured of a second term today despite his primary opponent's bitter attacks against the legislator's moderate stand on public school integration.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 -- In the eyes of the Brazilian Government and a majority of the public, Secretary of State Dulles' short visit here was a major milestone in the improvement of inter-American relations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The United States has decided to back an increase in the resources of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
DUBLIN, Aug. 7 (AP) -- -- Albert Thomas, a tiny Australian clerk, broke the world's record for two miles tonight with a time of 8 minutes 32 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The following is the text of a joint communique on hemispheric matters issued at Brasilia, Brazil, last night, at the conclusion of talks between Secretary of State Dulles and the Brazilian President:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 7 -- Collapse of the project for a summit conference on the Middle East caused some gloom in Lebanon today.
Some time next month, $42,000,000 in first preferred ship mortgage bonds will be publicly offered to investors, without having been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 7 -- Britain moved a fresh battalion of troops into Jordan today to help protect her new military supply line to Amman from Aqaba on the Red Sea, 180 miles to the south. [A British battalion usually consists of 600 to 700 men.]
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7 -- The annual midsummer revel known as Tanglewood on Parade was celebrated here today, all day.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 7 -- In a spanking westerly breeze that piped up to above twenty knots, Columbia paced the twelve-meter sloops in today's twenty-five-mile squadron run of the New York Yacht Club cruise.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in effect today that the Arab nations would have to accept the existence of Israel as a permanent entity if peace was to be maintained in the Middle East.
TRENTON, Aug. 7 -- The possibility of a legislative investigation of the financial structure of the State Highway Authority loomed tonight.

CAIRO, Aug. 7 -- Robert Murphy was reported today to have told President Gamal Abdel Nasser emphatically that the United States had no intention of pulling its troops out of Lebanon until the situation was stabilized and the Government there requested it.
The Fire Department ordered an investigation yesterday into a fireman's charge that he had been ordered to leave Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx before recovering from injuries.
THOMAS EDWARD MURRAY, electrical engineer, inventor and industrialist, is a plain-spoken, outspoken man of strong independent views.
Mrs. May Preston Davie, first vice chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, "just tending the store" for the committee, put five of the party's November specials on display yesterday.

Member banks' excess reserves decreased $74,000,000, on average, during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. From a slightly revised figure of $634,000,000 the week before, they declined to $560,000,000.

A brand new world of cruising experiences greets the skipper who leaves the tides, turbuence and currents of Long Island Sound or New York's Lower Bay and heads northward on a vacation run. He learns his pleasure craft can slide or coast "uphill" by taking advantage of flooding tides and the appropriate hour to start a voyage.

TAKE it from Tyrus Raymond Cobb, the holder of more baseball records than any other player, man's ingenuity has made some tremendous advances in Cobb's lifetime. But, where physical effort and competitive skill are involved, no substitute has been found for hard work.

Two hundred boys and girls rowed their boats merrily but with varying degrees of gentleness on the lake in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday. The occasion: the second annual rowing regatta conducted by the Department of Parks for youngsters from 9 to 14 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission questioned today the advertising of a jewelry concern that bought 16,000 smuggled diamonds from the Government.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The tensest moments for a good many of the 12,110 customers at the Saratoga track today came after the feature race was run but before its result was made official.
NEWARK, Aug. 7 -- New Jersey's new law prohibiting Sunday sales by general merchandise stores will be subjected to a court review on constitutional grounds.
Following is the text of the recommendations made by James Felt in his report to Mayor Wagner on reorganization of the Board of Estimate's Bureau of Real Estate:
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 -- Alberto Lleras Camargo was inaugurated President of Colombia this afternoon. The ceremony took place in the Capitol before a joint session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The $39,602,827,000 Defense Department appropriation cleared its final Congressional hurdle today.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug 7 (AP) -- A Bomarc defense-interceptor missile was launched successfully by remote control from 1,500 miles away today, but it failed to find its target.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Following is the text of the resolution proposed by the United States, as amended and adopted unanimously tonight by the Security Council:

Utica, N. Y., borrowed $2,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the building of a municipal auditorium. The money was raised by the sale of general obligations maturing serially from 1960 to 1988 to a syndicate headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that nothing was more important than work for a stable and just world peace.
New York will begin enforcing its jaywalking laws this morning, with both pedestrians and motorists on notice to respect each others' right of way.

Ward Industries Corporation has entered an agreement to acquire from the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., the outstanding stock of the three Amerind Shipping Corporations. These act as freight or berth agents for several foreign ships and shipping lines in several Southern ports.

Times have changed from the days when yachting fanciers went to watch yacht races in their own yachts. At next month's America's Cup Races, off Newport, R. I., they'll be watching from an ocean liner.
OSSINING, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Angelo La Marca, 33-year-old kidnap-slayer of infant Peter Weinberger, was electrocuted tonight in Sing Sing prison.
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today that a special session of the United Nations General Assembly was acceptable.
ATHENS, Aug. 7 -- In an urgent and dramatic effort to solve the Cyprus question, British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan arrived in Athens this afternoon.
BOGOTA, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Tonight the new Cabinet, consisting of six Conservative and six Liberal ministers, was announced as follows:
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The stock market improved modestly today despite the unsettling effects of yesterday's setback on Wall Street and the announcement of a sharp fall in June's industrial output index.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 622,204 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
BERLIN, Aug. 7 -- The East German police surrounded today the suburban hamlet of Steinstuecken on the southwest border of West Berlin and captured a man believed to be a deserter from their force.

A one-hour television program featuring the Moiseyev Dance Company of Moscow, first presented on June 29, will be repeated by tape recording later this year over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Alfons Landa, new president of the Penn-Texas Corporation, has been invited to become a counsel for a stockholders' group that is challenging the management contract between the Studebaker-Packard Corporation and Curtiss-Wright Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- St. Lawrence Seaway authorities were warned today that they had "dangerously" underestimated operation costs and overestimated the capacity of the new waterway.

A frustrated payroll bandit and his accomplice might have been sipping hot coffee yesterday while they wondered what went wrong. They had planned to grab the $2,000 payroll of the M. Wille Company, a Bronx gift concern.

Net income of Eastern Air Lines in the first six months this year was $4,940,378, equal to $1.69 a share on 2,929,180 shares outstanding. This compared with $5,319,810, or $1.86 a share on 2,858,636 shares outstanding, for the first half of 1957.
The submarine that emerged near Iceland four days ago was the second Nautilus to attempt a passage under the North Pole.

YONKERS, Aug. 8 -- A long overland trip from fifth position at the halfway mark carried Worthy Willow, driven by Clint Hodgins, to a one-length victory over Menace in the Putnam Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Army Chief of Staff, conferred today with Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss and the heads of the West Germany armed forces.
CAIRO, Aug. 8 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser's avowed neutralism is suffering severe strains.
Waiter Vincent, president of the Actors Fund of America, will celebrate his ninetieth birthday tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -The House of Representatives adopted today a four-year, $900,000,000 bill to aid science education.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8 -- The Soviet Union is sending Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to the United Nations to head the Soviet team that will charge the United States and Britain with "aggression" in the Middle East.
WARSAW, Aug. 5 -- That knock on the door in Poland these days means that the Government bill collector is outside and means business.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Constant vigil against the spread of secrecy in government was urged today before the American Newspaper Guild.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Reneged staged a comeback that satisfied the most skeptical in the crowd of 11,018 at the Saratoga track today. Favorite in the $23,700 American Legion Handicap, the 5-year-old son of Revoked ran through the slop with ease to take the seven-furlong test in 1:24.

Abdelmonem Shaker in his letter published in The Times of July 23 makes an eloquent plea for Arab nationalism. However, he also shows the grave error of this movement when he states, "Gamal Abdel Nasser is the living symbol of this Arab nationalism which is now burning in the hearts and minds of millions of Arab peoples * * *."

A group of eighteen United States commercial banks, headed by The Guaranty Trust Company of New York and J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., are arranging a three-year interim credit with Belguim, it was announced yesterday. The interest rate and terms were not disclosed.

Shipments of zinc from smelters to domestic industry rose sharply last month to the highest level so far this year. In addition, production continued to decline. But stocks of unsold metal in smelters' hands continued to mount, nevertheless, and at the end of July were the largest in more than twelve years.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Aug. 7 -- Akram Hourani, Syrian Vice President of the United Arab Republic, denounced suggestions for a Middle East settlement today as "giving new gains to Israel."

Adlai E. Stevenson has departed from Moscow without gaining satisfaction in his efforts to obtain royalties for American authors whose work has been published by the Soviet Government. One would have thought that the justice of the American authors' request for payment would have been obvious to Moscow, even if presented by one much less intelligent and persuasive than Mr. Stevenson.
CALGARY, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press) -- An American oil company disclosed today that it was investigating the possibility of using nuclear energy to facilitate recovery of oil.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities recommended today that Carl Braden and Frank Wilkinson, witnesses at recent hearings at Atlanta, be cited for contempt of Congress.

The Pan American International Oil Company, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), announced yesterday the signing of a contract with Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, the Argentine Government's oil agency.
PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy left here today with a declaration that Italy would work closely with her allies to assure peace in the Middle East.
A new ocean -- the frozen wastes of the Arctic -- has been opened to navigation and hence to naval utilization.

JOHNSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Two men have ridden in a Navy-built laboratory space ship traveling 18,000 miles an hour in an acceleration experiment. For six seconds, because of terrific pressure, their weight increased twenty times above normal to more than a ton and a half.
A group of Brooklyn business concerns obtained an order in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday barring the Jay Street Connecting Railroad from discontinuing its operations.

DUBLIN, Aug. 8 -- A poor first round cost the United States team the Aga Khan Trophy at the Dublin horse show today. Despite a brilliant recovery, the Americans, favored to take the top jumping award of the show, placed second behind Britain.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Senate rackets investigators voted unanimously today to ask the Senate to approve contempt-of-Congress citations against thirteen witnesses.

HICKORY, N. C., Aug. 8 (UPI) -- An emergency fund of nearly $2,000 was raised today to help pay the medical bills for a 4-year-old infantile paralysis victim caught in the middle of a legal battle over March of Dimes contributions.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 8 -A Long Island scoutmaster has been accused of looting the treasury of his Boy Scout troop before disappearing last month.
Houlihan-Martocci was cobroker with the L. J. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company in the recent sale of the Linwood Park Apartments on White Plains Road, Eastchester, N. Y.

Prime Minister Nehru has done a public service in stating bluntly that the Arab states will have to accept the fact of a permanent Israeli nation if there is to be real peace in the Middle East. A settlement, he said, "obviously involves the continuation of Israel and its acceptance by the Arab countries and other countries around it."
The ice-clad ocean that has been traversed by a submarine for the first time is perhaps the shallowest, and certainly the least explored of any on this planet.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 8 -- Venezuela had an unfavorable balance of $162,970,000 in its international trade during the first half of this year, according to a report from the Central Bank released today. However, its gold and dollar reserves at the end of the period totaled $1,282,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 8 -- Following are the texts of statements today before the emergency special session of the United Nations General Assembly by Sir Leslie Munro of New Zealand, President of the Assembly, and Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General:
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (AP)--Australia's Murray Rose today shattered the National Amateur Athletic Union out-door 1,500-meter swimming mark with a time of 18:06.4.
The head of a subway conductors' union charged yesterday that a lone conductor on a train would have to "seek assistance from the riding public to guarantee a safe ride."
Tennessee Williams' "Garden District" will open in London on Sept. 16 under the joint auspices of Jerry Leider and John C. Wilson in association With Toby Rowland, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- It is only three years since nuclear propulsion became a reality -with the first trials of the submarine Nautilus.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- T. Keith Glennan, a Cleveland educator and former member of the Atomic Energy Commission, is President Eisenhower's choice to head the new civilan space agency.

Nassau Towers, a four-story building containing sixty apartments at 260 First Street, Mineola, L. I., has been sold by Louis V. Albini and Jay J. Raddock, who built it a year ago. The structure is on a plot 231 by 121 feet and has a garage for thirty cars.
More than fifty contests in Brooklyn and Queens appear on the Board of Elections books for Tuesday's primary.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP)--Following is the text of a White House announcement on Presidential citations to the commander of the Nautilius and to the submarine:...
The Soviets have been making inroads among the peoples of Asia and Africa. I suggest a move by the United States which will dramatically reverse this process.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8--The Argentine Senate adopted today a controversial union organization law that virtually hands the labor movement back to Peronist control.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Albert Maltz, one of the Hollywood Ten in the 1947 investigation of communism in the movie industry, got a passport for Europe today within two hours after he had filed suit to require its issuance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--The man largely responsible for construction of the world's first nuclear-powered submarine was not asked to the White House today to share her moment of triumph.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -- The final week-end of the Berkshire Music Festival started tonight under a clear and cool sky. An audience of 8,353 was attracted to the Tanglewood concert, with its program of two tried-and-true Beethoven favorites -- the Seventh Symphony and the "Emperor" Concerto.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 -- One of the greatest executive sweepstakes of the American business world may be close at hand.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 8 -William J. Gerst, 80 years old, a retired accountant, was arrested today and charged with killing his paralyzed 74-year-old wife with a razor early this morning.
WASHINGTObL Aug. 8 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. of Chicago, has agreed to stop what the Federal Trade Commission contends is a misleading sales campaign involving encyclopedias and children's books.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 8 (UPI) -- The tanker S. E. Graham, which exploded in a collision with another tanker, the Gulfoil, yesterday, still burned near the mouth of Newport Harbor today. All efforts to extinguish the blaze were abandoned.
CASPER, Wyo., Aug. 7 (AP) -- One of Wyoming's pioneer uranium concerns -- the Globe Mining Company -- has been purchased by the Union Carbide Corporation.

As a Republican deeply interested in my party I feel obligated to write and urge all fellow Republicans to vote in the primary on Tuesday, Aug. 12. The designation of the Republican candidate for Congress in our Seventeenth Congressional District on that date is of the utmost importance.

A statement circulated yesterday by the New York Young Democratic Club indicated that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan had made up his mind to enter the race for the Democratic Senate nomination nearly a month ago.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined sharply yesterday. Net losses of 32 to 84 points were recorded, with the far months weakest. The drop was equal to $1.60 to $4.20 a bale.
Pedestrians waited for traffic lights and motorists waited for pedestrians yesterday as the police began enforcing New York's new safety law.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Judge Julius H. Miner today asked for a ruling on the tax status of a new proposal for stock transfer in the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. antitrust case.
The President was asked at his latest news conference if he had any plans to curb inflation.
WHAT is on view in a barn in Huntington, L. I., just ain't hay. It is Jamaican-made furniture.
WEST NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 8 -- The British Curtis Cup team took a 2-1 lead today in a bid to retain the trophy in the international series against the United States women golfers.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 8 (AP) -- John Wolcott of Bridgeport, Conn., sailed off with the Heinzerling Cup today and with it the nation's Snipe Class sailing championship.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Government published today a 159-page summary of the secret trial that sent former Premier Imre Nagy to death for his role in the 1956 anti-Soviet revolt.

CHILLED fruit soups are a summer delight in Germany and the Scandinavian countries. One of the most delicious of these cooling concoctions is the following cherry soup, which also includes fresh peaches and slices of orange and lemon. The recipe was requested by Mrs. Joseph Berke of Brooklyn.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 8 -- Arthur B. Bisguier, Allen Kaufman and Anthony E. Santasiere of New York City were winners today in the third round of the annual United States Chess Federation open championship and were among the twelve leaders with 3-0 scores.
NEWARK, Aug. 8 -- The enforcement of New Jersey's new law closing some stores on Sunday was stayed here today by Superior Court Judge Joseph L. Smith.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Following is a fact sheet issued by the Navy on the nineteen-day 8,146-mile trip by the atomic submarine Nautilus, which made the first voyage under the Arctic icecap:

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- A local official of the Communist-dominated Electrical Trades Union charged today that he had been expelled from the Communist party because he criticized party rigging of union elections.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- One of the largest bank mergers to take place in the West received initial approval here today, when directors of the California Bank tentatively agreed to terms of an offer from the Firstamerica Corporation of San Francisco, proposing a merger through an exchange of stock.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 8--Corn-on-the-cob, barn dances and summer theatre will be among the treats this North Shore community will offer this month to eight young Fulbright scholars from abroad.

The biggest house-moving project in the city's history is scheduled to begin next month. About 200 homes will be moved out of the path of the Clearview Expressway in Queens to sites on two former golf courses.
Nelson A. Rockefeller increased his lead yesterday in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor. He picked up four of the five Orleans County delegates to the G. O. P. state convention.

The Medical Arts Building, an eleven-story structure containing offices for doctors and dentists at 1882 Grand Concourse, corner of Tremont Avenue, in the Bronx, has been purchased by Klausner Associates realty operators.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers asked the National Labor Relations Board today to reopen its investigation of the Kohler company, against which the U. A. W. has been on strike for more than three years.
Gene (Ace) Armstrong of Elizabeth, N. J., whose professional boxing career spans but three years, vaulted into the middleweight division's top rank last night.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Richard Savitt, the defender, met his master in Neale Fraser of Australia in the Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

BASS fishermen have been at play now for more than a month and many of them have forgotten that they were barred by law from fishing in May and June. But some of them, especially those who do not fish for trout, have not forgotten and their pain is not assuaged. Complaints about the late season opening, July 1, come in from time to time.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Bob Bowman's third straight hit drove home the winning run in a two-run ninthinning rally tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies scored a 7-6 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 8 -- Richard Eibel, Polish seaman, won his chance today to become a permanent resident of the United States.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 8 -- Registration of voters for the coming Presidential election began today throughout Venezuela. Voting will be compulsory for all Venezuelan citizens over the age of 18.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will devote two hours instead of the usual ninety minutes of television time to the search for Miss America next month.

The assumption of Presidential office in Colombia by Alberto Lleras Camargo was a great day for the whole of Latin America. It took ten years of civil war and dictatorships before the tortured nation could reach this happy result. But let the dead past bury the 200,000 who died in the fratricidal strife. A new and brighter day has dawned.

Many investors are all too aware that dividend casualties have been unusually heavy this year. This is the toll, according to Standard Poor's Corporation, investment service: Of 5,500 publicly-owned corporations that report dividends, 554 reduced or omitted payments in the first seven months of this year.
A British Comet IV jet airliner is scheduled to arrive tomorrow at New York International Airport for a final series of noise tests for the Port of New York Authority.
A policeman, his wife and a woman store detective and her husband have been arrested on a charge of stealing clothing from a Bronx department store and returning the merchandise for refunds.

WARSAW, Aug. 9 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said here today that he thought the meeting between the Soviet and Chinese Communist leaders in Peiping had brought about Moscow's decision to back out of a heads-of-government meeting in the United Nations Security Council.
Communist China's growing economic strength may well be one of the key factors behind that country's apparent assertiveness in international affairs.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The eight-week-old strike of upstate ironworkers ended today. Negotiators for the union and contractors agreed on a pay and fringe package increase of 40 to 42 1/2 cents an hour.

George Dunlevy, troubleshooter for the New York Telephone Company for thirty-seven years, will retire next Friday on pension. For the last three years, Mr. Dunlevy has been assigned full-time to keep in order the 1,000 telephones in The New York Times building at 229 West Forty-third Street.
WORKING mothers in this country can finally rid themselves of all feelings of guilt. No longer must they feel that they are jeopardizing their children's future by holding down jobs outside the home.
A performance of "The Littlest Circus," a dance-pantomime, to be given Tuesday afternoon at the John Drew Theatre, East Hampton, L. I., will benefit the Guild Hall, a nonprofit center for the arts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 8 -- The Screen Directors Guild last night voted to drop its opposition to Samuel Goldwyn's discharge of Rouben Mamoulian as director of "Porgy and Bess." The group's board of directors also lifted a work boycott against the producer that had been announced last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 119.3 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 8 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower played a late afternoon round of golf at the Gettysburg Country Club today in an effort to straighten out his "terrible" game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -History's first undersea voyage across the top of the world, a distance of 1,830 miles under the polar icecap, was disclosed at the White House today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Following are the names and home states of the men on board the Nautitus during its transpolar voyage:

We note with great interest two letters in your column of July 20 by Lloyd Goodrich, director of the Whitney Museum of Art, and Roy R. Neuberger, president of the American Federation of Arts, commending The Times on its editorial support of "Government in Art" on July 13. A full discussion of the issues involved would take volumes. However, a few facts and opinions from another point of view should be considered.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 8 -(UPI) -- Willie Hartack scored a triple today, including a victory aboard Jerilynn in the $5,000 Claridge Purse, at Atlantic City.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 -- Authorities investigating the fatal burning of Frank Kierdorf, a Teamster Union business agent, questioned other teamster officials today on the apparent arson attempt that led to Kierdorf's death.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, urged ministers today to have "a temper of mind which, with due reverence for the past, has courage to be contemporary."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10--The House Veterans Affairs Committee recommended today tighter Federal controls over fund-raising activities of veterans' organizations. GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Connie Lou Robinson, a 17-year-old Pasadena (Calif.) high school senior, captured the medal today in the tenth United States junior girls' golf championship.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates reached Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves for eleven hits and rolled to their fifth straight victory tonight, 6 -- 4. The largest home crowd of the season and the second largest night crowd in Forbes Field history, 38,938, saw the game.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Connie Lou Robinson, a 17-year-old Pasadena (Calif.) high school senior, captured the medal today in the tenth United States junior girls' golf championship.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates reached Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves for eleven hits and rolled to their fifth straight victory tonight, 6 -- 4. The largest home crowd of the season and the second largest night crowd in Forbes Field history, 38,938, saw the game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- American women in their child-bearing years have 22 per cent more children on the average than in 1950, the Census Bureau said today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 -Snellenburgs, Philadelphia store chain, took over today the M. E. Blatt department store, the resort's largest, for an undisclosed sum.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- Western and Eastern scientists were reliably reported today to be close to agreement on the detection system needed to monitor an international ban on the tests of nuclear weapons.
Flying farmers by the hundreds were arriving here yesterday for their thirteenth annual convention. Seven hundred were expected, but bad weather along the way was delaying many.
The police checked numerous leads yesterday in their search for the thieves who broke into two display windows at Tiffany's at dawn Sunday and lifted out jewels worth $163,300.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Bill Hartack, who is making a runaway of the riding race at Atlantic City won today's featured Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Purse aboard Harriet Robinson's Fall Wind for his eleventh victory of the session.
Futures prices closed generally lower yesterday in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Aug. 11 -- The Shinnecock Yacht Club crew, with Frank Wadleton as the skipper, took the lead today in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget sailing championship. The ten-race series, with ten crews competing, is scheduled to end on Wednesday.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Organizers of the Venice Film Festival are up in arms over a Soviet complaint that a Russian film has been snubbed. The organizers, in effect, have told the Russians they are lucky that any Soviet film has been admitted to the festival, which opens Aug. 24.
The hay fever season is upon us -- to the discomfort of about 5,000,000 Americans.

August is approach-the-sponsors month in bowling. This month a team that is looking for a sponsor must get a benefactor or open the winter league season next month at its own expense. Newly formed quintets and established ones whose 19571958 sponsors have dropped out of the picture are now on the hunt for merchants and companies that have a benevolent feeling toward bowling.

The oil industry has been having a "recess" in recent months. Two interlinking causes: oversupply and lower prices. Now there are signs that things are looking up. That, at any rate, appears to be the conclusion of the Chase Manhattan Bank in its latest review of the petroleum situation.
ALTHOUGH the term "convenience foods" is a recent addition to the nation's lexicography, such foods have lightened the homemaker's burden ever since the introduction of canning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Senate gave speedy voice approval today to a compromise bill creating a new Federal agency to make and enforce safety rules for commercial, military and private planes.
SEATTLE, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Bill Muncey, the driver of the ill-fated Miss Thriftway, said today, "I'll race again -- and win that Gold Cup three straight times."
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 11 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Premier of Cambodia, arrived here today for an unofficial one-day visit on his way to Communist China.
The convictions of Harry Lev and three other men for conspiracy to defraud the Government on military contracts were unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

In early morning on a day in June, 1780, more than 50,000 men marched to the Houses of Parliament to petition for the repeal of an act that had been passed not long before. By nightfall London was in an uproar and for a week it was in the hands of a reckless, drunken, desperate mob.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Continental Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve a drastic fare revision plan, including low-priced coach service.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Comdr W. R. Anderson, the first captain to take his ship under the North Pole, said here today he believed that his orute under the polar icecap was a promising one for enormous submarine oil tankers and freighters.

It was an amusing comment when someone pointed out that the two biggest problems in our "depressed" economy were how to reduce and where to park the car. It is not amusing when a House Government Operations subcommittee comes forward with the statement that Americans are being bilked out of $100,000,000 a year by phony reducing preparations. More drastic action is urged upon the Federal Trade Commission and it should be taken.

GENEVA PARK, Ont., Aug. 11 (AP) -- C. Douglas Dillon, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, urged practical steps today to bolster the free world economic system by providing more assistance to less-developed countries and expanding international trade.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 11 -- The Democratic Action party, generally believed to be the strongest of Venezuela's political groups, opened its longawaited national convention here today.

Commercial paper rates and bankers' acceptance rates continued upward yesterday and the bond markets continued downward. Stocks, trading on the smallest volume in eighteen sessions, made new highs since August 1957, but lost part of their gains in the afternoon.

A ten-car express train on the Lexington Avenue line of the IRT crashed through a track bumper at the end of the elevated line in the Bronx last night. Six passengers received minor injuries and a seventh suffered a concussion and a fractured elbow.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 11 -- The board of directors of Angostura Bitters (Dr. J. G. B. Seigert) Ltd., has recommended that shareholders accept the Trinidad Government's offer to purchase controlling interest in the company.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Pacific Coast Conference served notice today it was ending its Rose Bowl contracts with the Pasadena Tournament of Roses after the Jan. 1, 1960, football game.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 9 (UPI) -- In homemaking the mind now prevails over the hands.
Bay Ridge groups yesterday protested the contemplated approval by the City Planning Commission of the proposed Seventh Avenue approach in Brooklyn to the Narrows Bridge.
PASSAIC, N. J., Aug. 12 -- The Board of Commissioners today authorized an application for a $107,000 loan to pay for plans that would redesign Passaic's $35,000,000 downtown shopping district.
PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller today picked up the nine delegate votes of Rockland County in his bid for the Republican nomination for Governor.

Two participants in the Apalachin gangland convention were sent to jail yesterday for refusing to answer questions by the State Investigation Commission under a pledge of immunity. The wit nesses were taken to civil jail on the orders of Supreme Court Justice Morris E. Spector and ordered held "until such time as you are willing to appear before the commission and answer such questions as may be propounded to you."
THE guest register of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel probably contains as imposing a list of potentates, pashas and princes as any of the world's carasensaries.

Before yesterday's ball game at the Yankee Stadium, Casey Stengel was delivering a loud lecture. Although he was supposed to be answering questions, it appeared that some of his barbed comments were directed at his players.
The Case of the Ten Missing Monkeys was solved yesterday with their capture in a cargo building at Idlewild. The tiny Galagos, known also as bush babies, started from...
Plans for a joint company operation in Italy were announced yesterday by the United States Rubber Company and the Rumianca Company of Turin. The latter is one of Italy's largest chemical concerns.
PORTLAND, England, Aug. 12 -- The epic voyage of the Nautilus ended here today "with enough gas left for a fast trip home."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Senate rackets investigators suggested today that James R. Hoffa was afraid to drop the ex-convicts on his union's payroll. He denied it.
STRIPES are the freshest news in home fashion fabrics this year.

LOON BAY, N. B., Aug. 12 -- There is something the matter this year with the Diggedywash River, spelled on maps by ignorant cartographers as Digdeguash. The trouble is going to be pinpointed pretty soon, and overcome, but there wasn't enough time to do it today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower vetoed today for economy reasons a bill calling for construction of an atomic-powered icebreaker for the Coast Guard at an estimated cost of $60,000,000.

When a publisher puts out a new novel it is reasonable to assume that he wants it to become a best seller, for if it does it not only is directly profitable but he and the author receive flattering offers from digest magazines and Hollywood -- and these sources are perfectly willing to pay for the privilege of using the story after their own fashion.
The United Aircraft Corporation's sales in the quarter and six months ended June 30 rose but earnings fell, the company announced yesterday.
About $8,000,000 will be spent to support scientific studies of heart and blood vessel diseases in the 1958-59 fiscal year by the American Heart Association and its affiliates.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Aug. 12 -- A call for a step-up in the linguistic field in the "cold war" with the Soviet Union was made here tonight by Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways. Mr. Trippe spoke at commencement exercises of the Middlebury College summer language schools.
Rockefeller Center, Inc., which, through a subsidiary, owns the Roxy Theatre, may step in soon to operate the movie house at Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue.

The work of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women will be furthered by its annual Angels Ball, to be held on Nov. 20 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Joseph Boneparth and Mrs. Roger Soman are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

Most women use a handbag and consider it an essential accessory. However, a survey just completed for the manufacturers indicates a strong desire by the users of handbags to associate them with "fun and gaiety." Restraint and formality were found to have little place in the American woman's conception of her handbag and what she wants it to be.

President Eisenhower arrived in New York last evening and took up residence in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He immediately began putting the finishing touches on the major statement of United States policy on the Middle East that he will deliver today to the emergency meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.

One hundred per cent amateurism in sports car racing is a fine thing, for the one per cent who can afford it. For the others it is a pain in the pocketbook. The ironbound rules of the Sports Car Club of America, under which a car owner or driver cannot accept one cent of expense money, are as moss-covered as the old oaken bucket.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower will have the status of a visiting chief of state when he addresses the General Assembly tomorrow.

A former president of the American Stamp Dealers Association was indicted in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday for violating the Trading with the Enemy Act. He was charged with having smuggled valuable stamps from Communist China and having sold them at 100 per cent profit.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday that it spent $11,097,309 more than it took in during the fiscal year that ended June 30.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 12 -- Thirteen Jordanians were sentenced to death and twelve to prison terms today on charges of having conspired in Syria and of having imported arms to overthrow King Hussein's Government.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- A group of young Soviet citizens described today their impressions after a one-month tour of the United States.

ROME, Aug. 12 -- United States military intervention has backfired politically in Lebanon. The presence of the troops there has served in a curious way to weaken friends of the United States and strengthen the Lebanese Opposition, which continues both its armed insurrection and its economic strike.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The speech of Senator Fulbright in the Senate on Aug. 6 is a bright omen. I hope that it means that the Democratic leadership will end its bipartisan acceptance of the Administration's lack of policy and take a stand in opposition. To Secretary Dulles bipartisanship means approval of his actions by everyone, not common participation in the formulation of a policy.
BONN, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- West Germany clamped down today on fuel imports and eased export restrictions to fight the excess production crisis in the coal industry.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 12 (AP) -- One of Arkansas' stanchest segregationists made a strong bid tonight to win a seat on the State Supreme Court.
Sceptre, the British challenger for the America's Cup, was seen from and officially spoken for on these shores for the first time yesterday.
Stockholders of the Standard Packaging Corporation have approved a plan to acquire the Eastern Corporation, Bangor, Me., it was announced yesterday. The merger will be effective about Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters Union announced today postponement of a scheduled meeting of teamster and longshoremen's union heads to discuss combined operations.
A clearance sale that has lightened the attics of the Metropolitan Museum of Art as it has enhanced the curio cabinets of hundreds of museum visitors is drawing to a close for the summer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The House voted today to overrule Supreme Court decisions in two more areas of the law. With a handful of members on the floor, two bills were passed and sent to an uncertain fate in the Senate.
SOUTH WEYMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 12 -- A silver-skinned Navy blimp, dubbed by its crew the Snow Goose, nosed into its mooring here today after a historic flight into the Arctic.

FATNESS in children is not cute once they are out of the crib. And nobody knows it better than Lane Bryant, which yesterday showed its back-to-school collection of clothes for chubby girls, unless it is the famous children's specialist, Dr. Benjamin Spock.
WARSAW, Aug. 12 -- Poland's Communist party opened an important new political front today in its criticism of the Roman Catholic Church.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Connie Lou Robinson of Pasadena, Calif., the medalist, and Judy Eller of Old Hickory, Tenn., the defender, each 17 years old, led the way through the first round of the tenth annual United States junior girls' golf championship today.

The stage is set for one of the most dramatic meetings the United Nations has yet held. Cynics and pessimists may say with some truth that a hastily convoked session of the General Assembly will not solve the problems of the Middle East. Others are bracing themselves for a war of words that would end like all modern wars in victory for neither side.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12 -- Allen Fox, a 19-year-old sophomore from the University of California at Los Angeles, took his place among the more promising young tennis players from the West Coast with the challenge he offered to Malcolm Anderson in the Newport invitation tournament today.

A United States shipping executive, widely known for his Great Lakes ventures, emerged yesterday as a major figure in Cuban maritime affairs. The development followed the decision by the Canadian Government to liquidate its thirty-year-old West Indies fleet.

Professor William W. Brickman of New York University announced plans yesterday for a five-week visit to the Soviet Union by seventy-three American educators. He said they would make the first searching, comparative analysis of Soviet education in thirty years.
Secretary of State John Foster Dulles yesterday became the victim of an old form of protocol known as hotel diplomacy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Some Western allies of the United States pressed the Administration today to seek a solution of the Middle Eastern question without recourse to measures that would aggravate the "cold war."
LISBON, Portugal, Wednesday, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Premier Antonio Salazar replaced Foreign Minister Paulo Cunha with Marcelo Matias in a major Cabinet reshuffle announced today.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 12 -- Scoring victories in the seventh and eighth rounds, Eldis Cobo-Arteaga of Havana and Robert H. Steinmeyer of St. Louis, with tallies of 7 -- 1 each, rose to the top of the standing in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Civil Defense has tended to become a topic about which every New Yorker gets stirred up every three or four years. We tend at that point to have a plethora of committees formed and reports rendered. By the time dollar figures are attached to the projects the public momentum for such projects has been dissipated.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- A Budhist leader declared here tonight that areas of agreement within the world's five great religions "far outweigh, both in number and importance, the differences of theology and doctrine that too often obscure the real significance of human faith."

A bill establishing tax regulations for mutual life insurance companies, introduced in the House last week, is acceptable to the institutions involved, an industry spokesman said yesterday. It was introduced by Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the International Business Machines Corporation, 590 Madison Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 12 -- A thirty-foot marble statue of Our Lady of Fatima will be erected here atop a knoll on the campus of Good Counsel College, ninety feet above the new Cross Westchester Expressway.
The city was cautioned yesterday to study thoroughly all pension plans for its employes before expanding the one for sanitation workers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek indignantly described today as "national treason" the publication last week of a photograph showing him standing with hands spread in a begging gesture before Secretary of State Dulles.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Bill Cox of the Noroton (Conn.) Y. C. today became the first skipper to win the Clifton A. Hipkins Trophy for the third time. He did it by retaining the men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Although the feature race on the card today was not a stakes event, it attracted enough class to provide a thrilling spectacle for the 14,787 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- President Eisenhower signed reluctantly today a bill continuing the program under which about $200,000,000 a year in Federal aid is granted for construction and operation of schools in areas with major Federal installations.

OCEANSIDE, Calif., Aug. 12 -- Floyd Patterson stretched full length on the deck chair in front of his motel overlooking the Pacific and yawned politely. It was a yawn of contentment, a lazy gesture that could have been induced by the sight of the breakers rolling lazily in on the beach. There was no hurry to the waves. There was no hurry to the heavyweight champion of the world.
THE woman's influence has spread from the kitchen to the quarterdeck.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12 -- The first withdrawal of United States troops from Lebanon is scheduled to begin tomorrow morning.
Jason Robards Sr. will make his first appearance on the Broadway stage since 1922 in the same play in which his son, Jason Jr., will be starred.

NEWARK, Aug. 12 -- Walter B. McGregor of Manchester, N. H., an investment counselor, was placed on the board of directors of International Railways of Central America by a court order today. Judge Joseph L. Smith of the Superior Court here declared Mr. McGregor the winner over Oliver R. Grace, partner in the investment advisory firm of Sterling, Grace Co. of New York, at the annual stockholders' meeting June 4.

A FEW hours after the State Investigation Commission adjourned yesterday's hearing into last November's gangland conclave at Apalachin, its chairman, Myles Joseph Lane, was assessing the new weapon used against balky witnesses -- talk or go to jail indefinitely.

The election of Stewart S. Hawes as president of Blyth Co., Inc., underwriters and distributors of investment securities, succeeding Charles R. Blyth, was announced yesterday. Mr. Blyth was elected chairman and chief executive officer.
YONKERS, Aug. 12 -- Moving to the front at the outset and never surrendering the lead, the favored Lumber Along won the Hudson Trot for 3-year-old fillies tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

CHANNEL 4's new course in English for Spanish-speaking New Yorkers is another worthwhile example of television's being harnessed for specialized audiences rather than for a program that aims at delighting everyone.

Two new films open today: "God's Little Acre," based on the novel by Erskine Caldwell and starring Robert Ryan and Aldo Ray, arrives at various neighborhood theatres. The drama was produced by Sidney Harmon, directed by Anthony Mann and adapted for the screen by Philip Yordan. The Security Pictures presentation is being released by United Artists.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies were 4.7 per cent higher in July than in the like 1957 month. A compilation by The New York Times yesterday showed total sales in the month for forty-five big chains of $1,422,234,158, against $1,357,982,692 in July, 1957.
HOUSEKEEPERS at the Waldorf Towers, the home of most visiting dignitaries here, are more accustomed to catering to the needs of royalty and foreign Government officials than to ordinary people.

In its first change of ownership since 1909, the apartment house for twenty families at 345 East Sixty-fifth Street was sold by the estate of Frieda A. Calle. The property is on a plot 27 by 100 feet. It was bought by an investing client of Philip Burack, attorney, in a cash deal negotiated by Walter J. Dickerson, broker. It is assessed at $38,000.

Mrs. May Preston Davie, vice chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, said yesterday she would ask the State Supreme Court to void an opposition group's call for a meeting next Tuesday to elect a new county leader.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 -- President Arturo Frondizi told an American Jewish Committee delegation today that its presence here had strengthened understanding between the United States and Argentina.
Science studies are booming in British schools, and school laboratories are being sponsored and equipped by large industries, a group of exchange teachers reported yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 12 -- The Singapore Government will introduce a bill in the Legislative Assembly tomorrow to give the police special powers to combat what is regarded as the menace of Chinese secret societies.
Steel production last month was the third largest for any month so far this year, reflecting the improvement in demand that began after the July 4 holiday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug 12 -- Cecil B. De Mille looked down from "a mountain of seventy-seven years" today and found the view "heartwarming." The city of Los Angeles joined with Hollywood in paying the movie director-producer a birthday tribute rare in the history of the movie colony.

Net income of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries in the second quarter declined to $14,090,034 from $19,227,621 in the corresponding period of 1957, John H. Hinman, chairman, reported yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek said today that he and Secretary of State Dulles had not, nor could they have, "arrived at any definitive conclusion" about the form of the proposed program for improvement of inter-American relations.

While the police continued their investigation of the $163,300 Tiffany jewel theft, it became known yesterday that jewelry valued at nearly $27,000 had been stolen two weeks earlier from a showcase in the Plaza Hotel lobby.

A contract for the purchase of two six-story buildings at 648 to 658 Grand Street in Brooklyn has been sold by David Pepper to Morris Alter and Arieh Dagan. The buildings contain sixty-six apartments and eight stores and occupy a plot 100 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- In a reversal of long-established policy, the United States gave its support today to the establishment of an Inter-American Development Institution.

A 23-year-old probationary patrolman wondered yesterday where the 23,482 other members of the city's police force were. In a four-hour period he put an end to a restaurant brawl, disarmed a gunman on a Harlem street and rescued thirteen persons from a gas-filled tenement.

A sharp rally in long-term U. S. Government bonds yesterday largely erased the declines of two previous trading sessions. Though closing prices approximated those of last Thursday and were as much as 1 3/4 points higher than at Monday's close, traders still described the day as a "technical reaction."

HAVANA, Aug. 12 -- Reports reaching Havana today said that a large group of rebels had entered the town of Herradura in the southern part of Pinar del Rio Province. They surprised and captured a rural guard post, seized a truck, loaded it with foodstuffs and retreated to the hills.

Cocoa futures tumbled in active trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Liquidation and selling by commission houses and European interests induced stop-loss ordering. There was switching from September to December.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -Most grain futures feebly reversed their downward trend, but nearly all corn options sagged further in more active dealings today on the Board of Trade.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug., 12 -- Iraq's revolutionary republic has abolished the powerful, autonomous seven-man panel of experts that dictated the vast national development program under the old regime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Government invited exporters today to submit any complaints they might have about undue restrictions against United States goods in six British Commonwealth countries, including the United Kingdom.

The development of a new type of Dacron textile fiber was announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. In the polyester group, it is suitable for both winter and lightweight tropical apparel. Now in production at Kinston, N. C., it is available in limited quantities in three denier staple or tow at $1.51 a pound.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The measurements of the yacht Sceptre, the British challenger for the America's Cup, were published today in the latest supplement to Lloyds Register of Shipping, ending months of secrecy.

John V. Lindsay, who won the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, is a non-organization candidate who pegged his fight on greater party liberalism and leadership. As an acknowledged insurgent, he had not been expected to be able to win without his party's endorsement.

An investment banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. bought $8,487,000 of Springfield, Mo., public utility revenue bonds, The bonds, which mature from 1962 to 1986 were purchased with a bid of 100.042 and a variety of coupons for a net interest cost to the borrower of 3.581 per cent.
Share prices experienced their sharpest decline since July 14, losing ground in every group yesterday.
Examples of the ingenuity that won 720 high school students $26,900 in the annual Industrial Arts Awards competition were displayed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 12 (AP) -- Commander Calvert, a veteran submariner, watched the nuclear-powered submarine Skate being built. He set records in the vessel before taking her on the Polar cruise.

Joseph Levy, described by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as one of the most active confidence men and passers of of forged checks in the country, was taken into custody here yesterday by two patrolmen.
JOB opportunities for women in radio and television are increasing. So says Edythe Fern Melrose, Detroit broadcaster.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 12 -- The contract bridge team of Harry Fishbein, Samuel Fry Jr., Lee Hazen, Leonard Harmon, all of New York, and Ivar Stakgold of Washington needs only one more thirty-six hand victory to become the 1959 official United States bridge squad.

"The Day on Fire," James Ramsey Ullman's new novel, will be published Sept. 22 by World. The story is based on the life of Arthur Rimbaud, the French poet who disappeared from the literary scene at the age of 20 and died when he was 37 after wandering in Europe and Africa. The book has 701 pages with 361,716 words.

11 A. M.: Two films, "Fireman" and "Rumplestiltskin," will be shown at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Other events include a story hour, "House of Four Seasons," at 11:30 A. M.; two films, "Eskimo Arts and Crafts" and "Eskimo Children," at 2 P. M.; a science demonstration, "Understanding Our Earth," at 3 P. M., and two films, "Fur Trade" and "Getting Together," at 4 P. M. For information, call PResident 4-2900.
The Port of New York Authority was accused yesterday of having produced "hardly factual" data in an effort to defeat the proposed Liberty Bride from Brooklyn to New Jersey.
A major upset in Westchester marked yesterday's primary elections in the metropolitan area.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Aug. 6 "A Look at the City Schools," is a challenge to every citizen interested in improving our city school system as well as to the public officials responsible for such improvement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Senate passed tonight three major tax bills in rapid-fire order.

New York is home town to 132 of the nation's 500 largest companies. Most of the 132 with headquarters here have their plants elsewhere. But New York is loaded with chairmen, presidents and vice presidents.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 12 -- Israel Maisels, leader of the defense counsel in the treason trial at Pretoria, resumed his challenge of the indictment today. He said the prosecution would keep the court sitting for eighteen months listening to "this rot and rubbish."
HARTFORD, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Connecticut's highest tribunal today declined to give substance to heirs materialized from the spirit world.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Carter Ford's Encore II of the Riverside Yacht Club upset the newly crowned Atlantic Coast champion, Vincent (Bizzy) Monte-Sano of Larchmont in a fast even-number. Lightning Class finish to feature the open junior regatta sponsored by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club today.
A MOHAIR blizzard hit Paris again during the fashion showing just ended there and, once again, Ascher of London was responsible. It started the mohair rage a year ago and it is still going strong.

There have been reports from Washington of late to the effect that when the member nations of the International Monetary Fund and Bank meet at New Delhi, India, next month a resolution may be introduced to study the desirability of increasing the resources of the two institutions.
President Eisenhower's speech to the United Nations General Assembly will be broadcast this morning by all radio and television networks and several independent stations.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The stock market was fairly buoyant today and in most sections gains outnumbered losses.

When Samuel Barber's "Vanessa" has its European premiere in Salzburg, Austria, on Saturday night, the freemasonry that exists among musicians will be demonstrated. A Viennese trumpeter will use a mute that an American trumpeter evolved after having heard a similar mute employed by a folk trumpeter in Puerto Rico.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Petite Julie Heldman, a 12-year-old student at the Hamtramck (Mich.) tennis school, today pulled the biggest upset of the Canadian junior tennis championships by defeating the top Canadian junior woman.
SUFFERN, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Erie Railroad's investigation of yesterday's train collision, which killed five persons and hospitalized twenty-five others, will open next Tuesday.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The rookie sensation, George Witt, pitched a two-hitter tonight and his team-mates supported him with an eight-run outburst in the eighth inning to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 10-0 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. It was the Bucs' sixth triumph in a row.

Charles S. Rhyne, president of the American Bar Association, said yesterday on his arrival at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, after a visit to the Soviet Union, that the Soviet Union "has a legal system in form." He added in a statement:
Despite a resurgence of inflationary psychology, a speculative binge seems unlikely at this time, the Bankers Trust Company said yesterday.
Six United States Naval vessels, headed by the guided missile cruiser Canberra, will arrive here Friday in honor of the city's Summer Festival.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Administration is far from happy about the Middle East debate starting at the United Nations tomorrow. It has slapped together at the last minute an agreement to go along with a United Nations economic development plan for the Middle East, but at heart it fears the...
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Jordanian sources are said tonight that Baha Al-Din Toukan, head of Jordan's delegation, had been recalled to Amman as a result a policy disagreement.

A good many Soviet citizens, we may reasonably suspect, were stunned when they read Khrushchev's latest major speech delivered at Kuibyshev. They could hardly have imagined beforehand the policy change he announced while dedicating the world's largest hydroelectric station. That change, of course, is the new policy of cutting back on future construction of such stations, an announcement that implied it might even have been wiser if the Kuibyshev station itself had not been built.
The A-S-R Products Corporation has learned that it pays to put its eggs into more than one basket.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 12 -- The Government declared today it was convinced that peace could be insured in the Middle East if the Soviet Union and other United Nations members respected the territorial integrity and political independence of nations in the region.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 -- James R. Hoffa was accused today by the trucking industry of blocking an agreement between employers and truck drivers in eleven Western states.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill to help the railroads by making it easier for them to obtain loans, abandon unprofitable lines and increase rates.
PARIS, Aug, 12 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle will make an 11,000-mile, nine or ten day campaign trip by air to sell his proposed new Constitution to the voters in Africa and Madagascar.
Two neatly dressed gunmen entered a spacious Queens home yesterday, bound two women and escaped with furs, jewelry and cash worth $24,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a theme "New York Is a Summer Festival" is one of the happier inspirations of the promotional mind and all the people who cooked up the idea deserve the plaudits of their fellow-New Yorkers.

The New York Savings Bank, which has its main office at Eighth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, has leased a store at 466 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-sixth Street, from the New York Central Railroad for a Grand Central branch.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 18 to 74 points (90 cents to $3.70 a bale) yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Congress abandoned today the elusive goal of an adjournment by Saturday. Instead its leaders talked of next Wednesday as both houses worked extra hours to dispose of major legislation.

WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N. M., Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Army theoretically blasted from the sky today its new Kingfisher target missile.
NEWARK, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted the president of a bankrupt metal plating concern and two employes on charges of fraudulently selling more than $300,000 in company stock.

A committee formed to change the unwritten rule against providing birth-control information in city hospitals will meet next Tuesday at 2 P.M. The group will review recent developments and discuss future plans.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Venezuela completed arrangements yesterday for a huge loan to help recover from debts left by the ousted Perez Jimenez regime.

Retail jewelers should take more interest in politics and inform their Representatives and Senators in Washington of their positions on pending legislation, according to William C. McCamant, director of trade and public relations for the American Retail Federation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Sinclair Weeks announced today tentative Federal standards for regulating billboard advertising along the new 40,000-mile Federal-state interstate highway system.

The Radcliffe Club of New York is arranging a tour of New York residences distinguished by their art collections. The event, which will take place on Dec. 6, will include a visit to the home of Edward Durell Stone, noted architect, and Mrs. Stone.
GUATEMALA, Aug. 12 -- Julio Vielman, reporter for Prensa Libre, charged today that President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes had struck a glancing blow at him and kicked him this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Man will attempt to take a small step into the "wild blue yonder" next Sunday morning with a rocket-boosted, eighty-three pound payload traveling at 35,000 feet a second.

The International Paper Company has selected a new agency for its account, following two months of interviewing. Although the company will not disclose its decision until the end of August, the winner is thought to be Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Secretary of the Navy apologized today for the failure to invite Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover to last Friday's White House ceremony for the atomic submarine Nautilus.

Headlines from the Middle East have had no effect on trans-Atlantic travel by United States tourists, the European Travel Commission reported yesterday. Departures in recent weeks exceeded the record figures established in the comparable period of 1957.

FOURTEEN new crabmeat recipes are featured in a new booklet now available to the public at no charge.

IN Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" there is a scene in which Mark Antony, talking to Octavius Caesar, says: This is a slight unmeritable man, Meet to be sent on errands; is it fit, The threefold world divided, he should stand One of the three to share it?
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Britain spears that Jordan may be the source of a major war if the United Nations does not find some solution that will guarantee her integrity as a nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed into law today a bill aimed at eliminating unneeded Government secrecy. He insisted, however, that the Government could keep "appropriate information or papers confidential in the public interest" from the public.

Mutual fund sales quickened their fast pace in July, depression, recession or world alarm notwithstanding. The National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday that purchases by investors in July reached a record total of $160,675,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors ruled today that both Connecticut and New York had an "equitable right" to the use of water in the Mianus River in the border area between the two states near Greenwich.

By knocking City Councilman Earl Brown out of the Democratic primary ring last night, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. retained his title as the undefeated and undisputed political heavyweight champion in Harlem.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. swamped his Tammany-backed adversary in yesterday's primary here to win a Democratic renomination for an eighth Congressional term.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 12 -- A pill said to be capable of halving the serious biological effects of a stiff dose of atomic radiation may be available soon for experimental use on human beings, a scientist said here today.

The ten-man racing crew that will man the British Twelve-Meter sloop Sceptre in its challenge for the America's Cup is long on experience in the after-guard and heavy on youthful muscle in the main cockpit and on the foredeck.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 21 points ($1.15 a bale) lower, with far October and December the weakest months.
A crippled 9-year-old Brooklyn boy died at Kings County Hospital yesterday, twenty-four hours after he was critically injured by a car operated by a motorist accused of being intoxicated.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Aug. 13 -- A British charter airline began today twiceweekly flights between Cyprus and Jordan, with an intermediate stop in Israel.

Three rewards toalling $15,000 have been posted for the arrest and conviction of the thief or thieves who broke into two display windows at Tiffany's early Sunday morning and stole jewelry valued at $163,300.

WHEN the grandmother and constant companion of a 5-year-old boy died unexpectedly, the child was told only that she had gone to Long Island, where, in fact, she was buried. The boy grew anxious and resentful.

Mayor Wagner received thirty members of the United States track and field team at City Hall yesterday. He told them that the team of seventy-one men and women that recently toured the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary and Greece had done much to improve international goodwill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The Administration and Democratic farm leaders agreed today on a compromise farm bill to meet the demands of Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, for cuts in price supports for corn, cotton and rice.

PASSAU, Germany, Aug. 13 (Reuters)--An audience of more than 2,000 cheered Antal Dorati, director of the Minneapolis Symphony, after a concert here tonight in which he led an orchestra formed entirely of refugees from Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today it was spending $175,000,000 in the current fiscal year on air navigation and traffic control equipment to make flying safer.

ASHLAND, Wis., Aug. 13 (AP) -- An Air Force officer and a civilian instructor were injured tonight when their open gondola plunged 100 feet to the ground. They had cut loose from a training balloon as it headed out over Lake Superior.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -The grain futures market which has been lame in nearly all of its past several sessions on the Board of Trade limped out again today, saving only two gains of earlier steady prices.
A station wagon that unfolds a nine-foot boat, a tent, a hot and cold water shower and a canopied kitchen--complete with sink--at the touch of five buttons was demonstrated here yesterday.
A "hold" or delay will be "built in" to the countdown on the lunar probe rocket expected to be fired from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Sunday morning.
