Whitey Ford, who needed one more shutout to tie a Yankee pitching record that has stood for forty-eight years, pitched three perfect innings against the Senators at the Yankee Stadium last night.
Domestic production of crude oil and condensate increased 291,450 barrels to 6,836,185 a day in the week ended last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -The House of Representatives completed Congressional action today on the long-controverted bill providing for the humane slaughtering of livestock. It sent the bill to the White House.

The Vick Chemical Company of New York plans to acquire the Lavoris Company of Minneapolis, a mouthwash manufacturer. This was announced jointly yesterday by H. S. Richardson Jr., president of Vick, and Harold C. Keen, president of Lavoris.
Andrew R. Olson has been elected president of the Protane Corporation, liquid petroleum gas distributing subsidiary of the Weatherhead Company, Cleveland, Ohio. He succeeds Morris H. Wright.
New York State won an agreement yesterday to prevent allegedly monopolistic practices to fix the retail price of milk in the metropolitan area.

MILAN, Italy, Aug. 13 -- Four young American singers were applauded cordially when they made their European debuts here tonight. They belonged to a group of eight young artists sent to Italy on the basis of selection in nation-wide auditions in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -United States officials said today they envisaged the United Nations peace force proposed by President Eisenhower as a kind of constabulary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -Senators disclosed tonight that President Eisenhower had ordered a top-to-bottom Pentagon investigation of published reports that United States officials were studying the possibility of surrender by the United States in a future nuclear war.
PRESIDENT EISENHOWER'S address before the United Nations General Assembly yesterday morning received excellent television and radio coverage.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 -- Two Brazilian Cabinet ministers -- Foreign Minister Francisco Negrao de Lima and Air Minister Francisco Correa Melo -- flew to Asuncion today to attend Friday's inauguration of Paraguay's dictator, Alfredo Stroessner, for a new Presidential term.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The House upheld President Eisenhower's veto of the Portsmouth, N. H., pay rise bill today. In six years, Congress has never overridden a veto by the President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -The Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee approved unanimously today the legislation needed to permit United States cooperation with and help for Euratom, the six-nation European atomic power community.

HONEY from Mount Hymettus, fresh land snails from French Morocco and crisp Italian biscuits seasoned with coarsely cracked black pepper. These are a small part of the unusual and bizarre fare so be found in the food stores that line Ninth Avenue between Thirty-sixth and Forty-second Streets.
Approval of the controversial Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, approach to the Narrows Bridge was voted yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The bridge would connect Brooklyn and Staten Island.

A store in the Hippodrome Building at 50 West Fortyfourth Street has been leased by the United Camera Exchange Company, photographic supplies. The shop has a frontage of thirty feet on the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue). The building occupies the blockfront on the east side of the avenue from Forty-third to Forty-fourth Streets.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13 -Chile withdrew her Ambassador here today in protest against the seizure by the Argentine Navy of a tiny island claimed by Chile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, compared today protests of foreign nations against United States shipping policies with those "of the child who complains about Santa Claus delivering the gifts which he is giving away."
The United States Appeals Court has rejected a petition by the plaintiff for a rehearing on its decision in favor of the Beech Aircraft Corporation in a damage suit against the company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -(UPI) -- The Secretary of Commerce announced his opposition today to the establishment of any new construction standards for the projected interstate highway system.

" THE DEMOCRATIC VISTA,"* by Richard Chase, is a conversation piece about American life and books and leaders. It is witty, it is provocative. And it is also gloriously implausible. Why? Because Mr. Chase's scholarly talkers are allowed to finish sentences, round out ideas, without interruption.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that its Hudson River passenger ferry service would be discontinued Sept. 13.

ALBUQUERQUE, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Fall-out from the latest two stratospheric nuclear explosions above Johnston Island will rain down on the entire world for the next ten years. Dr. Willard F. Libby, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today.
The crash of the KLM-Royal Dutch plane off Ireland yesterday, with all ninety-nine persons aboard apparently lost, ranks as the worst disaster on record involving a single commercial airliner.

The shopping center containing thirteen stores at 114-12 to 114-34 Merrick Boulevard, near Linden Boulevard, in St. Albans, Queens, has been sold by tthe Ber Car Realty Company. The seller was represented by Abraham Engelman, Manhattan lawyer.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -The Illinois Athletic Club's A team today defeated the El Segundo (Calif.) Swim Club, 11-4, in the first game of the National Amateur Athletic Union water polo championships.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -The first indication of commercial wheat supply from the 1958 crop became known to grain dealers today and futures prices on the Board of Trade found a slightly warmer reception.

A directive barring minors under the age of 18 from harness racing tracks in the state became effective yesterday.

ARROWHEAD SPRINGS, Calif., Aug. 14 -Little Henry did his laundry today. He hung it out to dry in his bedroom, draping four pairs of blue jeans across a low branch of the eucalyptus tree near the head of his bed. Big Henry, who shares sleeping quarters with Little Henry, didn't do his laundry. Hence the other eucalyptus tree, at the head of his bed, had nothing on it but leaves.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Since April 1, KLM-Royal Dutch Airlines has carried 31,500 economy class passengers on 1,100 transatlantic crossings, covering a total of about 4,500,000 miles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -The Senate Finance Committee approved today a bill to increase Social Security benefits and taxes.

The Erie Railroad announced yesterday that it would discontinue its Hudson River passenger ferry service Sept. 14. About 1,200 commuters use the ferry, which operates between Jersey City and Chambers Street in Manhattan.

John S. Thompson in his letter to The Times on Aug. 8 states: "The very recent improvement in the economic atmosphere is evidence that a turn in the business outlook can be secured by a moderate degree of patience and by a disposition to let the powerful recuperative forces inherent in our economy reassert themselves."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Senate tonight rejected a bill to block plans for extending the east front of the Capitol. The plans have stirred up a nationwide controversy among architects and others.

Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called on the United States today to make renewed efforts for reduced armaments, reduced tensions and reduced areas of conflict with the Soviet Union. ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- Governor Harriman is supporting Thomas K. Finletter for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, but he is prepared to settle for Thomas E. Murray. AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 14 -Premier Samir el-Rifai served notice today that Jordan would reject any United Nations proposal that his Government considered impractical.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Moscow warned today that countries bordering on the Middle East might be forced to take action unless United States and British troops were withdrawn from the Middle East.

THE last stretch of summer is the time when a clever woman takes a long look at herself in the mirror. Sun-dried hair and skin, make-up geared to the first sunburn rather than the last stages, neglected nails and a faded appearance often result from country living.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- This city, famed for its lovely old buildings, will soon see the completion of two new structures that are startling in their modernity. Three months before the official opening, the new permanent headquarters of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is emerging in its final form. Work on it began in 1955.

LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 14 -Thirteen persons from this area were among the Americans feared lost when a KLM-Royal Dutch Airline plane plunged into the Atlantic Ocean early today. They included two sisters, a man and wife, and a young couple who planned to be married soon.

Loans to business by the large New York City banks dropped $18,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decline compared With a rise of $144,000,000 in the like week of last year.

Prof. Charles A. Orr's letter published Aug.6 correctly applauds narrowing the gap between postal rates and postal costs. I agree also that a substantial increase at this time was not appropriate in view of the condition of our economy.

An American edition of Heinz Randow's account of a hunting mission in Ceylon will be published Aug. 28 by Doubleday under the title "Zoo Hunt In Ceylon." He tells of his adventures in seeking rare animals and reptiles for European zoos and circuses.
ALBANY, Aug. 14 -- The elimination of the jet fighter unit in New York City will reduce the strength of the New York Air National Guard by nearly 500 men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover said today that he would pass up the launchings of two new atomic submarines. His wife was reported angry because the Navy had not asked her to christen one of the vessels.

The Interdenominational Ministers Alliance in Brooklyn announced yesterday that it would seek a conference with Commissioner Morris .A. Jacobs. It will attempt to obtain clarification of his prohibition of birth control therapy in municipal hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A union newspaper complained today that an American who served with Philippine guerrillas opposing Japan in World War II is now being dunned by the Government for $554 for his passage home.

American Electric Power Company reported yesterday new highs in earnings for July and for the seven and twelve months ended July 31. The net for twelve months increased 7.5 per cent to $44,731,598, equal to $2.24 a share, from the $41,614,065, or $2.12 a share on fewer shares, reported a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Three Senate backers of the humane slaughter bill called on President Eisenhower today to sign the measure at the earliest possible moment.
Two new housing projects will be built side by side in the Bronx to provide a community for diversified economic groups.

SHOPPING the new world for all that is old was a task that took John and Earline Brice to South America for five months. The results of their trip will go on view Monday in more than a dozen vignettes at Macy's.

The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee plans to hold one more session in its inquiry into the shipping activities of Aristotle S. Onassis. But one member of the committee may decline to attend.
The award of a $1,028,000 contract for the construction of the transit shed for Pier 3 in the Fulton Terminal area of the Brooklyn-Port of New York Authority piers was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -The dramatic feats of the Nautilus and Skate in the Arctic Ocean have tended to obscure some basic facts that cast their achievements in a new light.
The Russians have taken the wraps off their foreign trade statistics.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill today providing for compensation to Jane Froman and two others injured in a World War II airplane crash at Lisbon, Portugal.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- The French Government revealed today some of the measures by which it hopes to convince Moslem voters that the September referendum in Algeria on the adoption of a new Constitution for France will be fair and free, Army control notwithstanding.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly today a farm bill supported by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP) -Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, will open the 1958 American zone Davis Cup tennis final tomorrow against Eduardo Soriano, youngest member of Argentina's squad.
CAIRO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Officials said today that secret radio stations were attacking the United Arab Republic and President Gamal Abdel Nasser in round-the-clock propaganda as-1 saults.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 14 -Dr. Yu Ta-wei, Minister of Defense, defined today the Chinese Nationalist military attitude toward the Chinese Communists as one of "great restraint and great determination."
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Dodgers' announcement that Walt Alston would be rehired next season got a nod of approval today from some of the players.
L. Judson Morhouse yesterday implied that Nelson A. Rockefeller was assured of the Republican nomination for Governor.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP) -Hurricane Cleo, with winds of 145 miles an hour near the center, whirled far out in the Atlantic tonight while an earlier storm flattened out into an easterly wave of squalls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A blonde secretary told a Senate committee today she overheard an ultimatum delivered to Dave Probstein, head of an Indianapolis taxicab company, shortly before he disappeared on June 6, 1955.
PARIS, Aug. 14 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle let it be known today that he was favorably impressed by President Eisenhower's speech to the United Nations General Assembly.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Birdie Tebbetts, who only two days ago was reported as due to be discharged, resigned unexpectedly today as manager of the Cincinnati Redlegs. He was replaced by Jimmie Dykes, one of his coaches.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14 -The Argentine state oil corporation (Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales) signed today a $20,000,000 contract to expand its refinery in Lujan de Cuyo. French equipment and United States patents and engineering consultants will help in an attempt to raise production to 48,000 barrels a day by 1961.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 14 (AP) -- Vivian D. Corbly, controversial National Adjutant of the Disabled American Veterans, resigned today, saying his continued presence would be "detrimental to the future welfare of our organization."

SHANNON, Ireland, Friday, Aug. 15 -- A New York-bound Dutch Super-Constellation carrying ninety-nine persons plunged into the Atlantic yesterday. Fifty-one of the passengers were Americans returning home.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Joey Jay yielded only one hit, a sixth-inning single by Jerry Lynch, tonight as the Milwaukee Braves downed the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 0. The game marked the debut of Jimmie Dykes as the manager of the Redlegs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -Republicans forced a vote on labor legislation in the House Education and Labor Committee today.

Robert Saudek Associates announced yesterday that it had obtained a sponsor for a television series featuring one-hour "preview" concerts by the New York Philharmonic. Leonard Bernstein will be the conductor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Football's professional world champions, the Detroit Lions, were solidly favored today to defeat the College All-Stars, composed of last season's varsity heroes, tomorrow night.

We doubt that any citizen would take issue with the statement that the United States is today under heavy attack by the Soviet Union and her satellites and that this attack has achieved startling successes in recent years both in terms of military technology and in terms of diplomatic maneuver.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa warned the Wagner Administration yesterday that its public works construction program must be curtailed. He said this was necessary to keep the city's debt and basic real estate tax rate within reasonable limits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -United States officials said today that possible actions opened up by President Eisenhower's United Nations speech yesterday ranged from voting a United Nations resolution of concern to deploying a United Nations force.
The construction of approaches and ramps for the second deck of the George Washington Bridge will begin immediately, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.
At midnight last night, MEridian 7-1212 passed its thirtieth anniversary. From that number, the New York Telephone Company has been announcing the exact time every few seconds.
CAIRO, Aug. 14 -- Egyptian reaction to President Eisenhower's proposals before the United Nations yesterday for a Middle East settlement were milder than might have been expected.

SHANNON, Ireland, Friday, Aug. 15 -- A New York-bound Dutch Super-Constellation carrying ninety-nine persons plunged into the Atlantic yesterday. Fifty-one of the passengers were Americans returning home.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Joey Jay yielded only one hit, a sixth-inning single by Jerry Lynch, tonight as the Milwaukee Braves downed the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 0. The game marked the debut of Jimmie Dykes as the manager of the Redlegs.

ROME, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -Pope Pius XII warned in a letter published today that some types of public shows are largely responsible for the present "progressive degradation of the person and of human life," for "audacious attempts at the sanctity of holy matrimony" and for the stimulation of "man's baser instincts."
YONKERS, Aug. 14 -- Billy Haughton was in the sulky as Duane Hanover scored his eleventh victory in sixteen starts this season when he captured the $10,000 Dunwoodie Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Following are the text of an address to the General Assembly today by Selwyn Lloyd, British Foreign Secretary, and excerpts from remarks by other delegates:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Space Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of T. Keith Glennan to head the new civilian space agency and Hugh L. Dryden as his chief deputy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -The House passed and sent to the White House today the much-delayed bill reforming appropriation procedures in line with a major recommendation of the second Hoover commission.

Pleasure boatmen in their thousands of flotillas ought to acclaim with loud and grateful thanks the man whose vision has provided so much smooth water for inland cruising. In his day, they derided his waterway as "Clinton's Folly" and "Clinton's Ditch."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- The Senate and House approved separate bills today to extend the program to import Mexican farm workers. The Senate bill would extend the program for a year, and the House bill for two years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -The Senate confirmed today the appointment of Miss Bertha S. Adkins as Under Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday labeled an attack on him by James A. Farley as "cheap, irresponsible and vicious."
Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Company dropped 61 per cent in the first half of this year, compared with the similar period of 1957.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 14 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru registered his opposition today to President Eisenhower's plan to create a United Nations peace force in the Middle East.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, wool, hides, lead and zinc declined; world sugar positions, copper, soybean oil, potatoes and rubber rose, and price movements for cocoa, coffee and the domestic sugar contract were mixed.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 14 -- Parts of President Eisenhower's program for the Middle East were welcomed today by Israel. The rest was viewed with considerable skepticism.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 14 (AP) -- A Supreme Court justice ruled today that the State Liquor Authority could not penalize two Auburn brothers for visiting Joseph Barbara's home at Apalachin last November.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -The North Atlantic Allies and Japan have agreed to a sharp reduction in the controls on shipments of "strategic" goods to Soviet bloc nations.
TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 14 -The United States is steadily lowering its barriers to trade, a leading official of the United States Commerce Department told the American Club here tonight.
Merger negotiations between the Motormen's Benevolent Association and the Transport Workers Union have failed, the motormen reported yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP) -- A fiery ballistic missile of an unusual nature, its flaming trail flashing on and off, roared up from the test center there tonight.
The word from the West Coast is that Paul Muni "definitely" will come to New York in "At the Grand," the musical version of "Grand Hotel."
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Elmer Valo broke a 3-3 tie in the eleventh inning tonight with a pinch single, enabling the Los Angeles Dodgers to post a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 15 -- A crippled Air Force transport plane landed at Mitchel Air Force Base today after a crewman had lashed its defective landing gear in place while suspended from his heels in the air.
ARROWHEAD SPRINGS, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Heavyweight challenger Roy Harris boxed the longest session of his training today, going seven fast rounds against two sparring partners.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 15 -- Aram Khatchaturian, like Dmitri Shostakovich, is regarded in the Soviet Union as one of its chief musical adornments. Tonight he got a program all to himself at the Palais des Beaux-Arts. For a Westerner with educated tastes, it was hard to take.
KINGSTON. N. Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Board of Police Commissioners today suspended Kingston's acting police chief. Robert Murphy, for thirty days on charges of misconduct and incompetence.
Federal moves to check inflation and speculation laid a heavy hand on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and the aggregate market value of listed issues declined about 2,000,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Iran warned her neighbor states in the Middle East today that their "negative nationalism" might destroy them.
CZESTOCHOWA, Poland Aug. 15 -- The Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland decided today to meet at the monastery that has become a symbol of church-state tensions.
St. Patrick's Cathedral -- one of New York's famous landmarks -- observed its 100th birthday yesterday.

CRISP, succulent pea pods are one of the delicacies of the Chinese cuisine. A reader who would like to prepare them at home has written to complain that she has not been able to find them in any grocery store. She would like to know why the vegetable, also known as snow peas, is not generally sold here.
BOONTON, N. J., Aug. 15 -Conrad Decker of Hightstown, N. J., a polio victim ten years ago, today gained the semi-final round of the metropolitan amateur golf championship.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Soybeans found some moderate support but the grains barely moved on the Board of Trade today.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Knode of Forest Hills, Queens, the favorite, deefated Jeanne Arth of St. Paul, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, in the quarter-finals of the Essex women's invitation tennis tournament today.

A survey among retailers of proprietary drugs and cosmetics has found that more than 70 per cent are in a low inventory position. The Research Institute of America questioned 75,000 dealers in making it study.

" The Heart Is the Teacher," the personal experiences of Dr. Leonard Covello as an educator, will be published Oct. 20 by McGraw-Hill. Written in collaboration with Guido D'Agostino, it tells of an emigrant who worked hard to become a teacher. For twenty-five of the fifty years Dr. Covello was in the teaching profession he was principal of the Benjamin Franklin High School in Harlem.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Mervyn Rose of Australia whipped Ewald Brunner of Germany, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, today in a second-round men's singles match of the Bavarian international tennis tournament.
An average total of 241 pedestrians a day received, summonses during the first week of enforcement of the city's pedestrian safety law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Lloyd Mangrum, professional golfer, says he lost $33,317 of his tournament win through his part-time finance company. He deducted the bad debt from his 1952 income tax return as a business loss.
Commodity futures prices closed generally irregular yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions before the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the State Assembly, formally removed himself yesterday from the contest for the Republican nomination for Governor. His action released about 160 convention delegates who had been pledged to his support.

WHAT a woman wears for evenings at home -- and particularly when she entertains -- is strictly a matter of taste. This month, she will find fashions, suited to country or city evenings, that can be worn at either formal or informal dinners.
ROME, Aug. 15 -- Pope Pius XII, in a broadcast to the Brussels World Fair, expressed confidence today in mankind's continuing progress and prosperity.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Saturday, Aug. 16 -- A Northeast Airlines plane crashed in the fog here last night and three hours later nineteen persons were known to be dead. There was an unconfirmed report that twenty-one of the thirty-three persons aboard the plane were killed.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 15 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has approved an expanded separate budget for the Syrian province of the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Paced by a trio of comparative unknowns, a College All-Star team that had not been conceded the ghost of a chance crushed the Detroit Lions tonight.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 15 (AP) -- David B. Williams of Boston, a Massachusetts District Court judge, was elected national commander of the Disabled American Veterans tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The House of Representatives passed a bill tonight to provide $275,000,000 in loans and grants for redevelopment of areas that have chronic unemployment or under employment. The vote, by a division of members standing, was 176 to 130.

The Food Fair store chain has taken a lease on a one-story building to be erected for its occupancy in Levittown, N. J. The building will contain 35,000 square feet of space and will be the largest in the company's eight-state chain. Other Food Fair markets average 25,000 square feet.

The long career of Anson Phelps Stokes that has just ended is not to be summarized by a listing of the many important posts he held, though the sense of mission is evident in all of them. Soon after his graduation from Yale at the turn of the century he became secretary of the university, a post that he held for twenty-two years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Court-appointed monitors called today for a union trial of Owen Brennan, teamster vice president and friend and business partner of James R. Hoffa.

OTTAWA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Faye Urban, 13 years old, of Windsor, Ont., today captured the juvenile girls' singles crown in the eleventh annual Canadian junior championships. She defeated Sharon Pritula of Detroit, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3.
WARSAW, Aug. 15 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka is quietly dropping from key posts a number of important Communist officials associated with the Stalinist wing of his party.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Senate confirmed unanimously and without debate today the nomination of T. Keith Glennan as Administrator of the new Space Agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 119.0 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The six-story apartment house for thirty families at 558 West 193d Street has been purchased by the Motor Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $92,000. It is on a plot 50 by 100 feet. The sale was made through Ehrlich, Corso Co., brokers. The buyer immediately resold the property to B. Wigder, an investor, through the George Gault Company.
UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The state Health Commissioner said today that, despite great gains in the fight against tuberculosis, the disease still was a major health problem in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Industrial production rose in July for the third straight month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today in its seasonally adjusted index. The July rise of two points meant that the customary vacation-time drop in production had been much less than usual.

Your recent editorial on elderberries stated that "nowadays elderberry wine and elderberry jelly are less than common commodities." I thought you'd like to know that in a few years you may find them more abundant than ever.

To meet the steady growth in demand for electric power in its recognized territory the Tennessee Valley Authority estimates it needs about 800,000 kilowatts of new generating capacity annually. Yet the Administration and Congress have become increasingly reluctant to grant funds for expanded power facilities, and in fact none at all have been appropriated since 1953 to start construction of new generating units.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 15 -- Chronic doses of radiation may have less genetic effect than acute doses, an international congress of radiation research here was told today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15 -- The strange case of Hassan Spata has plunged the strained relations between Yugoslavia and neighboring Albania to a new low. Some foreign diplomats speculated today that the dispute might lead to a diplomatic break.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Judy Eller, 17, of Old Hickory, Tenn., retained her United States Junior girls' golf championship and the Glenna Collett Vare Trophy today. The tall brunette, who is the daughter of a golf professional, defeated Sherry Wheeler, Glasgow (Ky.) power-hitter, 1 up, in the eighteen -hole final at the Greenwich C.C.

President Nasser's attempt to pre-empt Arab nationalism for his Soviet-backed pan-Arab imperialism that is now shaking the Middle East has created another Arab center of resistance to his designs. This new center is Tunisia, which under the leadership of President Bourguiba is taking determined steps against Nasser's drive to make all North Africa part of a pan-Arab empire stretching from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf.
The National State Bank of Newark announced yesterday that it planned to acquire the Federal Trust Company, also of Newark. The merger would be the largest in New Jersey's history.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 15 -- The Jordanian Army and police units searched three United Nations refugee camps here today for arms and infiltrators.
" The author's writing is remarkably polite," said a recent book review in one of our class magazines, and the commment was adverse. Obviously, the author in question was not Mr. Khrushchev.
GALILEE, R. I., Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Montauk (L. I.) Yacht Club won the team prize with 2,944 points today in the storm-shortened sixteenth annual United States Atlantic tuna tournament.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 15 -- Nettled by the calling of a foot-fault when victory was beckoning to him in the second set, Ronald Holmberg lost eight successive games and ultimately the match to Ashley Cooper of Australia in the Newport invitation tennis tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) New cases of paralytic polio are continuing to increase, the Public Health Service said today.

GALWAY, Ireland, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Ships carried thirty-seven bodies and bits of shattered wreckage to Galway today for study by pathologists and technicians to try to determine the cause of the North Atlantic crash of a Dutch airliner in which ninety-nine persons were killed.
Two new films on an imported double-bill program will open today at the Cameo Theatre.

Thirty Treasury agents raided an apparently abandoned factory in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday and uncovered what they said was one of the largest illegal stills found in the New York area in recent years.
The national commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars endorsed President Eisenhower's proposal for regional Arab economic development yesterday.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 15 -Official invitation of Nigerian governments, Federal and regional, issued today to foreign investors to stake their fortunes in this country, is considered here to be a timely reminder to the world of the industrial potentialities of Nigeria, its goodwill, and its need of foreign capital and skill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Jordan's former representative to the United Nations broke completely with his Government today, denouncing both its policies and personalities and disavowing even the statements he had made on its behalf.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- South African gold and gold-uranium shares advanced strongly today on the news that a United States-South African investment group's dollar issue had been approved. Elsewhere, prices moved irregularly or tended to drift lower.
FISHERS ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 15 -- A syndicate of summer residents of this resort bought an obsolete artillery fort here at auction today for $350,000.
GETTYSBURG, Pa. Aug. 15 (AP) -- "Oh boy, Am I tired," President Eisenhower said today in starting a round of golf.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on a bill to provide pensions of $25,000 a year for former Presidents of the United States.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Miss Carol Fox, general manager of the Lyric Opera Company of Chicago, announced today that the Italian Government had agreed to provide a subsidy for the organization.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Senate poured close to $3,900,000,000 tonight into the catch-all money bill of the waning session of Congress.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Yankee pitchers are still finding that twenty-game goal a tougher climb than running uphill in sand.

Non-violent resistance is the only successful weapon against race prejudice, a disciple of the late Monhandas K. Gandhi said yesterday after a visit to the south. Kaka Saheb Kalelkar explained that other methods by which the Negro could gain equal status would leave rancor and bitterness.

Gordon E. Dean, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission from July, 1950, to June, 1953, was the son of a Baptist minister. He became a newspaper reporter, a lawyer, a college instructor and, finally, after long Federal service in law, came to head the nation's most critical cold-war endeavor, the A. E. C.

What is the Soviet Government afraid of? That is the question which must inevitably come to mind in the wake of the news that the Soviet Government has been intensively jamming Russian-language broadcasts of the United Nations General Assembly. The question remains pressing even though there were indications yesterday that Moscow may have stopped or reduced its jamming.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 15 -Yale University officials announced today that a special memorial service would be held at Yale in early fall for the Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes. Dr. Stokes, Yale's secretary from 1899 to 1921, died at his home on Wednesday in Stockbridge, Mass., at the age of 84. He was a member of Yale's class of 1896.

First Mutual Securities of America leased offices in the new building at 630 Third Avenue at Forty-first street from Atlas Terminals, Inc., and Arthur Belfer, the builders. First Mutual is now at 10 East Forty-ninth Street. The lease on the new quarters was negotiated by Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker. Collins, Tuttle Co. is the agent for the building.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- In a surprise move, the International Amateur Athletic Federation today approved three controversial performances as world records among a list of thirty-six.
The State Council of Parks yesterday honored the memory of Herbert Bayard Swope, one of New York's most ardent park lovers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--The United States Government is somewhat apprehensive over the situation in Iran, officials intimated today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 15 -- The most serious terrorist bombing in many weeks killed three persons and wounded ten here today as the United Nations General Assembly was pondering ways to end violence in the Middle East.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 15 -- President Eisenhower's six-point plan for the Middle East was rejected by the Baghdad press today as "contrary to Arab interests."

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Those who know tennis best insist that in the 1958 American Zone Davis Cup final it will be the United States over Argentina, 5--0. As of a late hour today, though, the experts were three-and-a-fraction points off in their prediction.

Net income of the Consolidated Electronics Industries Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries in the nine months ended June 30 dropped to $1,055,885, or $1.34 a share, from $1,716,367, or $2.18 a share in the similar period a year ago, the company announced yesterday.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Aug. 15 -- This missile community is speculating excitedly about the Air Force's moon shot scheduled for Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- An ex-convict who is an official of the Brotherhood of Teamsters swore today that he never handled a large sum of "stolen or kidnap" money about the time of the 1953 Bobby Greenlease kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Union Telegraph Company asked authority today to raise rates on Oct. 1 on interstate private line teletypewriter services.

A very shallow sounding in the illimitable sea of space. This is the measurement of the nation's most ambitious effort to probe the "wild blue yonder" -- the lunar-probe program scheduled to start tomorrow at Cape Canaveral.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Navy moved swiftly today to smooth the ruffled feelings of Mrs. Hyman G. Rickover. It announced that the Admiral's wife had been on the list to christen one of the atomic submarines since July 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Arthur L. Wright, head of a company bearing his name, said today he had returned the concern's certificate as a securities dealer to the Pennsylvania Securities Commission for safekeeping. He said he also returned the licenses of fifteen of his salesmen.

" IDEALLY," Andrew Lytle tells as in his foreword to "A Novel, a Novella and Four Stories"* -- "the artist creates his reader as well as the book, establishing in his mind that perfect communion of sympathy and understanding which, unfortunately, remains ideal."
CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Congressional investigating committee hearings are similar to criminal trials but "the defendants' rights go largely unprotected," Joseph L. Rauh Jr. declared today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Bertram D. Tallamy, Federal Highway Administrator, said today that bridges on the New York State Thruway had been given a special surface "specifically provided so that it could be removed and replaced when corrosive action made that necessary."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee cleared for house action today a bill to authorize a subsidy program for domestic minerals production.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 15 -- Eldis Coho-Arteaga, a 28-year-old Havana telephone engineer, tonight won the open championship of the United States Chess Federation with a score of 10 -- 2. He defeated Herbert Avran in thirty-nine moves in the twelfth and final round after defeating Larry Evans of Los Angeles in the afternoon.
CRUGERS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -Three Roman Catholic Maryknoll seminarians and a visiting student were killed in a highway accident here this afternoon. Thirteen other students were injured, four seriously.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- A Soviet newspaper printed a letter today said to be from a 22-year-old girl who charges she was imprisoned and mistreated in Yugoslav jails for more than two months.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Aug. 15 -- Charges of assault and conduct unbecoming an officer will be preferred against a United States Army major who is accused of having beaten a civilian entertainer in an officers' club altercation, the Army announced today.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15 -- Canada is willing to send her Doukhobors back where they came from if they wish to go.

A benefit theatre party is being planned by the Sweet Briar Alumnae Club of New York for the Nov. 7 performance of "The Pleasure of His Company." The comedy, starring Cornelia Otis Skinner and Cyril Ritchard, will open at the Longacre Theatre in October.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- A consultative committee, mainly representing Parliament, reported tonight its general approval of the basic provisions of the proposed new French Constitution. Surviving another great test in the interzonal tournament of the International Chess Federation at Portoroz, Bobby Fischer drew in the seventh round against Yuri Auerbach of Russia, according to a report last night from Yugoslavia.

LOON BAY, N. B., Aug. 15 -- The St. Croix River is at a low stage now and very clear. Bass fishing is generally poor, but the visiting angler cannot relax because it is essential at such a time to keep a close eye on his guide.
GAZA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The United Nations Emergency Force, on patrol in the Egyptian-held Gaza Strip since March, 1957, is working smoothly despite the Middle East crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Radio Corporation of America obtained a patent this week for a system of effortless driving on a superhighway. It's a kind of automatic pilot, capable of following the road and even of turning out to avoid a stalled car.

Wall Street's newest but most elaborate stock market measuring rod has proved itself over almost a year and a half of use. That is, of course, the 500-stock Standard Poor's Corporation index, introduced on March 1, 1957.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 14 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale. The new October and new December contracts were weakest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Senate voted 88 to 2 today for an amendment that bars funds to support any study of possible United States surrender to an enemy in a future nuclear war. A new book by Elisabeth Elliot, author of "Through Gates of Splendor," is planned for publication on Sept. 3 by Harper. It is "Shadow of the Almighty," a biography of the author's husband, one of the five missionaries killed by the Auca Indians.

Advice was given yesterday to hay fever sufferers by the allergy department of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn. The department explained that between the middle of August and late September ragweed gives off airborne pollen to bring discomfort to some 5,000,000 Americans.

The weekly survey of the steamship charter market found chartering activity holding at previously set low levels, but rates dropped sharply in virtually all commodities except lumber from the West Coast.

The New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation and the Long Island Jewish Hospital at New Hyde Park, L. I., announced yesterday a joint program to rehabilitate persons crippled by arthritis so that they could again find regular employment.

Brazil's proposal that a high-level "Committee of Twenty-one" be set up in Washington to explore the whole field of regional economic development among the American nations is both timely and meritorious. It has been well received in several of the Latin nations and it should be warmly welcomed here.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 -- Steel production and orders continued to improve last week. The trend is expected to accelerate after Labor Day. Many steel users already are finding their inventories too low.

MELBOURNE, Aug. 17--One of the main features of the Australian economic picture is the increase in American investments. Many United States companies have opened branches or expanded existing ones in the last few years.

GALWAY, Ireland, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Airline officials said today that the bodies of twenty-nine unidentified victims of last Thursday's crash of a KLM-Royal Dutch airliner probably would be buried at Galway after a formal inquest tomorrow. Ninety-nine persons perished in the disaster.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that George D. Brown Jr. and Bernard W. Guenther, partners in the architectural firm of Brown Guenther, had been retained as consultants on the design of new developments.
Federal and city officials are getting ready for a traffic jam tomorrow along luxury liner row. Five trans-Atlantic liners will dock during the day with 6,800 passengers.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 16 -- The fate of crisis-rocked Jordan hangs for the moment on a small fearless Arab King 23 years old. In the current atmosphere of plot and intrigue, the British-schooled Hussein is fast turning into a steel-hard man.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Aug. 17--Norway reached an agreement with India today on a compromise resolution that would assign to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold complete responsibility for working out stable conditions in Lebanon and Jordan.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Paul Robeson called on the Soviet people today to fight for freedom. He did not specify what freedom or for whom, but he spoke and sang in general terms of man's right to be free.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 3 and 7 -- 5, today. The losses dropped the Pirates nine - games behind the first-place Milwaukee Braves.

The scorched tanker Gulfoil was towed into port yesterday from Newport, R. I., where sixteen of her crew of thirty-one died Aug. 7. The vessel collided with the gasoline-laden tanker S. E. Graham in a fog, setting both ships afire.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 17 -- Ashley Cooper defeated his Australian Davis Cup teammate and doubles partner, Neale Fraser, in the semi-final round of the Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today.

WHEN the weather is hot, there is a tendency to neglect hot vegetables and favor salads. However, because of the bulky nature of salad greens, it is almost impossible to eat a sufficient quantity to supply the mineral and vitamin needs of the body.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- House investigators said today bad military buying practices had caused a serious shortage of rocket launchers for United States warplanes.

MUSIC lovers have their problems when it comes to storing sheet music and records. Mrs. Mildred Kantor of Brooklyn writes that she has been searching in vain for a sheet music cabinet that she saw in 1941. The cabinet, she adds, was on castors and was low enough to slide under one side of a grand piano.

" A PRIDE OF RELATIONS," by Richard Charles, is a comic saga of country life in England. That took some strenuous doing at Thornton Avoril, a town somewhere between London and Bath.

The twenty-fourth year of bowling classes at Penn State University will begin next month. The sessions that started in a commercial lane in downtown University Park in 1935 have grown to the point where the bowling classes are now the largest of any of the sixteen sports available in the University's required physical education program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply in the wake of last week's increase in the Federal Reserve discount rate, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,800,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 1.895 per cent, compared with 1.524 per cent last week.

A volume that considers the most controversial and provocative aspects of Abraham Lincoln as man and President will be published in October by McGraw-Hill. Titled "The Lincoln Nobody Knows," it has been written by Richard Current.

The closing days of the Eighty-fifth Congress are proving no exception to the norm.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- Cadillac Motor Car Division, whose sales have held up well in this generally bad year, will present streamline 1959 models that are generally lower and more luxurious.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 18 -- JoAnne Gunderson, 19-year-old defending champion, successfully withstood the surprising challenge of a 17-year-old opponent as the United States Golf Association women's amateur championship started today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The top payment for disability under World War II G. I. life insurance was raised from $50 to $100 a month by a bill signed into law by President Eisenhower today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Russia upset Hungary, 11 -- 5, and France beat Italy, 9 -- 7, tonight to open the finals of the men's team foil competition in the world fencing championships. The two-week tournament opened in the morning at the University of Pennsylvania's Hutchinson Gymnasium.
Pratt Institute named Albert Christ-Janer dean of its Art School and Professor of Art yesterday. He is director of the School of the Arts and Professor of Art at Pennsylvania State University.

The text of Casey Stengel's speech to his players prior to a most unusual, off-day workout at the Stadium yesterday was not available. No one could tell for sure what the unhappy pilot of the Yankees told his slumping charges, who have dropped eight of their last eleven games.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The first of the auto industry's 1959 model cars began moving from assembly lines today. They came in limited volume from a few assembly plants, as more makers moved closer to the changeover.

Detroit, Mich., plans to sell Aug. 26 two series of bonds totaling $12,285,000 to finance various public improvements. One issue will come due serially from 1959 to 1983 and the other from 1959 to 1962.

LOUIS SUTZ and his wife are inveterate Sunday drivers. But they differ from many with the same predilection in two respects.

NEW DELHI, Jordan, Aug. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that he had agreed to a suggestion by Malik Firoz Khan Noon, Prime Minister of Pakistan, for an early personal meeting to discuss and resolve border disputes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Court of Appeals decision today that reinstated the school integration program in Little Rock, Ark., again puts squarely to the Eisenhower Administration the problem of enforcing integration orders against local resistance.

ABOARD U.S.S. NAUTILUS, AT SEA, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Nautilus submerged off England today. The nuclear submarine will stay under water until Monday, when, after a fast run, she will surface to dock in New York, probably at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Norway introduced a compromise resolution in the General Assembly today omitting any reference to the withdrawal of United States and British forces from Lebanon and Jordan.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The three-day Teamsters Union strike against seven St. Paul wholesale groceries ended today, but a two-week dispute with ten Minneapolis companies remained deadlocked.

Directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday declared a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 13. Dividends of the same amount were paid in each of the first and second quarters of this year, and in September, 1957.

Loew's State Theatre on Broadway last night showed some of the most pleasantly churlish scenes to hit the movie screen since Bela Lugosi last sneered at Boris Karloff. About 2,400 moviegoers attended the closed - circuit television show that could easily have been called "Requiem for a School Teacher," or "Harris Got His."

Cross-currents dominated the Government bond market yesterday. Yields on Treasury bills continued to climb swiftly in the direction of a 2 per cent level. But enough buying strength appeared in the long-term section of the list to carry the rest of the Government market forward.
Columbium or niobium?
In the pre-election season the major political parties often reshuffle their slates to take best advantage of the professional success and vote-getting appeal of their candidates.

Floyd Patterson retained his world heavyweight boxing title last night by knocking out Roy Harris. Bill Gore, trainer of the courageous challenger, asked the referee to stop the contest after the twelfth round of their scheduled fifteen-round bout at Wrigley Field, Los Angeles.
The Freethinkers of America filed a suit in State Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, from prohibiting birth-control therapy in city hospitals.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- The American Veterinary Association honored a 14-year-old Schenectady girl today for kindness to lost, strayed, abandoned and injured animals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House killed the controversial housing bill today and the Senate confirmed a major civil rights appointment as both houses drove to clear the decks for possible adjournment this week.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The American Hospital Association prepared today to re-examine its stand on the issue of hospital care for the aging.
LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 18 -- A one-week Country Fair to aid a drive for funds for the Dr. Hazard Memorial Hospital here opened today at Long Branch Stadium.

No sane man running for public office in New York State is going to commit political suicide by attacking wholesale the people of any nationality, color or religion that does any voting at the polls. So we must take it with a liberal shaker of salt when Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall, accuses Paul W. Williams, Republican candidate for Governor, of indicting an "entire people with willful and filthy libels."

Washington, Aug. (UPI) -- Representative Robert L. F. Sikes, Democrat of Florida, said today that United States troops in the Middle East were armed with the same type of rifles and machine guns used by their fathers and grandfathers while Arab soldiers had the most modern Soviet weapons.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Wyandanch, L. I., school officials conferred with experts from the State Department of Education here today on plans for building a new high School. Wyandanch has 170 secondary school students but no school for them.

Eleven of the first persons given summonses under the new jaywalking rules appeared yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court to pay $2 fines. The group included one man who condemned the enforcement of the jaywalking law as a "farce."
VIENNA, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Czechoslovak Communist Government has decreed a ban on the private practice of medicine effective next Jan. 1, Czechoslovak newspapers disclosed today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 18 -- The advantage of a good start in competition with no other tactical problems was shown convincingly in today's America's Cup Observation Trial sailing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House of Representatives refused today to suspend its rules and pass the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill. The vote was 198 to 190. The bill was sixty-nine votes short of the two-thirds necessary for passage under suspension of the rules. It was nine votes short of a majority.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Senate passed today a version of legislation to require the registration and numbering either by the states or the Coast Guard of all motorboats of more than ten horsepower.
A German freighter arrived here yesterday with a distinguished equine cargo.

The United States Plywood Corporation will begin marketing the entire fir plywood production of the Pacific Coast Company on Sept. 1, according to S. W. Antoville, president of U. S. Plywood, and Hugh J. Jacks. president of Pacific Coast.
ROME, Aug. 18 (AP) -- American musicians have won praise in Italy for an unusual round of summer concerts and appearances.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Two Vienna music critics today described the European premiere of Samuel Barber's opera "Vanessa" as a "wretched work" and branded Gian-Carlo Menotti's libretto "disgusting."

VENICE, ITALY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Spain and Poland added their protests today to those of the Soviet Union and West Germany over movies either included in or left out of this year's Venice Film Festival. Festival directors said they were rejecting all the complaints.

After a democratic process of filing and polishing, a group of smaller nations headed by Norway and backed by the United States and Britain has submitted to the United Nations General Assembly a new plan designed to resolve the present crisis in the Middle East.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Growing confidence in the United States business outlook was called a factor that helped the stock market extend its gains today.

MANY homemakers, when cooking pasta dishes such as macaroni and spaghetti, are frequently plagued with having pasta strands stick together after draining. There are several facile methods to prevent this.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Eisenhower vetoed today a bill to reimburse a St. Petersburg, Fla., contractor for losses suffered on a Navy construction job in the British West Indies.
Dore Schary, formerly head of production for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures, has signed an agreement with the National Broadcasting Company to produce five ninety-minute programs about the Civil War.
DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The automobile industry started production of its 1959 model cars today in an atmosphere of uncertainty.
A sharp increase in paralytic polio cases here was reported yesterday by Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner.
Governor Harriman declared yesterday that the Middle East crisis presented an opportunity for "peaceful progress and eventual harmony" in that area.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, upheld today the decision of the Yonkers Board of Education establishing overlapping sessions at Roosevelt High School.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 18 -- Malcolm Anderson stood as a strong challenger to Ashley Cooper for world preeminence in amateur tennis today with his victory over his Australian Davis Cup team-mate in the final of the Newport invitation tournament.

The new third-class service introduced by trans-Atlantic airlines on April 1 was patronized by more than 200,000 passengers in the first three months, the International Air Transport Association reported here yesterday.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 18 -- The Democratic Action party will not nominate a member of its own party for the Presidency, it was announced today by Dr. Romulo Betancourt, party chairman.
The Board of Education's high school division has declared war on "boondoggling" courses for slow learners.
Mayor Wagner ruled out the use of a payroll tax to meet future city fiscal crises yesterday. He said that "the same goes for any form of income tax."

Secretary of State Dulles set forth in detail last night what he called the challenge of the "acute" and "delicate" issue of indirect aggression. He said it should best be dealt with, "so far as possible," by the United Nations.

WEST END, Grand Bahamas, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Muirmen of Los Angeles yesterday won the United States skin-diving championship with 479 1/2 pounds of game fish. The team was composed of Bel Wren, Frank Hops and Dick Jaffa.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 18 -- An interim president for Rutgers University will be named Friday at a special meeting of the board of governors, Howard A. Smith, chairman of the board, said today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The initial plans for an expanded and diversified production schedule were made public today by officials of the Hal Roach Studios.
Premier Chou En-lai is usually regarded as the most knowledgeable and intelligent member of the Red Chinese regime in Peiping. He is also an unmitigated liar, and therefore doubly dangerous.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 18 -- The Norfolk School Board turned down tonight all 151 Negro students who had applied for admission to white schools in the city for the fall term.

The near-by September, October and December cocoa positions rose the daily limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The deferred months were strong on switching forward and on short covering.
State Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer will decide by noon today whether Daniel J. Riesner had the right to call a meeting of the New York County Republican Committee for tonight.
HAWAII which may become the fiftieth star on the American flag, is already gleaming brightly on the New York horizon.

Pooling of mortgage resources by savings banks for major construction projects, a financing method that has been permissible since 1956, is coming into wider use. In a recent loan of this kind, five savings banks joined forces to provide a mortgage for a shopping center in Plattsburgh, N. Y.
Plans for establishing an international bank for the Communist bloc have apparently run into snags.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Further evidence of the increased popularity of the Conservative party has revived speculation about the possibility of a general election this fall.
MADISON, N. H., Aug. 18 -- Representatives of a college community in Oxford, Ohio, opened a conference today on the role of Christian colleges having no specific church affiliation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 18 -- The United States will aid Yugoslavia's industrialization and development program this year, but probably not to the extent desired by the Tito regime, informed sources said today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Archbishop Karl J. Alter of Cincinnati formally opened tonight the nineteenth North American Liturgical Week.

A former managing agent of properties for the New York City Real Estate Bureau was indicted yesterday in the theft of $56,384.21 from the bureau. However, according to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, he made restitution of $56,202.62 to the city last June.
SOMEHOW the outrageous notion has gotten abroad that the consumption of strong drink is a popular pastime in certain quarters of Ireland.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Purchase of Mexico's telephone network by a group of Mexican business men at a cost of $28,000,000 will be announced Thursday, informed sources said today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Ron Holmberg and Mike Franks, paired for the first time in an apparent long-range test for Davis Cup play, breezed through their first appearance today in the 78th national doubles tennis championships at Longwodd.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Britain reminded Iceland today that gunboats would guard British trawlers against interference inside Iceland's new twelve-mile fishing limits.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Iraq, India and Indonesia called today for the immediate withdrawal of United States troops from Lebanon and British troops from Jordan.
CLOTHES alterations may be much simpler this year. For the most part, new fall wardrobes will need some alterations, but current fashions have done much to simplify the struggle of fitting.

YONKERS, Aug. 18 -- Seventh at the five-eighths pole, Top Deck, from the Edward O'Dowd Stable of Pine Brook, N. J., finished with a fine burst of speed to score a half-length victory over Golden Blade in the Tarrytown Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Winston-Salem school board, with one dissenting vote -- from the board's only Negro member -- assigned three Negro children to white schools today and rejected applications from five others.

Governors of the American Stock Exchange will hold a special meeting this morning to determine if a "corner" exists in the common stock of the E. L. Bruce Company of Memphis, Tenn., producer of hardwood flooring.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 18 -- A Chicago pacifist couple seeking to halt construction of a missile launching base north of here were twice escorted by the police from the reservation.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 18 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations ordered its affiliates today to end all dealings -- formal or informal -- with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, headed by James R. Hoffa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The long-delayed confirmation of W. Wilson White to head the Justice Department's new civil rights division was voted by the Senate tonight.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Chicago business improved little if at all in July over June, a survey by the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago shows.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Hector Torres allowed only one hit as Monterrey, Mexico, the defending champion gained an 11-0 victory over Pearl Harbor in the opening round of the twelfth annual Little League world series today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Georgianna Foster's outsider, Viscount, was clocked in 1:11 4/5, the fastest six-fur-long time of the Saratoga meeting, in winning the Bernard Baruch Birthday Handicap today by two and three-quarter lengths.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP) -Soviet marksmen dominated the world shooting championships today, sweeping all team events and dropping only an individual first place to a British trapshooter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The House passed Social Security and welfare pension legislation today as Congress continued its determined drive to get rid of adjournment-blocking bills.
CHICAGO, Aug, 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Members of the Australian, American and Argentine Davis Cup teams arrived here from Newport, R. I., and Rye, N. Y., today to join in the action in the national doubles tennis championships.

IN East Hampton, Provincetown, Woodstock and New York City -- in fact, wherever more than one painter or sculptor is billeted for the summer -- a recurring topic of conversation is the Ford Foundation's recently announced grant-in-aid program administered by its Humanities and Arts division.

HAVANA, Aug. 19 -- The offensive opened last June by the forces of President Fulgencio Batista against the insurgents in Oriente Province has failed, according to a broadcast by the rebel leader heard here today.

Daniel J. Riesner and his supporters were barred by a court order from holding a meeting of the Republican New York County Committee last night. The special meeting had been called by Mr. Riesner to elect a successor to the late Thomas J. Curran, committee chairman and county leader. Mr. Riesner is a candidate for the post.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ascribed today to its sister agency, the Civil Aeronautics Administration, the chief responsibility for the collision on April 21 between an airliner and an Air Force jet near Las Vegas, Nev.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A Polish runner with a powerful finishing kick captured the big event as the sixth European track and field championships opened today.

On Aug. 16 The New York Times published a story in which Governmental leaders scored any possible study of a United States surrender in any future nuclear war. The President labeled discussion of this topic "ridiculous" and Senator Lyndon B. Johnson added that "no thinking American ever gave credence" to a surrender.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -Dick Donovan pitched a four-hitter, marred only by Jackie Jensen's thirty-third homer, in leading the Chicago White Sox to a 7-1 triumph over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

The decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals at St. Louis in the Little Rock school desegregation case is a striking reaffirmation that ours is a government of laws: "We say that the time has not yet come in these United States when an order of a Federal court must be whittled away, watered down or shamefully withdrawn in the face of violent and unlawful acts of individual citizens in opposition thereto."
A proposal for the merger of National Theatres, Inc., and National Telefilm Associates, Inc., was announced yesterday.

GROTON, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The man who rode down the ways today on the unfinished bridge of the Triton is a submariner who is probably better known to the public than any other officer in the "silent service."
BUFFALO, Aug. 19 -- The rising cost of local welfare programs is posing one of the few intraparty problems that face Republican policymakers for the fall campaign.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 19 -- Crews representing the Larchmont Yacht Club and the Black Rock Yacht Club of Bridgeport, Conn., took the lead in the Long Island Sound Junior Yacht Racing Association midget championship today.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 19 -- Each United States expert employed in Pakistan under the aid program is said to cost Pakistan $25,000 in American currency and 24,000 Pakistani rupees a year. This works out to an average cost of 12,000 rupees ($2,520) a month to each expert.
Anchorage, Alaska, is to be the first stop for Mary Martin's concert presentation, "Music With Mary Martin," which is scheduled to tour more than fifty American cities.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 -- Of all the qualities with which mankind is endowed, none can evoke swifter or deeper admiration than courage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, whose career has become something of a cause celebre, was designated today to represent President Eisen hower at the New York celebration next Monday for the atomic submarine Nautilus.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- The Soviet Union is not happy at the way Yugoslavia reacted to the recent meeting in Peiping of Nikita S. Khrushchev and Mao Tse-tung, Soviet and Chinese Communist leaders.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved mostly downward yesterday. Final prices were 8 points up on March, but 3 to 37 points off on other months. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 19 -- The stage appeared set here today for the assignment of specific Negro students, to white Norfolk schools by Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower is looking for some chinaware.
ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Governor Harriman assailed today the New York Republican Representatives in Congress whose votes helped defeat the Kennedy-Ives anti-rackets labor bill yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -The East Boston Company, a real estate company controlled by Bernard Goldfine, has filed the necessary financial report with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering its latest fiscal year.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Seth Corwin, representing the Western Long Island Sound fleet, captured the opening race of the annual international 110 Class Yacht Racing Association championship today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 19 -- Yugoslavia's Goran Dance Ensemble, which was started by a student organization in Zagreb ten years ago, has been active long enough to develop professional cohesion. But it has not taken on any of the slickness of the commercial theatre.

While we subscribe heartily to Mayor Wagner's platform plank advocating more autonomy for New York City, his assumption that home-rule freedom to tax would create a magic solvent for city financial problems is strictly politics for state campaign consumption. In his four years in office the Mayor has failed to advance and stand by a single major new form of taxation.

A SAUCY fable by Charles Dickens was transferred to the television screen with pleasing results last night. The story was "The Magic Fishbone" and it was seen, in Margaret Fitts' adaptation, on "Shirley Temple's Storybook" over Channel 4.
GROTON, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The Triton, the largest submarine ever built, slid smoothly into the Thames River from the launching ways of the Electric Boat shipyard today.
An official of the State Labor Department said yesterday that complaints by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People about migrant labor camps were "exaggerated" and "false."

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- While Joanne Gunderson, the 19-year-old defending champion, advanced, a full measure of upsets marked the second round of the United States Golf Association women's amateur championship today.

In 1790, Aleksandr Radishchev published "A Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow," an appeal to the sovereign and the landed gentry to free the serfs voluntarily. The book was immediately banned and destroyed, only a few copies being preserved.

I have been reading much about the growing problem our stores and shops in Manhattan are undergoing in regard to off-street parking. Of equal importance is the on-street parking. On every midtown street there are signs about when one can park, with threats of being towed away, but every side street has its violators and special cars parked unmolested.
A. M. Sonnabend is no sleight-of-hand artist. He does, however, have a rare knack -- that of mixing together red and black ink on corporation ledgers and producing pure black.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 19 -Three men were killed and seven persons rescued today when a twenty-six-foot cabin cruiser capsized and sank in heavy surf at the approach to Great Egg Harbor Inlet. The inlet is between Ocean City and Longport, on the southern end of Absecon Island.

The American grandmother, particularly the pink-checked, silver-maned, twinkle-eyed variety, is largely a woman of the past. Today, she is likely to be partial to hair rinses, mascara and the chemise. Out of style, also, are many of her remedies and recipes. These have become as unsolicited as her advice on marital difficulties.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Several grain futures contracts again hit new lows for the season in a broad sell-off today on the Board of Trade.

Today's new film is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Imitation General," a military comedy starring Glenn Ford, Red Buttons and Taina Elg, at Loew's State, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street. William Hawks produced and George Marshall directed.
Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs indicated yesterday that he might be considering a relaxation of his ban on contraceptive therapy in city hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Eisenhower, acting under authorization voted by Congress a month ago, is expected to name a new Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs soon to head a staff of seventy-seven in the State Department and 274 in Africa.

ROYAL heads were not meant to look like cabbages. EVERYBODY knows that the frankfurter is America's favorite snack. Originated in Frankfurt, Germany, and introduced to this country at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St. Louis in 1904, it is now ubiquitous at baseball parks, football stadiums, seashore snack stands and at the backyard grill.
Ben Hecht will be featured on a new television series encompassing commentary, criticism and satire.

Futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil and wool declined; copper, lead, potatoes and rubber rose, and price movements for cocoa, coffee, sugar, hides and zinc were mixed.
NEWCASTLE, England, Aug. 19 (Reuters) -- T. S. Eliot's first play in five years received high praise from critics and audience following its "unofficial" opening here last night.

A three-mile-long waterfront railroad in Brooklyn, which had sought to discontinue operations because it has been losing $15,000 a month for the last five years, was ordered yesterday to continue operating until Oct. 8.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The British Government reaffirmed today that it would go ahead with its plan for Cyprus whether or not Greece and Turkey cooperated.

STAMFORD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Equipment under development in the United States could be fashioned within five years into a space ship that would be capable of carrying a man to the moon and back, the closing meeting of the American Astronautical Society was told here today.

The latest reports from Warsaw on what went on during the recent Mao-Khrushchev talks in Peiping are intriguing. Though unconfirmed, these Warsaw reports are not obviously improbable and fit well into a reasonable pattern. That Peiping would like the Soviet Union to supply it with ballistic missiles, nuclear warheads, greater economic aid, and help in launching a "Chinese" sputnik may be accepted as obvious.

A six-story apartment building on plot 83 by 100 feet at 150 Remsen Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Jerome Dansker, president of the Investors Funding Corporation, after an ownership of a few weeks. The building, containing fifty suites and two stores, was acquired by the 150 Remsen Street Corporation, represented by Jerome A. Weiss.

Governors of the American Stock Exchange side-stepped the issue yesterday of determining whether a corner existed in the stock of the E. L. Bruce Company. The company, a maker of hardwood flooring, is the prime stake in a fight for control be

NEWPORT, R. I. Aug. 19 -- Weatherly beat Vim for the first time in a match race today. The way it was done indicated she could not be counted out in the trials that will lead to a defender of yachting's big international prize, the America's Cup, next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Administration was in the unhappy state today of having to contemplate putting the Federal troops back into Little Rock before it had figured out how to get them out of Lebanon.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 19 -Foreign Ministry circles expressed satisfaction today over an agreement with the United States to buy United States military equipment.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 19 -- A military court imposed five-year jail sentences on three Haitian newspapermen convicted of sedition and inciting to armed revolt, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A bill authorizing Harry S. Truman to receive a decoration from Liberia was passed by the Senate today and sent to the White House.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 19 -Foreign Minister S. K. Huang said here today that he did not see how the United States "could do otherwise" than participate in the defense of the Chinese Nationalist-held islands of Quemoy and Matsu, off the Fukien coast.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon reported today that the opening of new posts had brought "almost all the significant points on the frontier" under day and night surveillance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- The Immigration and Naturalization Service took its "first step in the last move" today to get rid of William Heikkila, a Finnish-born former Communist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Tests show that radioactivity in a shipment of Japanese tea that arrived in New York July 31 is well below the established tolerance, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.

The Illuminating Engineering Society gave recognition yesterday to Duro-Test Corporation of North Bergen, N. J., for development of a new source for general lighting. This is reportedly the first time an independent lamp maker has been so honored.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP) -The Los Angeles Dodgers continued their mystifying domination of Milwaukee tonight by defeating the world champions twice before a crowd of 42,409. The scores were 4 -- 1 and 7 -- 2.

LUDLOW, N. B., Aug. 19 -Eastern New Brunswick is having a great salmon season and the southwest branch of the Miramichi is getting its share. A combination of factors is responsible but the major one is that there is plenty of cold, clear water.

It's peculiar about children in the suburban neighborhood these halcyon summer days. They are either screamingly present or ominously absent.
