MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19 -- Plans are being drawn for a $50,000,000 modernization and expansion of Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican telephone system. The program will get underway as soon as pending loans are concluded in the United States, an official of the system announced here today.

ATHENS, Aug. 19 -- Greece's Premier Konstantin Karamanlis told Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today that the British Government's latest formula for solution of the Cyprus problem was received here with "disappointment and regret."

BONN, Germany, Aug. 19 -- A foreign aid program designed to pump substantially more West German capital goods into underdeveloped countries is in the final stage of preparation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants defeated the Cincinnati Redlegs, 4 -- 3, today on the five-hit pitching of Johnny Antonelli and a tenth inning triple by Willie Kirkland that scored Orlando Cepeda.

Directors of Safeway Stores, Inc., yesterday increased the dividend on the common stock and voted to make future payments on a monthly rather than quarterly basis.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The stock market was fairly cheerful today and in most sections gains out numbered losses.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 19 -- Municipal elections open to Paraguay's non-Communist Opposition parties will be held next March, Interior Minister Edgar Insfran said today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 19 -- Following is the text of a statement by Gov. Orval E. Faubus on a decision yesterday by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis. TO an adult, a chair is a chair. To a child, a chair is a tugboat, a train, a truck. No one knows this better than a mother. As the mother of two, Marion Zelenko qualifies as a critic of the juvenile furniture industry. As a trained architect, she is prepared to do something about it.

Directors of the Corn Products Refining Company have approved a plan for the conversion of preferred stock into subordinated debentures as part of a proposed merger with Best Foods, Inc., it was announced yesterday.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Trinidad Government was expected today to acquire control of Angostura Bitters, Ltd., originators of the beverage flavoring extract.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The grain futures market leveled off today after several successive declines. Although gains on the Board of Trade were moderate they were general.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- The Peronist movement started today a recruiting drive to rebuild an organized party.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- A Federal grand jury here returned an indictment today charging Joseph P. Dupont, a member of the Governor's council, with preparing and filing sixty-two "false and fraudulent" income tax returns.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Eisenhower outlined his philosophy today on what the Government can and cannot do to stop inflation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -Robert Bernard (Barney) Baker, heavyweight organizer for the teamsters and former pugilist, raged today at Senate rackets committee testi mony linking him to Governor Harriman of New York.
MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Sir David Eccles, president of the Board of Trade, said today he was fully conscious of the serious difficulties that confront the British cotton industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Eisenhower made the following points in his news conference today:
Claire Bloom has been signed to co-star with Rod Steiger in the new Fay and Michael Kanin play, "Rashomon," based on two short stories by the Japanese author Hiroshi Akutagawa.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- Searching, a little mare with a streak of gameness, became the twentieth winner of the $27,250 Diana Handicap today.
GENEVA, Aug. 20 -- The East-West conference of scientists agreed today on a joint report on the possibility of supervising an international agreement to suspend the tests of nuclear weapons.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 20 (UPI) -- Monterrey, Mexico, seeking its second straight title, gained the final of the twelfth annual Little League world series today by crushing Darien, Conn 11 -- 5.
The sunken tanker Empress Bay was raised and moved 700 feet down the East River yesterday after fifty-six days as a shipping hazard between Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department reported today that it licensed $5,600,000 worth of goods for export to Soviet bloc countries in the second quarter of this year. It said this was a small increase over the first-quarter total but a drop from the $6,400,000 figure for the final three months of 1957.

The Soviet Union, according to reports from Rio de Janeiro, has let it be known that it would like to become one of the regular suppliers of crude petroleum to Brazil in exchange for tropical commodities.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 20 -- No one will ever accuse Gian-Carlo Menotti of writing a listless, static opera. The theatre is in his blood, and his latest work, "Maria Golovin," pulses with theatricalism.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 20 -- The Republican party was urged today to capitalize on dissatisfaction with the Harriman Administration's conservation record by drafting a strong conservation plank in the 1958 G. O. P. state platform.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -Negotiations seeking to turn one of the world's continents into an international laboratory, open to all, appear to be nearing a critical stage.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that "of course" there was a possibility he might seek the services some day of former President Harry S. Truman.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- An "explosively increasing demand for food" faces the world in the next few decades, Dr. Jacob George Harrar, director of agriculture for the Rockefeller Foundation, said here today.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 20 -- The United Aircraft Corporation of East Hartford is seeking to buy the 206-acre property of St. Luke's Convalescent Hospital on King Street.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 20 -The Jordanian Government is thinking of the proposed United Nations "presence" here in terms of a few international officers with limited powers, it was learned today.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad reported a net income for July of $2,931,000, the largest for any month this year. The showing, however, was due entirely to the road having credited to its income account $3,800,000 of increased mail pay, retroactive to July of 1956.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 -- The delegates of the ten Arab members of the United Nations drafted a compromise resolution today on the Middle Eastern crisis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -Senator Lyndon B. Johnson set Saturday night as the goal for the adjournment of Congress.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People wired Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas yesterday that it was ready to assist Negro parents in Little Rock "with all legal weapons" in pressing for the right to non-segregated education.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -President Eisenhower signed the reciprocal trade bill today. He called the legislation "a firm, forward step on the road to a stronger America in a world at peace."

Two educators yesterday recommended a six-day school week and a twelve-month school year. This, they said, would give youngsters a more intensive education and give them something to do in the summertime.

A "dark horse" agency has emerged as the winner in the "run for the roses." Keyes, Madden Jones, Inc., has been appointed to handle the $2,500,000-a-year advertising account of the Florists' Telegraph Delivery Association.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The American Hospital Association avoided giving support today to the extension of Social Security to pay for hospitalization of the retired aged.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The United States has informally warned Britain and Iceland against using force in their dispute over Iceland's new twelve-mile sea limit, Allied diplomats said tonight.

One might think that Governor Harriman's stated preference for Thomas K. Finletter would help Mr. Finletter get the Democratic nomination for Senator. It is quite the opposite, for in the same breath the Governor lets all interested parties know that "he is prepared to settle for Thomas E. Murray."
DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- The United Automobile Workers said today that recent announcements of proposed recalls of laid off workers in the auto industry were rosier than the facts warranted.

The possibility of a flight engineers' strike against Eastern Air Lines grew last night after the airline announced that it had accepted the report of a Presidential fact-finding board recommending that engineers for commercial jet craft be pilot-qualified.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The retirement of Lord Goddard, 81-year-old Lord Chief Justice of England, was announced today at 10 Downing Street. His resignation is effective Sept. 29.
The 1958 Freedom Award of Freedom House has been won by The Arkansas Gazette for supporting law and order during the school integration crisis in Little Rock, Ark.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) -- The Government reported today that corporations borrowed more money on bonds and other debt issues in the first half of 1958 than in any other half-year on record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Critics of the Supreme Court won an unexpected and smashing victory on the Senate floor tonight. By a vote of 46 to 39, they beat down a motion to table their pending "states rights bill" -- a measure vigorously opposed by the Justice Department and regarded as a broadside attack on the court.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 -- The Dodgers still are playing their quaint version of baseball here in the lop-sided, daffy ball park that makes a mockery of the sport. A tourist who inspects Walter O'Malley's Great Wall of China for the first time in several months still finds himself flinching at sight of the neighborly left-field screen, and blanching at sight of the distant rightfield barrier.
FLORENCE, Italy, Aug. 20 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said here today that "Intellectuals of the whole world, unite!" would make an excellent Democratic campaign slogan for the next United States elections.

MIAMI, Aug. 20 -- Dade County's public schools are not segregated and any absence of integrated classes is coincidental, Dr. Joe Hall, County School Superintendent, testified today in United States district court here.
A longshore worker's petition seeking annulment of an order revoking his registration as a cargo checker has been dismissed by Supreme Court Justice Morris E. Spector.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani interrupted Italy's midsummer political lethargy with a round of foreign policy consultations here today. He saw the Italian Ambassador to Washington, Manlio Brosio, and the envoys to Italy of the Soviet Union, West Germany and Brazil.
Day after day lately the low-price common stocks issues selling at $1 to $10 have paced the market in activity and in the upswing. The point has been made time and again by columnists and analysts.

The licenses of two auctioneers were restored yesterday on the signed stipulation that the men would not work in three Times Square shops accused of "shady practices," Commissioner of Licences Bernard J. O'Connell announced.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad began collecting $900,-$900,000 in passenger revenue today without punching a ticket.

President Eisenhower at his press conference yesterday made it unmistakably clear to the Governor and people of Arkansas that the Constitution and laws of this Federal Union, as interpreted by the courts of the United States, must and will be obeyed. If local authorities will not enforce the law, then the national will: "There can be no equivocation as to the responsibility of the Federal Government in such an event."
FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 20 -- George Meany agreed today to act as mediator in the stalemated merger negotiations between the Transport Workers Union and the Motormen's Benevolent Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appointed Lewis L. Strauss today to serve as chairman of the United States delegation at the second international conference on the peaceful uses of atomic energy in Geneva Sept. 1 to 13.
ABERDEEN, S. D., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic national chairman, said tonight the Eisenhower Administration had failed to spur an effort to keep ahead of the Soviet Union.
PARIS, Aug. 21 -- An Algerian rebel leader and a French Government Minister indicated today how wide the gulf still is between French and rebel aspirations.
The first commercial jet transport to be delivered to an American airline will arrive at New York Internationial Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 9:25 A. M. Sunday.

Mayor Wagner told a meeting of the Columbus Citizens Committee last night that the forthcoming Columbus Day parade "will take the same route up Fifth Avenue that it always has." After a short pause, he added: "And that goes for St. Patrick's Day, too."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The House of Representatives approved by a voice vote today a bill giving $25,000 annual pensions to former Presidents of the United States, and $10,000 a year to their widows, President Eisenhower was expected to sign the measure.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21 -- Mexico expropriated last night the vast American-owned Cananea ranch.

The American Federation of Musicians reported today that musicians in ten European countries had backed a six-point program to combat competition from recorded music. The program has also been endorsed by musicians in the United States and Canada.

CAIRO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Two sources close to the Gamal Abdel Nasser Government denied today a report that Saudi Arabia had agreed to oust the United States from the air base at Dhahran in 1962. The United States lease at Dhahran expires then.

CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. M. Harold Higgins and her son, Michael, toured their home course for an 81 to tie Mrs. John B. Balding and her son, Robert, of The Creek, Locust Valley L. I., in the Metropolitan Golf Association's mother-son championship at Upper Montclair today.

The Symphony of the Air, whose 1956 tour of the Middle East was canceled by the State Department because of "transportation difficulties" and alleged Communist activities among some of its members, is planning a "Toscanini Memorial Tour" of Europe and the Middle East in November.
ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The State Public Service Commission appealed to the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission today to force the continuation of Weehawken ferry service.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Britain's Mike Rawson tonight was declared winner of the 800-meter title when officials reversed his disqualification in the European track and field championships.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 21 -- Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino was asked tonight by Governor Harriman if he would be the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor. Mr. Carlino's answer was: "The jury is still out."
Floyd Patterson was knocked down cleanly by Roy Harris in the second round of their world heavyweight championship fight at Wrigley Field, Los Angeles, Monday night.
GENEVA, Aug. 21 -- Western and Eastern scientists ended their technical talks today with the joint conclusion that an international ban on the testing of nuclear weapons could be policed effectively.

As Chief Justice Warren has recently said, "The delay and the choking congestion in the Federal courts today have created a crucial problem for constitutional government in the United States." No wonder this is so. Cases have increased 62 per cent since 1941, but there are only 26 per cent more judges now to handle them.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 21 -- A proposed comprehensive zoning plan for the Town of Oyster Bay has drawn the opposition of residents of a dozen North Shore villages.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Sub-par golf carried JoAnne Gunderson, the titleholder, into the semi-final of the United States Golf Association's women's championship today.
NYBORG, Denmark, Aug. 21 -- Churchmen from around the world gathered here tonight to begin the annual meeting of the policy-making Central Committee of the World Council of Churches.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 21 -- Rear Admiral Ira H. Nunn, commander of the Atlantic Fleet Service Force for two years, has been named to head the United Nations delegation to the Korean Armistice Commission.

Willie Salesky, realty operator, has purchased the five-story apartment house for twenty families at 896 Fox Street, the Bronx. The deal was for cash over a mortgage of $29,000. The property, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, is near Simpson Street.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 21 -- The president of the National Legal Aid Association called upon the chief justices of the states today to assure "equal access to justice" by helping to extend the public or voluntary defender system throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- In his news conference yesterday, President Eisenhower gave a revealing definition of what he regarded as his proper course in the public school integration controversy.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Shawhan Fox, a Yale senior who sails with the Indian Harbor Yacht club fleet, moved into a good position to win the international 110-Class championship today.
The long jurisdictional fight to represent the white-collar workers in the steamship industry has ended with the merger of the two opposing unions.

In January, 1917, the British intercepted and decoded a message from Berlin to Mexico. It proposed that Mexico enter the war on Germany's side and persuade Japan to leave the Allies and join in an attack on the United States.
Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and Senator Jacob K. Javits are scheduled to address next week's Republican state convention in Rochester.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 21 -- Connecticut's Attorney General ruled today that the state cannot make school bus transportation grants to towns for private school children.
NICOSIA, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- About 700 Greek Cypriotes went on a hunger strike today to protest their imprisonment in British detention camps.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 21 -- Maurice A. Hutcheson, president of the Carpenters Union, was ordered by his fellow labor leaders today to account personally for corruption in his union. The tall, 61-year-old Mr. Hutcheson was directed by letter to appear before the November meeting of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A Supreme Court ruling that the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, must submit its dispute with the Grace Line to arbitration was upheld yesterday by Justice James B. M. McNally of the Appellate Division.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- The Government plans to crack down on false pricing to protect bargain-hunters.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 21 -Ten persons were wounded, one critically, in another explosion here today.
Low-price issues took the lead once again as the stock market yesterday made its third successive advance.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- Saratoga's first Powder Puff Derby today drew nine women riders aboard stable ponies in an event theoretically described as "non-betting." From the outpouring that came from the backstretch barns, it was hard to believe that interest in the race was entirely wagerless.
A first public distribution of common shares of the Champion Spark Plug Company will be made in early September, according to Robert A. Stranahan St., president of the company.
New court action in the fight for control of the E. L. Bruce Company was threatened yesterday.

Walter L. Johnson was cited in a New York Cotton Exchange resolution yesterday for his fifty years of membership and service in the Exchange. The resolution was presented by William K. Love Jr., president of the Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Gian Carlo Bergamini of Italy tonight won the world foil fencing championship as Albert Axelrod of Manchester, N. H., gave the United States its highest rating ever in the international competition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- The House approved today a compromise $3,697,305,478 money bill after House-Senate conferees had ironed out a controversy over Congressional control of the new national space agency.

Salvagers succeeded yesterday in moving the damaged harbor tanker Empress Bay out of the East River and into shallow water near Liberty Island. The tanker went down between Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges on June 26, after a collision with the freighter Niagara.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 -- The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals today granted a stay in the reinstatement of integration in Central High School at Little Rock, Ark. The stay is for thirty days or until the Supreme Court disposes of litigation in the case.
The Federal Reserve Board in Washington approved yesterday an increase from 1 3/4 to 2 per cent in the lending (discount) rate to member banks in the Dallas District.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- An increasing number of physicians are setting up private offices in community hospitals to the advantage of both, a thirty-state study has revealed.
The nation's largest copper producer, the Kennecott Copper Corporation, plans to step up domestic mining operations because of improving business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The United States is expected to announce tomorrow a one-year suspension of its testing of nuclear weapons. The suspension would begin con currently with the start of political negotiations with the Soviet Union for policing a ban on tests.

The twenty Republican members of the Legislature from New York City called on Mayor Wagner and the New York City Transit Authority yesterday to dispose of the authority's generating plants as soon as possible.
COPENHAGEN, Aug. 21 -- Denmark canceled tonight the scheduled visit here next week by the United States atomic submarine Skate.

Employes of the General Electric Company will give blood to the Red Cross at the Belmont Plaza Hotel today. Blood will also be donated at the S. S. Corrugated Paper Machinery Company, Inc., 166 North Fourth Street, Brooklyn, and at Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L. I.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- United States District Court Judge John W. Lord Jr today authorized the dismissal of the officers and five employes of Arthur L. Wright Co., Philadelphia investment concern.

The near-by cocoa positions were sharply lower yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Speculator selling and switching out of September to December weakened the nearby months. Some of the selling was evening of positions prior to first notice date, Tuesday.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 21 -King Hussein said today he would ask British troops to leave Jordan as soon as her Arab neighbors "behave themselves."
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Four ocean-going Soviet submarines seen in the English Channel yesterday are en route to join the Egyptian fleet, informed sources here believe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- A nuclear reactor using man-made plutonium as fuel has operated at "substantial power" for the first time.

An old single-decker bus that once lumbered through English village streets will begin touring New England today -- but it will pick up no passengers on the way. It already has a full load as the home-on-wheels of the Chudley family.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -This session's champion of the battle for Federal aid to education unquestionably is Representative Carl Elliott.

LUDLOW, N. B., Aug. 21 -The waters of the Miramichi have started to drop a little, but they are still about eight inches high and salmon fishing is no great shakes. Still, a little excitement was stirred this morning.
NEWARK, Aug. 21 -- An Associate Professor of Biology at Rutgers University has come up with what he believes is a solution to the food problem of human travel in outer space.

Naval progress has succeeded in doing what the Japanese could never do. The mighty aircraft carrier Enterprise yesterday went to her grave. Outmoded by the jet and atomic age, the "Big E" was ignominiously hauled to the junk pile. Eight Moran tugboats eased her from the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, and nudged her to Kearny, N. J., where she will be cut up and sold for scrap.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The Soviet Union threatened today to appeal again to the General Assembly, which will begin its regular session in mid-September, if the United States and Britain delayed their withdrawal from Lebanon and Jordan.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 3 points down yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 21Cuthbert Joseph Stovell, retired vice president of Congoleum-Nairn, linoleum floor! covering manufacturers, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. i age was 77. A resident of Orlando, Fla., he has been visiting his son-inaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Koster of Vhite Oak Shade, New Canaan. He leaves, besides his daughter, his wife, Dorothy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The General Assembly adopted unanimously today an Arab compromise resolution calling on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to make "practical arrangements" to uphold the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter with regard to Lebanon and Jordan.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Drug store officials gave in today to Negro youths who occupied all seats at the soda fountain and said they would remain until served. After five hours, the store began serving everyone.

The Day-hops The New York Summer Festival has been a part of the summer scene since June, 1954. At that time cultural and business attractions were offered to visitors as an inducement to spend their vacations here. Since then many have come to celebrate summer days in fun and frolic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- United States Information Agency executives began today to put to work $10,000,000 voted by Congress last night to make the Voice of America louder.

NEW YORK HARBOR was port of entry about 110 years ago for the Chinese junk Kai Ying, the first vessel of its kind ever seen in American waters. It anchored off the Battery, and over a stretch of months more than 50,000 persons were rowed out, at so much a head, to get a close view and to goggle at her Chinese crew, the first Orientals they had ever laid eyes upon.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 21 -Weatherly added a notch to her stature today by coming from behind to defeat Columbia in America's Cup observation trial competition in which the "observation" was down to a minimum.

THE end of summer vacation, traditionally doleful day for children, comes about two weeks earlier for countless New York parents than it does for their youngsters. Public schools in the city will reopen on Sept. 8, but summer camps are closing every day.

YONKERS, Aug. 21 -- Speedy Pick tonight paced the second fastest mile ever achieved over a half-mile track. The 5-year-old bay gelding closed with a burst of speed that carried him to a three-quarter-length victory over Widower Creed in 1:58 4-5 at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A measure to authorize the Fryingpan-Arkansas water project in Colorado will be permitted to die with this session of Congress, the Colorado delegation in the House of Representatives announced today.

The Solar Aircraft Company of San Diego, Calif., in the fiscal quarter ended July 31 had net earnings of $366,800, or 52 cents a share. In the similar period last year, profits were $640,000, equal to 91 cents a share.

BUCKY HARRIS always has claimed that a manager never resigns but that he is fired. It officially was announced the other day that Birdie Tebbetts had voluntarily tendered his resignation as manager of the Cincinnati Redlegs. When the news hit California, it was the biggest shock since the Los Angeles earthquake of 1933.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -Industrials continued their advance, but at a slower pace, on the stock exchange here today.
MONTREAL, Aug. 21 -- There is growing evidence of a relationship between blood type and susceptibility to some diseaes, a scientist reported here today.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 21 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. urged Virginians today to support him and the legislature in the state policy against any racial integration in public schools.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- The Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce honored Samuel Goldwyn today for forty-six years of "contributions to the general well-being of our community and the stability of its business climate."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- A four-year Federal education bill devoid of scholarships was approved today by Senate-House conferees. It would cost about $900,000,000 and be chiefly designed to spur science education.

The Veterans of Foreign Wars called yesterday for the United States to break diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
The Uniformed Firemen's Association won recognition yesterday from the city as exclusive bargaining representative for Fire Department members below officer rank.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 21 -- The Black Rock Yacht Club of Bridgeport, Conn., won the metropolitan midget championship today, defeating crews from four other districts in a fiverace program sponsored by the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bay Harbor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The butcher hog market continued its decline for the ninth day today with prices quotably steady to 25 cents a 100 pounds lower although the supply was 2,000 head less than expected.

Premier Charles de Gaulle has left Paris on what may be the most critical trip of his career: a visit to the most important positions in Africa in the effort to rally support for a new French Constitution. The purposes behind this instrument and its espousal by the Premier are several. As far as Africa is concerned the first, and most obvious, is to put an end to strife through a grant of greater autonomy.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Hamilton Richardson and Alejandro Olmedo, a newly formed combination, defeated one of Australia's strong teams today in the national doubles tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 21 Central High School will return to its previously white status when it opens Sept. 2, Superintendent Virgil T. Blossom said today.

As most stockholders in oil companies know, earnings have not fared well this year. Oil producers were affected by cuts in crude oil output in the first six months of the year. LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The British Government welcomed today the successful outcome of the East-West Geneva conference of scientific experts on methods of detecting tests of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Senate took another look today at the United States' position in the world.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Charles R. Swart, South African Minister of Justice, announced tonight he had been appointed acting Prime Minister during the illness of Premier Johannes Strijdom.

BALBOA, C. Z., Aug. 2 -- Commercial tolls collected by the Panama Canal Company in July were the highest for any month in the waterway's history, despite the fact that twenty-one fewer ocean-going commercial vessels transited than in July of last year.

The emergency session of the United Nations General Assembly has ended in a surprising climax by producing an all-Arab solution to the present crisis in the Middle East, which seems to be the best available at this time -- if it will work. This solution is embodied in a resolution submitted by ten Arab states, including embattled Lebanon and Jordan, and unanimously adopted by the Assembly as a promise of better things to come.

Alfred Hitchcock arrived here last night to prepare for the New York phase of his production of "North By Northwest," the suspense drama he will film for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Cary Grant and Eva Marie Saint, the film's stars, are scheduled to take part in the location shooting in Manhattan and Long Island. Several weeks' filming is expected to get under way late next week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -The long-haul credit for getting an education aid bill through the Senate goes to Lister Hill, Alabama Democrat.

The Air Line Pilots Association yesterday tacitly approved a Presidential fact-finding board's recommendation that flight engineers on Eastern Air Line jet planes be pilot-qualified. The company expects to begin operating jet planes in 1960.

BUFFALO, Aug. 21 -- Associate Judge Charles S. Desmond of the State Court of Appeals refused today to free five delegates to the Apalachin convention. They had been jailed for declining to answer questions before the State Investigation Commission.

LA GRANGE, Ill., Aug. 21 -- Even though the nation's railroads since the end of World War II have just about completed switching over from coal-burning steam units to diesel locomotives, the diesel locomotive business is on the upgrade.

At Grand Central Terminal, they call him "Mr. Courtesy." Among his friends are Red Caps and royalty, campers and commuters, President Eisenhower, Sophie Tucker and Cardinal Spellman. He is Edward George Fischer, the terminal's general station master.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- The Big Three auto companies suffered a wave of local walkouts today.
Lennen Newell, Inc., has absorbed the C. L. Company in its second merger in six weeks.

Socio-legal affairs are not my professional province. I am a physician. A recent experience of mine in a complaint court, however, reveals to my inexpert eye what seems to be a serious hiatus between our courts and our social agencies.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Approval of the acquisition of the Peoples Bank and Trust Company of Westfield by the National State Bank of Elizabeth was announced here today by the directors of both institutions.

Delaware plans to sell a $17,000,000 issue of serial bonds on Sept. 3 to finance various public improvements. The obligations would be dated Sept. 1, 1958, and would come due on Sept. 1 from 1959 to 1978.
" Your Hit Parade" has adopted a new format that will not restrict it to playing the same top tunes week after week.
Policemen who issue summonses for speeding brace themsleves for the inevitable excuse, complaint, denial. But all over the city yesterday policemen's heads were wagging in wonderment.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (AP) -United States shooters finally moved into the winning column of the international championships today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Robert (Barney) Baker's reputed "close" friendship with Governor Harriman amounted to three insignificant meetings, the big teamster organizer told the Senate rackets committee today.
LIME ROCK, Conn., Aug. 21 -- The biggest issue in this community is what to do about the automobile-racing track that cuts across Salmon Creek here and keeps people awake at night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- By a vote of 41 to 40, the Senate killed tonight legislation aimed at curbing the Supreme Court of the United States.
COLOMBO, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Ceylon's rubber producers are asking the Government to help the industry prevent the closure of plantations in the face of low returns.
IF Auntie Mame never existed, Great Aunt Emily surely did. During the last year, Patrick Dennis, born Edward Everett Tanner 3d, has devoted equal time to both of them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -The House of Representatives killed the $458,000,000 price support and incentive payments program to aid the minerals and metals producing industry today. The vote was 182 -- 159.

Small-boat Sinbads can't get enough of the protected, smooth-water cruising on the Erie Canal and the connecting and feeder channels of the New York State Barge Canal system. The reason is simple. You don't need an ocean-going liner to make that vacation voyage.

DOMODOSSOLA, Italy, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- Emergency crews tonight relieved the little resort of Bognanco Terme, faced with a food shortage, as pelting rain and landslides devastated resorts and roads in northern Italy.

The Board of Estimate appropriated $100,000 yesterday to increase the staff of its Bureau of Real Estate as a major step in a sweeping reorganization of the agency. The board also voted to increase the annual salary of the bureau's director to $20,000.
Another theatre has been added to the constantly expanding off-Broadway cluster.

Member bank reserves were tightened somewhat in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average net free reserves declined $59,000,000 to $403,000,000 from a revised figure of $462,000,000 the week before.

TOKYO, Aug. 21 -- The only country that has ever been attacked with atomic bombs warmly welcomed reports from Washington today that the United States might soon announce a temporary suspension of nuclear weapons testing.
TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Aug. 21 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle arrived here tonight to campaign for his new French Constitution in the southernmost of France's colonial possessions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- The Dominican Republic was the only United Nations member not represented this evening when the General Assembly unanimously adopted an Arab plan for calming Middle Eastern unrest.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Except for some weakness in soybeans and September corn, grain futures on the Board of Trade barely budged today from their previous closes.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 21 -- President Tito has accused the Soviet bloc of attacking Yugoslavia because she refused to hold to outmoded doctrines that would hinder her development.

The United Artists Corporation acquired the stock of Lopert Films, Inc. yesterday, it was announced by Arthur B. Krim, president of United Artists. Lopert Films, headed by Ilya Lopert, is a major distributor of foreign-made pictures in the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Senator William E. Jenner delivered his Senate valedictory today. He charged that "wild-eyed Socialists, ambitious intellectuals, power-seeking demagogues and hidden Communists" were pushing the United States to the verge of an inflationary catastrophe.
Seven motorists have had their New York State licenses revoked for driving with "reckless disregard for the life or property of others." Fifty-two other drivers face similar penalties.

The stone building with 5,000 square feet of commercial space at 203 South Washington Avenue, Bergenfield, N. J., has been sold by Lester L. Skinner to Prestige Records, Inc., formerly of New York. The buyer maintains its own studio for recording vocal and instrumental music and will use the Bergenfield building as a distribution center.
EUROPEAN fishermen catch about as many mackerel as their salty counterparts in Maine and Massachusetts. But continental cooks prepare the fish in more interesting ways than most Yankee housewives.
One of the world's great aerodynamacists said yesterday that the United States was probably ahead of the Soviet Union in the instrumentation of space vehicles.

As Republican candidate for Assembly on the West Side of Manhattan, I noted with interest the belated proposal of Bentley Kassal made in his letter published July 31, in which he implies that if re-elected he would introduce a measure in the State Legislature to establish a New York City Parking Authority to survey and evaluate present and future parking problems.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 21 -The Greek Cypriote Right-Wing terrorist organization known as E. O. K. A. called on all Greek Cypriotes today to refuse any cooperation with the British Administration in its efforts to impose its plan for ending strife in Cyprus.
IT is still hot outside but, at Tailored Woman, the first flush of autumn is sweeping the store.

It sounded like something out of a Lilliput fantasy, but the Police Department manfully spread this alarm yesterday for a stolen car: "Red, four and one-half feet long, five-mile-an-hour speed, called a Thunderbird Junior." The complainant was Bruce Winick, 7 years old.

New orders for machine tools have turned downward. Figures released yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders Association, Cleveland, indicate a new break in a succession of rises over the preceding month that has been broken only once before since December.
TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- Attorney General David D. Furman has ordered an investigation to find the extent to which outlawed games of chance and skill may still be operating at New Jersey shore resorts.
DETROT, Aug. 21 -- The apartment of a Pontiac teamster union official was damaged by fire last night in what Fire Department authorities described as a case of arson.
The Liberal party sought last night to tip the scales in favor of Thomas K. Finletter in the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will meet with Gen. Charles de Gaulle Sept. 14 at the French Premier's home in Colombey - les - Deux - Eglises in eastern France, it was announced here tonight.

A new mail service program providing next-day delivery of first-class mail in the metropolitan area on business days was put into effect yesterday. Some of this mail formerly took two or three days to be delivered.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged Macy's New York, with deceptively pricing auto seatcovers.
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday rejected a discrimination charge filed against the American Banner Lines by the National Maritime Union.

THE average citizen of ancient Athens is known to have been deeply suspicious of that subversive character Socrates. Whether he was as baffled and bewildered by the eccentricities of artistic and literary genius and as astounded by the bizarre tribal customs of the little world of the theatre as most conventional people are today is not on record.

ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 21 -- A sudden cloudburst, accompanied by thunder and lightning, caused cancellation tonight of the American premiere of the Ildebrando Pizzetti opera "Murder in the Cathedral."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Every state shared in the nation-wide 5 per cent increase in personal income last year, the Commerce Department reported today. Personal income averaged $2,028, a record.

" Things to Remember," a musical based on the early life of Hans Christian Andersen, is announced for Broadway presentation in January. The attraction will have its local unveiling at a Shubert theatre, possibly at the Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The end of nuclear weapons testing will not mean the end of fall-out. Radioactive debris will continue to shower the earth for years to come.

Their friends may prefer going to the beaches and ball fields, but sixteen high school students from the metropolitan area have found a better way to spend their vacation days this summer. These students, all boys, are taking part in an unusual and informal program established by the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.
BERLIN, Aug. 22 -- Dr. Josef Haemel, rector of Friedrich Schiller University in Jena, East Germany, has fled to West Berlin.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Britain announced today that she was prepared to suspend her tests of nuclear weapons Oct. 31 on conditions similar to those set forth by President Eisenhower. The Government said that it planned to carry out the short series of tests it had already announced, but that they would be completed as soon as possible.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 22 -- Paul M. Butler declared today that leaders of the Teamsters Union had a record of support and participation in the Republican party.

OSLO, Aug. 22 -- The Skate will arrive in Bergen tomorrow afternoon. It will be welcomed by the United States Ambassador to Norway, Miss Frances Willis, the Minister of Defense, Nils Handal; Vice Admiral J. E. Jacobsen, commander in chief of the Norwegian Navy, and other high ranking Norwegian and American officials.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Monterrey's Little Giants won their second straight Little League world championship today with a 10-1 victory over the Kankakee, Ill., Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators baseball club is expected to ask the American League, either shortly before or during the world series, for permission to move to Minneapolis.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 22 -- A general build-up of airborne radiation from nuclear tests of nations has resulted in the Tennessee Health Department's switching largely from a general policy of mass chest X-raying to the skin tuberculin test.
SAG HARBOR, L. I., Aug. 22 -- The oldest active Baptist minister in New York State will celebrate his ninety-seventh birthday here tomorrow.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 22 -- The Foreign Office and the United States Embassy here issued a joint communique today stating that "relations between the two Governments, and particularly between Haiti's Foreign Office and the American Embassy at Port-au-Prince, have never been closer than at the present."

The 106th Fighter-Interceptor Wing, New York National Guard, passed in final review as a jet defense team yesterday afternoon. Before a group of the state's highest military officers, the men marched at the Naval Air Station at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A conviction that the Soviet Union was at last willing to have international inspection posts on its territory was a basic factor in the reversal of United States policy on the suspension of nuclear tests, an authoritative source said today.
PARIS, Aug. 22 -- The French Government is determined to go through with its plans for early nuclear weapons tests, officials indicated tonight.
The largest domestic producer of lead announced yesterday that it would slash output 20 per cent next week as a result of the defeat of the minerals subsidy program in Congress.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N, J., Aug. 22 -- Dr. Mason W. Gross, 47-year-old provost and vice president of Rutgers University, today was named acting president of the university.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Ralph Terry of Kansas City missed pitching a perfect game tonight when his mound rival, Russ Kemmerer, singled in the third inning for the Washington Senators' only hit in a 1-0 victory by the Athletics.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Public school teachers from fifteen states agreed here today that high school students would gain greater knowledge by studying science and economics simultaneously, instead of in separate classes.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- A couple of old Elis, Seth Corwin of the American Yacht Club and Shawhan Fox of Indian Harbor, will be the chief contenders tomorrow when the five-day international 110 Class Yacht Racing Association championship is concluded.

MONTREAL, Aug. 2 -- Blood typing, vitally important in medicine, is becoming an increasingly valuable tool in animal husbandry, a geneticist said here today.

Taylor-Davis, Inc., dealer in steel products for reinforcing concrete, has sold the one-story brick factory building at 1329 Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, to the Ben Gross Company. The Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company insured title.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Winchester-Western division of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, New Haven, Conn., is looking into the feasibility of making rifles and shotguns with glass barrels. A patent for the innovation was issued this week.
PARIS, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- French nationals will be able to return to Egypt and regain a large part of their seized property, a French Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.

The new commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars called yesterday on the United States to refuse to pull its troops out of the Middle East until the Russians removed theirs from the satellite countries.
ALBANY, Aug. 22 -- The State Health Commissioner said today that there was "now no reasonable doubt" that smoking significantly increased one's chance of developing lung cancer.

Senator Lister Hill could not have expected that his momentous "global health" bill would be acted upon in the rush of the closing days of this Senate session. But it can, and will, be reintroduced in the next session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Consumer Price Index reached another high today with a rise from mid-June to mid-July of 0.2 per cent. The index level of 123.9 is 23.9 per cent above the 1947-49 average. The big rise came from transportation and medical services.
CAIRO, Aug. 22 -- Adoption of the Arab resolution on the Middle East crisis by the United Nations General Assembly last night was called a major victory by Cairo's newspapers today.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- A two-year contract that freezes wages at present levels has been signed by the United Auto Workers Union and American Motors Corporation for 1,200 workers at the Kelvinator appliance plant in Grand Rapids, Mich.
The first National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice will open next Friday at Loyola University in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, invited Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, today to debate the failure of labor reform legislation. The Senator declined the invitation.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Enrique Morea of Argentina scored an 8 -- 6 triumph over Dick Savitt today as the second annual Nations' Cup round-robin tennis tournament started at the Westchester Country Club.

LUDLOW, N. B., Aug. 22 -- There are a number of things an angler can do when salmon are not hitting, but generally they fall into two categories. He can cling to the standard recognized flies and fish them in the accepted way, or he can play tricks.
JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug. 22 -- The first group of Soviet tourists to visit this country got a taste of an old-fashioned, American traffic mix-up today.
NYBORG, Denmark, Aug. 22 -- An attempt to oust the only Iron Curtain churchman from the twelve-member Executive Committee of the World Council of Churches was begun today.

The Police Department estimated yesterday that 94 per cent of the city's pedestrians and motorists were obeying the new safety rules. The estimate was based on a city-wide survey of thirty intersections and six mid-block points.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 22 -- Federal Judge Walter E. Hofman is expected to instruct the Norfolk School Board Monday morning in its legal duty toward Negro applicants for white city schools.
The City Planning Commission was told yesterday that over-age firehouses and the lack of centralized training facilities were impairing the efficiency of the Fire Department.

Employes of the financial district will give blood Monday at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, to aid the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. There also will be a blood donation at the Bulova Watch Company, 75-20 Astoria Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 22 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that income per person on farms this year might surpass the record of $983 set at the peak of the Korean War in 1951.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 22 -- A group of residents here and in neighboring communities is seeking to buy a lake site in near-by Wilton as a family recreational center.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 22 -- A French vice consul was shot and critically wounded early today as he returned from a trip to the Beirut airport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Senate passed a bill tonight to raise the national debt limit to $288,000,000,000. It acted after Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, had forced a postponement in consideration of the foreign aid appropriations bill.

More than $1,000,000,000 in private capital was sought for 1,190 foreign investment projects during the year ended June 30, according to an analysis of the Department of Commerce. Credit in the retail apparel and merchandise field is an active, quick-changing business, as any member of Dun Bradstreet's Credit Clearing House division will say.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 22 -- The Jordanian Government ordered its radio station today to stop attacks on other Arab states at once.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 22 -- The Henry D. Mercer syndicate's 12-Meter yacht Weatherly was the star of the production today when she presented her wake to John N. Matthews' Vim in the America's Cup observation trials.
BERLIN, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An exceptionally tall young American slung a cowboy guitar over his shoulder today and set out to hitchhike through Communist East Germany.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, in an article published here today, declared that communism "ignores certain essential needs of human nature" and eventually will be overthrown.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Marine captain from Turtle Creek, Pa., won the world hand gun championship in the international shooting competition today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Sir Leslie Munro of New Zealand, President of the General Assembly, hailed today President Eisenhower's announcement that the United States was ready to suspend nuclear weapons tests.

TRENTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The chairman of the freedom of information committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors protested today a proposal to ban photographs in the chambers between sessions of the New Jersey Public Utility Commission.

Two six-story apartment houses at 234-36 Mulberry Street were among downtown Manhattan properties passing to new control in deals reported yesterday.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday it would provide better service and heating on Rockaway Division trains this fall.
EIGHT Congressmen gathered on Channel 2 yesterday evening and agreed that, by and large, they have accomplished something in the session now drawing to a close.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- The Soviet Government reported President Eisenhower's proposal for an agreement to ban nuclear weapons tests with unusual speed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Congress today asked that the United Nations consider establishing a permanent peace force.

TRENTON, Aug. 21 -- The remains of an iron ore furnace and a foundry cistern building, both constructed of red brick and forgotten for more than a century have been uncovered by excavators at the historic deserted village of Allaire.
Connecticut is planning the sale of $20,000,000 of bonds Sept. 9 to finance various improvements. The securities will come due in from one to thirty years.

NEWARK, Aug. 22 -- The state today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for hearings on the plans of the New York Central and Erie Railroads to discontinue ferry service between New Jersey and New York.
ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The chairman of the State Civil Service Commission explained today that the agency sets age limits for some jobs but only those that require "extraordinary physical efforts."
ROME, Aug. 22 -- The Italian Government began Operation Broom today to sweep out tax dodgers. Its first target is "Hollywood-on-the-Tiber," Italy's film industry.
THE traditional little cardigan has come a long way. The familiar button-down-the-front sweater, as well as pullovers, now reflect some of fall's major fashion trends.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Paralytic polio cases increased again last week, the Public Health Service reported today.

HAVANA, Aug. 22 -- The Cuban Government will open a new offensive against the insurgents of Fidel Castro in Oriente Province and against other rebellious groups in the Provinces of Camaguey and Las Villas, according to information received here.
PARK CITY, Utah, Aug. 22 -- "Mining is dead, and we're better off out of it," Gus Christopulous said this morning.
A sharply lower London market caused copper prices to decline yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Final prices were 39 to 41 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 252 lots.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A remarkably fast qualifying heat in the 1,500-meter run of the sixth European track and field championship stole the glory today from the methodical Russians.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark Aug. 22 -- The Government's decision to cancel the visit by the Skate followed a meeting of the Danish Atomic Energy Commission last Tuesday. It was unanimously agreed at that time to report to the Government that the commission had found the submarine's visit inadvisable.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Christopher T. Chenery's Rich Tradition overcame an early disadvantage in the $43,340 Spinaway today and won the stakes for 2-year-old fillies by a length and a half from Rockburn Farm's Recite.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Four times within a stroke of defeat Wednesday against Enrique Morea and Eduardo Soriano of Argentina, Malcolm Anderson and Robert Howe saved three match points today to reach the semi-finals of the national doubles tennis championship.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Emerson Clark, 66-year-old foundry superintendent from Preston, Ont., today became the first Canadian to win trapshooting's great honor, the Grand American Handicap.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, renewed today a proposal for a meeting of heads of government to review the international situation.

Directors of Gold Seal Products Corporation have voted a stock dividend of 2 per cent on both Class A and B stock, payable Sept. 22. The company said the payment is in lieu of the 10 cents cash paid in previous quarters.
Traffic deaths on the streets of New York were seven last week, an increase despite the jaywalk law with which apparently pedestrians and motorists are cooperating in the hope of reducing accidents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, served notice today that he would propose the use of the Federal Mutual security funds to offset any damages mineral tariffs might inflict on friendly nations.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower informed Premier Nobusuke Kishi of the United States proposal for halting nuclear tests in a letter made public today. It was dated Aug. 21 and delivered by Ambassador Douglas MacArthur 2d last night. The letter said:

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The stock market moved firmly ahead today in the busiest Friday in more than three years. Widespread gains of from a few pence to 2 shillings (28 cents) or so among industrials raised the Financial Times index of industrial ordinary share index 1.1 points to 190.2.
The First Region of the Army Air Defense Command celebrated its eighth anniversary yesterday with a military review at its headquarters in Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Robert K. Moore of Claysville, Pa., was the surprise winner of the national small bore rifle championship today with 6,385 points of a possible 6,400.
PERIGUEUX, France, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A young New York schoolteacher, aided by a freakish landslide, discovered today a fabulous prehistoric relief carving. It is said by experts to be 20,000 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 118.8 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Senate, by a vote of 66 to 15, adopted today the conference report on the $900,000,000 four-year bill to aid science education.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Iceland's Ambassador, Dr. Kristinn Gudmundsson, said here today that his Government might withdraw from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if the dispute with Britain over offshore fishing waters worsened seriously.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Bill Ficker and his yacht Nhycusa of Newport Harbor, Calif., increased their lead today in the international Star Class races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Secret Service said today producers of a television show that offers as much as $5,000 for dollar bills with certain serial numbers have uncovered five cases in which numbers were illegally altered.

The Executive Council of the A. F. L.-C. L O. has just achieved a notable advance in its drive on labor union corruption, with no sign of the serious defections that some of its leaders had feared. "Unity House," its meeting place at Forest Park, Pa., well described the occasion.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 22 -- Seven teen-age youths from neighboring Bayonne learned yesterday that Jersey City's top public safety official has a stern manner but a soft heart.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Pentagon officials made it clear today that the United States would continue to produce nuclear weapons and equip military forces with them, regardless of the test suspension announced by President Eisenhower.

A woman was run over by a subway train in Times Square yesterday and lived. The woman, identified as Barbara Birnbaum of 189 Park Place, Brooklyn, was taken to St. Clare's Hospital in critical condition at 4 P. M.

The President's decision to halt nuclear bomb tests was hailed yesterday by the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy. Clarence Pickett, Quaker leader, and Norman Cousins, magazine editor, who are co-chairmen of the committee, congratulated President Eisenhower in a telegram from New York.
FALLS CHURCH, Va., Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Forty-eight Protestant and Roman Catholic clergymen from Falls Church Fairfax County today condemned "enforced segregation" as contrary to the will of God.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 22 -- Anne Quast, a Stanford University senior, eliminated the defending titleholder to gain the final of the United States women's amateur golf championship today. WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner recommended today that Bantam Books, Inc., of New York, be required to make prominent disclosure when books it sells are abridged or reprinted under new titles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- President Eisenhower proposed conditionally today to halt nuclear weapons tests by the United States for a year, beginning Oct. 31. A similar proposal was made by Britain.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 22 -- Chief Judge Albert Conway of the New York Court of Appeals charged today that the judicial establishments in many parts of the country had become "obsolete and archaic."
LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- Violent storms lashed much of Western Europe today from Britain to Italy.

The Staten Island ferryboat Joseph F. Merrell was disabled by engine trouble yesterday afternoon as it moved past Liberty Island on its way to Manhattan. Seven hundred passengers remained aboard an hour and a half until the vessel was towed back to Staten Island.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 -- Life has returned to normal for the management of a Horn and Hardart cafeteria opposite the University of Pennsylvania.

The cigarette vending machine arrived in this city just thirty years ago last week. Its sponsor, the Rowe Manufacturing Company, which pioneered its development and introduction, had no celebration in its headquarters office here, but it disclosed some figures with dancing in the streets written between the lines.
With the new television season only a few weeks off, the networks are continuing to juggle their evening schedules for what they hope will be greatest impact.

DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Passenger car production in the United States this week fell to its lowest level in ten months, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Many plants are shut down for the change-over to production of 1959 models.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 38 points yesterday, with July the weakest. The drop equaled 20 cents to $1.90 a bale.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed a four-point program for peace tonight. He summarized it as: "Food for peace, health for peace, loans for peace and disarmament for peace."

PARIS, Aug. 22 -- North Atlantic Treaty Organization discussions were reported today to be moving toward a compromise in the dispute over Iceland's intention to extend its territorial waters from four to twelve miles.

Ground has been broken for a one-story industrial building at 4515-25 Park Avenue, south of East 183d Street, the Bronx, as the result of a package deal negotiated by the Frank S. Douglass Company. broker.

ONE enduring marvel about Spain is that in so small a country there can persist such tremendous contrasts. The prosperous capital in the center of the shield-shaped land that American officials see and American correspondents report is one kind of Spain.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 23 -Premier Samir el-Rifai of Jordan affirmed today a policy of looking for friendly deeds to back up soothing words from his Arab neighbors.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Wassum, sailed by John Snedeker and Bill King, today captured the opening Star Class race in the anual week-end invitation regatta of the Domino Yacht Club. Wassum beat out Walter Frachtel's Avocet.
REGARDLESS of whether it is to be finished with opaque paint or clear varnish, open - grained woods such as oak or mahogany require a filler if a perfectly smooth finish is to be achieved.

Eleven passenger ships of the Cunard Steamship Company, Ltd., will provide 217 transAtlantic sailings during the summer season of 1959, G. L. Bowen, general passenger agent for the line, has announced.
" Things look a lot brighter than they have in many months. I expect to land something right after Labor Day."
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 23 -- The Tennessey Valley Authority is taking steps in cooperation with state agencies to lessen flood damages in low-lying areas in the seven-state valley area.

AT a little past 9 in the evening of Oct. 26, 1917 (old style), a short, stocky, balding man with greyish stubble on his chin stepped forward on an improvised platform in a crowded, smoky room in what had been a Petrograd finishing school for girls and waited for thunderous waves of applause to die down.

Molten steel is being vacuumcleaned these days in a spectacular process developed just in time to meet a growing problem in the heavy equipment industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -In the confusion of this week's events concerning the Little Rock case, a significant fact may have been overlooked: the growing involvment of the executive branch of the Federal Government in the school segregation issue.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 23 -The eighth all-breed show of the Newtown K. C., held today on a new site, the grounds of Wooster School, was the best in the club's history. A strong final was judged by Theodore C. Hollander of South Hamilton, Mass.

COLUMBIA, S. C. -- South Carolina, relatively small in area and triangular in shape, is known as the Palmetto State and until recently, unless one traveled via U. S. 17, the coastal route, one could criss-cross the state over almost any other road and never even see a palmetto.

A study of the basic curriculum of the public schools will be started this fall by the Council for Basic Education, Washington, D. C. As the first step, the council is inviting certain scholars in each of the basic subjects -- ranging from American history to physics -- to prepare for publication a paper of about 4,000 words describing for his particular field the "proper educational aims of the public schools."

Employment in Illinois nonagricultural establishments in July totaled 3,273,100, a decline of 21,500 from the June level and off 214,600 from that for July, 1957, the State Employment Service has reported. Manufacturing industries reported 1,085,900 were employed in July, 8,400 below the June figure and 159,600 lower than the yearearlier total. In durable goods, the total was 699,700, down 4,000 from the June figure and 128,000 lower than in July, 1957.

IN addition to the other pleasures it affords, the reading of history can be very comforting. The knowledge that other men and other times suffered from the same follies and the same passions as we do, somehow reduces the anguish of our own.

THE prospectus of the United States performing arts program at the American Pavilion Theatre at the Brussels World's Fair proudly lists three orchestras. The Philadelphia Orchestra and the Juilliard Orchestra have successfully concluded their concerts there.
Assemblyman Malcolm Wilson of Yonkers appeared last night to be Nelson A. Rockefeller's probable running mate for Lieutenant Governor on the Republican state ticket.
DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 23 -A campaign to revitalize the economy of this small Fairfield County city is paying off handsomely.

THE Rona of Shirley Barker's new story is one of the smaller Hebrides, a stony, mistwreathed islet whose Gaelicspeaking folk have deep and ancient faith in the unseen. To Randall Woodbury, "new man from a new world," this is superstitious nonsense.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 23 -Anne Quast, a slim, studiouslooking collegian, staged a spectacular rally to win the United States women's golf championship today.

Experiments by E. G. F. Sauer, an ornithologist of the University of Freiburg, Germany, reveal that migratory birds use the stars to guide them on their amazing long-distance, ocean-crossing flights. Using the artificial sky in a planetarium, the experiments showed that the tiny warbler orients itself in its location on earth by the position of the stars, Dr. Sauer reports in the August issue of the Scientific American.
MADISON, N. H., Aug. 23--The unaffiliated Christian college has a vital role in the current American educational system, a group of educators agreed today at the closing of a week-long conference.

PLYWOOD is probably one of the most widely used of all home improvement construction materials. Popular for many years with professional carpenters as well as with do-it-yourselfers, experience has shown that there are many "tricks of the trade" which the home mechanic can use to simplify the job of sawing, drilling and joining these multi-ply wood panels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The last Saturday night of any Congress is a little like the last day of college. It is intensely personal and sentimental. It is full of innocent tippling in the cloakrooms. It may be wistful with farewells to departing comrades, but on the whole it is merry with humorous self-mockery and genuine good-fellowship.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 23 -- The appraisal of land for the first part of the 13.5-mile freeway through Des Moines and West Des Moines has begun.
THE doggedness with which Nikita Khrushchev keeps proposing a summit conference inevitably raises the question of whether he is under some compulsion to arrive at an agreement with the West.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- In tennis matches marked by friendly rivalry and no tension, Dick Savitt was in fine form today. He defeated two British players in singles matches and helped beat South America in a doubles event in the second day of the second annual Nation's Cup round-robin tournament at the Westchester Country Club.

The U. S. Navy has gone to considerable lengths to make its nuclear submarines safe against the radiation hazard. It has built into their reactors safety devices against explosions. It has shielded them thoroughly to protect crew members from radioactivity. It has trained its crews rigorously in the operation of the nuclear power plants.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Ten years ago essentially all the cucumbers grown commercially on Long Island went into brine vats.
THE United States Government, gloomily but inexorably, is drifting along with the most gigantic and costly -- and bipartisan -- failure in its history.
HONOLULU, Aug. 23 -- Juvenile delinquency is a growing problem on the Island of Oahu.
WASHINGTON, Sunday, Aug. 24 -- The Eighty-fifth Congress closed today with two history-making sessions to its credit.

TRAVEL on today's modern, limited-class access highways is supposed to be a non-stop affair, but the constant streamlining of roads, with the elimination of crossings at grade, has created a newer and more intricate problem -- what to do about a breakdown.

Five Latin-American journalism students awarded scholarships by the Inter American Press Association will begin their studies in this country next month. Two United States winners will study in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -India's chief creditors are scheduled to meet here Monday to explore means of providing her with financial assistance. She is seeking $1,000,000,000 in additional credits over the next two and a half years.

TRURO, Mass. -- A memorable charcoal - broiled swordfish dinner eaten on bay beach while a fiery sun sank behind Provincetown was the satisfying end of our recent vacation on the flexed arm of Cape Cod which lies between the Atlantic Ocean and the bay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23--The bill to aid science education cleared Congress today, with President Eisenhower expected to sign it into law.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 23 -- Russell I. Harris, at the tiller of Hurry Cain, sailed loft with top honors today in the Manhasset Bay One-Design Class as the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club resumed its interclub championship series.

The Eighty-fifth Congress returned to Washington last January for its final session in a mood of urgency brought on by the Soviet sputniks. The Senate majority leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, declared that "we must work as though no other Congress would have an opportunity to meet this challenge." President Eisenhower presented eight "impera tives" which focussed on improving the country's defenses and educational system.
THE local county agents face a barrage of lawn questions from home owners every year. Four of them were queried recently to find out just what the average gardener wants to know.

SEVERAL weeks of playing stereophonic records have cemented this listener's belief that stereo on disk is no passing fad. It is here to stay not because the industry has decided that it needs a shot in the arm, but because it is just plain good.

PICTURES of the Floating World of Everyday Life -- as the best Japanese prints of the eighteenth century were called -- provide the Brooklyn Museum with a small exhibition designed to show the development of the Japanese woodcut from simple black-and-white book illustration to resplendent color prints created for their own sake.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 23--The state's newest metropolis is rising here at the State Fair Grounds. It will be a going concern by Friday when Senior City is officially opened for tourist business.
A TASTE of fall weather -- clear blue skies and crisp air -- has given gardeners fresh incentive. Fairs, flower shows and botanic displays are planned in many communities this week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -Some of the most powerful, controversial and colorful figures of the last decade were serving their final hours as members of the House and Senate today.

FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 23 -The late Albert Anastasia's Spanish stucco mansion here will be sold at public auction at 2 o'clock Monday at the office of the Sheriff of Bergen County in Hackensack. The mansion, which overlooks the Hudson River from atop the Palisades, was built for a reported total of $100,000.

With only one more week before Labor Day technically the end of the vacation season, time flits for one with a pocketful of summer questions. Maybe the answers aren't there, but the questions should be rallied, anyway. Why, for instance, is a sandpiper called a sandpiper? It doesn't pipe; it peeps. Was it originally called a sandpeeper?

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Aug. 23 -- A generous farmer has donated $5,000 to New York City to cover its expenses in draining the "flood bowl" on Union Turnpike at the line between Queens and Nassau Counties.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 20 -- Although Brazil still continues to oppose the direct participation of foreign companies in her oil industry, millions of dollars in overseas capital is quietly assisting in the expansion of Petrobras, the national petroleum monopoly.

JOHN O'HARA'S "From the Terrace" will be out Thanksgiving Day, a big book, some 1,000 pages. It is the story of the career of a man who looks back from his fifty-ninth year--boyhood, rise to the top of Wall Street, World War II. Mr. O'Hara's town of fiction, Gibbsville, is not in it, although the location of the book's first part is not far from there.

HIGHLIGHTS of the amateur movie program for the twenty-fifth anniversary convention of the Photographic Society of America -- to be held Sept. 30 to Oct. 4 at the Hotel Bellevue-Stratford in Philadelphia -- were announced last week.
TELEVISION cameras of the National Broadcasting Company were on the scene at Cape Canaveral, Fla., last Sunday morning when the Air Force made its unsuccessful attempt to launch a rocket to the moon.

Free China has announced the appointment of a new Ambassador to the United States. He is George Yeh, no stranger to this country, who received his first degree at Amherst and has been back on many occasions on diplomatic missions. At home he has served as Foreign Minister for almost a decade. He will return, now, when a new threat is facing Taiwan.

MONTREAL. Aug. 23 -- The action of a piece of genetics material possibly as small as a tenth of a molecule can cause a change in heredity, a scientist reported here today.

ONE of those days of frenzied convulsion when the peak tourist-return season flings shipload after shipload of passengers onto New York's docks and waterfront occurred last Tuesday. Five trans-Atlantic liners came in almost simultaneously, dumping almost 7,000 travelers into West Street between Forty-fourth and Fiftieth Streets between 9 A. M. and about 3 P. M.
