SOUTH LEE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Bill Spear of Southport, Conn., and Sherwood Johnston of Greenwich, Conn., appeared, on unofficial figures tonight, to be the winners of the Berkshire Mountain sports car rally.

THE theatre could ill afford the loss of Wolcott Gibbs, these last eighteen years the drama critic of The New Yorker. He was one of the few, the ever dwindling few, who wrote about it with wit and detachment, with style and irreverence.
CARMEL, N. J., Aug. 23 -- Hundreds of men and women, many of them New Yorkers, will return to their original home here next Sunday to celebrate two anniversaries.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 23 -- First Landing, the odds-on favorite in all his seven starts, clinched his claim to the Eastern championship among 2-yearold colts today by winning the $57,500 Hopeful Stakes by five and a half lengths.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 23 -- A 52-year-old former owner of an ice cream parlor fatally stabbed his wife here today and then shot himself to death with a hunting rifle. The police said the couple had argued over whether their 13-year-old daughter should be permitted to use a bicycle.

IT hardly seems possible that this is only Volume II in the Auntie Mame Series. Those early enthusiasts who have followed the fortunes of the first "Auntie Mame" from a position of virtual performance on the best-seller lists, to the Broadway stage (the present dedication is inscribed: "To the one and only Rosalind Rusell") and finally to production as a Hollywood musical, may already be feeling a trifle winded, if not outright pooped.

At 6:40 P. M. last Thursday, Sir Leslie Munro, President of the General Assembly, announced that the Assembly would now vote on Document A/3893. Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Sir Leslie, rose from his chair on the President's left to count the raised hands. He counted eighty -an aye vote for every nation present (the Dominican Republic, for reasons not known, was absent).

ANYONE who has lived where the tall maize grows knows that corn must be hustled from stalk to kettle if its natural flavor is to be properly savored. Cartoons in corn-growing regions occasionally depict a harried housewife rushing a steaming cauldron into the fields to cook the ears with no delay.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Maxine Mitchell, a Los Angeles grandmother in her 40's, turned in an unbeaten record in eleven bouts today as she led three American women into the semi-finals of the individual foil competition at the world fencing championships.

The persistence of uncommon values in the securities markets weeks after the Treasury's last disruptive financing makes for a good argument that there is too much public debt around and not enough big-name common stock.

The Civil Aeronautics Board established a fixed, five-year, $10,380,600 subsidy for New York's helicopter service last week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- A dedicated group working for better living in rural Mexico is learning that the road to achievement sometimes takes startling twists.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 19 -- A new Jewish religious movement, which seems certain to touch off another bitter controversy between synagogue and state, has been started quietly in Israel.

CONSIDERING the amount of singing of popular songs that goes on, there are remarkably few outstanding talents in this field. CHICAGO, Aug. 23--Round Table galloped home two and a quarter lengths in front today in the $85,200 Arlington Handicap to remain unbeaten on grass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- The Post Office Department warned householders today that an increasing number of addicts were looting mail boxes to get money to buy narcotics.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 23 -- Television came to Belgrade today. The Belgrade fair was also opened, but the fair took second place.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Aug. 23 -- Morris County has embarked on long - range-planning. Situated on the western fringe of the New York commuting area it is close enough to New York to be influenced by industrial growth but far away enough to retain much of its rural atmosphere.
Jim Thomson, the superintendent of the Yankee Stadium, keeps both the playing field and the stands shipshape, operating with quiet efficiency and a miimum of annoyance.

OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Australia's Jon Konrads made up for his one loss to Tsuyoshi Yamanaka by outswimming the Japanese Olympian twice tonight on the final program of the Australian-Japanese goodwill meet.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 23--The winning of the Democratic nomination for Governor by less than a third of the total vote in the Aug. 7 primary has brought two reactions.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 22 -- The Communist-ruled southwestern state of Kerala is now a national problem of considerable political importance.
The Hudson River Day Line sidewheeler Alexander Hamilton will carry more than 1,500 passengers when she departs here next Saturday on the annual Labor Day week-end Steamboat Festival Cruise.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, a Democrat, replied for the first time tonight to recent Republican attacks on his administration's fiscal policies.
WARSAW, Aug. 22 -- Poland's Communists complained rather plaintively today that the trouble with the workers' movement in these parts was that there were not enough workers in it.
TRENTON, Aug. 23 -- New Jersey Republican and Democratic leaders worked this week to set up their campaigns, which will open in earnest after Labor Day.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 23 -The all-Arab plan for the Middle East approved by the United Nations General Assembly's emergency session seemed today to be bearing quick fruit in promoting peace here.

THE piecemeal construction of the Palisades Interstate Parkway, which has been abuilding since 1947, will come to an end this week when Governor Harriman cuts a ceremonial ribbon marking completion of the forty-two-mile road from the George Washington Bridge to Bear Mountain.
THE European championships are being played in Oslo, Norway. This is a very remarkable tournament. Eighteen European countries (in some years it has been nineteen and even twenty) send six-man teams.

Builders, realtors and lenders expect improved housing markets this fall in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve district. In the last two months demand for new and existing houses has increased and further gains are predicted.

A touch of summer lethargy seemed to affect the stock market last week. Low-price issues predominated in rather light trading. Uncertainty about firmer money rates, and mixed business developments may well have had a dampening effect.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Three members of Congress seeking re-election rolled up heavy leads tonight in returns from Louisiana's Democratic primary.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (UPI)--Herb Score was placed on the active list today and to make room for him the Indians sold Hoyt Wilhelm to the Baltimore Orioles.

AS far as the visual arts are concerned, New York as a summer festival is something less than world-shaking. Few oases, such as the Metropolitan Museum's important loan show of privately owned paintings, solace wayfarers in the desert.

A report published in the current issue of the Canadian Medical Association Journal describes encouraging results with a serum developed against specific types of human cancer. The serum, the report states, has prolonged the lives of a significant number of hopeless cancer victims, in some cases by as much as three years, during which the patients were free from pain without the use of narcotics.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Aug. 23 (Reuters)--More than 3000 Dutch families from Indonesia will be able to emigrate to the United States in the next two years, emigration officials said today.

THE city's first International Festival ended last week after entertaining about 100,000 people, spurring the tourist business and giving a decided filip to celebrations of British Columbia's centennial year.

IT takes considerable imagination to visualize Joey Jay of the Milwaukee Braves as a Little League ballplayer. Not only was he one, however, but he also was the first to be graduated from the Little League to the big leagues. What strains the imagination so much is that Pal Joey now is 6 feet 4 and weighs 225 pounds.

THE mind of even a familiar animal is as remote and inaccesible as the moon or Mars and to reach it involves many difficulties. Vinson Brown, author of a number of unusual and penetrating books on wild creatures, here provides a fine introduction to this particular kind of space travel.

The official second-quarter figures on total national production of goods and services -- technically referred to as the gross national product -- have just been released, and they make a somewhat better showing than preliminary estimates had indicated.

The latest report of the National Association of Purchasing Agents indicated that the business recovery is proceeding slowly, with no real upsurge expected in the immediate future. The possibility of a strike in the auto industry was said to have tempered some enthusiasm among business men.

The fourth annual Viennese Opera Ball will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 16. Mrs. Robert W. Dowling heads the ball committee and Mrs. Webb Hilbert and Baroness Julia O. Brunclik Oppenheimer are vice-chairmen for the event.
Mr. Dettmer's report on this year's Michaels Memorial Award finals in Chicago's Grant Park touched upon large, complex -- and delicate -- problems of talent boosting or busting.

That Joyce took after Swift he would probably be the first to admit.

Bank debits in the Ninth Federal Reserve District were 4 per cent above the 1957 level for the first seven months of 1958, the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis has reported. Debits increased 5 per cent in July above the 1957 level.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -The critical question of which is ahead militarily, the United States or the Soviet Union, remained a major unsettled debating point in the Eighty-fifth Congress.

ACCORDING to the experts, September may be a very difficult month for about 200,000 New Yorkers who suffer from hay fever that is caused by ragweed pollen. It is estimated that 75 per cent of all persons who contract hay fever are alleregic to ragweed, and of these, half are allergic only to ragweed.

THE nation's eighth nuclear-powered submarine -- the largest submersible ever built -- was launched last week when the 447-foot Triton slid down the ways at Groton, Conn. These photographs, taken at General Dynamic's Electric Boat Division plant at Groton and at the Submarine School at the U. S. Naval Submarine Base near by, show the men and ships of our nuclear Navy in the chrysalis of development.

FOR twenty years T. H. White has been busy with the creation of his own version of the great Arthurian cycle, otherwise known as the Matter of Britain. Mr. Cutler decorated the small city apartment in his way. Mrs. Cutler decorated the country house her way. Result: Everybody's happy.

TWO of Italy's most-praised acting talents, Anna Magnani and Giulietta Masina, are at work on their first film together. It is also the first time each has worked with the reigning Italian director, Renato Castellani. Titled "Nella Citta, L'Inferno" ("Hell in the City"), it is being fashioned from a script by Castellani and Suso Cecchi D'Amico at the tastefully renovated RIAMA Studios on Rome's Palatine Hill.

The men's clothing industry is concerned about wash-andwear suits. It's not the sales volume that is worrying it -the item is a boon to the field, which has been in the doldrums about a year. And the apparel itself does not bother it -- the garment has a definite place in the industry.

THE literature about the Administrations of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry Truman is liberally laced with ridicule, scorn and hate. Few writers have ever been able to take a coldly detached view one way or the other about these Presidents; they have either adored or despised them.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Carroll M. Carroll, in Carol Ann II, today won the Bear Mountain Predicted Log Trophy, reintroduced into competition by the Tarrytown Boat Club.

Summer looks a little dowdy, but it is green. It does not look -- as it did this time last year -- dusty and baked. It does not look like the threshold of autumn. So one is surprised when, in the back yard, as one prepares to sink into a chair in the sun beside a maple tree, to see a brown leaf drop upon the chair's back and slide, scraping, into the seat.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) -- Ships stranger than Jules Verne fiction are taking shape on the drafting boards of practical American, British, Japanese and German Engineers.

ONE of the most stirring dramatic productions in New York last season was the medieval Play of Daniel as performed by the New York Pro Musica Antiqua in the Cloisters of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 23 -- A resolution and a report highly critical of the United States Supreme Court as lacking in judicial self-restraint and invading the field of legislation were adopted by the Conference of Chief Justices today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 17 -- Leaders of the Communist party of Venezuela and outside experts expect that party to poll about 5 per cent of the total vote in the Nov. 30 presidential elections.

WILLIAM PENN, the great Quaker who established both the colony of Pennsylvania and the city of Philadelphia, is a fine subject for biography for young readers. Oddly, and a bit unfortunately, perhaps, for both of them, two quite acceptable ones have come along together.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Soviet spokesmen accused the United States and Britain today of "new maneuvers" in merely calling for talks on halting nuclear tests rather than actually suspending them.

WELLINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)--The New Zealand Government, despite financial difficulties, will provide special funds to enable the country to carry on its work in the antarctic after the International Geophysical Year ends Dec. 31.

A RECENT mistake in print delivery to a movie house on Fire Island, L. I., set the customers back on their heels, to put it mildly, and brought to light what can only be called a tale of two endings, in the case of Columbia's "The Key."
The Arab League, a regional organization so torn from within that many persons thought it was dead, unexpectedly found a new lease on life in the United Nations last week.

After reading Governor Faubus reply to President Eisenhower on integration I wonder if the concept of freedom does not need clarification. Mr. Faubus maintains that "free people of a democracy such as ours" sanctioned his stand on segregation "by their own votes at the ballot box."

IT is going to be a tough September for the balletomanes. Three ballet companies will be in business during the month; for about two weeks all three of them will be playing simultaneously, and there will be only four or five days when fewer than two of them are in action.

The publicity given the problems of providing college places for 6,000,000 instead of 3,000,000 students within a decade has created in many homes almost a "panic" attitude that is unjustified; a good many educators say.

STEVE LAWRENCE and Andy Williams, two of television's intermission season singing stars, started out in life worlds apart, one a big city boy and one a country boy. Yet the stories of their success have a striking similarity, including singing debuts as choir boys, fathers who encouraged their talent and, the clincher, Steve Allen.

KUNSAN, Korea, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- South Korean engineers have completed a fiveyear reconstruction project that has restored the virtually abandoned port of Kunsan, on the Yellow Sea coast, to serve the "rice bowl" provinces of South Korea.
It is heartening to read your statesmanlike editorial of Aug. 18 "The U. N. and Democracy."

THE American-born conductor, Karl Krueger, who formerly headed orchestras in Seattle, Kansas City and Detroit, has written a rather provocative little book. To a large extent it is a running history of the orchestra and of conductors.
The inaccuracy of present traffic accident statistics is "harmful to accident-prevention work," an insurance official charged here last week.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 18 -Vladimir Jabotinsky, firebrand of the Zionist movement, will remain buried in New York until a government more sympathetic to his activities attains power in Israel.
The recession seems to be drawing to a close a lot quicker than most people think it is, according to Dr. Geoffrey H. Moore of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Ernie Banks clouted his forty-first home run today to pull even with Babe Ruth's 1927 recordsetting pace, but it wasn't enough to overcome the steady five-hit pitching of Bob Porterfield as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 1.

Engineers of the General Electric Company reported at a nuclear ship symposium in Washington last week the development of a boiling water nuclear reactor system that costs 40 per cent less than the pressurized water reactor plant being installed in the Savannah, the world's first atomic-powered merchant vessel.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Members of a Negro youth group continued today their move to gain the right to receive food service along with white persons at downtown eating places here.

ST. DAVIDS, Wales--This is a unique city, a city which knows no busy hum of traffic, no railway trains, no cinema, no crowded sidewalks, no pall of smoke, in fact none of the atmosphere which we associate with a metropolis. It is not a dead city, although it is an ancient one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -Secretary of State Dulles warned Communist China today not to attempt seizure of the small offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu in the Taiwan (Formosa) Strait.
May I add these suggestions to Eric Johnston's brilliant article:
Because her parents could not take her on a promised airplane trip to Virginia, a 10-year-old girl became the first paying passenger yesterday on a helicopter sight-seeing flight from the Battery.

THE scheduled airlines' policy of charging passengers a $3 penalty when they failed to show up at flight time to claim their seats finally fizzled out officially last week. Although the hard-to-enforce penalty had been imposed rarely, it remained on the books until last Tuesday after which date the airlines had agreed to drop it.

HAVE you ever wondered about the brainstorming that goes on behind the scenes in a big department store like Macy's or Ohrbach's -- brainstorming that begins with an idea, balloons into glowing fullpage ads and winds up with police handling the crowds? If you have, wonder no more, for Martin Dibner reveals all the secrets in this high-powered, gift-wrapped novel.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 23--It ought to be easy to give away a handsome $6,000,000 property you no longer need to someone who can make good use of it. But nothing is simple in the labyrinth of international relations, particularly when the rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union is involved.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- Here in western New York on the lake from which it takes its name, the nonprofit Chautauqua Institution, once a village synonym for culture, is marking its eighty-fifth year.

SO rapid has been the development in the satellite programs of the United States and Russia that many volumes dealing with this subject have become obsolete before they were even sent to the bindery. Of the three books under review it can be said that two of them, fortunately, do not fall into the category of the unnecessary satellite books.
BERLIN, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A 7-foot-2 Colorado student hitchhiked out of Communist East Germany today after having collected new friends for the United States by strumming hillbilly music on his guitar.
With the weather in this area bit cooler, department and specialty stores improved their business volume last week. Observers estimated trade for the week at 2 to 5 per cent above the 1957 level.

PELHAM, N. Y., Aug. 23--Albert Young Jr. of Sea Cliff, L. I., who had been searching for a victory in the International Class for quite a spell, attained his goal today for the first time this season.

There is good sense and a certain amount of irony in the foreign oil contracts that President Frondizi of Argentina recently described. Now if Brazil could bring herself to agree to similar foreign investments in her oil industry, two of the most costly and foolish examples of economic nationalism in Latin-American history will have been breached.

MONTREAL, Aug. 22 -- Quebec's traditional political picture underwent a radical change this week with the announcement that the Civic Action League was forming a province-wide political movement. Its avowed intention is to unseat Premier Maurice Duplessis' National Union Administration.

BUFFALO, Aug. 23 (UPI) -James A. Farley, warming up for an all-out battle to capture the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, chided New York City leaders today for "stop Farley" tactics. He called for support as the "people's choice."
The resolution adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday was so foggy that some time will elapse before the outlines of the new order in the Middle East become clear.

The meeting of the East-West nuclear scientists at Geneva, which ended Thursday, forced Washington's hand last week. The technical agreement at Geneva on the scientific feasibility of a global nuclear detection system was followed quickly by an American and British offer to halt testing for one year, beginning Oct. 31, if negotiations to reach an agreement on a test suspension have started by that date.

TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- Japanese legislators have scheduled an investigation of a proposed $300,000,000 deal with a United States aircraft manufacturer to supply 300 supersonic jet fighters as the foundation of a modern Japanese air force.

Fall clothes are strictly on the up and up. From top to toe, everything about American fashions has risen since last year: hats, hairdos, waistlines and hemlines. The loose look continues, but with a difference: now it has been indented by a waistline that soars to a record altitude -- right under the molded bosom.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 -- There was a change in the tone of Cairo's editorials and radio commentary last night and today. Orders obviously had been passed to tone down the propaganda campaign against the Western powers and to reconcile viewpoints.
" THE chemise is dead!" some reporters cried. "Long live the Empire line!" "Nonsense!" others retorted. "the loose look is still going strong. All of the dresses in Paris are easy through the body."
CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 23--Jan Cwiklinski, once in the center of an international incident, sells ice cream in this New Jersey city as he waits for the day he may return to the sea.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Dragon Killer, the winner of the Arlington Classic, pulled an upset today at Atlantic City race course with a four-and-a-half-length victory in the $31,350 Ventnor Turf Handicap.

NYBORG, Denmark, Aug. 23 -- A special commission of the World Council of Churches has concluded after a three - year study that a Christian could in conscience agree to the use of atomic arms in a limited war.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 23 -Alaska voters are expected to vote in favor of making this the forty-ninth state by at least a 3-1 margin in Tuesday's special election.

FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 23 -- The merged labor movement, which last December expelled the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for corruption, moved this week to prevent its own affiliates from vitiating that sentence of excommunication.

PATROLMAN Richard F. Kenehan, the only New York City policeman who pursues criminals with drawing pencils and sketch pads, has noticed that gibes by other cops have mellowed since his portraits based on eyewitness descriptions led to the capture of two girls for the attack on the daughters of an Iranian diplomat in Bronx Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -In New York this week the eighty delegates to the United Nations General Assembly unanimously threw up a smokescreen of Arab pledges behind which the United States and British forces might gracefully depart from the Middle East.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 23 -Weatherly ended the last race of the America's Cup observation trials as the boat with the best record today, but she almost did not beat Easterner. Arthur Knapp Jr. put the Henry D. Mercer syndicate boat over the line a trifling 7 seconds ahead.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -The Giants finally caught up with Bob Purkey, an old nemesis, today and belted him for three home runs while downing the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5 -- 2.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (Reuters) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, in a speech published here tonight, expressed doubt at the possibility of another war.

Wall Street is a split personality with the cleavage steadily being widened by the long-term capital gains tax. On one side are the traders, the men who have for the day or the hour; In the other, the investors who have for six months and one day.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 -- Once again the Arab world, having threatened to burst assunder into shattered separate pieces, is feeling the centripetal force of Arabism pulling it back together into a form of unity.
Within hours after the submarine Triton slid down the launching ways last week at the Electric Boat Shipyard in Groton, Conn., another new atomicpowered undersea vessel began to take shape there.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -When a weary Congress finally shuts up shop sometime in the next few days and heads for home, it will not be with much anticipation of getting any rest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Hank Aaron smashed a two-run homer in the tenth inning today to pace the Milwaukee Braves to an 8-5 victory over the Giants before a crowd of 22,913. The crowd raised the Giants home attendance to 1,010,456 for sixty dates.

THE Los Angeles Rams have always been a flamboyant team, perfectly attuned to rabid fans accustomed to getting their showiness in wholesale lots. Maybe it's the Hollywood influence. As part of the Rams' flair for the spectacular, they unfailingly have been led by a brilliant passer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Members of the Eighty-fifth Congress, which adjourned shortly before dawn today, are heading out across the country to face November political judgment before the electorate.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 24 -- L. Judson Morhouse established himself today as a major power in Republican state politics in his own right with his re-election to his third two-year term as state chairman.

RECIPES for the preparation of seasonal fruits call for the use of different types of sugar. Because different manufacturers do not use the same terms on labels to describe essentially the same sugars, the acquisition of the kind desired can be a bit confusing.

A new model for philanthropy is the Ford Foundation's program for grants in aid to artists. In the first place, the money will go into a field which foundations have badly neglected in the past. Billions of dollars have been poured into education, health, social welfare and scientific research, but a relative trickle has gone into the promotion of the creative arts.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Britain's Brian Hewson pulled off the surprise of the sixth European track and field championships today by defeating a great field of milers to win the 1,500-meter title. The time of 3:41.9 was the equivalent of a four-minute mile.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 23 -- Chile may once again give serious consideration to the idea of selling copper to Iron-Curtain countries, it was announced here today. The decision is being contemplated -- now that copper has been taken off the list of strategic materials -- by the Copper Department.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 -- The adoption by the United Nation's General Assembly last Thursday of the Arabs' resolution to settle their family quarrels is bringing the problem of Israel back into the spotlight.
The Bridgehampton Child Care and Recreation Center for the children of migrant and local farm workers opened its season Aug. 18.

Murray Baron, New York County Liberal party chairman, refused to be pinned down yesterday on whether his party would run Thomas K. Finletter as an independent candidate for Senator if the Democrats should turn him down.

An autobiography by Ivy Baker Priest, Treasurer of the United States, has tentatively been set for Oct. 9 publication by McGraw-Hill. In "Green Grows Ivy," she tells of the career that took her from a mining town in Utah to the highest administrative job ever held by a woman in Washington.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will start its annual fund appeal Oct. 2. Mrs. Howard Phipps, campaign chairman and president of the council, announced a goal of $1,300,000 yesterday to help more girls become scouts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The betting is that President Eisenhower will make a farm speech in the Middle West in the coming campaign.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- August E. Rankis, the defender from the Baltic Chess Club of New York, defeated Dr. Bruno Schmidt of Homer, N. Y., today in the first round of the annual state championship tournament. It is being sponsored by the New York State Chess Association in the auditorium of Cazenovia Junior College.

Futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange last week continued downward with losses ranging from 55 cents to $2.70 a bale. These followed losses in the preceding week ranging from 55 cents to $3.20 a bale.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Pentagon ordered the Navy today to check its Far Eastern defenses in view of the Chinese Communist attacks on the Nationalist-held offshore islands of Quemoy and Little Quemoy.

Harry Gilroy's dispatch published on Aug. 3, "German Schools Shun Hitler Era," and the Reuter report appearing in the same issue concerning the reception accorded former Grand Admiral Doenitz, who spoke before a reunion of former U-boat officers and men, illustrate certain trends in the Bonn Republic.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 24 -- The Jamaica Government is giving favorable consideration to a proposal for a $4,500,000 300-room hotel in this island's capital city. The Chamber of Commerce has endorsed the plan.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- A brawl between Negroes and a white man and his wife outside a tavern in Nottingham last night led to one of the worst racial clashes recorded in Britain.

Tammany Leader Carmine G. De Sapio said yesterday as he left for the Democratic state convention in Buffalo that he did not know whether Mayor Wagner would accept a convention-floor draft for Senator.
Nicaragua has been rated highest among twenty-four Latin American markets in credit and collections performance on United States commercial exports in the first half of 1958.
A warm summer's day in New England may offer, among other activities for both natives and visitors, an old-fashioned, country auction.
About 70 per cent of New York State's major concerns have started preparedness programs against atomic attack, according to the State Civil defense Commission.

THE New York Jazz Festival played it safe at its third annual session at Randalls Island. In the course of two programs offered in Downing Stadium on Friday and Saturday evenings the festival held almost exclusively to proven jazz "names" -- proven both for their audience appeal and for the consistency of their performances.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Aug. 24 (AP) -- South Africa's Cabinet was summoned to a special session today to consider a successor to Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom, the stern segregationist who had led the nation since 1954.

The recent crisis in the Middle East drove from diplomatic consideration the topic which dominated international negotiations this past winter and spring -- a summit conference to consider the major causes of world tensions. In the past it was the verbose Soviet notes which pressed this issue. Now the Western Big Three have seized the initiative.
BUFFALO, Aug. 24 -- Democratic campaign strategists began a counter-attack today against an expected Republican drive to pin a "depression" label on the Harriman Administration.
Six new films will open here during the week. The programs follow:
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Soviet entrants today won two matches and gained a substantial lead in another in the international shooting championships.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 24 -- Rene Coudert's Luders-16, Winsome, beat Tom Hume's Charette in the Eastern Fleets Y. R. A. regatta staged by Riverside Y. C. today.

IN the seventh chapter of the twenty-first book of "Le Morte Darthur" Malory wrote of King Arthur: "And men say that he shall come again, and he shall win the holy cross. I will not say it shall be so, but rather I will say: here in this world he changed his life. But many men say that there is written upon his tomb this verse: 'Hic jacet Arthurus, Rex quondam, Rexque futurus.'"

The sudden withdrawal of Theatrical Interests Plan, Inc., as co-producer with William Darrid of "The Disenchanted" became known over the weekend. Despite last month's announcement that Mr. Darrid and TIP were partners, their agreement was not signed at that time.

ALGIERS, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- French soldiers risked ambush to search olive groves and mountain top villages today for an American missionary believed to have been kidnapped by nationalist rebels, possibly to care for their wounded.

Lewis A. Lapham, chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines, has announced the appointment of Burke G. Piper as chairman of the industrial organization's finance committee. Mr. Piper is vice president and treasurer of the Grace Line, which Mr. Lapham heads as president.

News comes over the river that Queens has not only had a higher population increase in the last thirty-seven years than any other part of the city, but that in addition Queens residents have a higher median family income, fewer are on relief rolls and children in that borough get into less trouble.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 24 -- This city's transportation system, almost hopelessly snarled yesterday when demonstrating students began racing about in seized buses, appeared to be on its way back to normal today.
HONG KONG, Aug. 24 -- The Peiping radio report of yesterday's Communist shelling of Quemoy described the bombardment as retaliation for Nationalist firing on coastal areas.
ODENSE, Denmark, Aug. -- The World Council Churches celebrated its tenth anniversary tonight with a commemorative service in a twelfth century cathedral that crowded to the doors.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Officials on the Nation's Cup round-robin tennis tournament, who have been awaiting the arrival of key players to conclude the competition, ran into another snag today at the Westchester Country Club.
The owners and operators of oil-burning installations were urged yesterday to have their equipment cleaned and repaired before the fall heating season starts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Rapid expansion of electric power consumption in ten countries of Central and Southeast Europe and Turkey points up a growing power deficit in some, while natural energy resources of others remain unexploited.

All things considered, the Yankees did well enough as they split a double-header with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday before a crowd of 40,700. Admittedly, the Bombers had a lot going against them.
Despite a recession and a decline in appliance sales there will be a gain this year in Italian sewing machines.
Eight hundred Catholics of Hungarian descent paraded to St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon to mark the feast of St. Stephen of Hungary. The Hungarian Catholic League of America was sponsor.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Dr. Wernher von Braun said tonight that the failure of Explorer V was "bad news," but that "we will certainly try again."

OF the city's eighty-one police stations, only seven have stood for a whole century, or for close to a century. Of these, six are in Manhattan. Brooklyn's Bedford Avenue station house counts 103 years.
Deputy Mayor John J. Theobald said yesterday he would seek better salaries and more recognition for teachers after he succeeds Dr. William Jansen as Superintendent of Schools next Monday.
Military and civil aircraft will participate in a series of tests that begin tomorrow to determine if one radar-beacon system can be used to track all of the traffic in the city area.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The grain uturesfmarket mustered only one faint gleam of a rally last week, but it was short-lived and the trend of prices otherwise was steadily down.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Like every recent session of Congress, the one just ended has been dominated by the figure of Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Military sources said today Maj. Gen. Paul D. Adams, who escaped with minor injuries in a helicopter crash, owed his life to his own safety orders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Assets farmers own -- such as land, buildings and livestock -- rose to a record value of $186,000,000,000 last Jan. 1. This was a jump of $10,300,000,000 in a year.
Republicans were asked yesterday to include in their state platform a pledge to support the efforts of the city's sanitation workers to attain pension plan revisions.
TAIPEI, Monday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Communist guns battered the Quemoys and near-by Tan islets anew today.

The achievements of ministers and laymen in fighting poverty and delinquency in Harlem show that man must not be discouraged in the face of great obstacles, the Rev. Donald W. Strickler said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The nation's 30,000 furniture dealers, with business running 8 per cent below last year's, are out to raise their sales this year by $250,000,000.

The creation of a Center for Rehabilitation Services by New York University was announced yesterday. The center will coordinate and broaden the university's program for the handicapped. These, however, will continue to function independently.

IN the massive forest of furniture designs introduced at the June markets this year, George Nakashima's group for Widdicomb towered like a lonely redwood above the rest of the trees. This group will go on view today in room settings at Altman's.
HONG KONG, Aug. 24 -- Communist China expressed its readiness to give further economic aid to Cambodia in a joint statement signed in Peiping today by the Premiers of the two countries.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 14 -- The ancient and honorable game of Scotland has become a political issue in this city. The position taken by the Government in a recent series of top-level meetings was that golf was not a constructive nor a commendable pursuit and that land used for golf could be used more sensibly for other purposes.

Lawrence A. Wien, realty investor, has contracted to buy the operating sublease on the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, from Webb Knapp, Inc. The sublease is being sold for a large cash consideration and a purchase-money mortgage through Harry B. Helmsley, president of Hemsley-Spear, Inc., broker.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 -- slow but steady recovery, step-up in inventory buying, better outlook for higher earnings and a strong market that will support recent price increases is the picture painted here for the current steel market.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 24 -- Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach, L. I., took himself definitely out of consideration for the Republican Senatorial nomination tonight. He said that family and personal obligations impelled him to a firm and final conclusion that he could not run.

The Eighty-fifth Congress closed its books with a creditable record of legislative accomplishment behind it, considering that White House and Capitol were under control of opposite parties. Despite such displays of strictly partisan politics as when the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill went down to defeat, crude partisanship has on the whole been admirably restrained.

In his letter in your Aug. 15 issue Carl Landauer expresses concern as to whether it is "good political strategy to propose a prohibition of the propaganda war and thus to concede that we hold Soviet propaganda more dangerous to our part of the world than dissemination of democratic beliefs can be to communism."
Quemoy and Matsu are much nearer to the Chinese mainland than to Taiwan (Formosa), despite the fact that they are held by the Chinese Nationalists.
THE current crop of peaches is the largest in ten years. As a result, the prices of this succulent fruit are down to bargain levels.

Our major political parties begin their quadrennial state conventions today, the Democrats in Buffalo and the Republicans in Rochester. The convention is an essential, if imperfect, part of the democratic process established by constitution and law in New York State. A political convention has been described as a mixture of parliament and mob.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 24 -- An American-style supermarket, believed to be the first in southeastern Asian, has just been opened here with all the fanfare and ceremony of a Hollywood opening.
The management of the E. L. Bruce Company was accused of fraud yesterday in the issuance of a block of stock that could decide control of the company in a forthcoming proxy fight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The chairman of the court-appointed monitors over Teamsters Union affairs said today that James R. Hoffa had not consulted them when he named an anti-racketeering commission for the union.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Aug. 25 -- The Defense Ministry announced today that the Chinese Communists attempted last night to land on tiny Tungting Island, eighteen miles southwest of Quemoy.

Jack Brause, realty operator, has conveyed title to the four-story business building on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 308 Fifth Avenue near Thirty-first Street to Gabriel Powers, an investor. The assessed valuation is $125,000. Edward L. Lane was the broker.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Dag Hammarskjold arranged today to leave by air for the Middle East at 6:30 P. M. tomorrow.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 24 -- Mayors, burgomasters and special envoys of sixteen European cities, including five from countries within the Soviet orbit, today saluted Edinburgh's twelfth International Festival of Music and Drama.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 24 -- An Army Jupiter-C rocket carried a 37.52-pound satellite aloft early today, but failed to thrust it into an orbit.

Bobby Fischer, the 15-year-old chess champion of the United States, lost one adjourned game and drew another in the interzonal tournament at Portoroz, according to a report last night from Yugoslavia.

Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas was described yesterday as "apparently sincere, but with a limited ideal, who is interested in doing good for only one segment of the population -- the white people -- even if it is at the expense of the colored people."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Seth Corwin, who was recently crowned champion of the internation 110 Class, and Sam Barton, who sails Aries in the International Class, brought additional honors to the American Yacht Club today.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 24 (AP) -- A $1.95 robbery is focusing international attention on a Negro handyman sentenced to die in the electric chair for the crime.
MORE than one shopper at Abraham Straus today will do a long double-take.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 19 -- This country is still on economic thin ice. But it is making progress.
"If an agency were to come to us seeking a merger, and we felt that the deal looked right, we would be interested in acquiring other agencies."

EASTFORD, Conn., Aug. 24 (UPI) -- An automobile with seven youths went out of control and overturned today. Four were killed as they were trapped in the flaming wreckage. A fifth was blinded and paralyzed.

ONCE a clothing wardrobe is complete for campus life, college students must gather their linens together for the dormitory. Since this is the first opportunity for freshmen to prove their homemaking abilities, there is always a degree of puzzlement on what and how much to select.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Aug. 24 -- Foul weather ruined the closing day of the Domino Yacht Club's invitation regatta today.

It was a surprise to drop into Toots Shor's and find Isaac Grainger in a huddle with Bill Talbert, Julian Myrick, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Danzig, Renville McMann and other titans, czars, captains and kings of tennis. Since when had golf and tennis become buddy-buddy?
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Industrial share prices rose substantially last week in unusually active trading in the stock markets.
OPORTO, Portugal, Aug 24 (AP) -- Stirling Moss of Britain drove his British Vanwall to victory in the seventh Grand Prix of Portugal auto race today.
RARELY in world history has a decorating trend like the current vogue for filigree taken on international significance.
The squeals of delight at Grand Central Terminal yesterday heralded the fact that young campers were coming home.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Three straight singles in the eleventh inning of the nightcap and a brilliant relief stint by Murray Wall lifted the Boston Red Sox to a double-header sweep over the Kansas City Athletics today.
Joseph E. Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, was a provocative guest yesterday on "Meet the Press" over Channel 4.

The atomic submarine Nautilus reached the East Coast of the United States last night. She surfaced at Ambrose Light long enough to record a trans-Atlantic speed record, then submerged to wait at the mouth of New York Harbor for a three-day welcome that begins this morning.

The Hercules Powder Company announced over the weekend a reduction of 7 cents a pound in the price of Profax polypropylene "to further broaden the diverse markets developed for the plastic during the past months."
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 24 -- There were post - mortems aplenty but no findings on this quiet Sunday after the completion of the eight races in the America's Cup observation trials.
LAKE GROVE L. I., Aug. 24 Dachshunds captured top honors in a Suffolk County Kennel Club match at the Lake Grove School today.

The vehicle-carrying freighter Carib Queen again has been offered for sale by the United States Maritime Administration on an as-is-where-is basis. The Federal shipping agency set a minimum bid price of $4,141,818, with 25 per cent payable at the time of the sale.

At the request of Governor Harriman, the Board of Estimate has pigeonholed the controversial Narrows Bridge project until after the election. The Governor intervened at the urging of John Cashmore, Brooklyn Borough President, who convinced him that the issue would be embarrassing in the political campaign.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- Representative F. Edward Hebert said today that his landslide victory over a Negro in the Louisiana Democratic primary had shown the nation "where we stand."

On Aug. 13 the House of Representatives voted 369 to 8 to cite Bernard Goldfine for contempt of Congress because of his refusal to answer questions put to him by the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight concerning certain financial matters. I was one of the eight who voted against the contempt resolution.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 24 (UPI) -- The first defendant in a mass treason trial of members of the toppled regime confessed in military court today that he had taken part in a plot against Syria. But he pleaded that he had acted only as "an army officer under orders."
ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- The last block to through transit on the forty-two-mile Palisades Interstate Parkway will be eliminated here Thursday just in time for the Labor Day week-end.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 24 -- The all-breed show and obedience trial of the Great Barrington Kennel Club, held today on the grounds of the Barn Club, wound up with the top honors going to a miniature poodle, Ch. Summercourt Square Dancer of Fircot, owned by Mrs. Lewis Garlick, Woodmere, L. I. Anne Rogers handled the winner.

Christians should be thankful not only for the good in life but also for the hardship and suffering, the Rev. Daniel P. Byrne of the New York Apostolate Mission Band said yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- American cricketers beat the British at their own game today. They unexpectedly defeated the Lord's Taverners by 132 to 131. The prize was a silver cup presented by John Hay Whitney, United States Ambassador to Britain.

TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Japanese collegians defeated an American squad in a two-day track and field meet which closed at Tokyo's National Stadium tonight. The score was 104 -- 103.
Budd and Stuart Schulberg will produce an adventure program for the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- The apparent tranquilization of the Arab world as a result of the special session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York profoundly influenced business on the stock exchange here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- State tax collections set a record in the 1958 fiscal year, the Census Bureau reported today, but the rise was the smallest since World War II.
The first jet transport to be delivered to a United States airline made its New York debut yesterday.

Consolidated net income of the Corn Products Refining Company and its United States and Canadian subsidiaries for the first six months of 1958 was $10,129,598, William T. Brady, president, said in a report issued for publication today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A five-run eighth inning, ignited by Stan Musial's pinch single, led to a 12-8 St. Louis Cardinal victory and a double-header split with the Pittsburgh Pirates today. NORTHPORT, L. I., Aug. 24 -- An army of skin-divers invaded Huntington Bay here today in a concentrated three-hour attack against the starfish, scourge of the oyster, Clad in skin-tight rubber suits, hoods, diving masks and flippers, 230 men and women skin-diving enthusiasts searched the murky waters off Sand City at Huntington Town beach on Eaton's Neck.

The steamship charter market reached the standstill point last week. There was no change in the rate index, but only because not enough business was done to have any effect.

Directors of the Universal Marion Corporation yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend. Twenty cents a share was declared, payable Sept. 27. The company paid 40 cents June 28 and April 4, this year.

The New York Gift Show in the New Yorker Hotel and the nearby New York Trade Show Building opened yesterday with heavy attendance and brisk buying.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 26 -Nelson A. Rockefeller's first twenty-four hours as Republican nominee was one round of hectic activity, broken only by less than six hours of uneasy sleep.
Owners of American tramp vessels charged yesterday that their best customer, the United States Department of Agriculture, was using "dictatorial tactics" against them.

The Liberal party nominated Thomas K. Finletter for United States Senator last night without waiting for the Democratic party to choose a candidate. The party's en dorsement also was given, as expected, to Governor Harriman, Lieut. Gov. George B. De Luca and Controller Arthur Levitt for re-election.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 26 -- The Government has been using cash payments to encourage Communist terrorists to take advantage of its amnesty program.

AT 11 A. M. tomorrow a Seaboard and Western cargo plane is scheduled to touch down at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. It will be bearing more than $1,000,000 of original fashions from Paris.
The Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways charged yesterday that the Department of Welfare was "dumping" relief clients on the area.
HONG KONG, Aug. 26 -- The Government closed one of this colony's Communist - dominated schools and the Peiping radio assailed the move tonight as an "atrocity."
BUFFALO, Wednesday, Aug. 27 -- District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County won the Democratic nomination for United States Senator early today.
LITTLE ROOK, Ark., Aug. 26 -- Following is the text of the address by Gov. Orval E. Faubus to the Arkansas Legislature today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals held today that military courts-martial had the right to try civilian dependents of United States service men overseas in cases involving non-capital offenses.
BUFFALO, Aug. 26 -- District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, wanted to be a baseball player in his younger days.

Thomson McKinnon, brokers in securities and commodities with forty-six offices in the United States and Canada, leased 35,000 square feet of office space in the building rising at 2 Broadway facing Bowling Green.
The chairman of the Planned Parenthood Association of Manhattan and the Bronx asserted yesterday that giving contraceptive service to city patients was the responsibility of the municipal hospitals.

The Algerian nationalists struck with terrible effectiveness and a remarkable display of coordination in France on Monday. In the process four French policemen and at least five terrorists were killed and there was considerable property damage. The question to be answered is whether the Algerian National Liberation Front (the F. L. N.) and the cause of Algerian independence will gain or lose by such tactics.

Plans for an industrial bank to stimulate further growth of Hawaii's economic resources were reported yesterday by Dr. James H. Shoemaker. Dr. Shoemaker, who is a vice president of the Bank of Hawaii, is on a visit here to confer with bankers on possible financing of construction and industrial development.
An estimated total of 20,000 persons visited the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn yesterday to inspect the atomic submarine Nautilus.

LAWYER, 54 years old, has been Attorney General since 1957. . . . Raised in poverty, he took Abraham Lincoln as his inspiration to get ahead. . . . Worked as a footpress operator in a button factory, shipping clerk and delivery boy while going to school. . . .

Directors of the Ward Baking Company took no action yesterday on a dividend on the common stock for the present quarter. Shareholders had received 25 cents quarterly. So far this year 50 cents a share has been distributed on the common stock.
The comments of the visiting Russian interne about medical care of indigents in the United States were grossly inaccurate.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 -- Australia, relatively untouched as a motion picture location for American films, will be playing host to a pair of Hollywood productions at year's end.
DAKAR, French West Africa, Aug. 26 -- Thousands of Senegalese yelled "Independence!" at Premier Charles de Gaulle tonight and he cried back at them that they could have it if they wanted it.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 26 -- After five more years of intensive development, Israel will still require at least $250,000,000 in annual economic aid, Levi Eshkol, Minister of Finance, predicted today.
THE first hunting of 1958 in this region begins Monday with the opening of the rail and gallinule season in New York and New Jersey. The season extends through Nov. 9.

The recent action of Governor Harriman in asking the Board of Estimate to postpone action on the Narrows Bridge project until after Election Day was criticized yesterday by three Republican legislators as "a temporary stay of execution.''

OSTEND, Belgium, Aug. 26 (AP) -- George Morris and Billy Steinkraus of the United States equestrian team finished first and second respectively, today in the Prix du Pesage event opening the Ostend international horse show.

VICTOR BORGE, whose off-Broadway enterprises are as diverse as a full-scale smorgasbord, returned from abroad last week to resume his role as a Connecticut farmer. He revealed, in the course of an interview, that his latest back-to-the-soil venture included the purchase of an estate in his native Denmark that boasts, in addition to a 200-year-old chateau, 16,000 apple trees and a six-acre cherry orchard.

CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, Aug. 26 -- The two most important leaders in Poland -- a Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church and the chief of the Communist party -- have held two secret and apparently fruitless meetings on disputes between the church and the state.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A curb on non-white immigrants was urged tonight by parliamentary representatives of this city, where race rioting erupted last week-end. Their statements were made in response to reporters' inquiries.

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, announced yesterday that the studio would release at least twenty large-scale motion pictures next year. He added that this would be the highest number of such films distributed by Paramount during the last several years.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP)---H. William Hoskyns of England withstood the onslaught of five Italians and two Russians tonight to ,become the epee fencing champion of the world. His record was six victories and one loss.

ARMONK, N. Y., Aug. 26 -An advertising executive of the General Foods Corporation stopped his car on a rural stretch of Route 22 here last night after another car had tapped his rear bumper. He was then deliberately run down and killed by the other driver, according to the police.

The International Harvester Company, the nation's leading producer of farm implements and tractors, had a net income of $29,343,000, or $1.81 a common share, in the nine months ended July 31. This compared with $31,347,000, or $1.95 a share, in the similar period of the previous year.

The City Planning Commission's 1959 capital budget will allocate to the New York City Transit Authority "only a very small fraction" of the additional money the agency has requested to keep the city-owned system in good running order.

Bipartisan candidate for Associate Judge Court of Appeals ELECTED to Court of Appeals in 1944 . . . at 63, described as judge before whom lawyers like to appear. . . . Big boned, lean, nearly 6 feet 2 inches tall, displays kindly humor in courtroom manner and is dignified and courteous. . . .

Charles Evans Hughes died ten years ago (Aug. 27, 1948). New York will never forget the high standards he set as investigator and Governor. The sound practices of public utilities in general, and of life insurance companies in particular, are largely due to his labors; the short ballot, too, is one of many other legacies he left us.

MIKE is a drake. He is a city drake. He knows his way through traffic. He senses strangers at the door if they turn a key in the lock or brush a hand across the outside panels. He gives warning with a drake's equivalent of a dog bark.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 26 -Sidney Bernstein of New York today administered the first defeat suffered by August E. Rankis, the defender, in the annual championship sponsored by the New York State Chess Association at Cazenovia Junior College.
MONTREAL, Aug. 26 -- X-ray technicians in Japan seem to have a higher sterility rate than do Japanese men of comparable social and economic status, according to a small sampling reported here today.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 26 -Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will find Jordan's Government in a skeptical mood when he lands here tomorrow in the role of mediator of Middle East tensions.

QUEENS Borough President from 1951 through 1957 . . . Business man, 53 years old, was almost political unknown when elected in Queens, ending eight years of Democratic rule . . . Considered able man who avoids extreme partisanship . . . Former president of Queens Chamber of Commerce . . .

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 -- A "very large proportion" of the faculty of Jena University in East Germany remains strongly anti-Communist despite - ever-increasing. Government pressure, Dr. Josef Haemel, former rector, said today.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Great Britain carried off the Nations' Cup for the second year today as many of the leading players entered in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills competed on the turf of the Westchester Country Club.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- A special General Assembly committee reported today that official United Nations documents tend to be wordy. The report took 6,000 words to back this up.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers turned down an offer late today by the National (railway) Mediation Board for further negotiations in a threatened strike on the Reading Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower ordered a virtual end today to a billion-dollar anti-recession housing program that had been an important help in increasing housing starts.
"WHAT can you say of a writer who has to write prefaces to explain his work?" James Joyce once asked in brisk disparagement of George Bernard Shaw.

Nikita S. Khrushchev's persistent theme in our long talk in the Kremlin was how to improve relations with the United States. When I said that non-interference in the affairs of other countries, live and let live, would help, he agreed emphatically.
Twenty-one of the city's top retailers, real estate executives and bankers agreed yesterday to help speed the off-street parking program in mid-town.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Fisheries' experts were reported today to have reached a compromise agreement in the dispute over Iceland's planned extension of her fishing limits.
NYBORG, Denmark, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches advised Christians today to avoid oversimplifying the questions of disarmament and atomic tests.

The City Planning Commission had bad news for the Board of Education yesterday. It served notice that it would make a cut of "not less than 50 per cent" in the board's request for a 1959 capital budget allocation of $113,739,540 in additional funds within the city's debt limit.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- Britain has been discussing with the United States the increased tension in the Taiwan (Formosa) area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Senate rackets investigators piled up new charges of Teamster Union strike violence today after Robert (Barhey) Baker, a star witness, had been stricken with a heart attack.
BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- A statue of George Washington, guarding the West Gate of the Boston Public Garden, is going to get its sword back. The weapon disappeared about three years ago.
Massachusetts plans to offer some $61,000,000 of various purpose bonds about Sept. 24. No other details of the issue were available yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--President Eisenhower said today that he would campaign for the election of a Republican Congress this fall on the issue of a more nearly balanced budget, sound money and a thriving economy.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The race for the North American junior sailing championship tightened today. The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Yacht Club moved to within 8 1/2 points of the leading Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club.
TOKYO, Aug. 27 -- Japanese and United States officials met today to re-examine Japan's military position in the light of Communist Chinese attacks in the Formosa Strait.

WHEN the Supreme Court hears arguments today on integration of public schools in Little Rock, Ark., Thurgood Marshall will be shooting for his nineteenth victory out of the twenty-one civil rights cases he has pleaded before the highest court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--President Eisenhower persisted today in his optimistic view of the nation's defenses. He rejected as "silly" the idea that the United States could be defeated by a single nuclear strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- India will receive substantial additional economic help over the coming year from a group of her creditors, a spokesman of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 27 -- A roadside melon patch on the site of the ancient Lydian capital city of Sardis in what is now Turkey has yielded the remains of a Roman dwelling.
RHINEBECK, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Governor Harriman opened his re-election campaign today with a county fair visit, complete with grandchildren, faithful dog and bucolic photography.
MIAMI, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Hurricane Daisy was listed as "severe" tonight with peak winds estimated at 115 miles at an hour.
BUFFALO, Aug. 27 -- Governor Harriman sought today to bind the wounds left in the wake of the divisive state Democratic party convention here.
It is a pity that only a few people were present in the Kremlin earlier this month when Adlai Stevenson met with Nikita Khrushchev.

GENEVA, Aug. 24 -- While waiting to see what the Russians are going to do at the second International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy, United States scientists setting up their displays here are engaged in some friendly rivalry among themselves.
CAIRO, Aug. 27 -- The dispute between Egypt and the Sudan about use of the waters of the Nile was revived today.
HAVANA, Aug. 27 -- A gun battle in which one man was killed and several were wounded occurred this afternoon at the exclusive Union Club, situated on the Malecon sea drive.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP) -- G. Franklin McSorley, suspended chairman of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission who was convicted of misconduct in office, was sentenced today to serve two to four months in jail.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 27 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, facing one of the most volatile issues of his Administration, is scheduled to hand down shortly a decision on the demands of university students for cancellation of city bus fare increases.
"Mail Flo" systems, to speed the sorting of mail, will be installed in four post offices here.

IT seems more than fitting, in rounding up the new French fashions, that Mlle. Chanel should be honored. The Chanel look and her fashion philosophy are equally indestructible. Despite the fluctuations of hemlines, waistlines or sleeves, her famous effortless suit with open jacket, slim but stridable skirt and inevitable jersey or silk shirt have remained essentially unaltered.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Rumania has announced a major purge of sports figures caught smuggling and "grossly violating Socialist sports morality." The other charges were not reported here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Control of Fairbanks, Morse Co. "is still in the hands of the Federal Court," Robert H. Morse Jr., president of the company, said today after a directors' meeting. His reference was to a Federal injunction issued last year preventing the Penn-Texas Corporation from acquiring control of Fairbanks, Morse until after the Fairbanks, Morse annual meeting in 1961.
Commercial banking hasn't been able to raise capital fast enough to keep up with the rising demand for loans, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

Former President Herbert Hoover hailed yesterday the new $25,000-a-year pension for former Presidents, signed into law by President Eisenhower. However Mr. Hoover said he would give his pension, after taxes, to charity.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 27 -Dag Hammarskjold arrived here this morning for three days of private talks with King Hussein and Premier Samir el-Rifai of Jordan.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The United States Army joined today in the fight against encephalitis-carrying mosquitos as the death toll in South Korea's sleeping sickness epidemic rose to 458.

The $11 million and the projected $26 million operating deficit of the New York Transit Authority for the fiscal year 1958-59 calls for a realistic reappraisal of the fare philosophy of the authority and the purposes of public ownership of transit facilities.

The Reading Railroad elected J. Warren Lawson, general freight traffic manager, as vice president-freight traffic yesterday. Mr. Lawson, 58 years old, has been with the road forty-one years. He succeeds Harry B. Light, who is retiring after forty-seven years in the traffic field.
COLORS flying, stoles are in the wind again.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Office of Naval Research reported today the development of a new type of ship propeller that it said opened unlimited speed possibilities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27--President Eisenhower gave the Republican National Committee a rousing "let's go get 'em" pep talk today.

Contrasts were furnished in the metropolitan district's qualifying trials for the United States amateur championship on Tuesday at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck. There were fifteen places at stake. Four went to golfers who are not likely to owe allegiance to this area should they carry off top honors at San Francisco during the week of Sept. 8. Don Cherry, for example, is, in his own words. "a Texan, first, last and always.
Revenues of the television industry increased 5.2 per cent in 1957, but expenses rose 10.7 per cent and profits fell 15.6 per cent.
ALBANY, Aug. 27 -- The State Education Department will offer twenty-five hours of weekly classroom instruction by television on Channel 11 in New York City, starting Sept. 22.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The fourteenth straight year of record school enrollment, about 45,000,000, was predicted today by Lawrence G. Derthick, Commissioner of Education.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- The United States Air Force has established that the body of man can withstand the shock of leaving and re-entering the earth's atmosphere. But there is a big question about his mind, an American scientist disclosed today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- Effective immediately. The Saturday Evening Post will accept alcoholic beverage advertising.
The final gap in a scenic route overlooking the Hudson River will be closed with a ceremony at noon today at Orangeburg, N. Y.
HONG KONG, Aug. 27 -- The Chinese Communist Government lodged two strong protests tonight against British activities in or emanating from Hong Kong.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- A "significant advance" in tire development was announced today by the United States Rubber Company.
The prospective supply of feed grains this year is estimated at 232,000,000 tons by the Department of Agriculture. That would be 6 per cent above the former record, established last year.

Contraceptive service for all city hospital patients who desire it without regard to their religious faith, was urged yesterday by Mrs. Helen M. Clark, president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Three sticks of dynamite and a partly burned fuse were found today under the bedroom window of the home of Maurice Hutcheson. He is president of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 27 -- The State Legislature shouted approval today of measures proposed by Gov. Orval E. Faubus to close schools forcibly integrated by the Federal Court.
Have you ever ridden a horse without lights in Des Moines, Iowa? If so, you've broken a law.

The 274 West Fortieth Street Corporation has purchased the three apartment houses occupying a plot 50 by 100 feet at 69597 Ninth Avenue, southwest corner of West Forty-eighth Street. The property is assessed at $85,000.

UNITED NATIONS Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold arrived yesterday in Jordan on a journey designed to resolve the crisis in the Middle East. Last night the Columbia Broadcasting System presented "Jordan: Key to the Middle East," a timely thirty-minute telecast summarizing developments that necessitated the Secretary General's mission.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 27 (Reuters) -- Brussels has outgrown its Melsbroek international airport after only nine years.
In the first inning at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, Bobby Richardson muffed a throw from Tony Kubek. Before the inning ended, the Athletics had scored seven unearned runs off Johnny Kucks.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Dr. Ernest O. Lawrence, Nobel Prize-winning physicist, died tonight in Palo Alto Hospital. He underwent surgery today for ulcerated colitis. He was 57 years old.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 23 -- Twenty-two months after his release from the Spandau war crimes prison, former Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz has emerged as a nostalgic public figure in West Germany.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 27 -- Mrs. James B. Dickey of South Orange has been selected chairman of the committee that will present an original musical comedy to benefit the laundry renovation fund of East Orange General Hospital.

CORK, Ireland, Aug. 27 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, said here today that an "all-out offensive" against traditional Catholicism in Latin America had jeopardized the future faith and freedom of millions.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- The sun, which French history especially has associated with great eras and triumphant events, burst upon Paris today as Premier de Gaulle drew nearer to his seat of government after his goodwill mission to Algeria and France's African colonies.
The Eaves Costumes Company, in existence for almost 100 years, has established two annual theatrical awards, one carrying a cash prize of $1,000 and the other $500.
POACHING an egg seems so simple. Yet, it involves far more know-how than making a spectacular dessert, such as baked Alaska.

The Beaux Arts String Quartet played a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The performance opened the ninth season of Norman J. Seaman's Interval Concerts. It was the first of ten events to be presented in the Interval series.

Gasoline stocks fell by more than 2,700,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday. They totaled 173,756,000 barrels, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. That compared with 176,487,000 a week earlier land 171,897,000 a year ago.

Thousands of Americans under the age of 40 who have not received Salk vaccine shots have escaped paralytic polio only through sheer luck, the National Foundation said yesterday in its 1957 annual report.

Directors of the Continental Baking Company increased by 5 cents the quarterly dividend on its common stock with the declaration yesterday of 55 cents a share, payable Oct. 1. This places the stock on a $2.20 annual basis.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- The question of fighting or peace for the United States forces in Lebanon rests largely on the nerves and common sense of a young Arabic-speaking lieutenant from Brooklyn.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- In the smoke of a growing consumer credit rate war, small British borrowers are wondering: where will new credit bargains turn up next?
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27 -- Argentina's anti-Peronist labor unions plan to test the Administration's new union organization law in the Supreme Court.
JUNEAU, Aug. 27 -- Alaska has voted overwhelmingly to make this vast territory the forty-ninth state.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The lone voice of dissent in the Arkansas Legislature today belonged to a young lawyer from Hot Springs. It was a small voice in the uproar of a House aroused against school integration.

TRUMBULL, Conn., Aug. 27 -- A Milford couple married last month were killed in an auto crash on the Merritt Parkway here shortly after noon today. They were identified by the State Police as Joseph Denisco, 47 years old, of 33 Laurel Avenue, and his wife, Theresa, 40.

The offer by a New York industrial promoter Sol M. Zweifach, for control of Mount Vernon Mills, Inc., a Baltimore cotton textile company, was rejected yesterday by directors holding a majority of the stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- A grant of $57,000 from the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation and its subsidiary, the American Rehabilitation Foundation, was announced at today's session of the American Congress of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Virginia's Pupil Placement Board suggested pointedly to the school boards of Charlottesville and Norfolk today that it be handed the job of assigning public pupils in the two cities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell entered a vigorous protest today against the participation by the Justice Department in the new Supreme Court action tomorrow on the Little Rock school integration case.
The liberal arts college is reported becoming a professional school in the same kind of transformation that has changed the high school from a classical to a comprehensive institution.

Investors ran out of enthusiasm in the final thirty minutes of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Substantial gains through most of the entire list were jettisoned and those remaining at the close mostly represented fractions.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 27 (AP) -- A new type of aluminum bridge said by its sponsors to incorporate unusual strength while offering speed and economy in construction was shown today at Lehigh University.
GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. 27 -- Big business needs scientists today in almost every department, in the opinion of one of Britain's leading industrialists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -When President Eisenhower insisted again today that it would be wrong for him to say whether he thought the Supreme Court's public school integration decision was right or wrong, he took a position that is not being followed by his own Administration.

When a 68-year-old Hungarian woman arrives here by plane today, the Fried family will be together again and safe on this side of the Atlantic. It will be a reunion that Paul Fried has been working on for two years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -One of the longest runs of consecutive price declines in the trade history came to an end today as the butcher hog market held steady to strong. Until today, prices had dropped on twelve successive days, from a top of $23.25 on Aug. 11 to $20 on Aug. 26.

In your editorial "Vox Populi" of Aug. 21 you heap gentle scorn on the contention of five Democratic leaders of New York City that the Democratic convention in Buffalo will be "free and open." And rightly so.
The Atlas Corporation reported yesterday net income of $8,057,185 for the first six months of 1958.

A police search on Pier 90 for the thief of $8,000 worth of jewelry caused a work stoppage of ten minutes by 100 longshoremen yesterday.

A continuation of racial integration this fall in the schools of Little Rock, Ark., was urged by a spokesman of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. in a telegram Tuesday night to President Eisenhower.

THE song of the press agent is getting sweeter every day, and of late it has been as varied as the bird song of the forest at dawn. Here are a few examples of the unpremeditated art of typewriter skylarks of the Western Hemisphere's tropic and temperate zones.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 26 -- The Australian Government promised today to protect Malayan tin against the importation of Russian tin at cut prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -The offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu are more important to the defense of Taiwan (Formosa) than they were three years ago, President Eisenhower said today.
