Commodity futures trading continued inactive yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was featureless in most markets. Prices moved irregularly.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Ancient Mayan wall paintings, buried in the jungles of southern Mexico, have emerged from obscurity to provide insight into one of the New World's oldest cultures.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Aug. 28 -- The biggest artillery bombardment since the Korean war continued this morning as the Chinese Communist guns surrounding Quemoy on three sides hammered the Nationalist bastion for the sixth consecutive day.

The Arkansas Legislature's rapid approval yesterday in Little Rock of Governor Faubus' bills to nullify any efforts at school desegregation formed an ugly prelude to the extraordinary session of the Supreme Court in Washington today.
The new operator of the Roxy Theatre will be Robert C. Rothafel, nephew of the late Samuel L. (Roxy) Rothafel, who built the showcase at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street in 1927.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points up to 1 point off yesterday. Trading was moderate.

Books by and about Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be published during the next two months. The first will be "On My Own," wherein Mrs. Roosevelt tells of her life since the death of President Roosevelt. The book will be published Sept. 15 by Harper.

The State Division of Housing offered help yesterday to the Rockland County town of Ramapo in wiping out slums that blot its verdant valleys and mountain settlements. Deputy Housing Commissioner Mary Lavery recommended, as a beginning, the construction of fifty state-aided low-rent units of the garden type of public housing.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation had sales and other income totaling $104,724,044 in the first half of this year. This compared with $103,794,459 in the similar period last year, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported yesterday.
Thomas K. Finletter said last night that he was undecided whether to accept or reject the Liberal party's nomination for United States Senator.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's comments notwithstanding, the Senators may move to Minneapolis.

A program of four ballets at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 29 and a supper party to be held later that evening in the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East will benefit the City Symphony Orchestra of New York.

Muhammad H. el-Farra of the Arab League office expressed a desire in his letter published Aug. 21 to know "what kind of Israel the Arabs are to accept." The answer to that rhetorical question is very simple.

United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, who reached Jordan yesterday, will need all his well-known qualities of diplomacy, ingenuity and self-confidence to find a peaceful solution for that pathetic nation's problems.

FOR much of the nation, the season in the sun will end next Monday night. However, since the long week-end is still in glorious prospect, there is time to consider marinades and basting sauces for the outdoor grill.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- The Army has tested a rocket motor with such power that it could hurl a defense missile to extreme altitudes "almost instantly."

Federal agents and city detectives seized thirty pounds of raw opium yesterday in an apartment at 94 Sheriff Street, on the lower East Side. They estimated the value of the opium at $1,000,000 in the illicit market, and said the seizure was one of the largest ever made in this country.
PANAMA CITY, Aug. 27 -President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. released a steel pour from an electric arc furnace this afternoon and started production for Panama's first heavy industry.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana)is planning to borrow $200,000,000 in the public market on long-term debentures. The issue will be offered next month by a syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The turnover in the stock market contracted further today and small falls predominated in virtually all industrial share groups. But the undertone was said to be firm. Losses were caused more by a slackening of demand than by selling pressure.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 27 -- If Hurricane Daisy strikes, the four America's Cup defense candidates and the British challenger Sceptre will be in a small, landlocked cove on Narragansett Bay near here.

The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, which began an investigation of "Dotto" a few days ago, said yesterday that its inquiry had been extended to at least three other television quiz programs.

ALGIERS, Aug. 27 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle arrived here today on the last leg of his 12,000-mile plane tour of French African possessions. He was welcomed with hardly more enthusiasm than an ordinary tourist.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- General Motors attributed the impasse in current labor negotiations today to the auto union's continuing insistence on a 48-cent-an-hour package.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reported yesterday a net loss of $3,448,839 for the first seven months this year. This was after crediting its income account with $2,272,845 of additional mail pay, retroactive to July 1, 1956.

Ralph Vaughan Williams was a composer who created music in the immortal tradition. He followed no "ism." "Whether my music is good or bad," he once wrote, "it is always honest, and by that I mean I could not put down on paper a line which I did not first feel in every part of me."

The men of the submarine Nautilus moved slowly up the stretches of lower Broadway yesterday in a warm flurry of ticker-tape and confetti. To pay honor to the Navy officers and men who, in the atomic-powered craft, bored through the silent sea under the North Pole three weeks ago, a crowd estimated by the police at 250,000 lined Broadway from Bowling Green to the City Hall.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Tempted of Mrs. Philip du Pont's Mooring Stable gave a courageous performance in winning the $29,250 Alabama today at Saratoga Race Track. Under a calculated ride by Bob Ussery, the daughter of Half Crown remained in front most of the way to take the mile and a quarter test by a length and a half.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -The grain futures market generally extended its recovery a little today from the low levels of last week.
A twin-engine Convair -- a familiar passenger and military plane -- yesterday flew about eighty miles an hour faster than any of 510 similar planes now in world-wide operations.
THORNWOOD, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- A plan to combine three central Westchester school districts was approved last night by the three school boards involved.
BUFFALO, Aug. 27--Mayor Wagner was disclosed today to have engaged in a bitter exchange of threats with Carmine G. De Sapio during the Democratic State Convention.
The Thermoid Company announced yesterday it would redeem in cash on Nov. 1 all outstanding shares of its convertible preferred stock at the call price of $55 a share.

Solar research and the practical uses of solar energy have brought together the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and New York University.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 27 -- Flave (Flick) Nipe, a 64-year-old Pennsylvania Dutchman who was the oldest driver in the race, had the fastest trotter in the thirty-third Hambletonian today.
MILWAUKEE Aug. 27 -- An attempt to unseat Carl J. Megel of Chicago as president of the American Federation of Teachers failed tonight. But it left the federation a house divided.

New York's party conventions have done their work. Frank S. Hogan, respected District Attorney of New York County since 1941, repeatedly elected unopposed with the endorsement of all parties, is the Democratic nominee for the United States Senate. Out of a profusion of candidates, out of a painful travail bitter through long hours, with divided opinion among party leaders, the nomination went to the man favored by Carmine G. De Sapio, the Tammany leader.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today the Washington Senators should build a better ball club and stay in the nation's capital. The club has been considering a move to Minneapolis.
MONTREAL, Aug. 27 -- An important committee of geneticists indirectly criticized the Soviet Union today for permitting only a single school of genetics theory to represent it at a congress here.

The General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries reported sizable gains in operating revenues yesterday for the seven and twelve months ended July 31. Net income rose slightly in the seven-month period above the 1957 level.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- Lilli Palmer, absent from American films for several years, will be seen as the wife of Clark Gable in the romantic comedy, "But Not for Me." The actress is now in Munich, Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -President Eisenhower indicated today that he would like to see "slower" movement toward racial integration in the schools.

The 512 Fulton Street Corporation has bought the five-story loft building at the northwest corner of Livingston Street and Hanover Place, Brooklyn. The s'eller was Spear Co.' The purchaser is a holding company of May's Department Store, which will occupy the property after alterations.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 27 (AP) -- Representative William Colmer, dean of Mississippi's Congressional delegation, and Representative Arthur Winstead headed for new terms today, sweeping to easy victories in the Democratic primary.

Sales and earnings of the Consolidated Foods Corporation in the fiscal year ended June 30 were the highest in the history of the big canner, processor and distributor of foods, Nathan Cummings, chairman, and S. M. Kennedy, president, reported yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 27 -- Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and Michael Davies of Great Britain each stood twice within a stroke of defeat today in gaining the quarter-finals of the Westchester Challenge Bowl tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Eisenhower indicated today that he would be willing to join Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Premier, in a resolution condemning interference in the internal affairs of other countries if the Soviet Union would apply it to its satellites.

MARIEHA, Ga., Thursday, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An expansion to nearly double its present territory was announced today by the Thirty-fifth North American Air Defense Division at near-by Dobbins Air Force Base.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed a $3,697,917,728 catch-all appropriation today carrying funds for the Atomic Energy Commission and several other agencies.

PARIS, Aug. 27 -- European experts saw great merit today, but complications also, in the United States proposal to increase the resources of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
State and Federal officials here joined yesterday to cope with professional gambling in Suffolk County.
A $45,000,000 skyscraper will rise on anotherblock on Park Avenue controlled by the New York Central and New Haven Railroads.

Fifteen acres on Linden Highway at Route 27 in Edison Township, N. J., have been purchased by Philip J. Levin, builder, for improvement with a shopping center. The propert3 was sold by S'ommer Bros. The center will contain 125,000 square feet of first-floor space and parking for 1,500 ears.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- The Association of Motion Picture Producers and the newly formed Musicians Guild of America have agreed on a new collective bargaining contract.
TUNIS, Aug. 27 -- Algerian rebels were spreading the word here today of attempts to sabotage French passenger ships and aircraft.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Aug. 27 -- Come to this ancient Flemish port and eavesdrop on the seventeenth century. If you are forwarned you may spend a delightful interval as a guest at the wedding party of Peter Paul Rubens, the painter, and his lovely 16-year-old bride, Helena Fourment.
OSTEND, Belgium, Aug. 27 (AP) -- William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., won the $300 first prize of the Prix du Kursall equestrian event today in the Ostend international horse show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) -- Five men jailed for refusing to answer questions about a mobster meeting at Apalachin, N. Y., asked Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan to free them until a state court acts on their appeal.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 28 -- Victor Seixas defeated Kurt Nielsen of Copenhagen today with an admirable performance for a player who has been out of competition for five weeks.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Ammon Bell of Hummelstown, Pa., topped more than 2,100 of the nation's finest .30caliber marksmen today to win the President's Cup.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Alabama Supreme Court took no action on Jimmy Wilson's appeal today, and thus virtually assured the condemned Negro a reprieve from the electric chair.

ATHENS, Aug. 25 -- Clay tablets, indicating methods of economic administration and bookkeeping of an ancient capitalist system, have been brought to light at Hagia Triada, near Phaistos in southern Crete.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The President of the national Woman's Christian Temperance Union said today that bars in the United Nations should be closed and that the State Department's special liquor fund repealed in the interests of "sober statesmanship."

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 28 -Charles F. Kingsley of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, L. I., won the national Raven Class title today after the fifth and final race of the series was called off because of heavy seas.
DURING the last nine months Macy's sleuths have banded the globe ferreting out furniture, accessories and housewares indigenous to foreign lands.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that the investigation into television quiz shows had not come upon any evidence that would require grand jury action.

Two kinds of pleasure boatmen steer cruisers along the Intracoastal Waterway in South Jersey. Some skippers cover mileage as fast as possible to and from Florida. They make the run between lower Barnegat Bay and Cape May just another link in the voyage.

Racing automobiles, particularly the passenger-car types, are like long-time prize fighters. Their fenders are cauliflowered, their noses battered and bruised, their bodies scarred and battle worn. It's the strong and undamaged hearts within them, the engines, that count.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP) -- An Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile was fired 3,000 miles tonight on a completely successful test of guidance and power.

Textile prices again are moving up after a long period in the doldrums caused by over-production and slow business. The chief reason is a pick-up in demand that cut stocks sharply at mill and wholesale levels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- President Eisenhower gave recess appointments today to four men he had nominated for Government positions before Congress adjourned.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio said tonight that United States military moves in the Far East had created a "brink-of-war situation that could explode at any moment."

A syndicate representing investing interests from Argentina has purchased a plot of land at Kappock Street and Johnson Avenue in the Riverdale area of the Bronx for improvement with cooperative apartments.

Directors of the Black Decker Manufacturing Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 50 cents a share, payable Sept. 30. Shareholders were paid 35 cents in previous quarters.

Pending the signing of contracts, it seems likely that Norman Forman will continue to champion George Panetta's cause. Mr. Forman, sponsor of Mr. Panetta's hit, "Comic Strip," is on the verge of becoming sole owner of the author's next comedy, "The Poker Game."
Delays or detours on a number of major routes will affect motorists in the metropolitan area over the Labor Day week-end.

Malcolm Anderson of Australia begins the defense of his title today as the favorite in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills.
During the early part of the twentieth century the railroads had a virtual monopoly of both freight and passenger transportation. Their only serious competition was the waterways.
St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases announced plans yesterday to complete its modernization and expansion program at a cost of $2,000,000.

A method for vacuum-packing food concentrates in fifty-five gallon steel drums for shipment has been perfected by three manufacturers. Known as "sterile pack," the new process represents years of research. Its developers believe it will result in improved food quality and major economies.

PARIS, Aug. 28 -- The Paris police have arrested more than 3,000 Algerians in the last twenty-four hours. The Algerians were herded into the Velodrome d'Hiver, Paris' equivalent of Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Officers of a carnival workers' local told Senate investigators today that they had been appointed to office, brought to St. Louis to vote in a Teamster Union election and paid $150 each for their time.

ORANGEBURG, N Y, Aug. 28 -- Governor Harriman, riding in a 1929 car, was a victim of the efficiency of parkway police as he left here today after a ceremony opening the final section of the Palisades Interstate Parkway.

The Board of Education appointed Samuel Schenberg yesterday to be director of science of the city school system. Six members of the nine-member board voted for Mr. Schen berg, who was the choice of Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Prices receded on a wide front in the stock market today. Trading volume continued to decline.
A loss of $553,000 was reported yesterday for the fiscal quarter ended July 31 by ACF Industries, Inc. The company's fiscal year ends on April 30.

BONWIT TELLER has 800 new reasons why no woman should go bareheaded this fall. This is the number of hats that was designed and made especially for the store by eighteen houses in France and Italy. The Standard Oil Company of California has decided to go ahead next week with its postponed offering of $150,000,000 of long-term sinking fund debentures. The capital issue was placed in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission on June 4 with plans to offer the securities for public subscription later that month.

I was quite upset to notice that in the campaign against jaywalking an individual can now be taken to the police station merely because he carries no identification on his person. The American Stock Exchange still has taken no action to change its ruling on the closing of short contracts in E. L. Bruce Co. common stock. Short sellers thus cannot be made to deliver their shares on demand from the buyers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The United Sates again warned Communist China today against trying to capture Quemoy and Matsu, Nationalist-held islands off the coast of China. It was the third warning in six days.

A store building containing 10,000 square feet of space at Westwood and Fairview Avenues, Westwood, N. J., has been leased by the Second WestwoodFairview Corporation to Westwood Shop-Rite, Inc. Shop-Rite operates supermarkets in Rutherford and North Arlington.
The nation's construction industry, usually regarded as a bellwether for the economy in general, appears to be heading for a record year in 1958 despite its lagging pace only a few months ago.
A man described by the police as a petty gambler was shot and killed in front of his Brooklyn apartment yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Hungary, a dominant factor in international saber competition for a half century, retained its team title tonight by trouncing Russia, 9 -- 3, in the world championship.

As has been unofficially reported the governors of the International Bank and Monetary Fund, holding their annual meeting at New Delhi, India, next month, will consider proposals calling for an increase in their resources. In a letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, Robert B. Anderson, who will represent us at the New Delhi meeting, the President has instructed him to propose such increased contributions, including American dollars.

Custom smelters of copper reduced the price of refined metal a half cent a pound to 26 cents yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 29 -- Wilber M. Brucker, United States Secretary of the Army, said here today the United Nations forces in Korea are now "stronger than three years ago in relation to the Communist forces in North Korea."

TWO days before his death at the age of 60 in 78 B. C. Lucius Cornelius Sulla, the retired dictator, completed the twenty-second book of his memoirs. Like so many other invaluable lost books, Sulla's did not survive the fall of Rome. If it had, it would unquestionably be an important and fascinating work, an authentically inside account of the corrupt politics and ferocious civil wars that did so much to destroy the Roman Republic.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 28 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Government Employes opposed extension today of the Federal Employes Security program to cover all Federal workers.

Say whatever else you will about the summer now waning, it has been a good season for wild berries and the birds that feed on them. Beginning with wild strawberries in June, which were bigger and more numerous than usual, it progressed through a big crop of black-caps and wild blackberries, both bigger and juicier than usual. And now the late berries are ripening.

THE general practice of medicine (in the United States a pretty demanding profession) seems, for some reason, to be a continual round of hilarity in England. The hero of this sprightly, ribald novel is a thoroughly frustrated practitioner under Britain's National Health Service in an English manufacturing town.

More pupils and more problems is the forecast for 1958-59, when the nation's schools reopen for the new school year this week and next. According to the United States Office of Education, about 45,000,000 students are expected to attend schools and colleges, a gain of over 1,500,000 since last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Eisenhower has made a tentative offer of his services to Republican candidates for Congress in their campaigns this fall and is sitting back to see what sort of response he gets. At his last two news conferences and in a message to the Republican National Committee meeting at Chicago earlier this week, he has indicated his interest in helping out the campaign effort to some unspecified degree.

From the obscurity of diplomatic language in the communique concerning the agreement between Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and the Premier of Jordan one fact emerges. Both agree that the basis for keeping the peace in the Middle East should be, if not a United Nations force, at least the "presence" of the United Nations in the area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce recommended today that private interests and state and local governments be authorized to buy and operate Tennessee Valley Authority power facilities.

ON June 9 the theatre in Ireland won an important victory over censorship. Captain Alan Simpson, director of the Pike Theatre, was discharged from court for lack of a prima facie case. After refusing to amend a play at the order of the police, he had been charged with giving performances at his theatre that were obscene and profane.

Labor Day marks the end of the summer season for retailers. Those specializing in fashion goods are losing no time in placing emphasis on the fall season, and a larger than usual number of wholesale buyers have come into the New York market for intermediate trips.

AS everyone knows, Andre Maurois is an urbane and often brilliantly persuasive writer, who knows as much about England, and perhaps even about America, as he knows about his native France. AS an admirer of Robertson Davies' fine novel, "Leaven of Malice," I was worried when the new one opened like a sequel. Happily, "A Mixture of Frailties" turned out to be an independent book, and a first-rate one. As good in execution as the earlier novel, it is larger in scope, richer in conception. It is not so specifically a comedy, although abundantly funny in Mr. Davies' highly individual vein.

VIENNA, Aug. 30 (Reuters) -- Workers digging a well on the Gotschuchen estate in the mountains of the Koschuta range in Carinthia found a thick layer of solid ice at an altitude of 4,600 feet.
LAST week in Hollywood two producers, survivors of many an industry storm, were involved in milestone productions. They are Samuel Goldwyn and Dore Schary.

LA PLATA, Md. -- Charles County, here in southern Maryland, is a region with an elegantly historic past and a blatantly gaudy present. Whether its future will combine tobacco-supported manor houses with slot machine-supported roadhouses, or choose one over the other, is hard to guess at this point.

Adlai Stevenson in his article which appeared in The New York Times on Aug. 28 reveals a confidence by Soviet Premier Khrushchev. Khrushchev, as paraphrased by Mr. Stevenson, said that "when the leaders of the Communist countries get together they always toast their best friend, the Secretary of State of the United States."
SACRAMENTO, Calif. Aug. 30 -- Senator William F. Knowland related today how he expected to make up a 662,000-vote deficit and defeat Attorney General Edmund J. (Pat) Brown for Governor on Nov. 4.

" AFTER the commercial failure of 'The Enormous Room' Cummings turned his back on book-length prose," Ben Ray Redman wrote in his review of the "E. E. Cummings Miscellany," collected by George J. Firmage.

SHOULD one ask more of a work of fiction than that it be well written, profoundly serious as well as hilariously funny? "City of Spades" is all that. At times it is also deeply moving, as sad and confused and violent as the century we live in.
LAWNSIDE, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Twenty - five policemen from Lawnside and six surrounding communities fought with two truckloads of young people from Philadelphia early today.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 31 -- Increased activity and strength were noticeable on the stock market last week.
The interesting article on Federal Reserve policy by Edwin Dale in The Times of Aug. 17 sidesteps an issue which it is important to consider seriously.
WILLIAM ALBERT NOYES Jr. is a scientist actively on a mission. He wants to see that scientists have equal hand with politicians in shaping tomorrow's world.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 31 -There will be no fixed pairings for the matches among Columbia, Easterner, Weatherly and Vim in the final trials from which one will emerge as defender of the America's Cup against England's Sceptre. The trials start tomorrow.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The stock market finished a generally quiet week on a dull note.
GENEVA, Aug. 31 -- Soviet scientists have privately proposed a cooperative research program with the United States in the new effort to tap the virtually unlimited energy of thermonuclear power.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's Labor Day statements:

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Aug. 31 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent his best wishes to United States Air Force Academy cadets today as they completed their move into the school's new permanent site north of here.
Appeals for eliminating racketeers and corrupt leaders from the trade union movement were made yesterday by organized labor and Government spokesmen.

Tommy Elliott of Miami captured the feature midget auto race of twenty-five laps (6 1/4 miles) yesterday at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the opening program of weekly midget car races at the former New York Giant ball park.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A shift over the last half century in the way Americans earn their living was revealed today in a study published by the Census Bureau.
"Twenty-One" goes on television at 9 o'clock tonight under a cloud of controversy.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- James A. Farley told a State Fair audience today that the Soviet Union did not want either war or lasting peace.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 31 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that the White House had required him last September to accept the Supreme Court's desegregation decision as a prerequisite to further negotiations with President Eisenhower in the Central High School controversy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- If television giveaways decline with the demise of "Dotto," you will hear no wailing from the Social Security office.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 31 -Red banners with the hammer and sickle floated anew here today as the so-called Popular Front held its last big pre-election rally in support of the Leftist Presidential candidate, Salvador Allende. The voting will be on Thursday.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Minnie Minoso's twentieth homer in the eleventh inning resulted in a 3-2 Cleveland Indian triumph over the Kansas City Athletics today.
Symbols of success vary endlessly. Depending on time and place they are likely to be anything from station wagons and ulcers to an extra wife and gold teeth.

MANILA, Monday, Sept. 1 -- The Philippine Foreign Ministry has been advised by sources outside the country that the United States will defend Nationalist-held Quemoy Island if it is invaded by Communist China.
The Christian Church must not align itself with either capital or labor if it is to fulfill its function in the community, the Rev. Dr. John H. Fischbach asserted in a sermon yesterday.
SADDLE RIVER, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Local business men had their last Sunday of legal opening today.

For the last month there has been talk about a young player from Peru, Alejandro Olmedo, being named to the United States Davis Cup team. Until a week ago it had been talk and nothing more. Neither the Davis Cup Selection Committee nor the team captain, Perry T. Jones, had said anything to give authorization for the speculation.
Some persons lately have been wondering what has happened to the simple virtue of public courtesy. Being polite to one's fellow man is a practice rapidly going the way of the dodo.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that new laws might be needed to define the status of television quiz shows.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Andy Connell's Blue Cloud led the Lightning Class today in the second day of the week-end interclub regatta on Manhasset Bay.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 31 -- West Germany's coal industry, harassed by surplus production, will make an all-out bid tomorrow to force the Government into a protectionist policy.
BOSTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -Tom Brewer won his fifth straight game today as the Boston Red Sox edged the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 2.
A towheaded, 19-year-old 6-footer from Piedmont, Calif., scored one of the notable victories of the tennis season yesterday in the national championships at Forest Hills.
More than 2,000,000 cubic yards of material in one section of the St. Lawrence Seaway must be dredged before the new waterway can be opened to deep-sea shipping next spring.
LONDON, Monday, Sept. 1 -Britain asserted early this morning that she must preserve the rights of British fishing vessels on the high seas.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Aug. 31 -- The Federation of Malaya celebrated the first anniversary of its independence today.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 31 -- Archbishop Titan Nersoyan, Patriarch of the Armenian Orthodox Church in Jordan, has been expelled from the country on less than two hours' notice.

FEW men are privileged to lend their names to the English language. Edward (Snapper) Garrison was one of them. He is the chap responsible for that catchy phrase, "a Garrison finish," denoting a whirlwind rush from far back to victory. It's more than sixty years since the Snapper rode his last winner and yet his fame -- and his name -- still endures.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 31 -- Four British frigates appeared off Iceland today and a wave of anger swept over the nation.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 31 -- James Rousmaniere of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club sailed his Atlantic Class sloop Lynx III home first today in the Thirty-fourth annual Stratford Shoal overnight race sponsored by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- Steel order volume continued to improve last week and a faster tempo is expected to set in this week following tomorrow's holiday. Most steel users' plants will be shut down tomorrow and many steel mills will curtail operations -- at least in finishing departments.
"There is a great area for Christian expansion in India," the Right Rev. John W. Sadiq, Bishop of Nagpur, India, said yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Carlton Willey, making sure the Pittsburgh Pirates start no late-season challenge against the Braves, stopped the Bucs and Ron Kline with a 2-0 shut-out today. The loss dropped the Pirates eight and one-half games behind the league-leading Milwaukee club.

ONE of the virtues of "Outlook" is its outspokenness. Yesterday afternoon over Channel 4, under the guidance of David Brinkley, the National Broadcasting Company program examined some of the problems of the nation's schools and forthrightly took a position on ticklish issues.
An upswing in the rate of highway traffic deaths yesterday afternoon caused safety officials to substitute pessimism for optimism as the Labor Day week-end passed its midpoint.

Two plays dealing with extrasensory perception are in the offing. One of them, "Roman Candles," is controlled by Maurice Evans. The other is "And No Birds Sing," which George Brandt is thinking of producing.
The Eighth Avenue Holding Corporation has purchased the six-story apartment house on a plot 37.6 by 100 feet at 2866 Eighth Avenue, at the southeast corner of West 153d Street, near the Polo Grounds.

A new conversational phrase for those who like to talk about the weather is being polished by Government meteorologists. By next summer it may be unsophisticated for Americans to say: "It's not the heat, it's the humidity."

PARIS, Aug. 31 -- The Opera Comique has the style of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann" in its bones. The tempos are right, the phrasing has the right kind of nuance and the enunciation of the French text is admirable.
Nat (Sweetwater) Clifton's steal of home in the eighth inning enabled the East to defeat the West, 6 -- 5, in the American Negro Baseball League's all-star game at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 31 -A fog and a so'wester of twenty to twenty-five miles an hour marred the second day of the three-day Great South Bay regatta today. Thirty craft were dismasted, but all were towed in by spectators in motor craft.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 31 -- A meeting of trade experts called by the United Nations to examine the formation of a South American regional market completed a week's discussion today.
The policy of barring birth-control therapy in city hospitals was seen yesterday as "a potential threat to the civil rights of the whole community."

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31 -- Paul Hoffman's Hother, a 46-foot cutter out of Larchmont, N. Y., today retained the Vineyard Trophy by finishing with the best corrected time in the twenty-fourth annual 231-mile Vineyard race of the Stamford Yacht Club.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 31 -- President Eisenhower demanded in a Labor Day statement today that the public as well as organized workers be protected against labor and management practices that "give rise to lawlessness and harmful abuses of power."

The Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation had net earnings from operations after taxes of $1,665,244 in the fiscal year ended June 30. This compared with $1,784,885, for the previous year, according to the report issued today.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 31 -The American Yacht Club's Sam Barton cashed in on an excellent start and led throughout as he scored with his International sloop Aries in the Sea Cliff Yacht Club's regatta today.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 21 (UPI) -- Following, as made public here today, is the text of remarks by President Eisenhower that were recorded on tape in Washington and transmitted to the Second International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy in Geneva:
MANILA, Aug. 31 -- The first annual Ramon Magsaysay Awards, patterned after the Nobel prizes, were presented today to five outstanding Asian personalities.

CINCINNATI, Aug 31 (UPI) -- John Temple, Ed Bailey and Jerry Lynch provided the power and Harvey Haddix and Don Newcombe the pitching as the Cincinnati Redlegs beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 2, and 7 -- 3, today to run their winning streak to six games. The streak is the longest of the year for the Redlegs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -Bob Turley today became the first Yankee hurler in four years to win twenty games in a season. He also is the first to reach that number of victories in the major leagues this year.
Production of malleable iron products suitable for the automotive, farm equipment and electrical industries is being introduced in Mexico for the first time.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) -- High winds and electrical storms battered upstate areas today and tonight. Roofs were torn from buildings, trees were toppled and power lines were snapped.

Representative Joel T. Broyhill, Virginia Democrat, suggested last night that a solution to the school integration problem in Virginia might be found if Gov. J. Lindsay Almond discussed the matter with President Eisenhower at a personal meeting.
A four-man committee of scientists has been named to propose a United States program for the international control of space exploration.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Two California drivers tried to set new streamliner records today on the salt flats of western Utah, but an engine of one caught on fire and an engine of the other exploded into small bits.
The three contenders for the New York County Republican Committee leadership pleaded yesterday for a militant organization to wage aggressive campaigns against Tammany Hall.
The steamship charter market continued depressed last week. Business was light and rates for cargoes remained virtually unchanged.
New York State has submitted to the Federal Civil Defense Administration a survival plan to meet the challenge of a possible nuclear attack.
The method most widely employed by economists today for estimating the over-all rate of economic activity for the immediate and early future is the construction of so-called "models."
BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 31--Johnny Gayer with four goals and Herb Kiefer with three sparked Bethpage to a 7-4 victory over the Brookville poloists at the State Park today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Giants thumped their "cousins" from Los Angeles, 14 -- 2, today for San Francisco's third victory in a row over the fading Dodgers. Bob Schmidt's grand-slam homer and Willie Mays' two-run blast were the key blows in a fifteen-hit Giant attack.
Now, more than ever before, Christian churches should evangelize and bring the Gospel into the secular world, Dr. Norman V. Hope, of the Princeton Theological Seminary, said yesterday.
Another proposal to build a parking garage under Bryant Park has been made by a group of private investors.
Payments of wholesalers' bills have started to recover from the downtrend earlier in the year, the Credit Research Foundation, Inc., reported over the week-end.

Labor Day was conceived in the Eighties by a New York carpenters' union president named McGuire, who proposed a big parade and picnic "to show the strength and the esprit de corps of the trade and labor organizations." Twelve years later President Grover Cleveland proclaimed Labor Day a holiday to honor all the working men and women of the entire nation.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 31 -- Although until last Friday the stock market remained outwardly very firm and active, a trend that had been gathering momentum at last broke through.

SAPPORO, Japan, Aug. 31 (AP) -- An American track and field team composed of touring Amateur Athletic Union stars and Armed Forces athletes in the area won eleven of twenty events from a Japanese squad but lost the meet, 111 -- 95.
More than 4,000 persons attended a solemn pontificial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday commemorating the 500th anniversary of the birth of St. Casimir, patron saint of Lithuania.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Out of a block of wood, foam rubber and a hank of terrycloth, a psychologist has created a mother that baby monkeys love. He thinks that human beings might be able to learn to love such a substitute mother.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 31 -- Lynn Wanamaker's bay gelding Trade Winds from Southampton scored 10 points to take the hunter championship at the Rice Farms junior horse show today. Reserve honors went to John Mann's bay gelding Beezeebub from Port Washington with 5 points.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The grain futures market scored its best price advances last week since the Middle East crisis more than a month ago when United States troops were sent into Lebanon.

POZNAN, Poland, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Germany dominated the European rowing championships today by sweeping three titles. The premier eight-oared race was won by Italy and the single sculls by Australia's Stuart MacKenzie.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--Asked to comment on the report from Manila on the defense of Quemoy, a State Department spokesman recalled, without other comment, President Eisenhower's remarks on the issue at his news conference last Wednesday.
Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to lose ground last week.
Preparations to provide extensive supplies of taconite for the nation's steel mills are under way at new taconite plants in Minnesota.

PROVIDENCE, R. I, Aug. 31 -- A collection of manuscripts, books and letters of John Hay, Secretary of State under Presidents McKinley and Theodore Roosevelt, has been presented to Brown University by John Hay Whitney.

OYSTERS are in season again and, according to the Fishery Council, the supply is expected to be as great as it was last year. This, despite reports that oyster beds have been invaded by starfish and drills (small marine animals), which are natural enemies of the oyster.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Aug. 31 -- The Harrimans of Sands Point and Albany and the Reillys of Levittown shared an informal luncheon of chicken salad, rolls and coffee on a backyard patio here today. Both families described the meeting as delightful.
Oregon is planning the sale of $20,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds on Sept. 17. The issue will come due serially from 1963 to 1972.

While concurring whole-heartedly with the import of your editorial of Aug. 22 -- urging removal of reciprocal restrictions on the travel of Russian visitors and diplomats -- I do not think it necessary to admit the State Department's contention that restriction serves as a valuable bargaining point.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Civilian medical care for dependents of military personnel will be reduced drastically Oct. 1 because of money limitations voted by congress.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 -- Pravda's statement today that the Soviet Union fully supports the Chinese Communists' "struggle" to win control of Taiwan and the Nationalist-held offshore islands was the most outspoken comment on the Far East situation to appaer here since the recent flare-up of activity in the Taiwan area.

With Labor Day's arrival a new school year cannot be far away and in New York City it brings a new man to the office of Superintendent of Schools, Dr. John J. Theobald, who takes over officially today. The office of Mayor of New York is sometimes spoken of as the second most difficult in the nation, failing short only of the Presidency.

MAKUNG, Penghu Islands, Aug. 31 -- Chinese Communist jet fighter planes have moved into a new airstrip on the main land just nine minutes' flying time from the Penghu (Pescadores) group of about sixty islands.

Malaya is celebrating the first anniversary of its national independence at just the time that the Communists have greatly increased the tension in the Taiwan Strait and throughout Southeast Asia. There is some significance in the juxtaposition.

IT may come to pass that New York City's next generation may look on ours as composed of softies who quaintly dialed telephones by an exchange and numbers system. The telephone company people think it probably won't be too long before only numbers are used throughout the country.

IT has been said of Cristobal Balenciaga that he is "the di Vinci" of the couture, "the Moliere of dressmakers." American designers have said that viewing his collection is like "attending the Sorbonne," and his fellow couturiers refer to him as "the master."

Political thinkers have attributed the unrest in the Middle East to the rise of Arab nationalism. It has been pointed out that Western nations should recognize the spirit of nationalism that is struggling to assert itself in the Arab world and come to friendly terms with it.

We are all familiar with the often repeated (and often justified) Southern complaint that Northerners try too often to intervene in problems which concern only the South and which are better left to Southern solutions.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31 -- Col. Saleh Samarai, former Iraqi military attache, who was shot by assassins here yesterday, was reported still not out of danger tonight.
Thurgood Marshall yesterday criticized President Eisenhower's expressed wish for "slower" racial integration in Southern schools. He contended instead:

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 31 -- The Chinese Communists eased their bombardment of the Quemoy Islands today, but trained six big guns on forty-acre Tungting Island, off Amoy, the Chinese Nationalist Defense Ministry reported

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 31 -- Tennessee Valley Authority directors said today in a six-page statement that a United States Chamber of Commerce report attacking T. V. A. was based on "fundamental misconceptions of Congressional policy and T. V. A. administration."
LADENTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- "The Case of the Slipping Armband" marked the conclusion of the Rockland County Kennel Club's twelfth annual all-breed show today.
Carmine G. De Sapio dismissed yesterday as "absurd and ridiculous" reports that the nomination of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for the Senate had caused a rift in the Democratic party leadership.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Sept. 1 -- Wilber M. Brucker, the United States Secretary of Army, said here today that the Chinese Communists must not underestimate the force of the recent warnings by President Eisenhower not to upset peace in the Formosa Strait area.

A truly remarkable example of international cooperation is offered the world today by the opening in Geneva of the second United Nations conference on the peaceful atom. And nowhere is this cooperation being shown more hearteningly than in respect to efforts to tame the vast power of the hydrogen bomb -- that is, to attain controlled thermonuclear reactions which can be used for generating electric power.

Shipping lines serving the Port of New York are frequently urged by port planners to "stagger" the docking times of their heavily laden liners during the summer rush season. There are several reasons why this system is proposed. The piers are capable of handling a certain number of passengers and a limited amount of cargo. Great ships create heavy traffic on the marginal streets.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- A Soviet scientist revealed today that the return to earth of two dogs, shot to a height of 279 miles in a sealed cabin on Wednesday, was achieved by special aerodynamic brakes and parachutes.
As a Democrat tremendously impressed by the candidacy of Nelson Rockefeller I wish to point out to others of like persuasion the pitfalls of a vote for him in the coming election.

In 1771 Lord Melbourne allowed his beautiful and talented lady to build a magnificent dwelling in which to entertain the fabulous figures of the time. In "Peace in Piccadilly" Sheila Birkenhead tells of the London society that has lived in this famous building for nearly 200 years.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Roman Catholics elsewhere in the world were asked today to pray for Catholics of the United States in their campaign against racial discrimination.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Gangs of whites clashed with Negroes and policemen in London tonight for the second consecutive night.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- The Huguenot Yacht Club predicted log contest, the first on the East Coast to be held at night, was won by Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, in Hurricane III, early today. Accuracy scores gave Du Mont 97.6896 per cent. This was his third victory this year.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Dismantling of bomber and rocket bases in Britain is demanded in fifty-two of 143 resolutions on disarmament that will be presented to the Labor party's annual conference.

HAVANA, Aug. 31 -- The violent political situation in Cuba has forced the Superior Electoral Tribunal to extend for ten days the period for nominations of candidates in the national election scheduled for Nov. 3.
A contract bridge team led by Alvin Roth of Washington last night came from behind to win the 1958 Knickerbocker team-of-four championship at the Statler Hotel.

The holiday rush to the beaches here yesterday resulted in a dramatic rescue for six persons spilled from a boat at Coney Island and for a man and his wife trapped on a sandbank off Canarsie. But tragedy struck a swimming party in Jamaica Bay.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 -- Confusion and angry internecine debate marked the labor and student situation here this weekend.

WARSAW, Aug. 31 -- Poland's school children will troop back to their classes this week and will become one of the most important elements in the struggles between the Roman Catholic Church and the Government.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Quinby Co., Inc., an investment concern, has lost a suit in State Supreme Court alleging unfair business competition by the New York Stock Exchange and one of its members.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 -- New York City is losing $500,000 in state aid that has been used in the past to finance more than half of its adult education program.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Religious ders here, acknowledging the "difficult situation," hurled sharp rebuttal today at a Harvard psychologist's indictment.

IT is often assumed on this side of the Atlantic that all French women are born cooks who can whip up intricate dishes without looking at a recipe. But, according to an authority who should know, Mlle. Francoise Bernard, French housewives can be just as stumped as Americans as to how to make an omelet or why a cake falls.

More than one-third of the nation's 88,000,000 drivers have below-average vision. Fifteen per cent of that group have eyesight so poor that they are dangerous drivers. These are two principal findings of a study by the Better Vision Institute.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Mitchell Saltzberg, 45, an accountant from New York, won the New York State Ches Association championship tonight when he drew his last game with August E. Rankin, the defending champion from New York.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Victor Seixas, the 35-year-old tennis star from Philadelphia, won the Westchester Challenge Bowl tennis final today.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Demolition of the first buildings on its slum-clearance site in Washington Avenue will begin in October, the Elizabeth Redevolpment Agency has announced.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 31 President Eisenhower's love of privacy on vacations was tested today. He was hugged and kissed by two 12-year-old girls as he emerged from services at the Navy's hospital chapel on the Coasters Harbor Island base.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington contended today that the Government had put $6,500,000,000 to $7,500,000,000 into a weapons system "which I think is totally unnecessary from the standpoint of future war."

PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 1 -- The eighteen school districts in Passaic County are in various stages of an $18,900,000 building program aimed at relieving 4,700 pupils now on part-time sessions and forestalling overcrowding.
GENEVA, Sept. 1 -- The Soviet Union reported today it had succeeded in running two atomic reactors on plutonium fuel -- one of the principal goals of the new atomic energy industry.
There is something especially shocking about the race riots in England, and one may be sure that the British are themselves more shocked and chagrined than anyone in foreign lands.
PARIS, Sept. 1 -- New ministerial talks on the Icelandic fisheries dispute are expected to start this week at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters here.
A program for residential as well as school integration was urged on the Board of Education yesterday in the final report of its Commission on Integration.
A new amphibious helicopter with great promise as an anti-submarine weapon has quietly been taking shape in the old Sikorsky factory in Bridgeport, Conn.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Weller's 13-year-old Highland Scott gelding, Mamscot, triumphed with Billy Haughton in the sulky in the Ardsley pacing feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight. A crowd of 28,159 saw the victor score in 2:06 1/5 and return $10.40 for $2. He led from wire to wire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The State Department, Congress was told, would be confronted with a hopeless dilemma if it had to disclose its sources of information in denying passports to alleged Communists.
Malcolm Anderson had his troubles again yesterday with the youth from Seattle who came within a stroke of defeating him in the Eastern grass court tennis championships.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 1 -- Bill Cameron, with his S boat Half Way, and Howard McMichael, with his International Kangaroo, lost that hungry feeling for victory when they won in their respective classes in the Larchmont Club's regatta today.

DARLINGTON, S. C., Sept. 1 -- After a week of Civil War-type pageantry and hominy grits-style eating, Darlington got around today to the business of running its ninth 500-mile stock car racing classic. The town had the enthusiastic support of some 80,000 visitors from all sections of the country.
The Ballet Theatre Foundation will benefit from the opening-night performance of the American Ballet Theatre on Sept. 16 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Instructions will go out tomorrow to the states on how to administer a little-noticed law signed last week by President Eisenhower. It makes those leaving the armed services from now on eligible for unemployment compensation.

Despite an increase in the number of judges and a tightening of preliminary procedures, it still takes up to thirty-eight months for a personal injury case to reach trial in New York City. Justice moves most slowly in Queens and most speedily in Bronx, according to a study by the Institute of Judicial Administration made public today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The American Legion Child Welfare Foundation announced grants totaling $32,500 today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 1 -- Nassau County's continued growth will again be reflected in a record school enrollment this month when an estimtated total of 281,000 youngsters start the new school year. This is an increase of about 18,000 pupils over last year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 -- Paul Hoffmann's Hother of Larchmont, which yesterday became the second successful defender of the Vineyard Trophy in the twenty-seven-year history of the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race, collected the bulk of the prizes at the annual awards luncheon today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- British troops paraded more than 1,300 Greek Cypriote youths before three British housewives and a hooded informer today in a hunt for the killers of a British serviceman.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 1 -- For the first time since the end of World War II there are definite indications that the breakneck pace of school construction is slowly catching up with the needs of Suffolk's burgeoning population.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Model changeovers and scattered work stoppages are combining to hold down auto industry output.
TORONTO, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Tom Bucy of Ann Arbor, Mich., won the open two-mile swimming race today at the Canadian National Exhibition in 40 minutes 15.5 seconds.

Jack Barry and Dan Enright, co-producers of "Twenty-One," said yesterday they had evidence that a former contestant on the television quiz program had attempted to blackmail them. The charge was met with a prompt denial.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Marine Sgt. V. D. Mitchell of Cardiff, Calif., won the national service rifle championship today over 1,800 competitors. He had 493 points of a possible 500 in the four-day shoot.
A young skin diver nearly lost his life off Staten Island yesterday in an underwater struggle with a six-foot sand shark that he had wounded with a harpoon.
The State Insurance Department has issued new regulations to protect the consumer in credit transactions, Julius S. Wikler, Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.
A smoldering fire broke out shortly before 4 P. M. yesterday at Pier 62 at Thirty-second Street and the Hudson River. The flames were brought under control within forty-five minutes.
PARIS, Sept. 1 (Reuters) -- Group Capt. Peter Townsend said tonight that he had "no intention" of returning to England.

Children in record numbers will flock to class when suburban schools reopen for the 1958-59 school year. In some communities, the new term begins today. In others, it will get under way later this week or next Monday, when New York City's public schools open.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Mobs of whites numbering 1,000 to 2,000 persons smashed windows in the Notting Hill district of London tonight. Negro residents fought back by hurling milk bottles and a gasoline bomb from windows and roofs.
Allison Danzig of The New York Times yesterday received a special award from the United States Lawn Tennis Association for "long and meritorious" service to the game.

A volume of biographical data on 2,000 Soviet personages is scheduled for Sept. 15 publication. It is called "Biographic Directory of the U. S. S. R." To be published by Scarecrow Press of New York, the 782-page volume has been in preparation for three years.
BEACH HAVEN, N. J., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Coast Guard search boats today found several aeronautical navigation charts near a spot where a small plane crash had been reported early this morning.
Definite signs of business improvement were reported by a majority of companies participating in nation-wide survey made by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Congress erred in choosing sharply increased Federal spending over tax reform to revive the economy, the First National City Bank of New York says in its monthly bank letter.

The executive council of the International Law Association nominated a new president yesterday afternoon at a closed meeting in the New York University Law Center, 40 Washington Square. The nominee's name will be announced to the first full session of the group this morning.

Schenley Industries, Inc., announced yesterday completion of a $103,750,000 financing program with seven insurance companies and fifteen banks. Under the arrangement, the company has had extended to March 1969, $28,750,000 of insurance company loans and obtained a new $75,000,000 line of credit from the banks.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 1 -- Six private homes here will be open to the public Sept. 23 for the annual tour sponsored by the Greenwich chapter of the National Society for Multiple Sclerosis. Proceeds from the tour will further research on the disease.

The election of a senior vice president and two vice presidents of the Texas Company (Texaco) was announced yesterday by Augustus C. Long, chairman of the board.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 (UPI) -- Milwaukee's Bob Buhl beat the Chicago Cubs, 2 -- 1, in his first start in more than three months in the opener of a double-header today. The Cubs routed the league-leading Braves 9 -- 3, in the second game.
LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The stock market took a turn for the better today. Minor gains predominated although turnover remained small as a result of the Far Eastern situation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Public support was advocated by an educator here today for the schools of religious and cultural groups wishing to preserve their values and culture. The advocate said he was not a partisan in any religious or regional argument.
