WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered an inquiry to determine whether to revoke the registration of Abraham Rosen, doing business as Al Rosen Co. of Boston, as a broker and dealer in securities.

TRENTON, Sept. 2 -- New Jersey was urged today to embark on a multi-million-dollar program designed to increase vastly its facilities for the care of mentally retarded, emotionally disturbed and delinquent children.

Mayor Wagner has made his commendable decision to finish out his second four-year term. Labor Day has come and gone, and so has summer's pause. Now, we hope, the season is right to get ahead with some unfinished city business. There is plenty waiting.
Investors returned from the Labor Day week-end yesterday restored in vim, vigor and optimism. Stocks made their best gains in a month.

The National Multiple Sclerosis Society said yesterday that tests on more than 500 patients had produced no evidence supporting the claim by a Philadelphia research worker that she had identified a germ as cause of multiple sclerosis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, welcomed today the changes that have brought the establishment of new independent nations in Africa.
GENEVA, Sept. 2 -- The scientists of the world took the first step today toward making the harnessing of the hydrogen bomb an international project.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 2 -- More than thirty foreign and local newsmen, including several Americans, and 400 Chinese Nationalist troops escaped unhurt early today when their convoy was ambushed off Quemoy by Communist torpedo boats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- H. J. Anslinger, Federal Narcotic Commissioner, attacked a recommendation today that free narcotics be supplied to certain types of addicts.
Norman P. Mason, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, announced yesterday the designation of a group of private citizens to review the valuation concepts of the F. H. A.

Most B coffee positions tumbled the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Several months closed that much lower. The volume was the largest since last Nov. 1.
The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $11,574,000 yesterday on short-term notes to finance five low-rent projects.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 2 -- A work stoppage at the Kennecott Copper Corporation's Utah Division ended today, at least temporarily. Members of Local 1438, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, fired the boilers serving Kennecott's power plant at Magna, Utah.

Aspirants for recognition in the entertainment field yesterday afternoon crowded into a rehearsal hall on the fourth floor of the Variety Arts Studio, 223 West Forty-sixth Street, to receive their final briefing before going into rehearsal.

The weight of his years and the burden of competing in two tournaments at the same time told heavily on Victor Seixas yesterday as he came from far behind to defeat Jon Douglas in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills, 4 -- 6, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 2 -- A 1,000-kilometer international sports car race is being planned for the new Daytona Beach International Speedway early next April. An F. I. A. (Federation International) approval has been applied for by Bill France, the speedway president.

Two brothers in their sixties, described by friends as inseparable companions, committed suicide last night by leaping from a sixth-floor loft window in the garment district. Roman Rebush, 65 years old, stepped onto a radiator and then jumped from the window at about 8 o'clock, the police said.
BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- The Massachusetts Republican Committee tonight named Charles Gibbons as the party's candidate for Governor in the November election.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Crude oil imports totaled 829,400 barrels a day in July in 104,700 barrels below the national allocation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Following is the text of an address today at the American Legion's national convention by Henry Cabot Lodge, United States representative at the United Nations:
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The stock market continued to advance today, with turnover in the most important sections expanding.
Government interviewers began taking the pulse of business in this city yesterday -- and found many merchants so busy that they had little time to answer the query, "How's business ?"
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 2 -- Paulo Guzzo resigned today as president of the Brazilian Coffee Institute, Government agency that supervises all phases of coffee operations in this country.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 2 -- Next season's Old Vie Company, which starts its operations in London in a fortnight, opened here tonight in the Church Assembly Hall with a new translation by Stephen Spender of Schiller's famous old drama, "Mary Stuart."
TOMS RIVER, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Business was so brisk at the Ocean County Jail here today that Sheriff Harry Roe called on the sheriffs of other New Jersey counties for assistance.
The long-awaited New York premiere of Sean O'Casey's comedy, "Cock-a-Doodle Dandy," will take place Nov. 12 at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse.
Eugene C. Reed has been elected to the board of Vanity Fair Paper Mills, Inc., here. He is sales manager.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- The sale of the Warner Brothers film processing laboratories, buildings and equipment to the Technicolor Corporation for an undisclosed sum was announced today by the two companies. The facilities are near the Warner Brothers Burbank studio and also in Brooklyn, New York.

The Wellington Fund, long a champion of balanced mutual funds, announced yesterday its entry into the common stock fund field through its new Wellington Equity Fund. A registration statement covering an initial offering of 2,000,000 shares to the public at $12 each was filed late last Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Fernando Berckemeyer, Ambassador of Peru, said today that a conference on copper, lead and zinc to be held in London this month "should be very helpful in improving the situation of these metals."
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 2 -- The Norfolk school board announced today that it had delayed the opening of city schools for two weeks, until Sept. 22.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Minneapolis approved a $9,000,000 bond issue today in its bid to attract a big-league baseball team and left any franchise shift in the hands of the Washington Senators and the American League.
Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday a new dividend policy under which it would distribute "approximately the full amount of the company's earnings" each year.
The unofficial end of summer was celebrated in traditional fashion in the Port of New York yesterday with the annual parade up the harbor of incoming ocean liners.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board is liberalizing its policy on mail subsidies for local service airlines.

POLITICS poked its head into the kitchen this week with the publication of "Distaff Democrats' Cook Book," a combined effort of the women's division of the New York State Democratic Committee. The recipes, essentially nonpartisan, cover all culinary categories from appetizers and soups to breads and desserts.
ABOARD LANDING SHIP, Formosa Strait, Sept. 2 -- The fire from the torpedo boats coming at us started slowly about forty minutes after midnight when we were six miles off Quemoy.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court was asked today to stop a legislative investigation of possible Communist tie-ups with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2 (UPI -- Herb Moford, a 30-year-old curveball pitcher who played in the minor leagues for eleven years, retired the first fifteen batters today and held the Kansas City Athletics to two hits as the Detroit Tigers triumphed, 6 -- 1.
For all the negative news about railroads in recent years, they still provide a form of travel that captures better than any other the romance of a great, broad nation ever on the move.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 2 -- The Danish Government approved today a contract between Denmark and Atlantic Ore, Ltd., for the construction of a port on Rype Island just south of Godthaab, Greenland.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Laszlo Ujvari, a Hungarian refugee who came back from the United States, today took the European springboard diving championship from a Soviet star.

JOHN BRENNAN is sad as he usually is at this time of year, because trout fishermen don't fish as much in the autumn as they ought to fish. Brennan, publicist of the New Hampshire Planning and Development Commission, thinks that a man who doesn't fish every day aint' fishing enough even if he does all of his fishing in New Hampshire.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Membership in the Teamsters Union climbed to a high of 1,618,097 in August despite the corruption charges leveled against it.
Those pencil-thin high heels the girls are wearing are a lot stronger than they look.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 2 -- Senator John J. Sparkman urged Southern Democrats tonight to remain loyal to national party leadership as a means to preserve racial segregation in the region's public schools.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Carmen Basilio, ex-welterweight and middleweight champion from Chittenango, N. Y., today protested the possible use of protective eyebrow patches by Art Aragon of Los Angeles in their twelve-round fight here Friday night.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP)--Chief Justice Carl V. Weygandt of Ohio will decide soon--probably late this week--whether to throw open the Sheppard murder case again.
Grants and appropriations totaling $1,195,588 for professional education and related needs were announced yesterday by the National Foundation as part of its expanded program in health and research.

THE union of South Africa's new Prime Minister is one of his country's most unyielding advocates of white supremacy. In a nation where whites are outnumbered 4 to 1 by non-whites Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd (pronounced fair-VOOT) has based his political career on extremism.

GENEVA, Sept. 2 -- Seventeen years after the dawn of the nuclear age, the nations of the world have installed a capacity of only 200,000 kilowatts of atomic electricity, enough to power a city of 200,000 persons.

WHEN John Landy of Australia visited our village a couple of years ago, the then holder of the world mile record of 3:58 was chatting pleasantly in frank, discursive fashion. Suddenly he lighted a conversational hot-foot and his listener leaped in surprise.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 16 points (20 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday. There was some increase in hedge selling toward the close.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Government expects to issue its first license for a new "small business investment company" around the turn of the year, the head of the Small Business Administration said today.

Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick strongly indicated yesterday that Bob Buhl, a Milwaukee Braves' right-hander recently taken off the disabled list, would be made eligible to pitch in the world series next month.

GENEVA, Sept. 2 -- A method of taming and using one of the most dangerous radioactive waste products from an atomic plant, radio strontium, has been disclosed by recent experiments in the chemistry of soils.
Sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area barely managed last month to reach the level of August, 1957.

YOUNG women who wear junior-sized clothes, once a neglected minority, are being pampered these days. Take the case of Franklin Simon, which has just coordinated all its junior departments on the Junior Terrace.

An urgent need for volunteers has united nine health and welfare agencies in a drive to recruit men and women to assist their professional staffs. At least 10,000 more such aides could be used, according to the announcement of the Joint Recruitment of Volunteers.
Seven new city schools, representing an outlay of $22,700, 000, will be opened next Monday when the new school term begins.

YONKERS, Sept. 2 -- Last in the field of six at the quarter pole in the pacing feature at Yonkers Raceway tonight, W. D. Direct rallied to take first place at the half-mile mark and remained there to score a length victory.
A 21-year-old Queens counterman was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the request of the police, who said he had murdered a young woman earlier in the day.
COLP, Ill., Sept. 2 (AP) -- School opened in Colp today with Negroes attending a local grade school and white students paying $200 tuition to attend schools in communities near by.
Columbia University will begin today to clear a site on Amsterdam Avenue between 116th and 117th Streets for its $17,000,000 East Campus development.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- A Pacific island coroner decided today that Eric de Bisschop, French explorer, was killed when he and four other men tried to ride their waterlogged raft across a reef to safety.

WARSAW, Sept. 2 -- The newspapers and the officials were full of solemn statements about the opening of school today but the 200 small boys and girls in the auditorium -- and their parents too -- concentrated on the wriggling white rabbit.
Eight candidates for the Supreme Court in the Second and Tenth Judicial Districts yesterday were assured of bipartisan nominations at informal conferences of Republican and Democratic county leaders.

The Second United Nations International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy, meeting in Geneva, has begun two weeks of frank and unrestricted exchange of information on how to harness the vast powers of the atom for the peaceful pursuits of mankind -- electricity, medicine, biology, agriculture and research into the secrets of nature.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The butcher hog supply of 10,000 head today was the largest since the Monday following the Memorial Day week-end. Prices were steady to 25 cents lower.
A searching look at the New York Thruway's financial and traffic future is under way by order of Clinton B. F. Brill, its new chairman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today began hearings on financial reports filed by the Cornucopia Gold Mine, Inc. of Pittsburgh.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 2 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. said today that school-closing notices had been drafted and would be dispatched promptly to authorities in any locality where Negro and white pupils were assigned to the same public schools.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 2--The school board of Arlington County, Va., disclosed in Federal court here today that it had rejected applications from all thirty Negro students who had sought to attend white public schools.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Dr. Verwoerd, who was chosen Prime Minister today by a parliamentary caucus of the Nationalist party after two ballots, was to be sworn in by Governor General Ernest G. Jansen later today.

A critical commentary on higher education by Prof. George Williams of the Rice Institute, Houston, Tex., entitled "Some of My Best Friends Are Professors," will be published Oct. 24 by Abelard-Schoman. Professor Williams contends that what is wrong with the American college teaching is the professors.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A 30-year-old marine technical sergeant, Michael Pietroforte of Rockville Centre, L. I., today shot the first perfect score in the fifty-five years of the National Trophy individual rifle match.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The Secretary of Defense assured the nation tonight that the United States was ahead of the Soviet Union in over-all military power "in being -- in the here and now."
HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 2 -- President Eisenhower has declined a request by the Governors of five Eastern states for a conference on the area redevelopment bill.
AFTER their six months of trouping in Asia and Australia, the New York City Ballet has returned home to the City Center, and everything is fine and dandy.
The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway experienced its most profitable month of 1958 in August. Increased grain and steel shipments offset declines in movement of automobile parts during the month.
NOT even one of Bergdorf Goodman's luxury-loving customers can be classified as having everything until she owns a Leslie Morris design.
JEWETT CITY, Conn., Sept. 2 Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff opened his campaign for re-election today in this eastern Connecticut community.
Traffic accidents during the three-day Labor Day week-end took 420 lives, exactly the number predicted by the National Safety Council.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- Striking workers at various plants of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation returned to their jobs today. But the Chrysler Corporation reported that 2,750 workers had not returned to their jobs and that 1,850 others had been laid off because of parts shortages stemming from one of the walkouts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Plumbers and Pipefitters Union reached an agreement today on a pattern-setting wage increase and revised hiring procedures.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The first space traveler will not have to be a superman or a psychological freak, a pschologist said here today.
GENEVA, Sept. 2 -- An irradiated atom here today at the Second International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy is illuminating one of the most baffling problems of medical science.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 -- Senator William F. Knowland chided Attorney General Edmund G. Brown today for failing to accept his challenge to a series of public debates in their campaign for Governor.
I should like to rebut the views on the Tenth Amendment advanced in a letter by W. J. Holman Jr. in your issue of Aug. 30.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 2 (AP) -- British troops fought a five-hour battle with small arms, rockets and grenades today against a Cypriote underground band holed up in a stone barn. One Briton and four Cypriotes were killed.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 2 -- Dr. Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd, Minister of Native Affairs, was elected Prime Minister of South Africa today. He succeeds Johannes G. Strijdom, who died Aug. 24.
The proposed abandonment of the Jay Street Connecting Railroad, a three-mile-long freight barrier along the Brooklyn waterfront, was opposed yesterday by the New York State Department of Commerce.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Swedish amateur sports officials today cleared Herb Elliott of any suspicion of professionalism in connection with the use of his name and picture in a soft drink advertisement.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 2 (AP) -- An $877,000,000 education aid bill was signed today by President Eisenhower. He said it would not do all that was necessary in a scientific world.

Investment bankers are groping in a fog to find a right price for new bonds. The "right price" in terms of yields is neither too steep for the issuing corporation, nor too low for the benefit of investors. The uncertainty is largely a result of the sharp decline in Government securities and a simultaneous bulge in the backlog of unmarketed new corporate securities.
The Labor Day holiday was expected to result this week in the first decline in steel production in nine weeks.
CORTLAND, N. Y., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The first permanent television teaching program in the state was dedicated today and went into operation with demonstration Spanish and spelling lessons.

Dinner and the Races at the Yonkers Raceway on Oct. 1 will be the first benefit given for the Leake and Watts Children's Home in Yonkers in twenty-seven years. The home, founded in 1831, is expanding its program.
The President recently stated that he was "going to stress getting down those deficits and keeping our money sound so that America can have a good, healthy, thriving, progressive economy."
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 2 -- Chile's bitterly fought Presidential campaign ended tonight. The outcome of Thursday's voting remains tensely uncertain.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The site of the ancient Lydian city of Sardis, once the capital of King Croesus, has been located by American archaeologists. It was found after two months of searching and only a few days before the experts left for home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Consumers continued to reduce their installment debt in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. However, the decline of $32,000,000 in consumer credit outstanding was smaller than in other recent months.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept 2 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus asserted today that the Federal Government was planning to use force against the citizens of Little Rock while allowing labor union racketeers to go unpunished.
Warwick Legler, Inc., has picked up new business estimated at $1,500,000 a year and Campbell-Mithun, Inc., appears to have a foot in the door of a similar amount.
The Sheraton Corporation of America, the nation's second largest hotel chain, announced yesterday it had entered the fast-growing comprehensive credit card field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Administration is ready with two plans to carry out any United States marshals to carry order insisting on the integration of Little Rock Central High School Sept. 15.

Today's new film is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's Western drama "The Badlanders," starring Alan Ladd, Ernest Borgnine and Katy Jurado, at a number of neighborhood theatres. Aaron Rosenberg produced and Delmer Daves directed. The screen play by Richard Collins is based on a novel by W. R. Burnett.
CAIRO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Al Ahram, a newspaper that often reflects the views of President Gamal Abdel Nasser, accused the United States and Britain today of arming Israel anew for aggressive purposes.
The United States should revise its attitude toward the International Court of Justice at The Hague, Attorney General William P. Rogers asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- The Republican and Democratic national chairmen urged all eligible servicemen today to study the candidates and issues in the fall Congressional elections and then vote.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Kerr Stable's Round Table will be flown to Atlantic City Race Course from Chicago tomorrow to run in the invitation $100,000 United Nations Handicap Sept. 13, Trainer Bill Molter advised the track today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Secretary of State Dulles held a long conference today with the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the military situation in the Formosa Strait.
Plans to double the size of the Morristown branch of Bamberger's-New Jersey, Newark department store, are being held up for lack of parking space.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 2 -- The Icelandic Coast Guard suffered a reverse today as it tried sterner measures against British trawlers challenging the new twelve-mile fishery limit. Abandoning yesterday's tactics of merely taking down names, Icelanders armed only with their fists tried to arrest two British vessels trawling along the eastern coast five miles inside the new line.
Twenty-one counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are looking to a meeting to be held here Friday for important decisions on the future role of the Metropolitan Regional Council.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz sought today to enjoin a group of milk dealers who, he said, had conspired to fix milk prices in the Syracuse area.

The proposal to spend over one million dollars to restore a work of at least debatable artistic value -- the Soldiers and Sailors Monument -- must have something of the fantastic to anyone who pauses to think about it.
ALGIERS, Sept. 2 -- A sixteen-member control commission went to work here today to supervise preparations in Algeria for the referendum on Constitutional reform.
The death of a 29-year-old hoodlum, who was waiting trial with Vito Genovese, underworld racketeer, on narcotics charges, is being investigated by the police to determine if he was slain.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 2 -- President Eisenhower summoned Secretary of State Dulles today to meet him here Thursday morning for a full discussion of what White House sources called the "serious situation" in the Formosa Strait.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Grain futures resumed today their retreat from last week's run-up on the Board of Trade.

PARIS, Sept. 2 -- The Ministry of the Interior, charged with France's internal security, announced tonight that 14,000 North Africans had been interrogated in the eight days since a wave of Algerian nationalist terrorism broke out in France.

OUR two books for today are very different, yet they are alike in one respect. Both are described as novels on their jackets. And neither is one. "The Eighth Day of the Week,"* by Marek Hlasko is a long short story. "House of Many Rooms," by Robin White is a collection of eleven short stories about the members of one family.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, returning yesterday from a two-month tour of Europe, said "juvenile delinquency is an epidemic all over the world."

Ford Frick, baseball's commissioner, said yesterday he would not ask the two major leagues to vote for expansion to ten clubs, nor would he make any recommendations along that line at the joint meeting in Chicago next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Harold J. Gibbons aggressively defended the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today against a Senator's accusation that it was a haven for criminals.
Steels and business machines were weak yesterday, and metals and oils were uncertain, but the market as a whole made minor gains. The New York Times rail average hit a new 1958 high.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 20 points (15 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday in moderate trading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Republican and Democratic national chairmen signed a pledge today for a fair campaign.

The late Claude Bowers, who was United States Ambassador to Chile for fourteen years, wrote that "he who sets foot on Chilean soil is free." These truly democratic people are to have their Presidential election today.

SALZBURG, Austria, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- An American scientist assured delegates to the conference of the International Union of Marine Insurance today that there was no danger of atom-powered merchant shipping polluting the seas.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Tony Anthony gained a split ten-round decision over Archie McBride tonight on the strength of two midfight knockdowns.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 3 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has signed a bill giving the Federal Trade Commission the right to police some activities of chain stores and other businesses engaged in meat packing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- High bids that may total as much as $223,795 were received today for gas leasing of about 16,000 acres of Federal lands in the Gubik Gas Field in Alaska.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 3 -- A group of air force officers today barred Air Secretary Roberto Huerta's entrance to his Secretariat building where he was to give the oath to three replacements for top posts. The group of officers were later confined to their bases.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Britain's gold and dollar reserves rose $5,000,000 during August to $3,089,000,000, the highest level in seven years.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman told the Liberal party yesterday that he had been "shocked and deeply distressed" by events at the recent Democratic state convention in Buffalo.
The First National City Bank of New York in its September Bank Letter finds the recent action by Congress in raising the Federal debt limit to $288 billion a strangely ironic gesture.
" WHERE'S everybody?" growled Casey Stengel as he looked around the half-deserted clubhouse.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- John F. Cuneo, a director of Fairbanks, Morse Co. and a stanch supporter of management in the heavy machinery concern's proxy battle with the Penn-Texas Corporation, has resigned.

The group of American steel-men who visited the Soviet Union last spring published their formal report yesterday, under the auspices of the American Iron and Steel Institute. It contained some kind words for the progress of the Russian steel industry.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The general advance continued on the stock market today. The market was helped by yesterday's firmness on Wall Street and the expectation (subsequently borne out) that the August gold and dollar reserves position would be strengthened.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Former President Harry S. Truman assailed the Eisenhower Administration's defense program philosophy today as "wicked" and "disastrous."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration reported today that a new ruling it had put in force would enable many of the million Korea veterans who dropped out of G. I. training to resume their education this fall.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 3 -- Chile will elect a new President tomorrow. A record vote after one of the bitterest campaigns in Chilean history is expected despite predictions of rain for the central zone.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- A Presidential emergency board recommended today that contract talks between American Airlines and its pilots be resumed under conditions "devoid of mutual suspicion."

The Greek population on Cyprus has just observed a day of mourning for the dead of its underground amid indications that the truce proclaimed by all sides four weeks ago is giving way to new violence. The British attempt to round up the underground is leading to new gun battles followed by Greek retaliation and the Greek Cypriote Right and Left are starting to fight each other.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) -- Man may soon realize his "cherished dream" of making flights to outer space, a Russian scientist said today.
GENEVA, Sept. 3 -- The annual profit to science and industry from radioactive isotopes can now be reckoned in hundreds of millions, whether dollars or rubles.

The anxiety with which the hemisphere keeps its eye on Venezuela is an entirely friendly one. These are naturally difficult days and months while that shaken country recovers from the harmful effects of ten years of a brutal and predatory military dictatorship. An attempted military comeback would almost certainly fail today, but the threat requires unceasing vigilance.

It seemed likely yesterday that Jimmy Wilson would not be executed in Montgomery, Ala., tomorrow for the crime of robbing an eighty-two-year-old woman of $1.95 in July, 1957. The Alabama Supreme Court was scheduled to rule on Wilson's application for a rehearing, and this was expected to mean an automatic reprieve.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- Competitive committees headed by Republicans and Democrats will seek voluntary campaign contributions of $2 and more from each of the 15,000 employes of a California manufacturing concern this fall.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Private car pools took parochial school pupils to their first day of classes here today even though a referendum last month approved their right to public transportation.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 3 -- The Marine Division of the Huntington Town Police Department is completing a successful year in its efforts to control the growing motorboat traffic.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- At the Pentagon today, associates of Vice Admiral Roland Nesbit Smoot characterized him as "smooth, quick-thinking, nonchalant."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Construction set a record in August, figures from the Labor and Commerce Departments showed today. The figures reflected a steady advance in publicly owned construction, some of which originated as an anti-recession measure.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Britain protested to Iceland today against the boarding of the British trawler Northern Foam by Icelandic Coast Guardsmen.
A knife that may have been the weapon used Tuesday in the murder of a physician and his wife in their Staten Island home was found by the police last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The current discussion of war over Quemoy and Matsu at least illustrates how completely the people of the United States and their representatives in Congress have entrusted the war-making power to a few officials the executive branch of the government.
This week's trans-Atlantic tide of returning students includes sixty who spent an unusual summer vacation in West Africa, taking part in a traveling seminar.

A plot of land 175 by 100 feet on the west side of Longfellow Avenue, 100 feet north of Seneca Avenue, in the Bronx, has been purchased from the city for improvement with a one-story factory building. The Joseph G. Platzner Company was the broker.

It is a relief to see the easing of Middle East tension. While the basic causes remain, nevertheless the United Nations has established a temporary atmosphere in which it is possible to labor for the elimination of these causes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- The United States asked the United Nations today to take steps to promote the development of outer space for peaceful purposes as an "important and urgent matter."
A series of extraordinary, punitive premium assessments levied by London marine underwriters against a large segment of the shipping fleet owned by Greeks over the world was disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Following is the text of former President Harry S. Truman's speech to the American Legion convention here today:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The United States today eased its restrictions on some items embargoed in trade with Communist countries but clamped down on others.

NOW that the bluefish are busting out all over the nearby ocean it is time for all of us to spend a moment in meditation. But we must not close our eyes; when we open them again the bluefish may be gone.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation announced yesterday an arrangement for distribution of Samuel Goldwyn's forthcoming screen version of "Porgy and Bess."
The "Tiffany of music stores," Liberty Music Shops, Inc., is more prosperous than ever despite its inflexible one-price policy in a business riddled with discounters and cut-throat competition.
The portion of the Globe Theatre Building fronting for twenty-four feet at 1555 Broadway near Forty-sixth Street has been sold by Webb Knapp, Inc., to the Rubinstein-Klein Realty Corporation.

" The Exploding Metropolis," a survey of American cities by the editors of Fortune, will be published Oct. 2 by Doubleday. It is a warning to city-dwellers and suburbanites of "the coming chaos" in city and suburb alike if big city projects and suburban overdevelopment are not studied from the viewpoint of human requirements. The book will have an introduction by William H. Whyte Jr., author of "Organization Man."

Following is the text of sixteen questions put to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan by the Liberal party and his answers. Mr. Hogan is the Democratic candidate for United States Senator and is seeking Liberal endorsement.

WASHINGTON Sept. 3 (AP) -- Under terms of Judge Letts' court order the teamsters have a right to call a new convention after the order has been in effect a year -- with the proviso that the monitors will supervise selection of convention delegates.

Coffee futures were active and trading was nervous yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was switching and evening of holdings as traders awaited further developments in Brazil following the resignation on Tuesday of Paulo Guzzo, head of the Brazilian Coffee Institute.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 (AP)--Joe Adcock pounded a three-run homer off a sign atop the left-field stands tonight, leading Milwaukee to a 11-5 victory over the Philadelphia Phils and moving the world champion Braves a step closer to their second National League pennant.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 3 -- Automotive engineers have finally recognized that not all motorists are contortionists.

GOOD things come in pairs. If one is permitted a paltry pun, they also come in pears. From the first week in September through the end of October, large, bell-shaped Bartletts with a clear, yellow skin and a superlative flesh are available here in abundance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:The recent enactment by Congress of the so-called "ex-President bill" granting pensions and benefits to ex-Presidents and their widow invites attention to a development that has been slowly reaching rosive proportions in both the liberal and state political scenes.
A city-wide appeal has been made so that the Children's Blood Foundation can expand its work with children and research in their blood diseases.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 -- The case of ten Negroes pleading in Federal District Court here that they be permitted to enroll at a branch of Louisiana State University in New Orleans was continued today by Judge Herbert W. Christenberry until Monday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 3 -- Rebel forces announced tonight that they would drop the strike that has gone on since May 9.
NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- A final legal effort to stay the New York Central and Erie Railroads from discontinuing their ferry service between New Jersey and New York was started here today.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 3 (AP) -- This was Britain's day at the European swimming championships -- mostly because of a 17-year-old schoolboy from Aberdeen.
LA PAZ, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Bolivian Government has charged Russia with "economic aggression" by selling tin at low prices, and will ask the United States for emergency help.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Employes must come out of their offices and "fight" like psychologists to solve problems of employe relations, a psychologist asserted here today. He said it would not suffice for them to use the industrial psychologists' analyses of their employes' complaints only to smooth over bad situations.

Murray I. Gurfein will get an Interim appointment to the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, it was reported yesterday. Mr. Gurfein was a top assistant of former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey when Mr. Dewey was prosecutor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- United States diplomatic sources said today that the United States would intervene if a Chinese Communist attack on Quemoy threatened to overwhelm the Nationalists there.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 3 (AP) -- German today won the two international events on the first day of the international horse show.
WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 3 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge today set Sept. 11 for the trial in New Haven of suits by two minority party candidates for places on the state election ballot in November.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Herb Elliott ran the second fastest mile in history today, 3 minutes 55.4 seconds, as two other runners in an invitation race at White City Stadium also broke 4 minutes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The United States recently sold a small amount of arms to Israel, the State Department said today.
THERE was another charming program last night at the City Center, where the New York City Ballet was giving the second performance of its four-week season.

A mother and her 8-year-old son were seperated briefly by a closed IND subway door yesterday morning. As a result, 300 passengers were knocked about in a sudden stop, and eight of them said they had been injured. The train was taken out of service after having tied up the track for almost three-quarters of an hour.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Montgomery Ward Co. should do better in the second half of fiscal 1958 than in the first, given a modest improvement in the economy, the company said today.
Hopes for an American victory in the national tennis championship received a heavy blow yesterday at Forest Hills Stadium, Queens.

Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for United States Senator, said yesterday that he had urged United States action in the United Nations to direct world attention to the repression of Jews by the Soviet Union.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 3 -- An armed man was captured in a fifteen-mile chase on the Merritt Parkway today after he had seized a 13-year-old Greenwich High School boy as a hostage.

ADANA, Turkey, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A United States Air Force transport plane carrying seventeen persons has disappeared on a flight near Soviet Armenia, where Russian fighters shot down an American plane June 27.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Governor of Virginia and the District Federal Judge in Norfolk have separately made statements which have the common quality of accepting certain realities about racial school integration that the extremists on both sides of the issue reject.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. accused the police of brutality today after he had been arrested on a charge of loitering.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Government was recruiting deputy United States marshals in Arkansas today for possible use if Central High School was reopened on an integrated basis.
The first man to plead not guilty and go to trial on a jaywalking charge did not have to pay the $2 fine yesterday.

Three railroad employes were injured and hundreds of commuters were delayed last night by a short circuit flash at Grand Central Terminal. A short time later, in a dock-throwing attack against one of the trains carrying passengers who had been delayed, the engineer was hurt.

The Ideal Fastener Corporation is celebrating its twentieth year of making zippers with the introduction of a new type of slide fastener it says cannot snag or catch on the material it holds together.
The Hecht Company, which operates thirteen department stores, had net earnings of $3,400,728, or $3.67 a share, in the twelve months ended July 31, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- An early convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to elect officers and to obtain discharge of the board of monitors is under consideration, union sources said tonight.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 3 -- Hugh Goodson, who heads the twelve-man Royal Yacht Squadron syndicate that is the sponsor of the British America's Cup challenge, Sceptre, arrived today.

An attempt to reduce one of the oldest and most complicated questions in international law to a few simple, practical principles engrossed some of the world's leading experts for several hours here yesterday.

A minority group of farmers in the New York milkshed went on strike yesterday but failed to stop deliveries from a three-state area into the city. The farmers, who received no support from the powerful Teamsters Union, demanded $6 a hundredweight (46.5 quarts) for their milk, compared with the July price of $4.20.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 3 -- The first round of Britain's fishery conflict with Iceland is nearing an end, sources close to the Government said tonight. But a second may follow immediately.
IN "Ice Capades of '59," which opened last night at Madison Square Garden, John H. Harris, its producer, has striven for a universality of appeal.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Sept. 3 -- A temporary injunction was issued today to restrain the United States Golf Association from interfering with a miniature golf tournament in Asbury Park.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller expressed serious doubt today that his election as Governor would insure restoration of any "forgiveness" in the state income tax.
HERZLIA, Israel, Sept. 3 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion urged American Jews tonight to use their influence to help Israel get new arms from the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned today that the failure of many countries to meet financial quotas might weaken the United Nations force guarding the border between Israel and Egypt.

In the face of a steady decline in passenger traffic, the nation's two largest railroads -- the Pennsylvania and the New York Central -- plan to seek higher fares, a move that almost certainly will drive more passengers to competing forms of transportation.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 -- United States scientists said today they believed they were on the verge of scoring the technological triumph of producing a controlled thermonuclear reaction on a laboratory scale.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Charges against four auto-racing officials accused of violating the state's Sunday "blue law" were dismissed here today when the grand jury refused to indict them.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- As the second production of its new season, the Paris Opera performed Francis Poulenc's "The Carmelites" tonight. This was the seventeenth performance for the opera, which is high score for a contemporary piece. There is credit in this record for the work and for France's leading lyric theatre.
TRENTON, Sept. 3 -- Attorney General David D. Furman today ordered an investigation of union organizing activities in the knitting - mill industry of metropolitan north Jersey.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 3 -- A Moroccan Government spokesman indicated today that Morocco had decided to join the eight-nation Arab League.
An aviation industry group set up to protect the public from excessive aircraft noise has given the Boeing 707 jet airliner a tentative, non-binding vote of approval.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -- Merian C. Cooper, producer and long a friend of the late Lieut. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault, today announced his plans to film "Chennault of China," the story of the famed Far Eastern soldier and flyer.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 3 -- Edwin G. Michaelian, County Executive of Westchester and Republican chairman of White Plains, was elected temporary chairman of the Westchester County Committee at an emergency meeting today of executive leaders.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle and his Government completed today their task of creating a constitution for France and her overseas holdings. The regime was invested June 1 with extraordinary powers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The grain futures market was headed toward a strong and broad price recovery until the final few minutes today on the Board of Trade.
Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central Railroad, said yesterday that a $6,500,000 tax load on commuter facilities was "driving us out of the city."

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 3 -- The start of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's twenty-sixth annual fall Race Week series was highlighted by close finishes as a fleet of 195 sailed on Manhasset Bay today.

A man identified as Raymond Richard Rossi, a pianist, was killed yesterday when fire swept through a twelfth-floor room of the Flanders Hotel, 135 West Forty-seventh Street. Two other persons were taken to Roosevelt Hospital.
Does the amount of alcohol in a drunken driver's blood give a clue to the kind of accident he might have?
MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union protested to the United States today against alleged launching of American camera-carrying and radio transmitting balloons over Soviet airspace.
Dr. John J. Theobald was installed yesterday as Superintendent of Schools.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 3 -- South Africa's new Prime Minister, Dr. Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd, and his Cabinet were sworn into office today. Meanwhile the more liberal elements of white South Africa -- even in Dr. Verwoerd's own Nationalist party -- pondered seriously the country's future under its uncompromisingly segregationist leader.
The value of waterfront railroads to business and industry in Brooklyn was emphasized yesterday by members of a special committee of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.

Debts, taxes and administrative expenses cut heavily into the $7,533,010 estate left by Mrs. Alice Pleydell-Bouverie, it was disclosed yesterday in an accounting on file in Surrogate's Court. Mrs. Bouverie, who was a sister of Vincent Astor, died on July 19, 1956.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 31 (UPI) -- Duke Snider poled a two-run homer over the short left-field screen in the last of the ninth inning tonight to power the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 5 -- 3 victory over over San Francisco. This marked the first time the Dodgers had beaten the Giants two games in a row this season.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- British diplomacy is gradually accepting the idea that the position of the United States toward the Quemoy and Matsu Island must be supported by the Government of Britain.

The Gabriel Company, Cleveland manufacturer of products for the automotive, communication and aircraft industries, plans to acquire the Talco Engineering Corporation, Mesa, Ariz. Talco produces rocketry and missile devices.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 3 -- Mrs. H. J. Robertson is heading a committee of East Hampton summer residents planning an informal evening with a group from the Orpheus Club.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 3 -- The adoption of a program to "revitalize" the Federal Home Loan Bank System and make it a more effective source of central bank credit for the nation's 4,500 member savings and loan associations was urged here today.
Delaware borrowed $17,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance highway, school and other capital improvements.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- The Inland Steel Company began closing its big Indiana Harbor works in East Chicago today as a wildcat strike by about 260 employes kept about 19,000 other workers from their jobs. The men walked out over relocation of a garage.

Except for his fine conformation, the Argentine-bred Ocelote had little in his favor as far as the 19,019 fans were concerned at Belmont Park yesterday. The 6-year-old import was a fine-looking animal, somewhat on the big side, but handsome none the less.

RENO, Nevada, Sept. 3 -- Grant Sawyer, a 39-year-old District Attorney from Elko, won an upset victory in Nevada's gubernatorial primary election yesterday. He defeated two major opponents and most of the old guard of the Democratic party.

YONKERS, Sept. 3 -- M. B. Milam's Senator Byrd, starting from the pole position, triumphed with Jimmy Jordan in the sulky in 2:04 2/5 in the Hyde Park pacing feature before 23,954 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
An advertising man whose background is primarily creative has been named to a top post with McCann-Erickson, Inc.
NEWARK, Sept. 3 -- The opening session here today of hearings by a subcommittee of the House Un-American Activities Committee ended on a note of disorder.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 3 -- Weatherly and Easterner reached the end of the America's Cup defense trail today when both lost for the third straight time in the final trials.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The senior United States commander here promised Nationalist China today that more help was on the way to meet the Communist siege of Nationalist-held islands.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 3 -- Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman denied today a Norfolk school board's motion that racial integration here be delayed until the fall of 1959.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, Aug. 27, there were:
STRAIGHTENING out the wrinkles in the wash and wear controversy has placed du Pont in the role of policeman.

Stanley Kramer's "The Defiant Ones" has been scheduled to open Sept. 24 at the Victoria Theatre, it was announced yesterday by United Artists. Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier are starred in the drama, directed and produced by Mr. Kramer from an original screen play by Nathan E. Douglas and Harold Jacob Smith.
Forty years ago yesterday women in New York State voted for the first time in a state-wide election.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 -- The scientific calm of the Second United Nations International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy was broken today by a United States suggestion that thermonuclear explosives could be used for peaceful purposes.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 -- A Negro witness at closed hearings of a House Un-American Activities subcommittee here today asked why the "conspiracy" to nullify school integration rulings had not been investigated.

TOKYO, Sept. 3 -- Three Japanese constitutional experts are scheduled to go to the United States next month to interview General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and others on the background of Japan's post-war Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Justice John Marshall Harlan of the Supreme Court refused today to order the release of five men who were jailed after they had refused to answer questions about a gangland meeting at Apalachin, N. Y.
If current efforts to create an international scientific body to supervise space exploration are successful, the United States is not expected to press for a United Nations role in this field.

TO make history palatable, one of the popular techniques devised is what might be called the "day" look at an event or man. It is the antithesis of the long look professional historians employ to illuminate their subjects. Lively writers who can make the past come alive and able researchers who apply journalistic methods to discover new materials are helpful if by their efforts a wider public becomes interested in history's meaning.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing output of copper immediately at its large mines in Morenci, Ajo and Bisbee, Ariz.

A myriad of art exhibits in American Middletowns will soon be displaying the tints of autumn. The show may be in an improvised gallery, or on a roped-off corner of Main Street anywhere between Portland and Key West, or Seattle and San Francisco.
CAIRO, Sept. 3 -- Israel did not send a representative to an emergency meeting of the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission today on the Gaza Strip-Israeli frontier.
The General Electric Company agreed yesterday to a request by one of its unions to defer wage increases due members for two weeks pending consideration of the union's bargaining proposal.

News on the situation in and near the Taiwan Strait was coming from a number of directions yesterday. In Washington Air Force Gen. Curtis E. LeMay was preparing to leave for Taiwan. At the same time Secretary Dulles was meeting with representatives of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and planning to go to Newport today to consult with the President, presumably about the crisis created by the Red Chinese bombardment of Quemoy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- There was praise and criticism today for legislation just signed by President Eisenhower to provide tax relief for the whisky industry.

Wanted: More metropolitan golf courses. Officials of some twenty golf associations in the metropolitan area are facing a problem. Tournaments are on the increase, yet the facilities are limited. There are approximately 150 private clubs within a fifty-mile radius of the city and they are asked repeatedly by men's and women's golf associations to play host to tournaments.
GREENSBORO, N. C., Sept. 3 --Almost no stir developed today as the second year of public school integration began in this Piedmont city of 119,000.

Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.
The captain of an American Liberty ship has disappeared from his vessel about 800 miles west of Britain, the Isbrandtsen Company reported here yesterday.

Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher, director of obstetrics and gynecology at Mount Sinai Hospital, termed "spurious" yesterday any implication that the fitting of contraceptive devices was not "proper and accepted therapeutic practice."
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 3 -- India and Pakistan have agreed to exchange prisoners captured in the recent border clashes.

A new toy -- the plastic hoop -- has spun full-blown on at the American scene. In a matter of weeks it has rolled up volume estimated by manufacturers and distributors at 20,000,000 units worth close to $30,000,000 at retail. Makers are spinning trying to keep up with the spiraling demand. The end, if there is one, seems nowhere in sight.

In view of the fact that our city government is frequently accused of neglecting business and industry, it is only fair to balance the scales by acknowledging publicly on behalf of New York's second-largest manufacturing industry an enlightened and far-reaching contribution by the City of New York.

HONG KONG, Sept. 3 -- Communist China has embarked on a momentous program establishing gigantic "people's communes" that will eventually sweep away the cooperative and become the nation's basic social unit.

Provision has been made for Theatre Guild subscribers to witness "The World of Suzie Wong." As directed by Joshua Logan, the dramatization by Paul Osborn of Richard Mason's novel will be unveiled Oct. 14 at the Broadhurst. The attraction, which another management is sponsoring, becomes the Guild's first subscription offering of the 1958-59 campaign.
NOT often seen on Fifth Avenue is the sight of a be-flowered pink picket fence and smiling gatemen. Yet, such was the scene at 54th Street yesterday.

PARIS, Sept. 3 -- The Tunisian and Moroccan Embassies made diplomatic representations to the French Government today against a police order that has forbidden the streets of the Paris region to North Africans after 9:30 P. M.

NEWPORT, R. I. (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today granting Federal charter to the Big Brothers of America, a volunteer organization founded in New York City in 1904. Men volunteers work with boys between 6 and 16 years old in the movement, aimed at preventing and correcting juvenile delinquency.
CAIRO, Sept. 3--President Gamal Abdel Nasser accused the United States and Britain today of still seeking the destruction of Arab nationalism by arming "Zionist" nationalism.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Administration took its fourth step in as many weeks today to effect major reductions in the budget, present and future.
QUEMOY, Sept. 3 -- A military and civilian hospital here was shelled by Chinese Communist artillery today and yesterday.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP)--A Bomarc interceptor missile streaked across the Atlantic today. It reportedly had been fired remotely from 1,500 miles away.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The British Government formally announced tonight that the "utmost strictness" would be used to curb the race riots that have erupted in London and Nottingham.

The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, continuing its inquiry into quiz show practices yesterday, asked to see the program files and financial records of "Twenty-One" and questioned six former contestants on "Dotto."

A new method for converting heat directly into electricity was announced yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. It uses little-known substances called thermoelectric materials to produce electricity simply, silently and without moving parts.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 3 -- A stocky man with a beaming countenance embarked today on the last leg of a campaign aimed at producing California's second Democratic Governor of the century.

Mikhail Tal, the Soviet national chess champion, and Oscar Panno of Argentina, adjourned after forty-one moves in the seventeenth round of the interzonal tournament at Portoroz last night, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

Two men, described as occupants of a Brooklyn Heights house where a cache of submachine gun parts and ammunition had been seized, were released yesterday in $1,000 bail. They were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court on Sullivan law violations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 3 -- Rapid and continuing transition from a subsistence to a money economy in several of its areas is the most significant development in Africa since the turn of the century, United Nations economists said today.
The New York City Opera Company will open its fall season at the City Center on Tuesday, Oct. 7, with the first United States performance of Strauss' "Die schweigsame Frau."

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 3--An Arlington County school official conceded in Federal court today that about a third of the white students in junior high schools were at or below the scholastic level of Negroes barred from these schools on scholastic grounds.

A group of short sellers of E. L. Bruce Company shares began court action yesterday to prevent the American Stock Exchange from requiring them to close out their contracts. The Exchange announced Tuesday that it would lift on Friday a ban that had deferred closing out of contracts on the stock. The decision meant that the short sellers would have to deliver stock on demand.

" Premier May," a French-made comedy with Yves Montand, Nicole Berger and Walter Chiari, has been scheduled to open Monday, Sept. 15, at the Baronet Theatre. It will follow the current run of "Law and Disorder.
CAIRO, Sept. 4 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and Dag Hammarskjold met tonight in crucial talk of the United Nations Secretary General's peace mission to the Middle East.

The various factions involved in the impasse over the short interest in the E. L. Bruce Company met yesterday for several hours but failed to solve their problems. These questions still remain: Is there a corner in the stock and at what price should the squeezed short sellers settle their contracts?
VALHALLA, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- The discovery of a primitive tunnel believed to have been a passage for American patriots in the Revolutionary War was reported by volunteer firemen here today.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Britain is willing to provide nearly 40,000,000 ($112,000,000) in financial aid to India, the Treasury announced today.

WAYNE, Pa., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Simeon II, exiled King of Bulgaria, became a plebe today at Valley Forge Military Academy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The President, according to today's Newport statement by Secretary of State Dulles, has not yet decided that Communist Chinese belligerence in the Taiwan Strait area endangers the security of Taiwan. If or when he should decide this affirmatively he has the prior endorsement of Congress for any use he may make to this purpose of the armed forces of the United States.

NEWARK, Sept. 4 -- For the second successive day, hearings being conducted in the Federal Courthouse here by a subcommittee of the House Committee an Un-American Activities were highlighted by an outbreak.
SOPHIE of Saks Fifth Avenue is the envy of her profession. This fashion designer does what she likes and her customers like what she does.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Justice Department invoked the Civil Rights Act of 1957 for the first time today in a suit to stop alleged violations of Negro voting rights.
VAN BUREN, Ark., Sept. 4 (AP) -- White high school students banded here today to oppose racial integration by physical force. They appealed to Gov. Orval E. Faubus for support.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Calvin Griffith, president of the Senators, refused to tip his hand today in the face of two new legal moves aimed at blocking transfer of the Washington baseball club to Minneapolis.

Gasoline stocks fell slightly in the week ended last Friday to 173,470,000 barrels from 173,756,000 a week earlier. A year before, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute, stocks were 171,683,000 barrels.
QUEMOY, China, Sept. 4 -- After a two-day lull the Chinese Communists resumed their heavy shelling of this island last night.
PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle went to a working-class quarter of Paris today to unveil his new Constitution. The well-organized ceremony left little to chance or to the Communists.
HERE in the East, when a physician prescribes a special milk for a new baby or an ailing patient, he will most likely say: "Get Walker-Gordon."

TRENTON, Sept. 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner is sure there are "abuses" in labor-management relations in New Jersey. He said so today as he announced that he had ordered the State Attorney General to investigate "possible irregularities" in this area.
CAIRO, Sept. 4 -- The United Arab Republic proposed today to the Sudan that a conference be held soon to consider several outstanding problems between the two countries.

Pitney-Bowes, Inc., manufacturer of postage meters and business machines, leased-three floors in the new office building at 630 Third Avenue, at Forty-first Street through Collins, Tuttle Co., agent, who reported the building 95 per cent rented.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- A "right - to - work" ordinance adopted by San Benito County was declared unconstitutional today by California's First District Court of Appeal.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- This city's three daily newspapers failed to publish today as a result of a walkout by union pressmen at The Detroit Free Press. The strikers were protesting the discharge of the chairman of the pressmen's unit at The Free Press, a morning paper.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- At the outset of World War II, Michel Debre, who directed the preparation of France's newest constitution, was mobilized as a cavalry officer. He was captured and later escaped to fight in the underground.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- This community, which is older than the United States, took a new lease on life tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- Senate rackets investigators said today that a teamster attorney had got a $15,750 "finder's fee" for helping a Detroit real estate company obtain a $1,000,000 loan from the union's welfare fund.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The grain futures market overcame most of the effects of an earlier bearish crop report in late dealings today on the Board of Trade and finished with small changes.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4 -- Columbia defeated Vim today in a yacht race that became a dreary procession instead of the slugfest that had been anticipated.
The Waterfront Commission said yesterday that it had opened a broad new phase in its drive to rid the Port of New York of criminals and racketeers.
HILLSDALE, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Sixteen gifted students at the Pascack Valley Regional High School here began an experimental course in elementary Russian today.

GREAT MILLS, Md., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Joan Elaine Groves center of a Federal Court controversy over segregation, stepped from a Negro school bus in this southern Maryland community today and quietly entered the Great Mills High School as its first Negro pupil.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- An official of the United States Golf Association said today that he was puzzled about the temporary injunction issued yesterday in Mount Holly, N. J., to restrain the association from interfering with a miniature golf tournament in Asbury Park.
PARIS, Sept. 4 -- In the referendum on Sept. 28 the French overseas territories will vote not only for or against a new French Constitution but for or against retaining their links with France.

In his appointment of a distinguished Moslem, M. C. Chagla, Chief Justice of Bombay, as the next Indian Ambassador to the United States, Prime Minister Nehru has chosen an eminent person for a sensitive post. Some additional things were doubtless in his mind.

The Henry Phipps Estates has sold the northwest corner of First Avenue and East Fifty-sixth Street to builders for improvement with a nineteen-story apartment house.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York and real-estate interests were accused last night by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. of being "reactionaries and obstructionists" blocking fire-prevention legislation.

Ralph Lowe, oil and cattle financier from Midland, Tex., sold a three-quarter share of his English-bred 4-year-old Gallant Man to Leslie Combs 2d of Lexington, Ky., yesterday. The price of the transaction was $1,000,000.

HONG KONG Sept. 4 -- Communist China tonight extended its territorial waters to twelve nautical miles from "all territories of the People's Republic of China." It said these territories included Taiwan. The previous limit was three miles.
Cotton futures advanced 6 to 17 points here yesterday in moderate trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Lebanese diplomats disclosed today that Dr. Charles Malik would head their delegation to the forthcoming General Assembly session and predicted he would be elected Assembly president "on the first ballot." The session opens Sept. 16.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 4 -- Following is the text of the school policy statement sent today by Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. to school superintendents in Norfolk, Newport News, Charlottesville and Prince Edward and Arlington Counties:
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher Richmond gave a dinner dance this evening at Sunninghill, their home here, in honor of their daughter, Miss Ann Warner Richmond.
