An international list of celebrated musicians, dancers and actors has been signed for New York this season by Sol Hurok, concert producer. From Sept. 20 through April, 1959, Mr. Hurok will sponsor 500 artists, more than he has ever presented since his first full season in 1914-15.

PARIS, Sept. 4 -- On Sept. 4 eighty-eight years ago, shouting crowds coursed through the Paris streets to the City Hall, where they proclaimed the death of the Second Empire and the birth of the Third Republic.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Sept. 4 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood and Mrs. Saul Weinsier of Fresh Meadow took a stroke lead in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's John B. Mackie Memorial Scotch foursome golf tournament today.
The Garrett Corporation had a net income in the fiscal year ended June 30 of $4,118,707. This compared with $4,940,582 in the preceding fiscal year.
An increase from twenty-four to forty-one in the number of poliomyelitis cases this year over last in the metropolitan area resulted in a warning against "compiacency" yesterday.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The State Senate's Republican majority leader, Walter J. Mahoney, said today he thought the State Thruway should consider lowering tolls instead of raising them.
Forebodings overlay the stock market yesterday. After a stubborn show of firmness in the morning, prices fell a little in the afternoon.
Detectives continued to hunt yesterday for a clue to the murder of a physician and his wife in their Staten Island home on Tuesday. At day's end they said they had made little progress.

ST. JOHN'S Nfld., Sept. 4 (UPI) -- A United States pilot was forced to abandon his attempted around-the-world flight today because Canada's Department of Transport refused to give him permission to take off across the Atlantic.

An account of man's conquest of the depths, from the time of Alexander the Great to the pioneering voyages beneath the North Polar Icecap by the U. S. S. Nautilus and U. S. S. Skate, is given in "The Complete Book of Submarines.
The teen-age boys hired to retrieve tennis balls at Forest Hills are traditionally polite, colorless, odorless and full of noblesse oblige.

BEACH HAVEN, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- William T. Uhl of Millneck, N. Y., won the first race, and Bizzie Monte-Sano of Larchmont, N. Y., took the second in the Lightning Class championship series in Little Egg Harbor today.
A spurned suitor shot and killed a young woman on an upper Manhattan sidewalk yesterday in view of persons walking toward the subway station at 110th Street and Broadway.
Jack Narz, the former host on "Dotto," and Sy Fischer, a part owner of the defunct show, were questioned yesterday by the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
A record total of thirty new city schools, including five high schools, will be opened in this school year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 -- For a distance of 400 miles, by train, plane, bus and afoot, the Democratic contender for California's Governorship pursued a strategy today aimed at giving his opponent no chance to lay a glove on him.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

IT is no secret that the wisdom of woman is a deep and wondrous thing, for which the logic of man is no fair match. A man reports that he was browsing among the book stacks at the New York Public Library recently when a woman let it be known that she was looking for something light and pleasant. The man suggested something by Evelyn Waugh.

A dispute over the handling of "pre-loaded" cargo at Pier 34, North River, yesterday will go before the joint International Longshoremen's Association - New York Shipping Association labor relations committee on Tuesday.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 4 -- One of the heaviest sentences in the history of the Nassau County Traffic Court was handed down today. A 21-year-old Hicksville youth was given a one-year jail term for traffic violations.
The possibility of a scenic artists strike that would affect the opening of about a dozen incoming Broadway stage attractions loomed large yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The annual tussle with income tax returns will be easier for some 17,000,000 taxpayers hereafter, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.
PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle called on the French people today to accept his proposed Constitution lest France become "out of date and disdained."

MANILA, Sept. 4 -- The Philippine Security Council at its first meeting today decided to adhere to the late President Ramon Magsaysay's policy of firm support of United States policy regarding the defense of Nationalist China.
BRIELLE, N. J., Sept. 4 -- This may have been the best day of the year for taking school tuna here, and it certainly was a fine day for trying out various kinds of tackle.

WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Sept. 4 -- Eighty-five commuters on this morning's 7:55 o'clock local out of West Haverstraw, N. Y., donned masks in the form of fish to emphasize that, since they are not fish, they need ferryboats to get them to work.
LONGMIRE, Wash., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Stanford University junior, marooned two nights in the crater atop 14,410-foot Mount Rainier, was brought down the mountain by five veteran climbers yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 4 -- Following is text of proposed French Constitution as translated by Paris Bureau of The New York Times:

Cyrus S. Eaton's credentials as a capitalist are as impeccable as those of Nikita S. Khrushchev as a Communist. The friendly meeting between the two men in the Kremlin Tuesday was not, therefore, without its irony. After all, when Premier Khrushchev told Western diplomats in Moscow he would "bury you," it was capitalists like Mr. Eaton who were uppermost in his dogmatic mind.
Outer space lies within the province of the United Nations, according to a report before the International Law Association.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The Trades Union Congress called today for the acceptance of Communist China as a member of the Security Council of the United Nations.

IN all probability no novel published this year will be more widely discussed or more critically admired than "Doctor Zhivago,"* by Boris Pasternak. This is a long, solid, rather old-fashioned and somewhat stiff chronicle of social upheaval and general moral disintegration during the Russian Revolution and civil war.
An international flavor will spice the city's public schools this fall.

A recent visitor to a large Southern city, now a thriving industrial and cultural center, made an interesting observation about walkers and walking. He lived for a week with his son's family in a highly desirable residential section.

It was announced yesterday that the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots had signed new agreements with thirty-one companies in negotiations with Atlantic Coast steamship operators. It was also said that the union expected to sign twenty more contracts today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Friday, Sept. 5 -- Senator Jorge Alessandri, candidate of the Rightists, was running strongly ahead early today in the returns from Chile's Presidential election yesterday.
Workmen installed plate glass panels on the second floor of the Museum of Modern Art yesterday that will give visitors inside a view of the sculpture in the garden.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 4 -- Foreign Minister Son Sann of Cambodia indicated after the break-up of Thai-Cambodian negotiations here today that Cambodia would refer the issue of who owns the mountain shrine of Khao Phra Viharn to the International Court of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Government disclosed tonight that it would resume shipments of surplus foodstuffs for feeding school children in Egypt.
The Liberal party decided last night, by a three-to-one vote, to endorse District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for the United States Senate. He had previously received the Democratic nomination.
A new issue of $150,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Standard Oil Company of California is on the market today on terms yielding investors 4.4 per cent.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4 -- This town may get tougher next summer on residents and out-of-towners who attempt to circumvent admission regulations at its three public beaches.
TRENTON, Sept. 4 -- Malcolm S. Forbes announced his voluntary retirement from the New Jersey Senate today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 4 -- The United States Embassy announced today the immediate gift of $2,500,000 to help Lebanon get over the effects of four months of rebellion.

Leon Cooper's letter published on Aug. 26 would seem to suggest that the throwing of garbage by tenants be policed by the banks that hold the mortgages on the property. Since the only weapon the mortgagees have is the threat of foreclosure, the burden of enforcement would fall back upon the landlords, where it properly belongs.
Plans to acquire the bulk of the Brooklyn waterfront property of Erie Basin for $7,500,000 were announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Official sources here called attention today to United States efforts to keep the Chinese Nationalists from jeopardizing the Taiwan economy by building up too big an army. In this respect, the United States could back its stand effectively by limiting supplies of military equipment.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Ideal sailing conditions greeted the sailors as the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club fall series continued on the bay this afternoon. There were 108 skippers out for the second day of the five-day competition; they represented twenty-three classes.

Budgeted expenditures for research and development are up an average of 4 per cent this year from those in 1957, the American Management Association reported yesterday. The figure was a result of a study made by its research and development division of more than 800 companies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Army is preparing to complain that Air Force propaganda efforts are belittling the Nike-Hercules air defense weapon while extolling the Air Force's Bomarc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- Representative John A. Blatnik, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that President Eisenhower's veto of an airport aid bill showed the Administration's "lack of comprehension" of jet-age air safety needs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The court-appointed monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were apparently assured today against interference from a commission that the union had appointed to investigate charges of racketeering against the teamsters.

A GENTLE flare returns to many gloves for fall. Mid-arm lengths of sturdy, hand-stitched leathers now tend to widen at the top, thus being in line with the season's cropped, bulky coat and suit sleeves.
Crowds were magnetically attracted yesterday to a special exhibit on the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal.

Eric Johnston will leave Wednesday for Moscow, where he will attempt to complete a deal for the sale of a group of American films to the Soviet state film agency and the purchase of a group of Russian films.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement today by Secretary of State Dulles on the Far East situation:
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 5 -- Japan will not accept Communist China's extension of her territorial boundaries to twelve miles at sea, the official spokesman for the Foreign Office declared today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- Frank Torre hit a bases-loaded single and Billy Bruton smashed a two-run triple as the Milwaukee Braves hopped on Dick Farrell for four runs in the tenth inning tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 9 -- 5.

The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company announced yesterday that, unlike the nation's major railways, it was not losing, but gaining, passengers and did not intend to seek higher fares for the moment.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Jimmy Wilson, 55-year-old Negro sentenced to die for a $1.95 theft, won an indefinite stay of execution today. He had been scheduled to go to the electric chair tomorrow morning.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 4 -- The public schools of Arlington County will open Monday on a racially segregated basis.

The American Cancer Society announced yesterday that it had made 216 grants totaling $4,330,339 for cancer research and training in thirty states, the District of Columbia and four European countries. Scientists and institutions in the New York area received $767,880.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Meadow A1 turned in heats of 2:00 3/5 and 2:01 2/5 to win the $46,4366 Fox Stake for 2-year-old pacers feature of an eight-race Grand Circuit card at the Indiana State Fair today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (AP) -- There's no roof on the Coliseum, but one fell in on the Dodgers in the first inning today. The San Francisco Giants scored eight runs in the inning and went on to rout Los Angeles, 13 -- 3, in the final game of the season between the clubs.

The Screen Directors International Guild and the Film Producers Association of New York have reached agreement on terms governing the work of New York directors for film producers here. Both organizations made the announcement yesterday, ending months of negotiating.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Sam (Toothpick) Jones broke Dizzy Dean's St. Louis Cardinal season strikeout record and became the National League's first 200-strikeout hurler in seventeen years as he fanned eight Chicago Cubs in a 4-2 triumph today.

President Eisenhower has again warned Communist China that under the authority vested in him by Congress he will not hesitate to commit American armed forces in the defense of the offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu if he finds this necessary to the security of Taiwan.
CARLSTADT, N. J., Sept. 4 -- The Meadowlands Regional Planning Board received a gift of $13,000 last night for a study by Dutch engineers of a plan to reclaim the Hackensack Meadows.

The Seabrook Farms Company has signed an agreement under which the Bateman Frozen Foods Company of Macon, Ga., will become a part of its operation. With the acquisition of Bateman, Seabrook Farms will become the nation's second largest in the frozen food field.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 4 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. today advised school boards under Federal court integration orders to refrain from assigning Negro students to white schools.

Failures among retailers of apparel and accessories, dry goods and general merchandise in August numbered eighty-three, with liabilities of $1,950,000, the Credit Clearing House, a division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
A battle took shape last night for three of the five Supreme Court posts to be filled at the fall election in the First Judicial District. The district embraces New York and Bronx Counties.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- The Cedarbrook Country Club in Cheltenham Township, adjacent to the northern end of Philadelphia, has been sold to an apartment developer for $2,150,000.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- The American Legion convention warned today against cutbacks in the defense program.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Governor Harriman's Administration has agreed to give New York City about $3,000,000 a year in extra state aid for welfare purposes.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4 -- "I'll never be scared again," 14-year-old Anthony Marchand said today. "I couldn't, after this."
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4 -- The United States has determined to repel any Communist Chinese attempt to invade the Nationalist-held islands of Quemoy and Matsu.

The Government yesterday announced plans for training expert seamen to man the world's first atomic-powered merchant ship, the Savannah. The Maritime Administration and the Atomic Energy Commission will take seventeen men, including a shipmaster and sixteen engineers. They will be trained in the handling of the new ship's power plant.
" Much of today's advertising is not very good," according to Fairfax M. Cone, chairman of the executive committee of Foote, Cone and Belding.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 4 -- "Isn't she a wonderful boat!"

A survey of American music from the turn of the century to the present will be presented by the New York Philharmonic and its new music director, Leonard Bernstein, during the orchestra's current season. The season opens at Carnegie Hall Thursday, Oct. 2.

GENEVA, Sept. 4 (AP) -- One of the most bewildered men in Geneva today is Representative Ludwig Teller, Democrat of New York, who came with a United States Congressional group to the atoms-for-peace conference.

A LOAD of strictly avant garde chapeaux from Paris arrived at 28 West Thirty-ninth Street the other day. The big cardboard boxes included, among other things, some bubble-domed "take me to your leader" hats from de Givenchy and Balenciaga.
An attempt to arrange a face-to-face debate between Governor Harriman and Nelson A. Rockefeller collapsed yesterday in disagreements over the subject and the time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The United States rejected today Red China's extension of its territorial waters to twelve miles from its coastline.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 4 -- Douglas Seeth of the Mattituck (L. I.) Yacht Club took a 2 1/4-point lead today in the Comet Class international sailing championships at the Devon Y. C.

Dr. V. S. Yemelyanov's personal attack on Dr. Willard F. Libby and his accusation that this country is seeking to test nuclear weapons under the pretext of using nuclear blasts for peaceful purposes is more than mere discourtesy.
TOKYO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Japanese Finance Ministry named "The Ten Commandments" and "Witness for the Prosecution" today as two of the four best foreign films shown in Japan this year.

His ravings and rantings about the sins of the United States, Britain and Israel are, from a practical viewpoint, no more ridiculous than similar rhetoric by Mussolini and Hitler between the wars.

The promise of more candor than is usual in a political campaign is given by Nelson A. Rockefeller's replies to press conference questions about New York's fiscal problems. The Republican candidate would not promise that his election as Governor, if it came about, would assure restoration of any "forgiveness" in the state income tax rate.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- James J. Nance resigned today as vice president of the Ford Motor Company and general manager of the M-E-L division. He was succeeded by Ben D. Mills, another vice president, who had been Mr. Nance's assistant.

SINCE Jerome Robbins' "Ballets: U. S. A." scored such a success at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, and at the Brussels World's Fair, Leland Hayward got the idea that perhaps the home folks might want to see what the Europeans liked so much.
The battle over the controversial Seventh Avenue link in the Brooklyn approach to the proposed Narrows Bridge will be renewed at a public hearing before the Board of Estimate on Friday, Sept. 26.

To enlarge upon your editorial of Sept. 2 "The English Race Riots" I should like to point out that until after World War II the British "urbane sense of tolerance" rarely touched her colored subjects in England.

WASHINGTON journalists are alarmed and Washington legislators are hopping mad at Calvin Griffith for even contemplating the shift of his American League franchise from the capital to Minneapolis. The alarm of the press-box tenants -- and presumably the faceless fans -- is not important.
YONKERS, Sept. 4 -- Adios Harry, J. Howard Lyons 7-year-old, that had been suffering from a variety of minor ailments, became harness racing's leading money winner once again tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Norman W. Manley, Chief Minister of Jamaica, will arrive in London tomorrow to discuss the spate of race riots between whites and Negroes, chiefly West Indians, in London's northwest districts.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- The United Automobile Workers warned the Big Three car manufacturers today that the union was preparing to select a strike target and set a strike deadline.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 4 -- Mrs. Mattie Dickson, an 83-year-old retired domestic worker, donated $10,000 today to help combat what she called "disgraceful abuses in American democracy."

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, sugar, potatoes, copper, zinc, lead and rubber rose. Coffee, cottonseed oil, wool and hides declined.

Victor Seixas made his exit from the national tennis championship yesterday. With the former American and Wimbledon titleholder went Alejandro Olmedo of Peru, beaten in a heroically waged fifth set that gripped the 6,000 spectators in the Forest Hills Stadium with its intensity and electrifying exploits.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 4 -- Governor Harriman toured the State Fair today. The theme of the fair is "a salute to our senior citizens," and one of the chief exhibits is a "senior city" dealing with the education, health and welfare problems of older persons.

State and municipal long-term financing declined during August to $363,372,229, the smallest monthly total since November of 1956, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The total for August of last year was $595,239,988, and for July of 1958, $631,364,968.

Although two more Federal Reserve banks -- in Chicago and Minneapolis -- followed the lead of four other banks in raising their discount rates from 1 3/4 to 2 per cent yesterday, the New York bank stood pat. It had been rumored for several days that the New York bank rate might even go up to 2 1/4 per cent.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 4 -- Eighty young musicians from a dozen or more countries have come to Bucharest, carrying with them the bundles of hopes and fears and frustrations that are part of the special little world of the international music contest.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Sept. 4 -- The ultimate victims of attacks on mutual savings banks are savings and loan associations, George A. Mooney, New York State Superintendent of Banks, said here today.

The Society of Mining Engineers, a body of the American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers, announced the selection yesterday of Jerome W. Woomer as president of the society for one year beginning next February.
The first live whale exhibited here since 1897 became an Aquarium tenant yesterday under conditions as worrisome as its whale-out-of-water trip from Alaska.

YOKAHAMA, Japan, Sept. 4 (AP) -- John Thomas of Cambridge, Mass., today leaped to a Japanese high jump record of 2.09 meters (6 feet 10 3/8 inches) as he surpassed two previous performances he set in Japanese - American goodwill track and field meets within two weeks.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Sixteen commodores of the Argentine Air Force asked for retirement and eight others were under arrest today.
GENEVA, Sept. 4 -- United States scientists suggested today they might have been the first to harness the thermonuclear reaction of the hydrogen bomb.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the post-Suez slump in exports appeared to have come to a halt during the second quarter of this year. The slump can largely be attributed to the event that preceded it -- the Suez Canal crisis, which caused a bulge in United States exports of oil, wheat and cotton.

Two plots on opposite corners in the Gun Hill Road section of the Bronx have been bought by Jack Brause, president of Rita Properties, Inc. The parcels, 150 by 100 feet each, are at the southeast and southwest corners of Decatur Avenue and 211th Street.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 4 (UPI) -- The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals has upheld television coverage of courtroom proceedings.

Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas told British radio listeners yesterday that he had never declared his personal views on integration or segregation -- but simply believed that the issue should be decided by majority will.
HAVANA, Sept. 4 -- President Fulgencio Batista reiterated today his determination to hold the general election scheduled for Nov. 3 despite revolutionary violence in Cuba.
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- Under France's proposed Constitution, the President of the Republic would have vastly increased powers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 4 -- While television quiz shows are being investigated in New York, a movie company here is negotiating for a new novel dealing with the rise and fall of a quiz program in the Madison Avenue advertising world.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 4 -- Lester L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, made known today that the company was "actively dealing" with the possibility of producing a "smaller" United States-built car.
Peiping and the Summer White House at Newport, R. I., traded warnings yesterday but Chinese Communist artillery fire against the Nationalist-held island of Quemoy slackened.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, Vice Chief of Staff of the Air Force, departed this morning for a tour of Far Eastern bases, including Taiwan. He was accompanied on the flight by Maj. Gen. Shaolien Lang, chief air attache at the Chinese Nationalist Embassy here.
MADISON, Wis., Sept. 4 -- The Director of the Budget said today that the Federal budget could well be back in balance by fiscal year 1961, two years from now.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Sept. 4 -- For the second successive year, integrated public school classes began here today without incident. No picket or segregationist agitator was visible.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 4 -- The Administration of President Alberto Lleras Camargo presented its economic and social policy for the next four years to a joint session of the National Congress last night.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 4 -- Harry de Leyer's horses, from St. James, L. I., captured three events during the first day of the twenty-fifth annual North Shore horse show on the grounds of the old Field Club today
Headquarters for the Republican state ticket headed by Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor and Kenneth B. Keating for the Senate were opened yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.
GENEVA, Sept. 4 -- A group of physicists announced today that they had discovered one of the missing links in the forces that hold the atom together. It was said to be of great importance.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 4 -- Bank operations of the future were previewed here today by the National Cash Register Company.
State colleges of Texas are planning an offering of seven issues of new bonds totaling $17,080,000 on Sept. 16. Dated Oct. 1, 1958, the bonds will come due serially on July 1 from 1959 to 1968.

Three young men and a young woman, employed by resident buying offices here, are about to begin evening college courses as winners of the first annual scholarships awarded by the Association of Buying Offices.
The police are investigating the disappearance of a 43-year-old jeweler from the West Side Jewelry Exchange. They said he was believed to have "many thousands of dollars worth of gems" with him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Inventory liquidation in manufacturing and trade continued for July at the somewhat reduced stage of June, the Department of the Commerce reported today.

LONDON, Sept. 5 (Reuters) -- Two Icelandic gunboats loomed out of the fog today and tried unsuccessfully to board two British trawlers within Iceland's disputed twelve-mile limit, the British Admiralty reported.
BREWSTER, Mass., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- A taxi driver was killed and eight other persons, including four New Yorkers, were injured in a head-on collision on the Mid-Cape Highway today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Army announced plans today for a $35,000,000 program for quantity production of the new M-14 Springfield rifle and the M-60 machine gun.

The Queens Symphony Orchestra will give five concerts during the coming season. Rehearsals begin at 8 P. M. on Sept. 17 at the Forest Hills High School. Membership is invited in all sections of the orchestra. Information may be obtained by telephoning BO 86346.
CEDAR GROVE, N. J., Sept. 5 -- Most of the 12,000 residents of this West Essex community will take part this week-end in a program to celebrate the township's incorporation fifty years ago.
A Davis Cup squad of twelve players was named yesterday by the selection committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association at Forest Hills.
A United Nations "Peace Force and Observer Corps" was proposed yesterday at a meeting of the International Law Association.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 5 -- The Rev. Leo R. Ward, Notre Dame Philosophy Professor, said today that business men might be deceived but that at least they vaguely thought of themselves as working for the freedom of man.
An infuuential Roman Catholic weekly is cautioning members of that faith against demanding legal support for their opposition to artificial birth control.
ROTTERDAM, Sept. 5 (AP) -- After four indecisive jump-offs, two of the world's top riders decided today to share first place in one of the toughest contests so far at the Dutch horse show here.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly to close 3 points up to 4 points off yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale). There was some liquidation in the far months, but the trade bought near months.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Britain's Trade Union Congress today asked nationalization of key sections of the nation's engineering industry.
Directors of the National Broadcasting Company have elected Matthew J. Culligan and P. A. Sugg executive vice presidents, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Two New Orleans men were awarded a patent this week for a circular, revolving bed. They regard it as a desirable decorative center for a living room or efficiency apartment.

VAN BUREN, Ark., Sept. 5 (AP) -- White students protesting integration succeeded today in barring Negroes from Van Buren High School. But they failed in a bid to entice more students to join their classroom boycott.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 5 -- The Chinese Communists have thrown an increasingly effective blockade around Quemoy, the Nationalist Defense Ministry spokesman, Rear Admiral Liu Hoh-tu, said today.

Three buildings on a plot 57 by 100 feet at 63-65-67 West Fifty-fifth Street have been purchased by C. Bastis, president of the Sea-Fare Restaurant chain. The structures will be demolished and a one-story building will be erected for a new restaurant.
Investors held their breaths yesterday as threat and counterthreat crossed China's Golden Gate -- the island of Quemoy. Activity and prices both declined.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Britain fully shares United States concern over the possibility of a Chinese Communist invasion of Quemoy and Matsu, a Foreign Office statement declared today.

CORDUROY has long been the fabric for baby clothes, sportswear and raincoats. Now that it is turning up on fabric counters under new guises, it has a fresh fashion significance. This is because fall corduroy fabrics have an overlay of floral or abstract printing, making them suitable for dressy cocktail clothes and theatre suits.

Simpsons-Sears, Ltd., in its report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed a net profit of $1,109,202 for the twenty-one weeks ended June 4. Operating profits for the period were $2,318,930.

The reply of Arnold Neiderbach in The Times of Sept. 3 to the Aug. 30 letter of W. J. Holman Jr. sufficiently takes care of the Tenth and Fourteenth Amendments as they relate to the Supreme Court integration decision of 1954.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was fined $14 today for refusing to obey a police officer.

Idun seems to be all right again. The fine filly owned by Mrs. C. Ulrick Bay had an easy time winning a mile race at Belmont Park yesterday, and she was so highly rated by the 18,022 customers that she was a 2-to-5 favorite.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 5 -- John N. Matthews' Vim from Oyster Bay, L. I., sliced her bow over the line ahead of the Henry Sears syndicate's Columbia today to keep alive her hopes of becoming the America's Cup defender.
South America is developing rapidly into a competitor of Europe for the North American tourist trade, according to Dr. Jose A. Mora, secretary-general of the Organization of American States.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 5 -- Arnold J. Toynbee, British historian, said tonight that a new world government seemed to be the only alternative to genocide.

It has been a long time since any railroad has raised capital through a common stock offering. There have been a limited number of rail stock issues in recent years, but almost every one was undertaken in a recapitalization program.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's Bill Virdon broke up a rookies' pitching duel between Carlton Willey of Milwaukee and George Witt of the Pirates tonight when he hit a tenth-inning home run that provided a 1 -- 0 Pirate victory.
FASHION is doing exactly as the Romans did. First, the Empire gown -- it was worn originally by the girls of Caesar's day -- was heartily accepted. Now the stole is coming back into favor.

Members of Local 707, International Brotherhood of Teamsters will give blood today in the New York Regional Red Cross blood program. The donations will be made at St. Alphonus Roman Catholic Church Hall, 312 West Broadway.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 5 Senator Jorge Alessandri, who won a plurality in yesterday's balloting and is potentially the President-elect of Chile, is a solitary leader who inspires confidence in followers and mistrust in oppnen-ts.
TUSCUMBIA, Ala., Sept. 5 (AP) -- A surgeon who was called yesterday to pronounce 21-year-old Joe Hubbert dead brought him back to life.

TORREJON de ARDOZ, Spain, Sept. 3 -- World tensions in the Middle East or in the Taiwan Strait have hour-to-hour repercussions here in the closely guarded control room at this huge United States-Spanish airbase near Madrid.
SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 5 -- The United States team took a substantial lead over the amateur golfers of Canada and Mexico today.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Acting under this state's new Right-to-Know Law, a concern whose plant is scheduled to be razed tried today to force the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency to open its files.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Paul told the Warren County School Board today that it could not bar Negro pupils from the county's white high school. The lack of a Negro high school in the northern Virginia county was cited as a major reason for the decision.
Many benefits will accrue to the liquor industry under the Forand bill, which was signed on Tuesday by President Eisenhower.
The State Supreme Court yesterday postponed until Sept. 17 a hearing to determine whether the Waterfront Commission has the right to subpoena books and records of pier union locals.
SANTIAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Senor Alessandri's probable election assures the continuance of President Ibanez' austerity program to fight Chile's 40-year-old inflation.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 5 -- Norfolk school board attorneys postponed filing a petition in Federal Court today to nullify a State Supreme Court injunction against the assignment of seventeen Negro pupils to white city schools.

QUEMOY, China, Sept. 5 -- Despite efforts by Nationalist Chinese and United States military leaders here to obscure developments, it is apparent that an effective blockade of Quemoy has been imposed by Communist China.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Detroit Free Press filed a $1,000,000 damage suit today against the striking Local 13 of the Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union.
The high point in last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center may well have been Patricia Wilde's performance in George Balanchine's "Pas de Dix."
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Earl H. Schrader Jr., who resigned last week as chief assistant prosecutor of Jackson County (Kansas City), was indicted today on charges of perjury and solicitation.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that United States auto makers had scheduled production of 195,500 passenger cars for September, an 8 per cent increase over August's 180,313.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior said today that announcement of the proposed new crude oil import limitation program for the area east of the Rockies would be delayed until Tuesday the earliest.

SANTA FE, N. M., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Outbreaks of encephalitis in the Las Cruces area of southern New Mexico caused Gov. Edwin L. Mechem to proclaim a state of emergency today. He called out the National Guard at Las Cruces to institute control measures.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5 (UPI) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles wrote Gov. James E. Folsom today that United States embassies abroad were being flooded with letters about the death sentence imposed on a Negro farmhand for a $1.95 robbery of a white woman.

THE general trout season in New York State closes tomorrow, but fishermen get a little extra break this year. Under new legislation, they may fish until Sept. 30 in Queens, Orange, Rockland, Dutchess, Putnam, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
LONDON, Sept. 5 -- India's Finance Minister, Moraji Desai, said here today he preferred that his Government pay for financial help rather than get it free.

There will be no rejoicing anywhere, not even among a majority of the South African people, that Hendrik Verwoerd has been chosen Prime Minister. This is an affliction which the unhappy people of South Africa will have to bear for a while.
Cookie Lavagetto's Senators, who seem to have the peculiar notion that nobody wants them, almost wore out their welcome at the Stadium last night so far as the Yankees were concerned.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 5 -- On a day in which wind was at a minimum but the eagerness of sailors at a maximum, the third session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's big five-day regatta was held in the bay today.

OSLO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Herb Elliott of Australia tonight was clocked in 3 minutes 37.4 seconds, the second fastest 1,500 meters in history, and then said he was quitting international competition for six months.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 5 -- Lebanon took another step toward normal conditions today when the rebels shut down their four clandestine broadcasting stations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--The Air Force has abandoned plans to attempt a second rocket shot to the moon this month. The first "lunar probe" failed Aug. 17.
Last November an 18-year-old youth stood before General Sessions Judge Irwin D. Davidson for sentencing on an automobile theft charge.

BEACH HAVEN, N. J., Sept. 5 -- William T. Uhl of Mill Neck, L. I., and Thomas C. Munnell, Southport, Conn., today scored victories in the Lightning Class international championship series in Little Egg Harbor.

I should like to take this opportunity to commend your newspaper for the article on adult education in your Sept. 1 issue. The facts concerning reduced aid to adult education are substantially correct and the defense of the cut made in your Sept. 2 article is patently specious.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 5 -- On a day when just about everything that could went wrong, Columbia showed enough basic virtues for her afterguard not to feel too disappointed at losing today's America's Cup trial to Vim.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy would like a new station house in the heart of Greenwich Village.
The new capital market next week is slated to be the most active it has been in any week this year, provided that the Sears, Roebuck Co. financing appears on schedule.
Paul J. Kern, former president of the city's Civil Service Commission, filed a $500,000 damage suit yesterday against the board of directors of the Western Pacific Railroad Company of San Francisco.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Army squads won the first three places today in the top team event of the national rifle matches. The winning all-Army blue squad fired a record 1,475 of a possible 1,500.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York, Jerome Dansker, president, bought the six-story apartment building on a plot 117 by 116 by 233 feet at 66-92 Selfridge Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

Two volumes of essays by Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, the physician-poet, are planned for publication next year by Twayne. For their first issue in book form to commemorate the sesquicentennial of Dr. Holmes' birthday the essays have been edited by Albert Mordell.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that cotton growers would be permitted, under a new program, to exceed their 1959 cotton planting allotments by 40 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 5 -- Morocco has made formal application to join the Arab League, it was understood here today.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Communist China's fifteenth Supreme State Council opened yesterday in Peiping under the chairmanship of Mao Tse-tung, the chief of state, the Peiping radio reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 645,432 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

An 18 - year - old amateur astronomer will accompany a United States expedition to the Danger Islands in the Pacific to study a total eclipse of the sun. The eclipse will take place Oct. 12.

The long-rumored merger of the United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation and Buffalo-Eclipse Corporation has reached the stage of formal negotiation, it was announced yesterday.

Newspaper executives from South and Southeast Asia agreed yesterday that the crisis over the Chinese islands of Quemoy and Matsu demonstrated the need for a United Nations police force to keep the peace.

Richard Savitt and Herbert Flam were beaten in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday and, for the first time that anyone could recall, the United States was shut out of the semi-finals of the tournament.

The doorstep of a policeman's house that became something of a monument to his humane qualities was the object of much attention on Broome Street yesterday. BERLIN, Sept. S (AP) -An East-West dispute erupted in Berlin today over a linden tree and left two Communist policemen out on a limb.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The stock market closed tower today despite a rally after a bad start. The recovery did not extend to Government loans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Average wholesale prices at the primary market level were unchanged at 118.7 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service today recommended influenza shots for persons the disease might affect seriously and for professional and service groups wishing to guard against absenteeism.

The United States has improved its standing among the twenty-six merchant shipbuilding nations of the world. Since the first of the year this nation has risen from eighth to fifth place, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported last week.

The old tales die hard. Year after year one hears that it's the frost that colors the woodlands, though sumac, chokecherry and an occasional maple begin to turn before the temperature on the chilliest nights gets much below 50. Actually, an early frost lessens the color rather than heightens it. If frost strikes before the coloring process is well started the leaves turn sere rather than gold and orange and crimson.

This has been a strange economic recession. Unemployment has pushed past the 5,000,000 mark, but prices have gone on climbing. Industrial output has fallen and margin requirements have been stiffened, but the stock market has moved steadily higher.

NOW that Labor Day has come and gone New Yorkers who have been painfully aware of an unusually severe mosquito invasion this summer are allowing themselves to hope that the pests will go away, or hibernate, or something.
