PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 7--Political candidates made last-minute appeals for votes today and tonight on the eve of Maine's last September general election.

A Christian, a Jew and a Moslem shared a Presbyterian pulpit yesterday to emphasize their belief that only the spirit of brotherhood could bring peace to the Middle East and ultimately to the whole world.
The fight for the leadership of the New York County Republican organization, waged bitterly since mid-July, ended yesterday.

NEWARK, Sept. 7--The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark announced plans today for a special school to train mentally retarded girls of all creeds. The school, to be opened this fall by the Mount Carmel Guild, also will serve as a job-placement agency.

PETER KAVANAGH comes out of a doorway on East Twenty-ninth Street, wearing an ink-smeared tee shirt and khaki pants. His hair is wild and wiry, his eyes ice-blue, and when he speaks, you can hear a distant thunder.
Insurance against "catastrophic'' medical expenses is growing rapidly.
Pan American World Airways' first Boeing 707 jet left New York International Airport yesterday for London.

When the Federal Reserve authorities, after the close of the financial markets on Aug. 4, announced an increase in margin requirements for trading in securities, the president of the New York Stock Exchange, it may be recalled, entered a plea in protest against the board's action. He declared:
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 7 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today the intention of the United States to keep Southeast Asia free.

A cool, wet spring and a rainy July caused attendance to decline at beaches this year, operators in the metropolitan area reported yesterday. Only the Rockaways, of four major beach areas, noted an increase over last year's attendance.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa -- Quiet-spoken, mild-mannered Harry Oppenheimer, the 49-year-old head of the leading gold and diamond mining organization in Africa, has now settled comfortably in the chair vacated by his father, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer.

No one--certainly not the advocates of more rigorous and advanced schooling for the able -would answer "no" 'to the question posed in Samuel Tenenbaum's letter in The Times of Sept. 2; "Shouldn't we continue to try to educate all our children to the maximum of their abilities?"
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7 -- Mary Ann Mobley of Brandon, Miss., a choir singer who would like to appear in a Broadway musical comedy, began her reign today as Miss America 1959.
OMAHA, Sept. 7 (AP) -America is in a healthier condition today because of the Supreme Court school integration decision, Lester B. Granger told the National Urban League Conference today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 7 -- An attempt to overthrow the provisional regime headed by Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal failed today.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 7 -- A charge of "growth discrimination" in the levying of property taxes here was made today by a study group of the Democratic Town Committee.

As if quiz shows did not have enough trouble at the hands of the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, they were the target last night of on-the-air satire, which could be a good deal more deadly and efficient.

Once more the farce of "electing" State Supreme Court judges has begun -- a parody on democracy and good government. Last Tuesday Democratic and Republican political leaders met -- informally and entirely "off the record." They chose seven judges to sit in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The voters didn't, and won't, have anything to do with it.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The grain futures market appeared to be on the verge of a strong rally a few times last week, but each small bulge opened a smothering volume of profit-taking.
The International Law Association decided yesterday against an immediate call for a United Nations peace force.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Sept. 7 -- Safety features of cars will be promoted actively in the 1959 model year, Harry A. Williams, managing director of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, said today.
One retail store after another is attempting to offset rising costs by adding a charge for a service that once was free or by putting a limit on services that stir are free.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, conferred today with Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem and other Iraqi Government officials on the second leg of his Middle East peace-making mission.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 7 (AP) -- The StudebakerPackard Corporation, poised for a major comeback effort this fall, said today it would add a leading educator and business executive to its board.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- In an eleventh-hour switch, Calvin Griffith, president of the Washington Senators, today decided not to move his club to Minneapolis.
HONG KONG, Sept. 7 -- The Peiping radio pictured all mainland China today as the scene of anti-American demonstrations in which at least 111,600,000 persons took part.
ABOARD THE CRUISER HELENA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Beakley termed the escort oporation a success.
OKLEE, Minn., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Coya Knutson came home today, but not to her husband who had urged her to quit Congress.
BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- The casualty insurance companies serving Massachusetts have asked the state for an average increase of 12 per cent in the injury liability rates for private passenger automobiles.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 7 -- Senator Jorge Alessandri, winner of Chile's Presidential election, said today his Administration would follow economic policies that "will make sense to any business man." He added that his Cabinet would be technical and independent of political parties.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 7 -- The stock market showed some hesitance last week in view of Far East developments but there was no sign of selling pressure. In fact, some stocks met with good demand.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 7 -- President Camille Chamoun's chauffeur was shot and seriously wounded last night at a cafe in the village of Ajaltoon in the mountains ten miles northeast of Beirut. It was not believed that the shooting had any political significance.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Plans for Nassau County's first modern hotel in eighty-five years were announced here today by George Morton Levy, chairman of the Roosevelt Raceway executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Without a murmur about the sanctity of states' rights, the South is quietly yielding to the Federal Government the right to share in the financial support of 1,400 widows of Confederate veterans.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Steel orders and production are expected to rise further this week. Some plants were close for Labor Day last week and most steel users were in the post-holiday transition state. Attempts to catch up will increase activity this week.

A lunch hour at the barbershop has always been a proud and happy occasion for those who have always been a little vain about their hair, and have a thick head of it to be cut off after the two-week period between visits,
Your wonderful Topics writer has done it again. The Sept. 1 column on those noxious boors, the incessant talkers at public performances, was a positive gem.
Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved in a narrow, irregular range last week but closed at slightly better levels than the week before.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 -- The news that the Soviet Union was planning a special party congress in January pushed the China crisis off the front pages but not out of Soviet newspapers today.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- Chief Minister Norman Manley of Jamaica said here tonight that some of the incidents of Britain's current race riots would shame even a Southern state in the United States.
Ceremonies were held yesterday in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, in memory of Maryland heroes of the Revolutionary War who fought in the Battle of Long Island.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Secretary of State Dulles warned today that the Chinese Communists had not renounced "the use of force to serve their expansionist aims."
WOMEN'S eyes should light up when they see Gimbels' fall shoe collection, just as the heels light up on a number of the store's late-day footwear.
Freddie Trenkler, star clown skater of the "Ice Capades," fell from a swinging rope during last night's performance at Madison Square Garden and injured his shoulder as he struck the ice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7--The Government's anti-recession mortgage-buying program has scarcely slackened as a result of President Eisenhower's order in late August barring "par" purchases.
An upturn in the steamship charger market, a usual occurrence after Labor Day, failed to materialize last week. Brokers said there were no indications at present of any impending improvement.

WITH the first presentation this season of "Serenade" on its Saturday afternoon program, the New York City Ballet can finally be said to be officially in residence at the City Center, for this is in a sense its "signature" ballet.
Althea Gibson insisted on her womanly prerogative during the national championships at the West Side Tennis Club and had her way despite the rules of tennis.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Some sound policies could start Argentina's stagnant economy flowing.

THERE is no mystery as to why Australia dominates Davis Cup competition. The land Down Under has the best tennis players in the world. This was demonstrated anew at Forest Hills yesterday when a pair of Aussies vied for the American championship for the third straight year. This insured the island continent of its fifth United States title in eight years.
The Citizens Union has added its voice to the dispute over birth-control therapy in municipal hospitals.

Alpha Agency, insurance underwriters, leased a store in the new office building at 123 William Street in the downtown Manhattan insurance district. The lessee will move from 99 John Street later this year, according to Robert D. Murdock, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, the broker in the deal.

It is a good thing to remember in a time of alarms that the great constructive work of the United Nations in many phases can go forward. Typical is that of the United Nations Children's Fund, whose Executive Board is now in session here. Reports submitted and plans outlined have revealed, once more, how great is the scope of this operation.
John Robbilotto, a suspect in the murder of Willie Moretti in 1951, was found slain early yesterday in a Brooklyn street. He had been shot four times in the head at close range, the police said.
Bertha Savage, lyric soprano, at her Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon disclosed a voice that, although not always handled with skill, is of innately appealing quality.

A split with the Washington Senators was the best the Yankees could get in the season's final double-header at the Stadium yesterday. After they had succumbed to Pedro Ramos, 1 -- 0, in the opener, the Bombers hammered Vito Valentinetti, Jim Constable and John Romonosky for the 7-0 equalizer.
Two films will open at first-run theatres, this week. The program follows:
PRINCETON, N. J. Sept. 7 -- Princeton University will raise its tuition rates $250 in the 1959-60 academic year, but it will protect students against being priced out.
Negotiations between the city and the Cunard Steam-ship Company, Ltd., for a new freight pier have reached the engineer planning stage.

A plot at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street has been assembled by the 1028 Park Avenue Corporation, represented by David Gale, attorney. It consists of five five-story apartment houses and is known as 1020 to 1028 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The public schools of the nation's capital open tomorrow with a number of innovations, including the addition of a week to the school year.
FANGLIAO, Taiwan, Monday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Waves of United States and Nationalist Chinese marines stormed ashore early today in the two nation's first combined amphibious maneuvers.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 7 -- At least fifty boats capsized or were disabled as a sudden squall hit the fifth day of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fall Race Week series today.
Heavy rain, wind, thunder and lightning buffeted parts of the city yesterday afternoon as an erratic squall line moved over the metropolitan area from the Great Lakes.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 7--With a swift rush, Columbia swooped back into the foreground of the America's Cup defense picture today. In the heavy going that she obviously relishes, the favored Henry Sears syndicate contender inflicted another decisive defeat on Vim.
The vigor and steadiness of the business recovery remain uncertain, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in its September monthly review published today.
" The Arthur Godfrey Show," a weekly night-time series that makes its debut on Sept. 23, will feature guest stars on most performances. It also will have a permanent dancing chorus of eight.

The Big Blosson Realty Corporation sold the apartment house for fifty-two families at 807 Tinton Avenue at East 158th Street to an investing client of Julius Seigal. The house also contains two stores. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $45,000.

Executives of Calkins Holden, Inc., and Burke Dowling Adams, Inc., have come close on several occasions to completing a merger. They did again late Friday night. But when the talking was finished, the only thing definite was that there would be more talks this week.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- The stock market was firm and fairly, active last week, with industrials showing sufficient strength to push The Financial Times index to a new 1958 peak of 1906 on Thursday.

The Rev. Dr. Joachim Prinz, president of the American Jewish Congress, said yesterday that a continuing process of assimilation and disintegration threatened the future existence of the Jewish people.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 7 (AP) -- France today won the Prix des Nations jumping contest, the final feature of the five-day international horse show here.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7 -- A northwest thunder squall struck the Eastern Yacht Racing Association fleet off the Indian Harbor Club on Long Island Sound today. Three small sloops capsized.
LONDON, Monday, Sept. 8 -- Sultan Said bin Taimur of Muscat and Oman ceded his only overseas colony to Pakistan today.
May I add this experience in connection with garbage being thrown from windows to those previously described in your columns.

LIME ROCK, Conn., Sept. 7 -- George Constantine of Southbridge, Mass., won the United States Auto Club Road Division's inaugural race at Lime Rock Park today. Constantine drove a newly imported Aston-Martin 3.9, owned by Elisha Walker of Syosset, L. I., to an easy victory. He led all the way and averaged 78.838 miles per hour.

Ashley Cooper and Althea Gibson rule the world of tennis. The supremacy of the 22-year-old youth from Australia and the young woman from Harlem was established beyond question yesterday as each added the American title to the British singles titles they won last July.
Members of the "Beat Generation" were termed "quitters in the game of life" yesterday by the Rev. Bernard P. Donachie at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs employed their favorite weapon -- the home run -- and rang up a double victory over the San Francisco Giants today, 6 -- 4 and 4 -1, before a crowd of 23,435.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Union warned West Germany today that "solidarity with the United States and British policy of interfering in the home affairs of the Arab states may prejudice" the interests of West Germany.

The trend to the lightweight suit more and more men are wearing has accelerated the change in traditional weight standards in tailored and sports clothing, Women's suits and skirts, however, are rising more wool in blended-fiber apparel.

SADDLE RIVER, N. J., Sept. 7 -- This town of 1,200, which every Sunday heretofore did a thriving business, became a sleepy hollow today. One could not buy so much as a newspaper, a bottle of milk or a gallon of gasoline.
LONDON, Sept., 7 -- The Mormon Church dedicated its first British temple today at New Chapel, Surrey, with services to which only Mormons with a "recommend" from their Bishop were admitted.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- A challenging course that winds through lanes of giant cypress trees awaits the start of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship tomorrow.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Gil Hodges drove in three runs with two homers to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.
VAN BUREN, Ark., Sept. 7 -- A Federal court will be asked tomorrow to uphold the right of thirteen Negroes to attend the senior high school here.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Oil has been discovered in Syria in commercial quantities, the country's Minister of Planning said yesterday. An American-owned drilling concern found the oil, and Soviet experts confirmed the discovery, he said.
Housing, medical care and education were described yesterday as major problems facing the Government of Haiti.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- For the second successive day Ch. Merriedip Duke George, an Old English sheepdog, carried off the top honor at a dog show.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- "Kimberly," a story of contemporary drama in the South African diamond fields, has been purchased by Jack Palance for independent production. The original scenario was written by Clay Fisher, a novelist who usually writes in a Western vein.

Many persons failed to report their incomes or reported significantly less income than they had received when they were visited by census-takers in 1950, the National Bureau of Economic Research said in a report yesterday.
LIKE every good Scout -- boy or boutique -- Ferris Megarity is prepared to overcome any adversity to do his duty.
HAVANA, Sept. 7. -- Sporadic fighting has broken out in easternmost Oriente Province after a lull for several weeks in both Government and rebel activities, according to reports today.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Round Hill, a gray gelding from Ted Wahl's Round Hill Stables in Greenwich, Conn., won the open jumper championship of the twenty-eighth Lawrence Farms Horse Show today.

LEEKS, the mild-flavored and incomparable addition to the soup kettle, are in season. The long-stalked white and green vegetable, sometimes called the poor man's asparagus, will remain in peak supply through November. It is available locally at many vegetable counters and at almost all open-air markets.
MONZA, Italy, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Mike Hawthorn today virtually clinched the 1958 world auto driving championship by finishing second to Tony Brooks in the Grand Prix of Italy. Both are English.

The chairman of the Harvard Department of Economics in a pamphlet written for the "American Enterprise Association" states that "there is abundant evidence that unions today have too much economic power." This opinion has provided a handy climax to the monthly letter for August, 1958, of the First National City Bank.
The Committee for Economic Development urged business yesterday to assume full partnership in a grass-roots drive to increase the national productive output.

Robert J. Mangum is a former policeman and for the last few years has been Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of a youth program, until he resigned from the department two months ago. After an otherwise good record through the years he had received a reprimand from Police Commissioner Kennedy last February for "impulsive and improper" action, accompanied by lack of "good judgment," for countermanding a traffic arrest without reporting the incident to the Commissioner.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 7 -- United States warships assisted today in escorting a Nationalist Chinese convoy carrying supplies to Quemoy.
Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia moved closer to the lead in the interzonal chess tournament at Portoroz, Yugoslavia, last night, according to a report received here.
THE many roles that money can play in family life have become a source of lively inquiry among specialists in human relations.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey taxed the Eisenhower Administration yesterday with lack of in frankness in developing policies that committed the United States to defense of the Nationalist-held islands of Quemoy and Matsu off the Red China coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- American Aviation magazine said today the International Air Transport Association had fined member airlines "the somewhat shocking total of $663,000" for breaking its rules.

The "release" of Nikolai A. Bulganin from membership in the highest policy making body of the Soviet Union, the Communist party Presidium, comes as no surprise. As early as July last year, after the equivocal role he played in the unsuccessful Malenkov-Molotov effort to purge Khrushehev, it was clear that Mr. Bulganin's days among the Soviet mighty were numbered.
A 17-year-old boy was killed with a blast from a sawed-off shotgun in East Harlem early yesterday, the innocent victim in a quarrel over a girl.
Tramp ship operators throughout the world have been asked to establish a $30,000,000 pool to keep Liberty ships and other vessels built during World War II off the high seas.

HONG KONG, Sept. 7 -- The Chinese Communist Government charged today that the United States had sent warships into Communist China's territorial waters. A Gov ernment statement containing a "serious warning" was broadcast by the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency. The statement said:

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru contended today that the islands of Quemoy and Matsu must sooner or later be surrendered to Communist China but he appealed for a peaceful solution of the dispute.
VENICE, Italy, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A Japanese film, "Muho-Matsu No Isho" ("The Rickshaw Man"), won first prize tonight in the Venice Film Festival.
Governor Harriman accused Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday of favoring a state tax revision that would benefit the rich at the expense of the poor.
DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Johnny Longden, the world's leading jockey, suffered a broken right leg in a riding accident for the second time in two years today.
Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, was kept off United States television screens yesterday by two hard-hitting Australian tennis players.
" J. B." will be the next tenant at the ANTA Theatre. Archibald MacLeish's Biblical parable, written in verse, is scheduled to open there Dec. 11 under the auspices of Alfred de Liagre Jr.
A new school year will begin today for more than 1,357,000 city youngsters.
IF there is a caterpillar in the house, do not be alarmed. This advice, from the New York Pest Control Association, comes on the heels of a caterpillar invasion that began here about two weeks ago.

OXFORD, Md., Sept. 7 (AP) -- A sudden, violent thunderstorm turned a tune-up race into a nightmare today for forty skippers who are entered in the North American Star Class sailing championship, which begins tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakato, said today that rank-and-file union members would correct wrong-doing by some of their leaders if they were guaranteed a secret ballot and an "honest count."
GUY LAROCHE'S new career at Bergdorf Goodman is a brief but checkered one. His first sportswear collection for this store was presented Friday and checks appeared in every variety.
Mayor Wagner disclosed yesterday that he planned to campaign upstate for the Democratic state ticket this fall.
WHEN Ashley Cooper won the tennis championship of the United States at Forest Hills yesterday he was asked whether he was going to telephone Helen Wood in Melbourne.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Navy Lieut. Richard H. Tabor broke the endurance record for simulated space flight today and fortified himself with four hours' sleep and a steak dinner for the last leg of his seventy-two-hour stay in a 10by-12-foot low pressure chamber.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The league-leading Milwaukee Braves and the second-place Pittsburgh Pirates, trying to make a battle out of the National League race, split a double-header today and the Braves maintained their seven-and-one-half-game bulge.
Four adults used wooden paddles and a baseball bat yesterday to rescue a boy who had fallen on the electrified third rail of a subway track in Brooklyn.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 7 -- The twelfth synagogue constructed since the end of World War II in West Germany was dedicated today in Duesseldorf.

Nelson A. Rockefeller said yesterday that he regarded the Governorship as "a goal in itself" and not as a steppingstone to higher public office. Several New York Governors have been considered potential candidates for the Presidency.

THOR HEYERDAHL, the Norwegian writer, ethnologist and adventurer of "Kon-Tiki" fame, proved to his own satisfaction by his famous raft voyage that pre-Inca Indians from Peru could have emigrated to the eastern islands of Polynesia. But possibility was one thing, likelihood another.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The Soviet Union is increasingly shopping in the United States for chemical technology, according to a survey reported in Chemical and Engineering News.

ROME, Sept. 8 -- In an encyclical letter addressed to the Roman Catholic episcopate in China, clergy and faithful, the Pope has announced the excommunication of all the Chinese prelates who participated in any way in the appointment and consecration of Communist or "progressive" Bishops without the permission of the Holy See.
" THE VOICE OF FIRESTONE," traditionally one of the period pieces in brodcasting, succumbed tentatively and a little reluctantly last night to the twentieth century.
BERLIN, Sept. 8 -- Reports from Leipzig say that crowds at the fair are smaller this year than last and that controls placed on visitors from Western countries are the explanation.
GENEVA, Sept. 8 -- The use of isotopes, or tracer elements, has enabled physiologists to explain many mystifying processes in the bodies of animals and man, it was reported here today.

Mrs. Henry S. Prescott, chairman of the theatre benefit committee for the New York Botanical Garden, has announced that because of the indefinite postponement of the New York opening of "At the Grand," the garden has changed plans for its theatre party.
The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will benefit from theatre parties on Oct. 8 and Oct. 27.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 8 -- Fifty-four growers of tomatoes arrived in New York today from Italy to study more efficient methods of producing tomato paste for export to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the United States Supreme Court granted a conditional stay today in condemnation proceedings for acquisition by New York State of Tuscarora Indian lands for the Niagara Falls power project.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Lieut Richard H. Tabor emerged from a low-pressure space chamber today with a grin and an endurance record of seventy-two hours.

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Science must determine whether prolonged exposure to such things as cooking odors and perspiration odors would be a hazard before man can safely venture into space or take indefinitely long voyages in nuclear submarines.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Contrary to that once popular refrain, there'll be no changes made in the territorial set-up of major league baseball. At least not in the foreseeable future.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- State Department officials were preparing today to defend their China policy on two diplomatic fronts: in a bristling reply to Nikita S. Khrushchev and in "a fresh approach" to Communist China at talks in Warsaw.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 8 -- A Chinese Nationalist transport vessel bearing ammunition and supplies was blown out of the water at Quemoy this afternoon under the eyes of crews aboard United States convoy ships.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Dow Finsterwald of Tequesta, Fla., captured the $17,000 Utah open golf tournament today with 267. Fred Hawkins of El Paso and Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., were next at 268.

The First National City Bank of New York and the County Trust Company of White Plains said yesterday they would not appeal a Federal Reserve Board decision denying them permission to join in establishing a new holding company.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 8 (AP) -- The joint Federal-State Action Committee approved a proposal today to make available to the states 40 per cent of the Federal tax on local telephone bills for vocational education and sewage treatment construction.
The liner Brasil, the first new American luxury liner for the New York - Brazil - Argentina service, made her maiden appearance here yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- The five-month deadlock in labor negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation appeared to have been broken today.
Federal mediators decided yesterday to intervene in the stalled contract negotiations between the General Electric Company and the biggest union active among its 250,000 employes.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 8 -- Order prevailed as classes resumed today in Nashville's partly integrated schools.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) -Former Senator George H. Bender said today that the $250 a day he received as head of a Teamsters Union clean-up committee would be turned over to charity.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, of Michigan accused two labor union publications today of falsifying his voting record in Congress.
LONDON, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- Chi-Chi, one of four giant pandas in captivity, has tried for the second time to make it only three.
Austin, Texas, has announced that it will seek competitive bids Sept. 18 for $9,100,000 of various purpose bonds. The bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1958, will mature from 1959 to 1983.
PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, Sept. 9 -- Maine voters swept Gov. Edmund S. Muskie into a seat in the United States Senate in yesterday's election.

Recently I returned to America after three years of travel in Asia and Europe. During that time I took part in numberless conversations about the United States. In one city after another I heard persons say accusingly, sympathetically or with resignation that Americans, alas, have no culture.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 8 -- The next two extraordinary sessions of the State Supreme Court for the Suffolk land scandals case were scheduled today to be held Sept. 17 and Oct. 6 "somewhere in Suffolk County." Space in county buildings has been termed insufficient.

A letter was mailed yesterday to holders of the common stock of Central Public Utility Corporation advising them of the formation of a stockholders' committee seeking to intervene in proceedings before the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding a proposed merger.
BLEXEN, Germany, Sept. 3 -- The largest floating drydock built in Europe since World War II is about to slide down the ways here into the Weser River estuary.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- French territories that choose their independence by rejecting the proposed Constitution Sept. 28 will not determine the over-all result in France.
City police officials said yesterday that the growing complexity of law enforcement demanded increased professionalism in crime detection and prevention.
The bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad cut its service yesterday. It stopped running 104 of its 1,136 weekday trains linking Manhattan, Jersey City and Hoboken.
A man who the police said was resisting arrest for attempted bribery in connection with a television contest was accidentally wounded yesterday by a detective.

A PENNY for your thoughts today; in fact, a subway token, Macy's, having the subway commuter in mind, has imported "fold-up and snap" key holders with an attachment to hold tokens. The attachment has a special spring-like tip that prevents the tokens from slipping astray.
Many Russians are eager to learn about American living standards and improve their own material prosperity, a group of United States students reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A Southern law professor today likened court enforcement of integration to Federal police efforts that failed to carry out prohibition aims of the Volstead Act.
TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- Japan claimed jurisdiction over a 19-year-old United States Air Force enlisted man today after a fatal shooting incident.
HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 8 -- Federal Judge John Paul charged "politicians" and "officers of the state" today with inciting public hostility to the racial integration of Virginia's public schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -The National Industrial Traffic League and the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to lift its suspension of freight forwarder rates on volume shipments between the East and West Coasts.
HONG KONG, Sept 8 -- A statement expressing Mao Tse-tung's approval of a resumption in Warsaw of ambassadorial talks with the United States was broadcast today by the Peiping radio.

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has urged President Eisenhower in a lengthy letter to revise United States policy on China and to extend formal recognition to the Chinese Communist regime.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Travis Kerr's Round Table took a $3,000 step toward the money-winning lead among thoroughbreds today when he won the mile-and-a-sixteenth Ambassador Purse at the Atlantic City Race Course.

Stocks rose to a new high for the year yesterday in sprightly trading. The advance was fairly broad, carrying with it the blue chips as well as lower-price specialties. In recent sessions, activity has centered on the latter.

Your editorial of Aug. 81 "The Rule of Law" poses serious questions that I would like answered. Must all decisions of the Supreme Court be accepted as the law of the land regardless of consequences? Should people accept without question every word of the court?

VAN BUREN, Ark., Sept. 8 -- A Federal judge refused today to consider a request from an attorney for Negro students at Van Buren Senior High School that he cite the school board for contempt. But the judge advised the lawyer that he should file a new action in the case.
Two groups of parents kept twenty-one Negro children home when school opened yesterday, threatening court tests of the Board of Education's zoning regulations.
PARIS, Sept. 8 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle said today that nations must unite in a world government or perish.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 8 -Gentler breezes fanned the dying embers of gallant Vim's America's Cup defense hopes back into roaring flames today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept 8 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Herbert Christenberry issued a preliminary injunction today requiring Louisiana State University's branch school in New Orleans to cease its policy of discrimination against Negro students.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 8 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said tonight that the principal objective of Israel's foreign policy was to maintain the status quo in the Middle East as long as possible.

The possibility of portraying Falstaff in both parts of "Henry IV" fascinates Burl Ives. His wife insists it is not a whim. She says her husband is willing to devote eight months to the dual stint at England's Shakespeare Memorial Theatre.

The most reasonable interpretation of the recent increases in discount rates by several Federal Reserve banks is that the Reserve authorities believe that the commercial banks will be less aggressive in seeking loans and investments if the volume of their "free" reserves (surplus reserves minus borrowings from the Reserve banks) is reduced below the $500 million average of July and the immediately preceding months.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- More than forty nations began talks here today to determine whether prices and production of copper, lead and zinc should be stabilized by international agreement. The United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union, West Germany and most of the important producing countries are represented.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that farmers would harvest 12,105,000 bales of cotton this year, thanks to favorable weather and a record yield of 486 pounds to the acre.
The steel industry has scheduled steel-making operations this week at the highest level so far this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ALGIERS, Sept. 8 -- A world traveler from Illinois went swimming in the heart of the Sahara yesterday, ate dates with a kaid this morning, shook hands with French oil workers and turbaned African shepherds and got snubbed by a dromedary.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 8 -- Brazilian coffee growers have turned down the latest Government plan to ease this country's mounting surpluses, which was announced Saturday by Finance Minister Lucas Lopes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Treasury bill rate fell back a little this week after a month of steep increases, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,800,000,900 of the 91-day discount bills was 2.359 per cent, compared with 2.462 per cent last week.
" The Invisible Man" may no be visible this fall.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- Lieut. Hillman Robbins, the defending champion, had to go the full eighteen holes to win in the opening round of the United States Golf Association's amateur championship today.
An attack on Rockaway slums will be planned Thursday when health, housing, slum-clearance, welfare and fire officials meet with Queens Borough President James J. Crisona.

Eight men were held yesterday as material witnnesses or on technical charges of vagrancy in the killing of John Robbilotto, who was found shot dead Sunday morning on an East Flatbush street in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Ten states hold primary elections tomorrow, nearly completing the selection of candidates who will compete in Novemeber for seats in Congress and for state and local offices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Federal Judge Harry J. Lemley, who authorized a two-and-one-half-year delay in school integration at Little Rock, has applied for retirement, the Justice Department said tonight.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 8 -Sceptre, the British challenger for the America's Cup, was back on the ways today for rigging repairs.

A "rubber road," almost three and one-half miles long, has begun moving a mountain to a huge dam site on the Trinity River near Redding in northern California.
Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals swore in Robert J. Mangum as second Deputy Commissioner yesterday in a brief ceremony in his office.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 2 points higher to 6 points lower than on last Friday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will collect blood today at the Lockheed Aircraft Service International, Inc., at Idlewild, Queens. Blood also will be given at the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 4 Irving Place.

Michael H. Prendergast accused Republicans yesterday of having made thirty-two misstatements of fact in their 1958 state platform. These range, he added, from "the hilarious to the outrageous."

The biggest news in the capital market this week -- or indeed for many weeks -- is Sears, Roebuck Co.'s proposed $350,000,000 debenture issue, the largest public debt offering ever to be underwritten in this country.

The Minute Man of Revolutionary War fame has been called upon periodically in the intervening years to serve as a symbol of the pristine American spirit. MODELS held on to their hats and billowing skirts with some urgency yesterday at a breezy fashion show presented on a hangar strip at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Descending from a Trans World Airlines Jetstream plane to a runway, they wore the first collection of French and Italian couture originals imported by Alexander's.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP)--The grain futures market failed to muster much buying support today even after a broad general decline. Prices on the Board of Trade closed near their lows of the day.

With all seven employes at work at 9:15 A. M. yesterday at the Art In Metal Company in Brooklyn, Robert Kerner was startled to hear someone "punch" the timeclock. When Mr. Kerner investigated, he found a monkey.

THE great Sauterne wines of France are sweet. The vast majority of California wines that bear that label are dry and the difference is caused by a phenomenon of nature. In the Bordeaux regions where Sauternes are produced, the grapes are deliberately left to shrivel on the vine and develop what is called pourriture noble, or noble mold.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 8 -- Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night" was given a welcome tonight by an obviously deeply moved audience at the Lyceum Theatre. MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Beaming its broadcast to North America the Moscow radio charged today that the United States was "nearing the edge of the precipice" in the Far East.

There are moments when geography must rule diplomacy. There is a definite absurdity in attempting to keep the islands neighboring Amoy under a Government hostile to the China mainland. The fancy that their control is essential to the defense of Taiwan is only a shade less fantastic than a theory that the control of Long Island is essential to the defense of Bermuda.
OXFORD, Md., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Weather hampered the North American Star class sailing championship for the third time today. Lack of wind becalmed the boats and the day's race was called off.

The largest underwritten offering of corporate debt securities in American history was oversubscribed yesterday. It raised $350,000,000 for Sears, Roebuck $ Co., the biggest retailer of general merchandise in the world.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 9 -- Liberal Democrats, allied with the northern wing of the national party, were steam-rollered into defeat, but not submission, at the biennial state party convention today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -The administrator of the Government's petroleum import curbs proposed a new formula today for determining how much each importing company might bring in. The aim of the revision is to make one rule applicable to all importers, to make its application automatic, and to give it a fairly steady base.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 9 -- President Eisenhower talked with Secretary Dulles and other officials today about the military situation in the Taiwan Straits and the latest note from Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.

" Salute to Summer," New York's third "Summer music gala," took place last night at the Wollman Memorial in Central Park. The concert was presented by the city in cooperation with the Concert Artists Guild. The performers were Martina Arroyo, soprano; Morey Ritt and Stanley Babin, pianists, and Isidor Lateiner, violinist.
The designation of Stanley H. Lowell as Acting Deputy Mayor was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Demand for zinc -- one of the hardest-hit metals in the recession --turned sharply upward last month, a report of the American Zinc Institute showed yesterday.
The number of buyers in the city to fall in lines of fall apparel and buy new merchandise has set a record for the week after Labor Day.

BY vocation a housewife, Mrs. Peggy Laut of Jamaica, Queens, lists entering cooking contests as her most absorbing avocation. This petite, brown-haired grandmother has been trying her hand at inventing prize-winning recipes for about twenty years now. She has received thirty-five awards, ranging from an egg beater to a General Electric range.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 9 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. said today that Warren County's high school might be the first to close under Virginia's anti-integration laws.
LONDON, Sept. 9--The conference of major producers and consumers of copper, lead and zinc who are meeting here under sponsorship of the United Nations divided today into small working parties.

A series of meetings and teas are being held to complete plans for the anniversary cocktail dance to aid the Children's Health Service. The event will take place in the ballroom of the Pierre on the afternoon of Nov. 13.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A near-sweep by Democrats in traditionally Republican Maine jolted Republicans today, confronting them with the probabilities of heavy House and Senate losses in November.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 19 -- Rumania's Communist Government has put an end to flirtation with new ideas and has returned to the security of "Socialist discipline."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Following are texts of letters from Attorney General William P. Rogers to Dean Dauley, City Manager of Little Rock, Ark., and to Wayne Upton, president of the Little Rock School Board, both dated Sept. 7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Eight members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged President Eisenhower today to place more emphasis on economic aid to under-developed countries in next year's Mutual Security program.
YONKERS, Sept. 9 -- The first Soviet citizen ever to put down a $2 bet at the Yonkers Raceway picked a winner tonight. He pocketed $20.60 and promptly announced that he was through with betting.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- The outbreak of race riots in Britain, a nation long proud of its record of racial tolerance, has provoked a number of frank inquiries into what the British people really feel and think about the Negroes in their midst.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- United Artists announced today that it would release a minimum of twenty-six large-budget features in 1959.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -Grain futures dealers decided today that current prices on the Board of Trade still were not much of a bargain and they allowed most contracts to continue their decline.
An optimistic annual report on Brooklyn was sent to Mayor Wagner yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore.
HONG KONG, Sept. 9 -- Premier Chou En-lai said tonight it was the United States, not Communist China, that was "using armed force to achieve territorial ambitions."

GUATEMALA, Sept. 9 -- The United Fruit Company ceased its operations indefinitely in the Pacific Coast division of Tiquisate as of midnight last night rather than pay its workers a salary rise and fringe benefits.
ON the noisy, industrial southern edge of Greenwich Village, on the upper floor of a loft building, a young music lover and a gray-haired cabinetmaker are manufacturing harpsichords.

A "shipper" from California by way of Chicago was the winner of the featured mile race at Belmont Park yesterday. Annie-Lu-San, a 5-year-old daughter of Khaled, held a late lead to take the event by a head over Craftiness of the Short Brook Farms.

Although the musical version of Sean O'Casey's "Juno and the Paycock" has been virtually set for some time, it was not until yesterday that the celebrated Irish playwright gave the all-clear production signal.

BUENOS ARIES, Sept. 8 -- An indication that President Arturo Frondizi was reconsidering his Air Force policy was seen in the swearing in today of Interior Minister Alfredo Vitolo as provisional Minister of Defense.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Wesley Powell, former administrative assistant to Senator Styles Bridges, forged far ahead in a five-man race for the Republican nomination for governor in New Hampshire's primary tonight.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 9 -- In a primary marked by few surprises, Senator Arthur V. Watkins seemed assured of renomination on the Republican ticket here today.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 -- Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation held an extraordinary night session today to try to work out a settlement of their contract dispute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -The Government announced two major foreign aid transactions today.

THE late summer crop of sweet green peppers is in excellent supply, being 3 per cent above last year's and 25 per cent above average. This abundance suggests their generous use in meals during September.

The First National City Bank of New York has leased space for a branch office in the twenty-seven-story office building under construction at 730 Third Avenue. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agent for the structure, negotiated the lease.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said yesterday that the lack of adequate attention to civil defense was the most dangerous threat to survival facing the nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Unemployment declined last month to its lowest point since January and employment rose for the sixth consecutive month to a high for the year, according to joint estimates by the Commerce and Labor departments.
The development of an operation that permits patients with cancer of the esophagus to eat steak and french fried potatoes ten days after surgery was announced yesterday at Montefiore Hospital.
CAIRO, Sept. 9 -- Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub, foreign Minister of the Sudan, was named today by the council of the Arab League as its candidate for the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly.

Two works carried over from the New York City Opera Company's spring season of American opera bring the number of works announced by the company for its fall season to thirteen. Seven will be in English.
Last season the Rangers finished second in the National Hockey League, their highest in sixteen years.

Last Sunday's professional sports car race at Lime Rock, Conn., attracted a crowd of close to 10,000. Most of them sat through two thunderstorms and laughed at the mud to watch this first effort of the United States Auto Club road racing division.

BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 9 -A dance was given t the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club this evening by Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Bondy of Salem Center and Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Perkins Foss 3d of Katonah for their debutante daughters, Miss Sally Rae Bondy and Miss Nannette Blakeley Foss.

Stockholders of Pillsbury Mills, Inc., approved a change in the corporate name to the Pillsbury Company at the annual meeting yesterday in Minneapolis. The change was in line with company plans for greater product diversification.

During the Civil War, Atlanta was the key city to the Confederacy's communications and supplies. Its strategic importance made its destruction important to the North. How this occurred and what happened in the Southern city are told in two books scheduled for publication shortly.
Corporation employes, in avoiding political activity for business reasons, are endangering American democracy, according to a Cornell University professor.
A 79-year-old artist will have his first one-man show Tuesday, but nobody thinks he is backward. For Leo Schutzman did not being to paint until he was 73.

Most of the country's merchants expect retail sales in the second half of the year at least to equal last year's and possibly go 4 per cent above that level. They also look for the full year's sales to be as good as those for 1957 or slightly better.
The Federal Government will soon reserve $4,000,000 of its newly available urban renewal funds for aid to the West Side rehabilitation project.
HARRISON, Ark., Sept. 9 (AP) -- United States District Judge John E. Miller of Fort Smith said today he had been assigned temporary duty on the bench of the Eastern District of Arkansas.

CUELGAMUROS, Spain, Sept. 7 -- The Valley of the Fallen, the modern monument built by Generalissimo Francisco Franco near Madrid to commemorate the dead of the Spanish Civil War, has been officially opened to the public.

ROCHESTER, N. Y, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The State power Authority, acting quickly on authority from Justice John Marshall Harlan of the United States Supreme Court, today asked United States District Judge Harold P. Burke to condemn eighty-six acres of the Tuscarora Indian Reservation.
Despite patrolling by the city and railroad police, New York Central trains continue to be stoned on the Harlem viaduct.

The latest Government figures on employment and unemployment have confounded the expectations of both pessimists and optimists. The pessimists feared six months ago that the sharply higher unemployment figures registered in the first months of this year might go well past the 6,000,000 mark by this time. Happily this has not happened, but last month's unemployment figure of almost 4,700,000 does represent a rise of the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate to 7.6 per cent.

The master of the liner Queen Elizabeth, Capt. Charles S. Williams, will be seen here on the bridge of the world's largest passenger liner for the last time today. Captain Williams, who is commodore of the Cunard Line, will be on the last voyage before retirement when he arrives in Southampton next Tuesday. He is 63 years old.

THE Meldan Furniture Company opened its new showroom yesterday at 351 East Sixty-first Street. The showing introduced this company's 1959 furniture designs in a luxurious setting of simple graybeige walls and rich gold carpeting, highlighted with touches of Bristol blue, gold and white.

John J. Hoeckh, Inc., and Foss Dohm, Inc., property management concerns have combined operations at 370 West Forty-sixth Street. The companies will continue to do business under their respective names.
The Treasurer of Orange County was temporarily enjoined yesterday from selling United States Government property on Stewart Air Force Base, near Newburgh, N. Y., to satisfy local tax liens.

TAIPEI, Sept. 9 (AP) -- With United States help the Chinese Nationalists can keep Quemoy supplied despite "a relatively determined effort by the Chinese Communists" to blockade the besieged outposts. Vice Admiral Wallace M. Beakley said today.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Price movements on the stock exchange today were small and irregular, although gains predominated in the main industrial sections.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 9--Bob Silver, a sophomore quarterback, suffered a simple fracture in his lower left leg in the Columbia football team's workout this morning.

The theatre benefit committee of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service has been holding frequent meetings at the Carlton House to further plans for its theatre party at the Nov. 19 performance of "The Marriage Go-Round."

The New York Central Railroad has tapped the Interstate Commerce Commission for one of its youngest commissioners, Robert W. Minor, 38 years old, to become its vice president -- law. The post pays $55,000 a year.
Governor Harriman predicted yesterday that the election this fall would result in "one of the greatest Democratic victories in the history of the state."

TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- Action by the Legislature that would circumvent a court order requiring the reassessment of all real property in New Jersey by Jan. 1 appeared probable tonight for the first time.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -The Government was assailed here today for inconsistency in its policy toward oil imports by a leader of the petroleum industry.

A new approach toward a solution of the Palestine refugee problem was made in a report issued yesterday. It is the result of much study, thought and civic-mindedness by a panel of independent scholars and authorities on the Middle East grouped in a recently formed American organization called the Institute for Mediterranean Affairs.

THE New York City Ballet gave us a new Swan Queen at the City Center last night, the like of whom has not been seen in these parts in half a dozen blue moons. Her name is Allegra Kent, and we have all known that she was a gifted youngster for some time; but to take on the role of Odette in "Swan Lake" is quite another matter.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Sept. 10 -- A rise in automobile prices is "inevitable," George Romney, president of American Motors, said today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- A $200,000 so-called "wrong door" suit filed against Frank Sinatra, the actor, and Joe DiMaggio, former baseball star, was dismissed in Superior Court today because of an outof-court settlement for $7,500.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 -A second reduction of United States troops in Lebanon was officially announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Dr. Malcolm Charles Moos, who was named today as the administrative assistant to President Eisenhower in charge of speech-writing, is one of those Republicans whom the late Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire, pillar of Republican orthodoxy, once characterized as "sons of the wild jackass.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 10 -- It took a jury only sixty-five minutes today to decide that 30year-old Mrs. Caroline L. Reidy, a former Democratic ward leader, was not guilty of accepting money under false pretenses.
I have never met a better trained and experienced executive in the field of public administration than Robert J. Mangum.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 -For the second time in two months United States Marines swarmed ashore on a Lebanese beach today.
The question of American intervention in defense of Quemoy and Matsu has not been resolved. Until a decision is made, it is the privilege and the duty of Americans to discuss and debate the issue.

Today's new film is "Wind Across the Everglades," starring Burl Ives and Christopher Plummer, at the Mayfair, Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. Nicholas Ray directed the Warner Brothers drama, which was written by Budd Schulberg and produced by Stuart Schulberg. Gypsy Rose Lee and George Voskovec are in supporting roles.
The recession appears to have left the typewriter-manufacturing industry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -The Government forecast today record crop production for this year on the smallest acreage in forty years.

Roy Campanella held his first open press conference yesterday and seemed to enjoy every minute of it. The Dodger catcher, paralyzed from the neck down in an auto mobile accident on Jan. 28, met reporters and photographers in a large room on the sixth floor of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.
ALBANY, Sept. 10 (AP) -The chairman of the State Lottery Commission said today he would recommend to the commission that reports made to it on the operation of bingo games be made public.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- Mohammed Abmed Mahgoub, Sudanese Foreign Minister, today entered the race for president of the General Assembly against Dr. Charles Malik, Lebanese Foreign Minister.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- A collection of early Thomas A. Edison movies, said to have been made by Edison himself about 1900, has been found in an attic.
An 8-year-old boy has asserted that he killed both of his parents with a knife in their Staten Island home Sept. 2, District Attorney John M. Braisted Jr. of Richmond County announced last night.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (UPI) -Ralph (Tiger) Jones, the middleweight trial horse from Yonkers, tossed a road block into the rising career of Mickey Crawford tonight.
ATLANTA, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gov. Ernest Vandiver won the Georgia Governorship in a landslide tonight over two opponents in the Democratic primary.

LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 10 -- While commercial deals between East and West Germany are being quietly arranged at the international fair here, the two states are exchanging hard words on the political level.

Twenty-one Negro pupils -fifteen in Harlem and six in Brooklyn -- were kept out of public school yesterday for the third consecutive day in a protest against their assignment to predominately Negro schools.
Pan American World Airways and National Airlines have agreed on a number of financial and operating moves that some observers believe may lead to a series of airline mergers.
Only 4,180 voters here registered centrally for this year's election, the Board of Elections reported yesterday. The central registration period ended Monday.
Webb Knapp, Inc., the realty development concern, has purchased a 90,000-square-foot parcel of land on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets.
Old Public School 82 in Manhattan, which has been part of the passing scene since 1885, witnessed a remarkable new set of events yesterday.
MADISONVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The police broke up a blockade in front of a desegregated school today. They escorted three Negroes into the building and made four arrests.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)The report of today's livestock markets here by the department of Agriculture follows:
PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- S. A. C. means Strategic Air Command, but it will take on a new meaning for personnel in the future: Stay Away from Calories.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Comment in the official press tended today to support the belief here that the Soviet Union will lead a major drive to seat Communist China in the United Nations at the General Assembly session opening Tuesday.
Buddy Bregman, music arranger and conductor on the Eddie Fisher show, may star on a weekly television program beginning Oct. 2 over the National Broadcasting Company network.
BUFFALO, Sept. 10 (AP) -Reports of possible pay-offs to city officials on paving contracts were read into court records today.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Counsel for twenty-nine oil companies began arguments in United States District Court here today on a defense motion to dismiss an indictment on price-fixing.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Sept. 10 -- Shouting war cries and hurling iron tipped hunting spears, a band of Tonga warriors clashed in the Zambesi valley at Gwembe today with a force of armed European and African police.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian exports in July were valued at $413,400,000, down from $438,000,000 a year ago, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.
Nelson A. Rockefeller appealed yesterday for the increase use of television for education, especially to inform citizens about civil rights problems.
LONDON, Sept, 10 -- A meeting of the world's principal producers and consumers of copper decided today that inter-governmental control of price and production of the metal was unnecessary.
I commend to Duane A. Dittman, whose letter referring to the recently signed National Defense Education Act appeared in your Sept. 3 issue, a careful reading of the bill.

NEWARK, Sept. 10 -- An associate general counsel of the Interstate Commerce Commission took a long look into the future of railroading here today and came up with the prediction that eventually there would be no passenger traffic.
DALLAS, Sept. 10 -- A Federal judge yesterday upheld two Texans charged with having raised wheat without a Government acreage allotment.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 10 -- Public health activities must be planned on a regional basis becauseof the increasing complexity of public health problems in areas around metropolitan centers, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe said today.

THE young Eskimo is seldom scolded or rarely punished, and his opinion is eagerly solicited and widely respected. These are the findings of Dr. Morton I. Teicher, director of Yeshiva University's School of Social Work, who has lived with the Eskimos and has done anthropological field work among them.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation mailed to stockholders yesterday the detailed plans of a proposed liquidation of the company to be voted upon at a special meeting Sept. 30. The liquidation and dissolution, which would be accomplished within three years from date of adoption, requires approval of holders of two-thirds of the outstanding capital stock.
ALGIERS, Sept. 10 -- A Sharp increase in military activity has taken place in Algeria.
There has been some spirited bidding recently for William Marchant's comedy - drama "Faster! Faster!" But it is Carmen Capalbo who has acquired the Broadway rights.

The spot September cocoa position was steady early yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, but the market weakened late in the session to close at or near the lows. Short covering was noted in the morning. Later, general selling induced stop-loss ordering.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Minor gains outnumbered losses on the stock market today, although the turnover remained small.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has made a $15,500,000 mortgage loan on the thirty - four - story office building recently completed at 750 Third Avenue. Uris Brothers, builders, own the property.
The redevelopment of the Jamaica business district and its neighboring residential slum into an urban "dreamland" was suggested yesterday by a Federal official.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in gross income for the three and six months ended June 30. Net income in both periods, however, was less than the year-ago levels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A teamsters' lawyer acknowledged today that the union had investigated three Senate investigators and had run a credit check on prospective jurors in the bribery trial of James R. Hoffa last year.

Paul Ilton, who died in January, was internationally known as an archaeologist, lecturer, teacher and author. A posthumous account of his twenty-five years as an archaeologist and of the treasures he personally excavated is given in "The Bible Was My Treasure Map," which Messner will publish Sept. 29.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Following are excerpts from a brief submitted to the Supreme Court in the Little Rock, Ark., school integration case by Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, as a friend of the court.
GROTON, Conn., Sept. 10 (AP) -- New research findings promise to allow Navy frogmen to swim deeper and longer without danger of ailments known as the bends, a Navy physician reported today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -Democratic leaders from northeastern states met here today in the wake of their triumph in Maine to hear three potential Presidential candidates assail the Republicans for everything from the Far East crisis to the economic recession.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Specific substances have been found that may cause the mental deterioration that sometimes accompanies severe kidney damage, it was reported here today.
NOT much of Betty MacDonald's "The Egg and I" is left in the Negro musical show of that title at the Jan Hus Auditorium, where it opened last evening.
BOSTON, Sept. 10 -- Three New England states whose primaries were largely overshadowed by voting events in Maine emerged today with slates for the coming campaign.
The Republic of Liberia has become a full member of the International Ice Patrol, David M. Thomas, consul general for that country, reported yesterday.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 10 -President Eisenhower will report to the nation tomorrow night on the "situation in the Taiwan Strait."

WEST PATERSON, N. J., Sept. 10 -- A construction company paymaster was robbed of $20,000 in a deserted section of a public park here today and then was locked in the trunk of his car while the bandits fled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- A Miami lawyer testified today that he had heard Thurman A. Whiteside offer to "release" Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communication Commission Commissioner, from any pledge Mr. Mack "thought he might have had" in the Miami Channel 10 television dispute.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that he had the power to order Central High School closed before it actually opened Monday and might use it.

Stocks retreated yesterday after the advances of Monday and Tuesday, when new 1958 highs were set. There was nothing disorderly about the drop. In fact The New York Times industrial average just managed to register a 1958 high before prices eased in moderate trading.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the 15-year-old United States chess champion, drew with Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia in the twenty-first round of the interzone tournament at Portoroz last night, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
OMAHA, Sept. 10 (AP) -A New York financier said today that he had a "purely selfish reason" for working to give Negroes a fair chance to get good jobs.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Robert H. Morse Sr. announced today that he had agreed to sell control of Fairbanks, Morse Co. to the Penn-Texas Corporation.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- The United Automobile Workers set a strike deadline today against the Ford Motor Company.

Business in bonds yesterday was good and bad. On the one hand, the huge $350,000,000 Sears, Roebuck Co. debenture issue was heavily oversubscribed; on the other, long-term Government bonds sank to new lows for the year.
Estimated net income of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company dropped 21 per cent in the nine months ended July 31, from the level in the period last year. Net sales fell 10 per cent.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 10 -- This was "Back the Indians Night" in Cleveland's huge Municipal Stadium and the Yankees, it must be said, cooperated to the full.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves continued their march toward a second straight National League pennant by beating the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3 -- 0, tonight on the three-hit pitching of Juan Pizarro.
The two top officers of the United Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. endorsed yesterday the use of "troops and tanks if necessary" to enforce school integration in the South.
A blind Catholic-Arab citizen of Israel expressed his intention yesterday of eventually returning to Israel to work for closer relationships between the Arabs and Jews in the Middle East.
A proposal for solving the Palestine refugee problem was offered yesterday by the newly formed Institute for Mediterranean Affairs.
The filter cigarette has arrived in Moscow.
