BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 10 -- The most tantalizing mystery about Rumania has nothing to do with high party politics or great international problems. It has to do with shop windows.
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The United States Air Force said today it will give Japan jurisdiction over the case of Airman 3/c Peter E. Longpre in the accidential shooting of a Japanese youth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, disclosed today that he had issued orders for the Army and Air Force to halt their feud over whose anti-aircraft missile was better.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -The new, young (45) Attorney General of the United States, William P. Rogers, is giving the country a striking demonstration these days of how the Federal Government can make the country aware of its policies in a complicated and controversial question such as public school integration.
Customs revenues in the Port of New York last month were virtually unchanged from collections during August, 1957.

THE season for fresh figs is very short -- from now until the end of September. Because of their extreme perishability, figs are available only in limited quantities and at prices that class them as a luxury item. But for those who enjoy this earliest fruit of man, now is a good time to savor its deliciousness.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 10 -Columbia and Vim, the two able racing sloops that are competing for the right to defend the America's Cup against the British yacht, Sceptre, remained in harbor today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -Except for a few minutes of active dealings early in the session, the grain futures market was a draggy affair again today with major guiding influences absent.
Governor Harriman and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan are scheduled to open campaign headquarters today in the Shelton Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.

THE only things missing yesterday at Macy's press showing of its French and Italian originals were champagne and the clash of cymbals. It has a morning of triumph for those buyers who had scoured the recent French and Italian Couture collections like quiet, ever-flagging commandos.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 10 -- The annual post-season East Hampton bridge and canasta party and fashion show will be held at the Maidstone Club here tomorrow as a benefit for the East Hampton Neighborhood House.
The construction of Contello Towers, a $5,173,320 cooperative housing project for middle-income families, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
Stock in the forty-eight-yearold Champion Spark Plug Company is being sold for the first time today on behalf of controlling shareholders.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 -- Martin Stanovich, a 43-yearold Chicagoan with a deceptive golf style, beat the defender, Lieut. Hillman Robbins, in the third round of the United States amateur championship today.

Important conferences are getting under way in Washington between Secretary Dulles and Foreign Minister Fujiyama of allied Japan. These conferences were scheduled before the Taiwan crisis and are not directly related to it, but they involve a revision of our mutual security treaty that is a keystone of our whole Pacific defense structure.
PARENTS who want to learn with their children may choose from a variety of courses this fall.

The City Council and Fire Commissioner Cavanagh deserve applause for their efforts to protect the lives of the thousands who work in New York's factories and loft buildings. Credit is due to the Council for passing the three fire safety laws on Tuesday -- in addition to those they passed last spring -- and to Mr. Cavanagh for proposing them in the first place and for his hard-hitting campaign to get them passed.
The absence of any significant "organized anti-Semitic movements" in South America was reported here yesterday by the American Jewish Committee.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 10 -- The first master plan for this South Shore community was submitted to village officials here tonight.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey will move today to force an early showdown on metropolitan rapid transit.
Philip Morris' Johnny is being recalled from the minors. His high-pitched "Call For Philip Morris" will figure prominently in the company's fall television and radio campaign.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -High Republican leaders said today they were convinced party pressure would force Sherman Adams to leave the White House soon.
WARSAW, N. Y., Sept. 10 -Representative Kenneth B. Keating, the Republican candidate for Senator, made his first batch here today for the upstate term vote.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The condition of pastures on Sept. 1 was reported at 86 per cent of normal, compared with 82 per cent a year earlier and 77 per cent for the ten-year Sept. 1 average.

The Salem Industrial Center in Massachusetts is being sold by the Employe Profit Sharing Plan of Webb Knapp, Inc., the realty development concern. The Signal Manufacturing Company of Lynn, Mass., has contracted to buy the property, which covers thirty acres.
An experimental automobile designed to make driving of tomorrow as easy as automatic television tuning of today has been developed by General Motors.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 10 (UPI) -- The Alexandria School Board upheld tonight the dismissal of a Negro school cook. She was discharged because she had sued the board to have two of her eight children admitted to a white school.

Mrs. Mabel C. Scholtz' Warhead won the $30,200 Discovery Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, at a mile and a furlong, was named for one of the turf's best weight carriers. Warhead was one of two horses that carried the top burden of 124 pounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 10 -Except for the pro shop, the best place to find a golf ball at the Olympic Club is in one of the hundreds of cypress trees that line the fairways. That is, if you can reach them.
PURCHASE, N. Y, Sept. 10 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Clara Rossin trophy in the ninth annual senior championship today.
GENEVA, Sept. 10 -- A prominent United States scientist proposed tonight that American and Soviet scientists collaborate as modern-day alchemists in the creation of new elements.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Western diplomats speculated today that the United States might propose to the Chinese Communists the demilitarization of Quemoy and the neighboring mainland coast.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 10 -United States customs agents and border patrolmen captured thirty-one men and seized $10,000 worth of military equipment and medical supplies on a boat just north of here early today. One other man escaped.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Dick Stuart crashed a tworun homer with two out in the tenth inning tonight to help Bob Friend become the first twenty-game winner in the National League this season as the Pittsburgh Pirates downed the San Francisco Giants, 6 -- 4.
TORONTO, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Bob Bedard, Canada's top-ranking player, upset Ulf Schmidt of Sweden, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in the third round of an international invitation tennis tournament today.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Sir Hugh Foot, Governor of Cyprus, left here today with broad authority to implement Britain's seven-year plan for Cyprus as he sees fit.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, which operate a large department store chain including Stern's and Gertz in New York, showed lower earnings in the quarter, six and twelve months ended July 31 from those periods last year.
OXFORDS and tweeds will be de rigueur at the Coliseum for the next ten days. A visit to the ninth annual National Homefurnishings Show, which opens today, is like taking a stroll in the country.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- Foreigners suspected of contributing to recent agitation and violence here have been rounded up by the Mexican Government over the last five days.
The work load of this country's privately owned shipyards has fallen below the so-called "boom" mark -- 3,000,000 deadweight tons -- for the first time since the early days of last year.

FOR roughly thirteen years, or ever since the publication in this country of his first work, a book of short stories called "Fireman Flower," William Sansom has undergone the peculiarly grating experience (the desecription cannot possibly summon up the taste of dust or the sensation of exhaustion) of being regularly accused of virtuosity.
The board of directors of the Protestant Council of the City of New York adopted a resolution in a special session yesterday supporting birth-control therapy in municipal hospitals.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- The gloves are off! It's police, boxing officials and a Methodist minister vs. Kitione Lave, the Tongan Terror.

When the New York legislative session ended in late March we remarked that "the Republicans can claim merited credit for leadership in handsomely increasing aid to education in a critical period for our national welfare." True, the Republicans cut $2,200,000 out of a Harriman budget item for aid to adult education. But in its place, in general aid to education, they added $53,535,000 on a full-year basis.

Leg-work, research and scientific analysis have been employed by the police and the Staten Island District Attorney's investigators in their efforts to solve the murder of Dr. Melvin A. Nimer and his wife.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Paramount Pictures sought an injunction today in Federal District Court here to prohibit William Holden from appearing in the Mirisch company's "The Horse Soldiers."

Two new deputy chiefs, one battalion chief, two captains and four lieutenants were sworn in yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. The ceremony for the nine men took place in Mr. Cavanagh's Municipal Building office.
Only two strands of ribbon bar traffic from the full use of new facilities on two bridges spanning the East River. The ribbons will be cut in ceremonies today and Monday.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 10 -- Members of the four teams taking part in the fifteenth International Tuna Cup Match, which began its threeday stand this morning, had a restful day. Only one bluefin was spotted -- that one was not interested.
A 17-year-old youth was charged with burglary yesterday after he confessed twenty thefts in the Bronx since last June.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Tribes are being subjected to "heavy administrative and psychological pressure" to agree to end Federal trusteeships, an Indian spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- An examiner of the Federal Power Commission ruled today against a $32,286,000 expansion program proposed by the Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line Company of Detroit. The program would have provided natural gas to ten distributing companies for new service in twenty-nine Wisconsin communities and one in Michigan.
It cannot be denied that "Divorce Hearing," last night's opener on Channel 5, has a fascination about it. Whether it provides more than eavesdropping entertainment is debatable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- When the Supreme Court tomorrow resumes hearing the Little Rock high school case in the form presented by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals, the two principals will wholly have changed their positions since 1956 and 1957.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -The United States Commander in Chief in the Pacific was reliably reported today to have questioned some of the premises of United States policy in the crisis over the Taiwan Strait.

Stockholders of Namm-Loeser's, Inc., have been notified that the $2,500,000 price paid earlier this year for the assets of the Hughes Hatcher Company, a Detroit-based men's clothing chain, would be scaled down because of an embezzlement of funds from that company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Westinghouse scientists said today they had developed a power plant utilizing the sun's rays, which some day might enable man to exist on the moon.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Most Soviet youngsters will be sent to work at the age of 15, taking high school courses in the evenings or by mail, under a new system of education that is receiving increasing support from Soviet authorities.
The ninth annual Animal Kingdom Ball for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will be held at the Pierre on Jan. 22.

A DISH with definite bourgeois beginnings is emerging as a piece de resistance at many of New York's most sophisticated cocktail gatherings, supper parties and assemblages of wine and food societies. This is the fabulously appetizing quiche lorraine of Franco-Germanic origin and Swiss adoption.
The Seafarers International Union moved on two fronts yesterday to protest the recent sale of eight Canadian steamships to Cuba.
HONG KONG, Sept. 10 -Communist China said two United States planes flew over China's mainland today, one apparently penetrating nearly 200 miles.

VAN BUREN, Ark., Sept. 10 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed a new suit today in an attempt to force the Van Buren school board to carry out desegregation of the senior high school here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he might ask the next Congress to reinstate incentive scholarships in the new scienceaid program.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- West Indian opposition to any British restriction on the immigration of Negroes to Britain developed today.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Wisconsin Democrats, showing unusual strength in urban areas, renominated 42-year-old Senator William Proxmire by a large margin yesterday. In the process, they outdrew the Republicans in the total vote cast in the primary; which they had not accomplished before in the century.
Massachusetts announced yesterday that it would seek competitive bids Sept. 24 for $61,000,000 of various purpose bonds. The bonds, to be dated July 1, 1958, will mature from July 1, 1959 to 1978.
The Liberal party sent to Mayor Wagner yesterday a twenty-two-page memorandum opposing the sale of the city's rapid transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 10 -- The Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan concluded their talks on recent border incidents in an atmosphere of unexpected cordiality today.
BUFFALO, Sept. 10 (AP) -A group of mothers. Negro and white, drove to City Hall today to ask for a city demonstration of sympathy for mothers in Little Rock, Ark., fighting for school integration.

Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham, honorary chairman of the eleventh annual Blue Grass Ball, will be guest of honor at a cocktail party and reception to be given in the Terrace Room of the Plaza before the ball on Sept. 25 by Mrs. Conrad W. Thibault, Mrs. Clyde E. Weed and Mrs. John C. Wood, cochairmen of the ball, and Mrs. Searle Whitney.
A five-week strike of 550 tile workers that had delayed scores of major construction projects in the metropolitan area was settled yesterday.
The General American Transportation Corporation and the Fruehauf Trailer Company have arranged a licensing agreement that they believe could eventually limit the future of the railroad box car.
Three new protests were issued yesterday against Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs' ban on birth-control therapy in New York's municipal hospitals.
PARIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Interior Ministry said today it was ordering road blocks set up throughout France to stop cars carrying Algerian terrorists and their arms.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Frank Offord, a dealer in second-hand furniture found jewelry and gold plate worth 100,000 ($280,000) in an old safe he bought for 30 shillings ($4.20).

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Eleonora R. Sears' Diamant from Pride's Crossing, Mass., won the Professional Horsemen's Association Challenge Trophy event as the fifty-third Piping Rock horse show opened today.

No person seeking aid has ever been turned away by the Federation of the Handicapped, 211 West Fourteenth Street, New York 11. Every handicapped person, man, woman or child, regardless of race, color, creed or disability, is entitled to all the free services that the federation has given for twenty-three years.

A lawyer employed by Morris Ernst in his investigation into the mysterious disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez yesterday filed a $500,000 libel-slander suit against the Columbia Broadcasting System.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Government specified today why it faced a record peacetime deficit of $12,200,000,000 in the current fiscal year.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Sept. 11 -- Faulty driving adds one-third to fuel costs, an automobile executive said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has told airlines they should be able to operate jet planes at standard fares because they will be more economical than present aircraft.
SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 11 -- The Scranton Corporation announced today acquisition of the Mutual Broadcasting System for more than $2,000,000.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Governor Harriman's "catch-up-with-progress drive" for the suburbs was contrasted with "long-standing Republican neglect" today by Democratic candidates for the Legislature.
Chicago plans to offer $20,000,000 of various purpose bonds on Sept. 25. The issue will mature from 1960 to 1977.

Artur Rodzinski, whose stormy resignation in 1947 from the musical directorship of the New York Philharmonic was followed by an equally stormy resignation from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra the next year, is returning to Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The head of the court-appointed board of monitors of the Teamsters Union threatened today to go into United States District Court in a dispute involving special hearings called by the union president, James R. Hoffa.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 -Wind shifts had much to do with deciding today's final America's Cup defense trial in favor of Columbia.
Stocks surged forward again yesterday to new 1958 highs. The drive was on, according to many, to scale the historic highs set in 1956. And, many said, the goal was within sight.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, the second-ranked middleweight contender, finished strong tonight to gain a unanimous ten-round decision over Spider Webb of Chicago.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 11 -- John S. Bugas, vice president of the Ford Motor Company, reported some "air clearing discussion" today in the contract talks with the United Automobile Workers.
PHILADELPH1A, Sept. 11 -- The Pennsylvania Superior Court denied unemployment compensation today to 25,000 Westinghouse Electric employes who lost time in five work stoppages in 1954, 1955 and 1956.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Two boys who had anonymously left $2.62 to pay for damaging an asphalt paver here last week were located yesterday. They were given $1.62 in change and praised by the owner of the paver; however, his offer of further reward received parental vetoes.
The National Foundation has made nineteen grants, totaling $1,184,432, for research into the after-effects of poliomyelitis and for the rehabilitation of victims of the disease.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Department of Commerce officials reported today that economy-minded bureaucrats had set up a natural gas business in northern Alaska and saved the Government money.
Miss Virginia Dancy, who heads the debutante committee for the annual benefit tea dance for the Judson Health Center, was honored yesterday at a luncheon in the White and Gold Suite of the Plaza.

The three editorials of The Toronto Globe and Mail which appeared as advertisements in your issues of Sept. 2, 3 and 4 contained much misinformation about the situation in the Far East and showed ill will, if not hatred, of the Government of the Republic of China.

A hearing will be held here by the Public Service Commission, 199 Church Street, on Sept. 19 on an application by the New York Central Railroad to discontinue all but passenger service at its Thornwood and Hawthorne stations in Westchester.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York ended yesterday its four-week resistance to a rise in the discount rate. It increased its charge for loans to member banks from 1 3/4 to 2 per cent.

Eight-year-old Melvin Dean Nimer was remanded to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for further psychiatric examination. At the same time authorities continued to check his story that he had killed his mother and father in their Staten Island home Sept. 2.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 -Brave Vim and her brave crew went down with their colors flying proudly tonight when they received the news that their gallant bid to defend the America's Cup had failed.

The Anaconda Company has decided to make its engineering department available to other companies for planning, designing, engineering and supervising the construction of major industrial plants of all kinds.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Production of films may be in a slump here, but at least some of the town's screen writers are at work.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Maxwell H. Gluck as Ambassador to Ceylon, effective about Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -Today's Supreme Court debate rumbled with the phrases of great historic issues -- covering the ground from Cato to states' were the simpler human issues were the simpler human issue of children and the stand of Orval E. Faubus.

PORTOROZ, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the 15-year-old United States champion, became an international chess grand master today. He is the youngest player to hold that title.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Resignation of Mel B. Lindquist as general industrial relations manager was disclosed today by the Ford Motor Company. A successor has not been announced.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 -- Columbia, hailed as a yacht of destiny from the planning-board stage, earned the right today to pursue that destiny to the supreme goal.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today called the importance of the rehabilitation and employment of handicapped persons a subject "close to my heart."

Cocoa futures were steady early yesterday, influenced by a lack of deliveries on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Later in the session, general selling, liquidation, hedging and stop-loss ordering tumbled prices. Little buying interest was shown and manufacturers were out of the market.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said tonight that the Republican party could not give the nation the forward-looking leadership it needed to mobilize economic and military resources.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was building new blooming and structural mills at its South Works, Chicago. The mill will produce the standard structural and wide-flange beams of the lighter weights in demand by the construction industry.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks increased $61,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday from the preceding week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $105,000,000 in the comparable 1957 week.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies were 2.1 per cent higher in August than in the like 1957 month. A compilation by The New York Times yesterday showed total sales in the month for forty-five big chains of $1,525,999,477, against $1,494,015,800 in August, 1957.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Ernest V. Hollis Jr., a research analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday of a bullet wound found by the police to have been self-inflicted. He had been "depressed" and had been under treatment, his wife said.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- Government attorneys announced today that they were dropping some charges in the Powell sedition case.

On the stage of the National Theatre, on the lower East Side, a group of actors went through a reading yesterday for what will be the last play in the most famous of the nation's remaining Yiddish theatres.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A United States District Court action today paved the way for the Penn-Texas Corporation to take over control of Fairbanks, Morse Co., ending a two-year corporate battle.

Ogden R. Reid, president and editor of The New York Herald Tribune, announced yesterday the selection of Howard D. Brundage as chairman of the executive committee of the newspaper's board of directors.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 11 -- After four days of study here, ten educators from India expressed interest today in the American college entrance system and the importance of a student's cumulative record.

Capt. Ernest H. Nelson, master of the American Export Lines' Constitution, will be sailing his last voyage in command when he takes the 29,500-ton liner out of her Forty-fourth Street pier at noon today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Supreme Court heard final argument today on the Little Rock school case, then recessed until noon tomorrow. Its decision is likely to come down at that time.
MANILA, Sept. 11 -- Admiral Felt, asked about a report concerning his attitude on the defense of Quemoy, denied today that he was not in sympathy with United States policy in Taiwan Strait.

Ernest Hemingway and Henry James would appear to have something slightly in common, according to a recent story in this newspaper. Three of Mr. Hemingway's stories, written twenty years ago about the Spanish Civil War were about to be reprinted in a magazine here when court permission was asked to stop their publication.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The moderator of the Southern Presbyterian Church warned tonight that the use of force "can accomplish nothing but chaos" in the school desegregation crisis.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The State Superior Court in reducing attorneys' fees in a divorce case from $110,000 to $17,000 commented today that "in Pennsylvania the practice of law even in the field of divorce is still a profession and not a business."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold suggested today a new approach to the disarmament problem: a series of talks among international scientific, military and legal experts.

THERE is a certain amount of well-organized chaos aboard an ocean liner that is about to embark on a maiden voyage. From smokestack to keel, decks are awash with engineers, piano tuners, loudspeaker repairmen, interior designers, visiting firemen and ship's personnel.

WHAT were the circumstances that determined how and when last night's address by President Eisenhower should be televised? Did the arrangements serve to alert the viewing public to the realities of the Far East crisis?

A majority of members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies came through the recession-ridden first half of the year with higher billings than a year ago. Nearly half expect increases also in the second half.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Navy and the Air Force claimed flying safety records today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11 -- Chief Judge Simon E. Sobeloff of the United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the order of a Federal District judge for integration of the Front Royal High School in Warren County, Va., on Monday.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 11 -- Warren County's only high school will close Monday -- at least briefly -- under Virginia's program of "massive resistance" to racial integration.
The Board of Estimate yesterday fixed next Thursday for a public hearing on the proposal to run two lanes of traffic separated by a mall through Washington Square Park.

The Dorothy Welsh Realty Corporation has sold a 14,000-square-foot plot in Long Island City, Queens, to Robert L. Adams. The purchaser plans to improve the property with a one-story warehouse building for occupancy by a merchandise distributor late this year.
LEIPZIG, Germany, Sept. 11 -- West European business men at the semi-annual trade fair are saying that the most interesting exhibit is the newly developed Communist capitalist.

TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- A proposal that the Port of New York Authority assume the task of integrating metropolitan rail facilities and of taking other steps to solve the region's rapid transit problems appeared doomed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- A National Airlines attorney suggested today that Judge Horace Stern should disqualify himself from presiding over the rehearing of the Miami television channel case.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 11 -- The Government said today that it had been questioning foreigners visiting Rumania and that its purpose was to discover and oust undesirables.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 11 -- The Djinn, a French helicopter that combines characteristics of a pogo stick with those of a hummingbird, was demonstrated here today by the Republic Aviation Corporation.
Seven Negro pupils who have been boycotting Harlem schools since the new term began Monday attended a private tutoring session yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 11 -- Charles Libove, a Brooklyn-born violinist who used to dream of the concert stage while earning his living in the pits of Broadway musical shows, was selected tonight to enter the final round of Rumania's international music festival.
About sixty white-capped members of the Seafarers International Union picketed the United Nations Secretariat Building and the Cuban Consulate General here yesterday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Sept. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's assertion that there is not going to be any "appeasement" of Communist China in the Quemoy crisis won particular favor from the Chinese Nationalists today.

New York Catholic Charities has bought the building at 17 East Eightieth Street and will open a center for mentally retarded children of pre-school age. The building is now occupied by New York University's Institute of Fine Arts.

A new race named for an old horse occupied the feature spot at Belmont Park yesterday and the offering was both as to form and performance. The event was a hurdle event for 3-year-olds and it was called the Elkridge after the famous jumper who was retired from competition as a 13-year-old in 1951.

ONE of the chemise-pushing dictators that American men have been railing at arrived from Paris yesterday, and he turned out to be a shy, intelligent man who changes style only because he believes women want him to.
Frank S. Hogan and twelve officials of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations looked each other over yesterday and apparently liked what they saw -- and heard.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Following is the text of the introduction to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's annual report on the work of the United Nations, made public today:
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Andy Bathgate, scoring star of the New York Rangers, pulled a new one today when the forty-two-man squad opened training for the National Hockey League season.
The Federal Government has set next Jan. 1 as the date for the completion of state and local civil defense plans to meet a possible nuclear missile attack.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The tightening in money conditions has begun to affect mortgage money, the Government disclosed today.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society has acquired the Equitable Building at 120 Broadway as part of a deal in which Webb Knapp, Inc., bought a parcel of land on the Avenue of the Americas.

American release rights to "Dreaming Lips," a German-made import with Maria Schell, O. W. Fischer and Phillip Dorn, have been acquired by Distributors Corporation of America. The import is a remake of a film that starred Elisabeth Bergner. F. A. Mainz produced and Paul Czinner wrote the scenario.

No one would have expected that miracles were to be accomplished by the meeting of India's Prime Minister Nehru and his corresponding leader in Pakistan, Malik Firoz Khan Noon. But what was done was constructive. An agreement was reached on some of the points of irritation in the border dispute between the two countries. There was, on both sides, a repudiation of force as the way to settlement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- National Airlines' plan to scoop the aviation industry and be first with domestic jet service will not become a fact until it passes the tests of Government regulations.
A one-man campaign to erase a travel inconvenience for Queens subway riders was won yesterday by Aaron J. Pasternak of East Elmhurst.
ALTHOUGH there is only a snap in the air now, the gala winter season is practically here.
Some opinion in Wall Street is mildly enthusiastic about the New York Central Railroad and some isn't.
Morarji Desai, India's Finance Minister, said here yesterday it was the firm policy of his government to encourage private industry and foreign investments in certain industries.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 11 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is investigating complaints from residents here and in neighboring communities that its new $280,000 Diesel-electric locomotives are too noisy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Following are the texts of a letter from Wayne Upton, president of the Little Rock School Board, to Attorney General William P. Rogers, and Mr. Rogers' reply sent by telegram today:
A city detective on the Narcotics Squad was arrested last night and charged with conspiracy to sell opium. He was immediately suspended by First Deputy Police Commissioner James R. Kennedy.
WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Delaware Supreme Court today affirmed the right of Edward M. Gilbert to examine the Bruce stock ledgers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -The Government's new bearish crop report hit the Board of Trade today with something less than an alarming thud. Dealers shrugged it off and went on about another day's business of slow activity.
The Pennroad Corporation, an investment company said yesterday it planned to register today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of 1,286,619 shares to stockholders.

In August, 1941, the German submarine U-570 suddenly vanished. Shortly thereafter German Naval Intelligence received reports that a ghost U-Boat was operating against her sister ships. The story of this incident is told in "H. M. U-Boat," by John D. Drummond, which the British Book Centre will distribute Sept. 22.

Short sellers of E. L. Bruce Company shares lost yesterday an attempt to prevent the American Stock Exchange from requiring them to fulfill their contracts. Justice Henry Epstein denied their motion in Manhattan Supreme Court for a temporary injunction blocking the imposition of the Exchange's order.
The cotton futures market closed 1 point higher to 10 points lower, in a quiet market.

Pleasure boats will pre-empt the Atlantic Ocean off Newport beginning next week and pretty much take it away from the gulls, the swordfish and tuna while they churn up quite a commotion. They will be trying to see the America's Cup races.
FORT ERIE, Ont., Sept. 11 (AP) -- An oilman washed ashore after being battered for six hours in raging Lake Erie, said today his father had yielded a chance of survival so he might live.
MONTREAL, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Canada's major railways said tonight they would seek an immediate 19 per cent increase in freight rates to meet a potential wage bill of $60,000,000.

Socrates, a philosophical giraffe who refuses to get seasick, arrived in port here yesterday en route from Africa to Colorado Springs. He measures 17 feet 5 1/2 inches from head to toe, making him possibly the largest ever shipped into the United States.
Bing Crosby's first show under his American Broadcasting Company contract will be televised on Wednesday Oct. 1, from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- A bipartisan Senate Dis armament Subcommittee said today that United States interests would be served by seeking an international agreement to suspend nuclear weapons tests.

OMAHA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Winthrop Rockefeller contended tonight that the South's failure to provide the separate but equal education for Negroes once ordered by the Supreme Court was one of the roadblocks to integration ordered by the high court in 1954.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Industrials moved aimlessly on the stock market today. Buyers were reported standing on the side lines.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The powerful but divided French Socialist party began its annual congress near Paris today with clear indications that a majority would back Premier Charles de Gaulle and his proposed constitution.

TUNIS, Sept. 11 -- The liberal Tunisian newspaper L'Action bowed today to pressure from the country's authoritarian, one-party regime and agreed to suspend publication after a final appearance next Sunday.
The city school system issued an urgent appeal yesterday for teachers.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's radio and television speech last night on the Far Eastern situation, as recorded by The New York Times:

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., achieved the highest sales in its history in the six and twelve months periods ended July 31. Earnings, however, were less than a year before, according to the report issued yesterday.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan has taken under advisement a motion by twenty-nine oil companies charged with price-fixing to move their trial to Tulsa, Okla.
The Amato Opera Theatre opened its eighth season last night at 159 Bleecker Street with one of the most demanding operas in the entire repertory, Mozart's "The Magic Flute."
HUNGER for greenery and flowers sends some New York office workers to the park for their lunch hour, others to the florists on their way home, others to cultivating window boxes on their days off.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A Pentagon official disclosed today that additional supplies of conventional ammunition, including bombs, had been ordered sent to the United States forces in the Pacific at the request of Admiral Harry D. Felt, the commander in chief there.
Governor Harriman and other top-ranking Democrats reported last night that they were finding unmistakable signs of a sweeping Democratic victory in New York this fall.

FACED with matters of the utmost gravity, the owners of the sixteen major league baseball clubs met in Chicago earlier this week and did what they usually do when confronted by a crisis. They did nothing.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 11 -- A demand for more equitable political and financial treatment of the nation's cities by state legislatures was made today.

EVER since the publication of Gen. Lew Wallace's "Ben-Hur" in 1880 the Biblical novel has been one of the most popular varieties of fiction. Every year it seems that dozens of them are published, most of no perceptible worth but each certain to find its body of contented readers. A number have been among the world's great best-sellers.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- There is need for a new look at cases in which cancer apparently becomes resistant to the drugs used against it, a scientist suggested here today.
What is the likelihood that a child of 8 would kill his parents ?
Ceremonies commemorating the 182d anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence and the conference that followed will be held at Tottenville, S. I., tomorrow at 2:30 P. M.

KENTVILLE, N. S., Sept. 11 -- Some anglers just refuse to give up. For example, there's Jose Martin, a silk merchant from New York. Today, he traveled thirty-five miles by car and five by punt just to catch a small trout.
When children like Melvin Dean Nimer are sent to mental hospitals the state tries not only to cure them but also to continue their education.
A million visitors are expected to attend seventeen major events at the New York Coliseum between now and April, its management said yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 11 -- Dag Hammarskjold completed his trouble-shooting tour today but left a question mark as the net result in Middle Eastern minds.
The American Medical Association has endorsed the use of hypnosis by physicians and dentists, but condemned it for entertainment.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Whippoorwill carded a two-over-par 35, 41 -- 76 for a 54-hole total of 239 over the windy Fenway Golf Club course today to retain the Women's Tri-County Association's Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy.
Music events tonight will include Ella Fitzgerald and the Oscar Peterson Trio at 8:30 o'clock in Carnegie Hall and a Dixieland jazz concert at the Central Plaza, 111 Second Avenue, also at 8:30.

The first large-scale experiment in redeveloping a deteriorated neighborhood without general demolition has been assured by the Federal Government's willingness to make an initial grant of $4,000,000 toward West Side Manhattan rehabilitation.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 11 -The Government crisis had new impetus this evening.

Member bank average reserves showed little change in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. At $165,000,000, net free reserves -excess reserves less borrowings -- were up $37,000,000 from the week before.

GENEVA, Sept. 11 -- The United States delegation to the second International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy, endorsed today the principle of international scientific cooperation. But it shied away from any formal step toward collaboration with the Soviet Union.
Employes of Liebmann Breweries, Inc., 3582 Third Avenue, the Bronx, will give blood to the Red Cross today.

YOKOTA, Japan, Friday, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, Vice Chief of Staff of the United States Air Force, took off today in an unofficial attempt to set a non-stop flight speed record from Japan to Washington.
A Bach concert was presented last night before a sold-out house in Carnegie Recital Hall. The conductor was Vaclav Nelhybel, making his New York debut.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- The directors of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company today authorized the issuance of 447,346 additional shares of the company's capital stock.
A team of amateur frogmen will descend into the ocean off Bellport, Fire Island, tomorrow in another search for the hulk of the historic old Savannah.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The United States and Japan agreed today to negotiate revisions in their 1951 security treaty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- Charley Coe of Oklahoma City, who is a former champion, two newcomers to the tourney and a 34-year-old week-end golfer are the semi-finalists in the United States Golf Association's amateur championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The United States and Britain have accepted a Soviet proposal to hold negotiations in Geneva on an agreement to suspend nuclear tests.

A floor committee has been formed for the Astor Ball to be held on Sept. 30 in the newly redecorated Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel. The fete, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Ogden Reid, will benefit the Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund, which gives summer vacations to needy children.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Sept. 12 -- Chinese Communist batteries subjected beaches on Quemoy Island to a record bombardment yesterday, forcing a vital Nationalist supply convoy to return to sea without unloading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The National Park Service believes it has found the exact spot at which the Star Spangled Banner was flying in the dawn's early light of Sept. 14, 1814.

OZARK, Ark., Sept. 11 (AP) -- A Negro student at Ozark High School said today that she and two other Negro girls had been told not to return to classes after ten white boys and girls tried to attack them during the lunch hour Tuesday.

PARAMUS, N. J., Sept. 11 -- The local blue law ordering stores to close on Sundays will be reinstated Sunday after a month of nonenforcement. During that time officials were expecting clarification on the recently passed state blue laws, it was announced today by Mayor Fred C. Galda.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Life in a professional football camp is like this: One player quits, another returns and forty-three aspirants for steady jobs go about their chores ever hopeful that a "good move" will catch the coach's eye.

The 11,000-deadweight ton cargo ship Concordia Tadj will make her maiden appearance in this harbor on Sunday. She is scheduled for an initial sailing on the Concordia Line's Persian Gulf service two days later.
BONWIT TELLER is not following the pack. While other stores are now tooting their line-for-line copies of French and Italian couture originals, Bonwit's has managed to quietly upstage them.
Adlai E. Stevenson said yesterday that he believed that Democratic sentiment was increasing throughout the country.
The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., increased sales and earnings in the six months ended June 30 over those of the year before, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

CAP D'AIL, France, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Sir Winston and Lady Churchill celebrate their golden wedding anniversary here tomorrow. Gifts and messages of congratulation were flooding in today from every part of the world.
HONG KONG, Sept. 11 -- The Chinese Communists' Foreign Ministry disclosed tonight that Peiping expected the stalled Chinese-United States ambassadorial talks to be resumed soon in Warsaw.
UNTIL a Scandinavian fashion designer named Katja came along, Swedish modern was a term used for furniture. Now it can be aptly applied to the lean, functional dresses she creates.

Rabbi Harold H. Gordon, executive vice president of the New York Board of Rabbis, said yesterday that despite adverse conditions 80,000 Hungarian Jews "are making an heroic attempt to maintain their religious institutions and way of life."
DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ford Motor Company settled a $2,658,000 tax case with the Government yesterday by payment of $1,064,356 to the Internal Revenue Office in Detroit.

Apart from the concern expressed over New York's growing slums, one fact is plain now -- this city is an audio slum. Regardless of the hour or the condition of one's neighborhood, both peace and privacy are violated by TV and hi-fi.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 563,851 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
OXFORD, Md., Sept. 11 (AP) -- E. W. (Skip) Etchells of the Central Long Island Fleet scored impressive victories in both races today to take the lead in the North American Star class championship.
American Airlines within recent weeks has made some progress in financing purchase of the 110 jet planes it has ordered, William J. Hogan, executive vice president-finance, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Administration disclosed today its intention to freeze $1,170,000,000 in extra defense funds that had been voted by Congress.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court refused yesterday to stay arbitration of a dispute involving the Grace Line and the International Longshoremen's Association, independent.

Having turned out a London hit with his first play, "Five Finger Exercise," Peter Shaffer has another script on tap. Entitled "The Hunt of the Sun," it was purchased by Peter Glenville, director, whose next effort here will be "Rashomon," due Jan. 15.

YEAST breads can be made in considerably less time by following a new method developed by General Mills. The recipe is merely a matter of adding yeast to Bisquick in combination with the perfect proportion of liquid.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 11 -- Pakistan and India have decided to exchange several small strips of land along the disputed eastern frontier "with a view to removing causes of tension."

Four of the seven Negro young people seeking readmission to Central High School in Little Rock this September spent the summer here at our New York City Mission Society camps. We were careful not to make this fact public for obvious reasons; they needed and deserved a summer in as normal and relaxed an environment as possible.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 11 -- H. Geoffrey Lynfield of Hillcrest Park, a New York patent lawyer, was puzzled recently when he received his check in a dining car of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
One of the delegates to the Apalachin gangland conference last November failed to answer a subpoena yesterday and it was believed he was in hiding and perhaps had fled the country.

Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, said last night that Tammany Hall would seek to control the District Attorney's office if his opponent was elected.
A rebuilding of the Rockaways, with modern housing, industry and amusements, was envisioned yesterday by Borough President James J. Crisona of Queens.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, said tonight problems such as Little Rock, the Goldfine hearings, and Middle East crises were "making, not breaking, the strength" of the Republican party.

As the people of this country and millions outside our borders await the Supreme Court's decision on the Little Rock school integration case, which will be another milestone in the constitutional, legal and political history of this country, it may be useful to better understanding to look back to the 1954 and 1955 opinions that set the stage for the present situation.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 11 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that if the Supreme Court ordered Negroes readmitted to Central High School he would probably sign into law measures empowering him to close it.

The Little Orchestra Society will open its twelfth season under the direction of Thomas Scherman on Oct. 6 with the New York premiere of Thomas Augustine Arne's masque, "Comus," based on the text of John Milton.

Two harness drivers were suspended indefinitely yesterday by the New York State Harness Racing Commission. George P. Monaghan, chairman, charged that Charles Wingate and Harry Burright had bet on horses other than their own and had conspired to fix a race at Monticello Raceway.
BEIRUT, Sept. 11 -- Around Al Maza House today the marines were calling themselves the "Lost Battalion."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The manager of a downtown eating place that began serving Negroes last month after a "sitdown" demonstration said today the new policy had not hurt his business.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- Don C. Dunaway, a veteran of more than twenty years in operations of foreign affiliates of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, has been elected president of the American Independent Oil Company.
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- United States scientists fired a twelve-foot inflatable satellite tonight but the illuminized ball apparently failed to burst clear of its rocket and inflate.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Baghdad radio has taken an anti-United States and pro-Communist line on world issues despite the Government's protestations that it wants continued friendship with the West.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower indicated today that the President had vetoed her wearing sack dresses. But she showed little enthusiasm for the sack's successor -- the empire silhouette with the waistline under the bosom.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Britain has no commitment to the United States in the Far East crisis, the Government announced tonight.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, said today that there would be much to be gained by breaking New York City's school system into neighborhood districts.

HERKIMER, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, traveling through the industrial villages of the Mohawk Valley, called for more industry and jobs for upstate areas today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Eisenhower told the American people tonight that they must fight, if need be, to prevent any conquest of the Quemoy and Matsu islands by Communist China.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Alabama Supreme Court denied today the rehearing request of Jimmy Wilson, 35 years old, a Negro doomed for the night-time robbery of a white woman, and set his execution for Oct. 24.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Robert Moses warned today that the $705,000,000 Niagara power project "not only may be delayed but may be stymied" by litigation over the site of a storage reservoir.
MARABA, Brazil, Aug. 29 -Sudden wealth and sudden death lurk in the deep whirlpools of the rivers around this island town of diamond prospectors.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 11 (AP) -- A Navaho-guided missile was fired today in the first of a series of Air Force high-altitude tests.
GROTON, Conn., Sept. 11 (AP) -- A Navy space medicine expert said today that pre-flight ear surgery might be necessary for space voyagers to forestall a distressing type of motion sickness.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The chairman of the Senate rackets committee described Harold J. Gibbons, No. 2 man in the Teamsters union, today as a man of disintegrated ideals whose testimony was "clearly inconsistent with the facts."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Justice Department announced tonight several more steps aimed at enforcement of integration in Little Rock, Ark., if the Supreme Court orders immediate resumption of the program.
OMAHA, Sept. 11 -- Optimistic Democratic leaders from thirteen Midwestern states drafted today a "new departure" farm program.

MURIEL KING'S collection of custom designs, shown yesterday at Stein Blaine, reflects the mature views of a woman who has been making wearable clothes for many seasons and never allows the news from Paris to rattle her.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- Farmers, flower growers, machinery dealers, artists, housewives, American Indians and merchants of Westchester and Putnam Counties presented 4,000 exhibits today at the opening of the thirty-fifth annual country fair of the Yorktown Grange.

Some years ago, in a speech in the House of Commons, Sir Winston Churchill said: "Where does the family start? It starts with a young man falling in love with a girl -- no superior alternative has yet been found." Fifty years ago today the young man, Winston Churchill, having fallen in love with a young Scots girl named Clementine Hozier, married her and, as he said much later, "we lived happily ever after."

Two Republican and two Liberal party candidates for the State Supreme Court in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and the Bronx) formally declined their nominations yesterday. The parties have until midnight tonight to find substitutes.

IT has been said of Malik Firoz Khan Noon, Pakistan's Prime Minister, that he wears a laurel wreath easily. Guards of honor, flags and the fanfare of trumpets associated with the Prime Ministership do not flatter him. Malik Noon ('malik" means titular chief) was born to it.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP) -- David Oistrakh, Soviet violinist, will return to the United States next year for concerts in another series of Soviet-United States cultural exchanges.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Martin Clark of 139 East Seventy-ninth St., New York, and Oyster Bay Cove, and Mr. and Mrs. Matthias Plum of Adsamor House, Chatham, Mass., formerly of Tuxedo Park, gave a dinner dance this evening at the Clark home in honor of their debutante daughters, Miss Ann Valer Clark and Miss Patricia Grace Plum.

ALTHOUGH winter arrives in Brooklyn at the same time it does in Manhattan, Abraham Straus is already prepared for the first cold blast. This store has imported some cozy sportswear from Switzerland, Austria and Italy.
A virus has been found that many aid research on trachoma, a chronic form of conjunctivitis afflicting millions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The United Press International reported erroneously yesterday that Norman E. Jorgensen, a National Airlines attorney, had suggested that Judge Horace Stern disqualify himself from presiding over a hearing on Miami Television Channel 10.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Army Corps of Engineers has eased restrictions on foreign manufacturers who bid on contracts to supply heavy equipment for its power projects in this country.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- The Soviet Union produced six witnesses today who testified that United States radio stations beaming propaganda at the Soviet Union used "lies" and "slander" in their broadcasts.

OLIN STEPHENS, the monarch of American yacht designing, is now generally a landlubber. The famous creator of Columbia, Vim and many other heralded American yachts owns no yacht. He spends most of his week-ends on his New England farm, away from the yachting set, and few yachtsmen are among his personal friends.
When historians of the future total up the happenings of this rather bizarre period they are bound to have some difficulty deciding on a fitting label for our distraught times.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Far Eastern situation popped back into the grain futures market today as a major buying influence and prices moved ahead throughout the list.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 12 -- President Eisenhower appealed today for a public support of the Supreme Court's opinion directing immediate admission of Negro students at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The State Department announced today four American composers would visit the Soviet Union for three weeks starting this month. The visit will be under terms of the United States-Soviet Cultural Exchange agreement signed last January.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, denied today that he had met or talked with a "very active Republican personality" reputedly sent to him in 1956 as a Teamsters Union emissary.

Last June, an unarmed United States Air Force military DC-6 transport plane on a routine flight from Wiesbaden, Germany, to Teheran, Iran, wandered across the Soviet frontier and was shot down by Soviet Mig jet fighter planes.

James D. Norris, former president of the International Boxing Club, moved in State Supreme Court yesterday to cancel a subpoena requiring him to appear before the New York County grand jury that is investigating bribery and corruption in professional boxing.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Watson W. Wise, Texas oilman, was among seven persons sworn in today as members of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly.
Governor Harriman and a group of educators gave a half-hour demonstration on television last night of the New York State educational television program that will begin Monday, Sept. 22.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Soviet Union told the United States today that a missing United States Air Force transport plane had crashed in Soviet Armenia, killing six of its crew.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 12 (AP) -- An unidentified missile, believed to be the Air Force's Goose, a guided decoy weapon, streaked across the Atlantic from the test center today.
MACAPA, Brazil, Aug. 30 -- After two centuries of stagnation and oblivion, the equatorial territory of Amapa, half jungle and half savannah, may be approaching the threshhold of a bright future.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 12 -- Following is the text of a proclamation issued by Gov. Orval E. Faubus ordering the closing of all senior high schools in the Little Rock School District:
Fourteen northbound IRT subway trains were delayed up to twenty-four minutes in the Bronx last night when mechanical trouble developed on a Lenox-White Plains Road train.

WEDGEPORT, N. S., Sept. 12 -- If they are going to catch any fish in the International Tuna Cup match being held here, members of the four teams better hurry. It was two days down and only one to go as the fleet of converted lobster boats returned to harbor early tonight.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- The Socialist party was asked by one of its leading members today to back a policy of negotiation to end the Algerian war.

Directors of the Chrysler Corporation have approved a new stock option plan for executives to replace four previous grants and lower the option price of the stock. Options for 285,236 common shares were approved by the board subject to cancellation of options for 245,111 previously granted. Members of the stock option committee are not eligible to participate in the plan.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- The French welcome the prospect of negotiation over Quemoy and the other offshore islands but are not optimistic about a settlement.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 12 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. announced tonight that he was assuming "all power and control" over the Warren County High School at Front Royal.

The slowly improving position of the copper industry was reflected by sharp increases in metal deliveries to fabricators last month, both here and abroad. Declines in producers' stocks also were encouraging, metals men said.
For the first time in modern history, Russian-built merchant vessels are being offered for sale to foreign owners.
ONEONTA, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The nation's first coast-to-coast television network program offering a college course -- atomic physics -- and college credits will begin Oct. 6.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Urban Renewal Administration said today that the limited funds available for slum clearance until Congress next meets would be allocated among the nation's cities and towns on the basis of population.
LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan disclosed tonight that there would be no general election this winter unless exceptional circumstances arose.
NEWARK, Sept. 12 -- Three Federal judges today stayed the New York Central and Erie Railroads from abandoning their ferry service between New York and New Jersey.

As expected, the new Constitution being offered to the French and their overseas dependents is arousing fiercely critical comment in political and intellectual circles. But it seems to have failed to arouse any excitement among the French people, who are apparently accepting it. The referendum will be held Sept. 28.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Superior Court Judge J. Edward Knight refused today to stay his order to Lakewood Township to reassess all local properties at 100 per cent of true value by Jan. 1.

The majestic bald eagle, America's national bird since 1782, is going into a serious and mysterious decline. Although the encroachment of civilization is party to blame, some ornithologists believe that large numbers of the birds are becoming sterile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy said today that he would delay planned reductions of about 55,000 men in the Army and Marine Corps in view of the China crisis and other considerations.
Three armed men robbed a Coca-Cola bottling plant in Brooklyn of $25,000 yesterday.

TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- Attorney General David D. Furman ordered a halt today to penalty procedures that have permitted thousands of traffic violators to escape revocation or suspension of their licenses over the last six years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals ruled today that draftees who fail the intelligence test may still qualify for induction into the armed services.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept, 12 -- Two Texas pairs won the opening events of the Lone Star Bridge Championships today at the Shamrock Hilton Hotel here.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- The combined Oxford - Cambridge team won its three-day series of court-tennis matches with Philadelphia by 9 -- 6 today at the Racquet Club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The Yankees advanced two more strides toward that inevitable pennant tonight. The Bombers flattened the White Sox, 5 to 0, with Bob Turley tossing the shutout for his twenty-first victory of the year against six defeats.
Steel production last month was the largest of any month so far this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

In his momentous Thursday night speech President Eisenhower has flung down a new challenge to the doctrine of blood and iron adopted by the Communist despots as the road to world conquest and has espoused instead the doctrine of peace with honor under which all disputes should be settled by peaceful negotiations and conciliation.

The new management of the Penn-Texas Corporation was se back yesterday in its effort to recover $1,041,500 it said was illegally diverted from the company by David Subin and Leopold D. Silberstein, former head of the diversified concern.

About two years ago, the Electro-Motive division of the General Motors Corporation at the urging of the railroads built two experimental light, economical, low-slung streamliners. It dubbed them Aerotrains.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 11 -- Running the blockade to beleaguered Quemoy under Communist artillery fire is something that is understood truly by a hundred ragged, underpaid sailors of the Nationalist Chinese Navy aboard an LSM in convoy today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- There was no indication in the Soviet note today as to what had caused the crash of the United States plane.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- Round Table has the opportunity tomorrow of becoming the richest winner in the history of the turf, and the general belief is that the 4-year-old son of Pricequillo will make it.

Robert L. Joseph is in the middle of negotiations for the rights to George Bernard Shaw's "Heartbreak House." If the producer completes the transaction with Shaw's estate, he will present the play on Broadway next season.

CAIRO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Middle East News Agency said tonight that it had monitored a Baghdad radio broadcast that said Iraq's Ruling Council has removed Brig. Abdul Salam Mohammed Arif from his post as Deputy Commander in Chief of Iraq's armed forces.
Time is running out on our nebulous policy in respect to the Chinese offshore islands with apparently little public concern over the dangerous position into which that policy has now led us.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Sept. 12 -- Life must be grim back in the United States, what with the oil kings fighting it out with the railroad kings for control of New York, racial "debauches" all over the place, strikes here, strikes there.
The Salvation Army will welcome its largest class of officer candidates since 1940 tomorrow. A ceremony will be held at 3 P. M. at the Army's Centenial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street.
Anderson, Clayton Co. suffered a sharp setback in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended July 31 from the preceding year, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- The Soviet official press agency Tass said today that President Eisenhower's speech on the Taiwan situation was "an attempt to justify the policy of military blackmail and threat of force" against Communist China.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Snow Man, owned and ridden by Harry De Leyer of Hollandia Farms, St. James, L. I., won the first phase of the three-day William S. Blitz Memorial Gold Challenge Cup $1,000 special jumper championship competition at the Piping Rock horse show today.
GROTON, Conn., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Some of the men on the atomic submarine Nautilus have been receiving less radiation than their wives and families ashore, the vessel's medical officer reported today.
ATLANTA, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The voices of liberals and moderates were lost today in the outspoken denunciations of the ruling by Southern leaders.

THE anguished cries of "Help! Burglar! Police!" rang out on the fifth floor of Hammacher Schlemmer the other afternoon. For a moment no one moved. Then a customer stepped forward and declared: "I'll take it. It's marvelous. But can't I have it with MY voice?"

MATTITUCK, L. I., Sept. 12 -- A fortunate commuter, Edward P. Gilles, "skips" seventy miles over Long Island's congested traffic to his job during most of each year. He simply flies his monoplane to the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, where his job is to pilot airliners to Mexico City and San Juan, P. R.
An exhibit showing how electronic computers have cut the time of astronomical calculations from months to minutes opens today at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium.
The thirtieth anniversary of the start of United States airline service in South America was celebrated yesterday in Rockefeller Plaza.
MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 12 -- A church that simulates hands in prayer will soon be built here.
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The new civilian space agency announced today plans to make this test station into another base for satellite launchings.

The decision of Walter P. Reuther's United Automobile Workers to put Ford on the front burner has sharply increased the pressure on both sides to find a successful fire-prevention formula before the strike match is lit next Wednesday.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 12 -- The rousing family contest for the America's Cup defense assignment having been decided in favor of Columbia, the vanquished colsed ranks today with the victors today to keep yachting's foremost prize in the United States.

Negotiations aiming at a merger or acquisition of the Diners' Club, Inc. by the Hilton Hotels Corporation, the nation's largest hotel chain, have been under way several days, it was learned from investment bankers here yesterday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The quarterback problem is getting to be chronic with Army. As Coach Earl (Red) Blaik described the problem today, it is symptomatic of the insufficiency of football manpower at West Point.
Walter Winchell will return to the Mutual Broadcasting System radio network as a newscaster next month.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 12 -- Another round took place today in the eight-year fight by James J. Colt and his Metropolitan Racing Association for permission to operate a $6,000,000, daytime harness racing track. The site would be Mr. Colt's 1,000-acre property in the Secaucus Meadows.
The proposed revisions in the oil import program should be clarified and modified before becoming effective, James W. Foley, president of the Texas Company, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- A Chicago Bears' halfback, Willie Galimore, broke away for runs of 95, 45, 21 and 15 yards tonight to score four touchdowns and lead the Bears to a 42-31 victory over the Cleveland Browns in an exhibition football game.

On Sept. 5 at Massena, N. Y., a three-quarter of a billion dollar power dam was placed in operation with appropriate ceremonies and with distinguished international participation. The dam was named for Robert Moses, chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York during the past four years.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The Paragon Glass Works, Inc., of 963 Newark Avenue, manufacturer of electronic tubes and decorative light bulbs, will move to Lewiston, Me., because of "high rent" here.

A smiling, blond 9-year-old Hungarian boy arrived by air from Switzerland yesterday morning for an emergency heart operation. The surgery is expected to prolong his life beyond the brief span physicians had predicted.

ROYAN, France, Sept. 12 -- The World Parliament Association said today that peace would be continually threatened "unless and until statesmen and leaders of the whole world agree to the constitution of a world authority."

BABYLON, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Robert Moses has revitalized his long-running campaign to have Mitchel Air Force Base closed by sending a letter and a fresh batch of newspaper clippings to Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy this week.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- A new simplified technique for extracting gamma globulin from blood was reported today to the American Chemical Society.
Underwriters are facing an active new capital market next week with considerably more optimism than they displayed last week-end.
TORONTO, Sept 12 (Canadian Press) -- Bob Bedard of Sherbrooke, Que., Canada's topseeded tennis player, but unseeded in the invitation tournament here, scored an upset today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- A majority of the Latin American states favor Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon for President of the forthcoming General Assembly, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Virgil T. Blossom, Superintendent of Little Rock schools, and Attorney General William P. Rogers today discussed "common problems" stemming from the Supreme Court's order for immediate integration of Central High School.

OXFORD, Md., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Ken Smith of Huntington, L. I., grabbed the lead from Herb Hild of the East River Fleet, New York, in the last straightaway to win the fourth race of the North American Star regatta series today.

MAKUNG, Penghu (Pescadores) Islands, Sept. 12 -- Nationalist China's unsuccessful attempt to land new supplies yesterday in its besieged offshore island of Quemoy underscores a grim fact -- the Communist blockade is highly effective and critically serious.

The State Investigation Commission questioned Dr. James G. Douglas of Utica yesterday regarding Joseph Falcone, the missing delegate to the Apalachin gangland conference last November. Falcone failed to answer a subpoena to appear in the Criminal Courts Building on Thursday.
The new $26,000,000 Moore-McCormack Lines passenger ship Brasil left here yesterday on her maiden voyage in the South American service.
A unit of the Metropolitan Regional Council moved yesterday to have the council designated as the agency to seek a solution of the region's commuter rail problem.
ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- Governor Harriman attacked today two of the Republican candidates on the state-wide ticket.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Rev. Maurice F. McCrackin, who has refused for years to pay his income taxes, went on a sitdown strike today when arrested by a United States marshal and several tax agents.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, declared today the Democratic party was controlled by "a group of power-hungry men."
The short sellers of stock in the E. L. Bruce Company have come to the end of the line.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Supreme Court unanimously rejected today the Little Rock school board's appeal for a delay in racial integration of Central High School.
TORONTO, Sept. 12 -- If Alabama electrocutes Jimmy Wilson it will shock the conscience of the world, a group of Canadian judges warned today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Court-named monitors said today they would decide soon whether to recommend that the Teamsters Union bring dismissal charges against James R. Hoffa, its president.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A mandate ordering immediate resumption of racial integration at Central High School in Little Rock is expected to reach that city Monday. That is the day that had been set for opening of the fall term at the school.
A 300-pound Canadian swordfish, its massive carcass stretched on a wooden table in the Fulton Fish Market was being critically inspected by two city officers.
Unemployment insurance claims in New York State dropped last week for the eighth straight week.

Hydraulic fluids and lubricants for aircraft nuclear propulsion systems, said to withstand higher temperatures and radiation dosages than the fluids now used, have been developed by the General Electric Company.

Norman Granz, whose name-filed, raucous Jazz at the Philharmonic presentations set the mode for jazz concerts during the last ten years, has dropped his earlier format in favor of a simpler and decidedly more attractive type of programing this season.
A tenant evolution is under way in the once predominantly insurance district of downtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Japanese Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama agreed with the United States today that Communist China's use of force had caused "grave tensions" in the Far East that should be settled by peaceful means.

Banks across the nation joined in raising the prime rate, the interest rate on loans to their biggest customers with the best credit ratings, from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent yesterday. Other bank lending rates are scaled upward from the prime rate.
The New York Central Railroad will consolidate some of its trains serving Cleveland, Buffalo and other Midwest cities. The new timetable becomes effective Oct. 26.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Lew Burdette pitched three-hit ball tonight to bag his seventeenth victory of the season as the Milwaukee Braves crushed the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a proposed regulation aimed at curbing illegal stock transactions involving foreigners.
LANCIEUX, France, Sept. 12 -- Robert W. Service, poet and novelist of the Yukon, died yesterday in his home on Robert Service Street in this Brittany coastal town. He was 84 years old.

IZMUR, Turkey, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Two young United States sailors were sentenced to ten months in a Turkish jail today for having torn down two Turkish flags here. They were identified as James F. Thomany, 18 years old, of New Lenox, Ill., and Bennie Ross Day, 19, of Connersville, Ind. Both are in the crew of the U.S.S. Barry of the Sixth Fleet.

BEIRUT, Lebanon Sept. 12 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, left here today for New York to report to the General Assembly on his tour to seek practical arrangements to settle the crises in Lebanon and Jordan.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 12 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus issued a proclamation today closing all four high schools in Little Rock.

A new suspect in the Staten Island murder of Dr. Melvin A. Nimer and his wife was flown here from Virginia last night as the mystery surrounding the case deepened.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12 -- "Lolita," an unusual novel of the relationship between a 40-year-old man and his 12year-old mistress, was purchased today for motion-picture filming by the directing-producing team of Stanley Kubrick and James Harris.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 12 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, made a slashing attack today on President Eisenhower's speech last night. The Senator said that Quemoy and Matsu were not essential to the defense of Taiwan.
ALBANY, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Governor Harriman made six appointments today to local councils of the state university.

"THE WILD SWAN" came home to roost on television antennas last night during a pleasant flight of fancy on Channel 4's "Shirley Temple's Storybook."

THE Jewish New Year begins at sunset tomorrow. Known as Rosh ha-Shanah, it is a time of solemn prayer and quiet joy. It is also a time when families dine on foods made with sugar and honey, symbolic of the wish for "sweetness in the New Year."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 11 to 14 points (55 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday, with old crop months strongest.
GENEVA, Sept. 12 -- Dutch scientists took the lead today in pressing for an international safety code to protect the public against the radioactive hazards of an atomic energy industry.

CHRISTCHURCH, N. Z., Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- The United States Navy has agreed to help a Soviet Antarctic aerial reconnaissance team.

Peter J. Crotty, Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, asserted last night that he was a liberal. He addressed the New York City chapter of Americans for Democratic Action.

A promising pattern for labor union democracy has been hammered out by the new American Bakery and Confectionery Workers in the constitution it adopted at its first convention at Atlantic City.
