WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Dr. George K. C. Yeh, new Chinese Nationalist Ambassador to the United States, said today that his Government would not agree to a cease-fire in Taiwan Strait.

E. C. Williams in The Times of Sept. 6 observes the coincidence of the phrase "deliberate speed" in the Supreme Court's 1954 school segregation ruling and in Francis Thompson's "The Hound of Heaven." The record should be set straight.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Lamar McHan-to-Gern Nagler passing combination clicked for two touchdowns and set up the third for the Chicago Cardinals tonight in their 21-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in an exhibition game between the National Football League teams.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants set a 1958 National League record for runs scored in one game when they blasted the Philadelphia Phillies, 19 -- 2, in the second game of a twilight-night double-header after snapping their six-game losing streak with a 5-2 victory in the opener.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru reminded Parliament today that international disputes could not be settled without a little give and take.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Commonwealth Edison Company approved today a plan to distribute its full earnings to shareholders in cash and stock dividends.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Widespread violation of laws covering competitive bidding on contracts involving millions of dollars of public purchases and work has been reported by the State Department of Audit and Control.

Bernard Newman, New York Couny Republican leader, announced the selection of former Representative James G. Donovan and Edward J. Fontana yesterday as candidates for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District. The district covers Manhattan and the Bronx.

DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 12 -- The Ford Motor Company is planning a new offer to the United Automobile Workers.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume. Trading in most markets was dull.

Crops in the Great Northern Railway's territory are turning out so much better than had been anticipated in mid-summer that management of the carrier has advised its stockholders it is "confident" about the outlook for earnings for 1958.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, Sept. 13 -- Political aspects of the Quemoy situation, as outlined by President Eisenhower Thursday night, are considered here to be less important now than the problem of keeping the tenuously held Nationalist islands from starving to death.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 12 -- United Sates private capital is expected to aid Brazilian companies being formed to explore for oil in 1,400,000 hectares in Bolivia. One hectare equals 2.471 acres.

DUBLIN, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The Irish Amateur Athletic Union finally has located the proper forms and, one month and six days after the deed, today submitted Herb Elliott's 3:54.5 clocking for the mile run for recognition as a world record.

Charles A. Fenton, Professor of English at Duke University and author of "The Apprenticeship of Ernest Hemingway," has a new biographical study of an American writer on the Yale University Press list. It is "Stephen Vincent Benet," which gives a critical evaluation of Benet's work.
HAVANA, Sept. 12 -- Attacks on transportation and sabotage by rebels in Oriente and Las Villas Provinces appear to be increasing, according to reports of travelers from the two areas.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Johnie Day Jr. of the Westchester Country Club won the sixteenth Westchester Golf Association's husband-wife championship today over the par-70 Old Oaks course. They carded a gross 36, 38 -- 74 to score in a field of seventy-one teams.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today the formation of Chrysler International, S. A., for development of world markets for Chrysler and Simca products.
The stock market's drive toward record highs lost impetus yesterday, The consensus in Wall Street was that it was just a pause, and that another forward surge was imminent.
Additional progress in the construction of the $70,000,000 French Line passenger vessel France was reported here yesterday by Jean Marie, chairman of the board of the steamship company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decision ordering immediate racial integration at Little Rock's Central High School brought mixed reaction today but little surprise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Justice Department abandoned today a five-year effort to put the National Lawyers Guild on the Attorney General's list of allegedly subversive organizations.
Medical, welfare and educational leaders continued yesterday to protest Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs' ban on birth-control therapy in New York municipal hospitals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- Negotiators of the Teamsters Union and the trucking industry reached a tentative agreement today to end a month-long strike and lockout in the West.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- Governor Harriman has approved the establishment of a New York Guard, a state military organization that would replace the New York National Guard if it should be called to active Federal service again.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, said yesterday that the time had come for a White House conference on race relations.

The Premier of Israel was reported on Sept. 4 to have told "more than 350 persons from the United States, Canada and Latin America" that the "actions of American Jews" may determine whether or not Israel obtains armaments from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Court of Appeals here held today that civilian employes of the armed forces overseas could not be tried by court-martial for any crimes.
Watch Your Step, a 2-year-old son of Citation, won Belmont's $10,000 Anticipation purse yesterday with an impressive clocking of 1:09 3-5 for six furlongs down the Widener chute.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Unbeaten Len Matthews, the young Philadelphia knockout artist, proved he could box as well as punch tonight as he outpointed Tommy Tibbs of Boston in a ten-round, nationally televised bout at the Arena.
A narcotics squad detective, suspended early yesterday and charged with possession of more than two pounds of opium, was released later in $2,500 bail for a hearing Sept. 17.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 8 -- The twin worries of too great a dependence on fish and on the Soviet's bloc are nagging many an Icelander.

More than 14,000 chemists and chemical engineers from all parts of the United States and several foreign countries attended the annual autumn meeting of the American Chemical Society held at Chicago last week. NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 -The New Orleans Item, founded eighty-one years ago, will go to press for the last time tomorrow.
PARIS, Sept. 13 -- A French policeman was shot and badly wounded by an Algerian on a crowded street this afternoon. The gunman was later captured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Boastful and self-congratulatory noises emanating from the vicinity of Atlantic City and Omaha this week had a valid and persuasive ring about them as national and local functionaries of the Democratic National Committee got together for a series of regional strategy conferences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A Washington syndicate purchased controlling stock interest in the Munsey Trust Company yesterday from the Dewart family of New York.
MASSENA, N. Y., Sept. 13 -The Wiley-Dondero Ship Channel, named in honor of two legislators who sponsored the law authorizing the St. Lawrence Seaway, was dedicated here this morning.

BONN, West Germany, Sept. 13 -- The Government hopes that tomorrow's meeting between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Premier Charles de Gaulle in Lorraine will give fresh impetus to French-West German cooperation.

SICILY is celebrated as an island of rugged grandeur; volumes have been written about its architecture, its mountains and picturesque volcanoes. But relatively little has appeared about the island's cuisine which, like that of southern Italy, is lusty, robust and notably delicious.

AS recorded in the obituary columns of The Times, there passed away last week a great gentleman of the theatre, Charles O'Brien Kennedy. PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 13 -- Dr. Charles M. Hanisch, the race chairman at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, almost ran into trouble today. The wind flattened midway through the club's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound week-end program.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- A temporary reduction in the production and export of lead and zinc was suggested today as a short-term measure by a meeting of thirty-two nations. A cut in exports for one year or less was proposed.

Y. -- Cruise ships are nothing new to the lower St. Lawrence River between Montreal and the sea, but the sight of two of them carrying more than 800 passengers all the way from the Great Lakes as far as here made a sensation on the upper river and along the newly man-made channels of the St. Lawrence Seaway last week-end.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Frank S. Hogan opened his upstate campaign for the United States Senate today by invading this home city of his Republican opponent, Representative Kenneth B. Keating.

The American Kennel Club, long perplexed by the problem of exhibitors who wished to bring to a show dogs other than those they had entered, settled the matter at its quarterly meeting recently at the Hotel Biltmore.

A NEW Federal law, the Automobile Information Disclosure Act, designed to take some of the guess work out of automobile prices, will go into effect Friday. The law makes it mandatory for automobile manufacturers to put a price tag on their new passenger cars and station wagons.
A nation-wide combined campaign for American Reform Judaism was announced yesterday. The goal is $2,850,000.

FAIR HILL, Md., Sept. 13 -Caste, a 10-year-old horse, overlooked by many among the 5,000 who crowded the William duPont Jr. estate, won the twomile Manly Steeplechase Handicap by a length in 4:00 today. It was the second fastest time of the famous race, formerly run at Pimlico, and three-fifths of a second behind the track record.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -The president - elect of the American Medical Association urged the medical and related professions today to help find more productive lives for older persons.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -India has put out feelers looking toward United States financing of a steel mill of 1,000,000-ton capacity.

A proposal by the Montclair (N. J.) Bird Club for a statewide hawk watch has burgeoned into plans for one of the biggest hawk watches ever held in the United States.

A two-day "open-house" celebration marking the thirtieth anniversary of Newark Airport will be held the weekend of Sept. 27-28, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday. The field was opened officially Oct. 1, 1928.

Hundreds of New Yorkers and Canadians living in New York visited yesterday three Canadian destroyers that are passing a long week-end in this city. The ships tied up at Pier 86, West Forty-fifth Street and the Hudson River, on Friday and will remain there until Tuesday morning.

THE Rutherford, N. J., physician, William Carlos Williams, who also happens to be a poet, novelist and short-story writer, observes this week his seventy-fifth birthday. He received the National Book Award in 1950 for his "Selected Poems" and "Paterson, Book Three," and it is the long work. "Paterson," the four books of which appeared between 1946 and 1951, for which he is best known.

New York's piers are generally under attack from the tenants they serve. They are either called old and outmoded or too small and not gaited to present-day cargo handling methods. Sometimes the tenants say the new ones are too big.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- America's allies in Western Europe have been deeply disturbed and frightened by the crisis in the Far East. Official and public opinion strongly opposes any military action by the United States over Quemoy and Matsu that might lead to a war with Communist China.
ROME, Sept. 12 -- There is no immediate prospect that the Vatican will implement its long-standing decree authorizing a Papal merchant fleet, a Vatican spokesman said today.
ARMONK, N. Y., Sept. 13 -Three weeks ago a plane crashed while heading in to the small airport here. This week there was a new item on the school board's agenda.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- El Paso (Tex.) Natural Gas Company goes before a Federal Power Commission examiner next Wednesday to ask for approval of a merger the Department of Justice has branded a monopoly.
AMBERG, Germany, Sept. 12 -- West German and United States tanks banged away at each other this week for the first time in thirteen years.

DENVER, Sept. 13 (UPI) -Tommy Jacobs toured the Wellshire municipal course with a 3-under-par 67 today to maintain his two-stroke lead at the end of fifty-four holes in the Denver Centennial open with a score of 199.

HONG KONG, Sept. 13 -Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Premier of Cambodia, has said in a letter to the editor of the English-language Hong Kong Standard: "I do not intend to see communism installed in my country."
In a few weeks college football coaches probably will be in more hot water than a bar of soap.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- The San Francisco Opera Company has recorded another "first," punctuated with bravos, in opening its thirty-sixth season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- An Air Force spokesman said last night that there "is no present intention" to abandon Mitchel Air Force Base at Garden City, L. I.
WARSAW, Sept. 13 -- Poland's capital, which has found itself selected as the host in proposed talks between the United States and Communist China, has taken a rather gloomy view of the whole thing.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 13 -- The impact of an aircraft company's operations on the economy of Long Island was disclosed here today in a study by the Republic Aviation Corporation.

PIERRE BOULEZ has a horrendous reputation. Horrendous, that is, if you find the music of Arnold Schoenberg and Anton Webern a bit difficult. For M. Boulez, who belongs to the group of European composers who have come to maturity since World War II, uses techniques so complex they make the retrograde mirrors, canons and other permutations and combinations of Schoenberg's twelve-tone rows seem simple by comparison.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 13 -- Indications are that pigs in Europe have lived too long in clover. They have waxed so fat and so numerous that their market value is being deflated.

Business in general in the southeast continues to show strong signs of recovery. Department store sales last week again were substantially above levels of a year before. With dollar volume for the year thus far only 1 per cent below the level last year, many merchants were predicting that sales would equal or better the 1957 volume this year.

This season marks the centennial of the most celebrated series of joint debates in American history. Seven in number, they were part of the 1858 Senate campaign in Illinois between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas.

The 12-Meter designation carried by the racing sloops that will meet for the America's Cup does not describe their length or any other single dimension. It reflects their conformity with a complex mathematical formula balancing out to 12.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Louisiana State University asserted today it would admit only those Negroes it was compelled by the courts to admit. It warned such Negroes that they were "unwanted" and would be considered symbols of difiance to the university's customs.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- "Gorblimey, 'ow it rynes," said an elderly Cockney barrow boy in a sheltered doorway watching the downpour drench his fruit cart and drive away business. "It's all them 'oydrogen explosions, that's wot it is."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 13 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, President of the governing junta, will be proposed by the Republican Democratic Union party as the "unity" candidate for President, it was announced today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Charley Coe of Oklahoma City proved a first-rate golfing mechanic today. His do-it-yourself ideas enabled him to win his second national.

For her, adjustment began with the death of her handsome, young father, and with her own youthful marriage to a husband beset by a domineering and everpresent mother.

Milwaukee's National League pennant-clinching number was cut to five.

Dickinson Letts to help purge the International Brotherhood of Teamsters -- and the courage of Judge Letts himself.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- Centers where New Jersey residents may receive free eye examinations were listed here this week by the State Medical Society. Tests are available to all residents 25 years old or older who are not now undergoing eye treatment.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- The Radical party voted approval today of the proposed French Constitution by 716 to 544.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America announced last night that Samuel Lemberg, New York philanthropist, has been named to receive the seminary's Louis Marshall Award. Mr. Lemberg was cited for his "dedication to spiritual and cultural betterment of our people."

Hoyt, Red Bank dental surgeon, seems to be the top scorer in predicted log races and the winner of the national championship.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The people of Karachi have taken up bingo enthusiastically. The game, known here as tombola; has been made attractive with the addition of a few promotional frills and big cash prizes.

THE next six to eight weeks are just what the gardener ordered. They are perfect for planting trees, shrubs, hardy bulbs, many perennials and, of course, lawn seed. The fall growing season gives these plants time to get established and they will greet spring with opening buds and new leaves.

July department store sales in the Third Federal Reserve District were the highest on record for that month. The seasonally adjusted index for July was 10 per cent above that for June and 141 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- In a few rather dry, unemotional words, the Supreme Court made clear to the South this week that there will be no retreat from the decision that children in the public schools may not be segregated on the basis of race.

THE Venice Film Festival ended one of its most successful sessions in years last Sunday night. Fourteen feature films from ten nations were screened in formal competition and more than twice that number were seen in the noncompetitive "information section," designed to keep festival-goers, including a press corps of 600, abreast of currently worthy film fare from all over the world.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Indians climbed to within a game and a half of the thirdplace Boston Red Sox today by beating the Bosox, 4 -- 1. Cleveland staged a three-run seventhinning rally in which Dave Sisler walked home the winning run and Vic Power doubled in two more.

ED SULLIVAN and Bob Hope are studying travel folders in anticipation of recording their respective television shows in several distant lands this coming season. Mr. Sullivan already has decided to do a program in Alaska in November and expects to visit the Hawaiian Islands and Tokyo later.

The J. I. Case Company, Racine, Wis., manufacturer of farm and industrial equipment, has reported for the nine months to July 31 net income of $2,988,861, or 5 cents a common share. For the similar period a year earlier, the company reported a net loss of $993,805.

BUSINESS and professional women may "fulfill their feminine role" as volunteer leaders of Girl Scout troops.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Industrial shares maintained last week what is being described him as a "boomlet." The market was firm in most sectors, although South African gold mining stocks eased toward the end of the week's trading after hitting a two-year peak, on Monday.
Wyandotte, Mich., School District, which received no bids for $6,925,000 of bonds when offered last week, will reoffer them Sept. 22. The bonds mature from 1959 to 1984.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- The stage manager of the San Francisco Actor's Workshop company has been barred by the State Department from making a trip abroad, it was announced here today.

The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., who led the Montgomery, Ala., Negro community in its non-violent resistance to segregation, has written an account of this event. In "Stride Toward Freedom" he tells what it was like to live through that experience and depicts the spirit of a people "who had had enough." The book will be published Wednesday by Harper.

Blitz memorial and the open jumper championship as the fifty-third Piping Rock Horse Show drew to a close before an overflow crowd today.
The City Planning Commission was directed yesterday by Mayor Wagner to give "preferential treatment" to school construction in allocating scarce 1959 capital funds.

The first exchange of television programs between the United States and the Soviet Union began yesterday under awkward circumstances. It took the form of an interview by American students with Anastas I. Mikoyan, Russian First Deputy Premier, on "Youth Wants to Know" over Channel 4.

OXFORD, Md., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Skip Etchells, a 47-year-old boat builder from Old Greenwich, Conn., won the 1958 North American Star Class sailing champions today, easing home in third place in the last contest of the five-race series.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Sept. 14 -- A machinist and an electrician from the Chicago area -- both born in Scotland -- won the first United States lawn bowling doubles championship today.
Politics cannot free races, Bishop William Jacob Walls said yesterday at the Caldwell African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, 1288 Stebbins Avenue, the Bronx.

As a daily reader of Letters to The Times let me metaphorically wish that the observations of James Reston, Norman Thomas, James Warburg, Thomas Finletter were uttered from trumpets as effective as those which are reputed to have brought down the walls of Jericho.

Prices of domestic cotton fluctuated narrowly last week, closing with moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 9 to 30 points (45 cents to $1.50 a bale) up for the week.
Small cars and large trucks figured in advertising account developments over the week-end.

The religious significance of Rosh ha-Shanah and the need for a greater emphasis on spiritual values were stressed in sermons as the Jewish people ushered in the Jewish New Year 5719 at sundown yesterday.

Donald Goldman's dream to establish permanent quarters for the Shakespearewrights, the group over which he presides as founder-producer, has come true. Hereafter, the five-year-old organization will make its headquarters at 115 MacDougal Street in Greenwich Village.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- World production of cotton is expected to resume its upward climb and create new surplus problems, the International Cotton Advisory Committee reported today.

The commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary as a parish of St. Camillus Roman Catholic Church, Rockaway Beach, Queens, began yesterday. A golden jubilee mass was celebrated by the Rev. Edward P. Curley, a former administrator of the church. The pastor is the Rev. John F. Murphy.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 14 -- In a surprise move today, the United States began the withdrawal of two Marine battalions from Lebanon.
DAVIS PARK, Fire Island, L. I., Sept 14 -- Amateur frogmen found a copper-sheathed hulk yesterday in the ocean off Old Inlet at the site where the historic steamship Savannah was believed lost.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (Reuters) -- Pravda denounced today a vice not unknown in the capitalist West -- the nottoo-busy "business" trip on a fat expense account.

The U. N. General Assembly opens its thirteenth regular session tomorrow with the customary "minute of silent prayer or meditation." This choice is offered in deference to the Communist members, who have withdrawn diplomatic recognition from the Almighty. There are issues enough, however, for the Assembly to pray or meditate over. This situation is not too discouraging.

This choice is offered in deference to the Communist members, who have withdrawn diplomatic recognition from the Almighty. There are issues enough, however, for the Assembly to pray or meditate over. This situation is not too discouraging.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 14 -- A large pavilion stood virtually empty through the international trade fair that closed here today, a mute reminder that the United States was not represented.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson, Sweden's undefeated European heavyweight champion, tonight increased his chances for a world title fight by knocking out the previously unbeaten Eddie Machen of Redding, Calif.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -- Frank H. Ricketson Jr. announced today his resignation as vice president and general manager of theatre operations for National Theatres.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The chairman of courtinted monitors for the sters Union challenged towhat appeared to be a ter move by James R. a, president of the union.
Vehicular traffic congestion, an unwelcome side-effect of the anti-jaywalking law in force since Aug. 8, has caused concern in the Traffic and Police Departments.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 14 -- This state's first "all-girl" bank will be in operation shortly in near-by Portland. The Middletown Savings Bank will open its first branch bank with an all-girl staff in charge, in October, according to Howard B. Smith, bank president.

PARIS, Sept. 14 -- The Socialist and Radical parties, representing most of non-Communist Leftist opinion in France, gave qualified approval today to Premier Charles de Gaulle and his proposed Constitution.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 14 -- Ray Kaufman made it two straight victories as he sailed his Furious II to Snipe Class honors today in the interclub championship series conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
A young woman stabbed to death in Inwood Hill Park Saturday night was identified yesterday by the police as the German-born wife of a merchant seaman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Major speeches by President Eisenhower, former President Harry S. Truman and Vice President Richard M. Nixon were announced today as both political parties began stepping up campaign preparations.
DETROIT, Sept. 14 -- Walter P. Reuther took cognizance today of the distribution by Knowland supporters of the tract attacking the auto union president.
Halfway through a so-called "All Star Jazz Show" at Town Hall on Saturday evening, Billie Holiday walked out on the stage somewhat hesitantly and dragged her way through a slow, slow ballad.

The New York Yankees clinched the American League pennant yesterday in Kansas City by defeating the Athletics, 5 -- 3, in the first game of a double-header. In the second game, the Yanks won, 12-7, with five runs in the fourteenth inning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Justice Department and counsel for the Senate rackets investigating committee clashed sharply today over whether the department was pushing cases of possible perjury referred to it for prosecution.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 -- A more-than-ordinary pick-up in production, a sharp rise in new orders at some steel plants and general expectation of an operating rate of about 75 per cent of capacity soon were highlights in the steel market late last week. Improvements in production, orders and backlogs are expected this week.

The Young Men's Real Estate Association of New York, Inc., will hold its first fall luncheon meeting Wednesday in the Shelburne Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. Robert T. Walsh, executive vice president of the New York Board of Trade, will speak on New York busines organizations' service to the real estate industry.

MONTREAL, Sept. 14 -- Canada, if not confident of marrying her dollar to the pound sterling in world trade, is hoping at least to be able to announce an engagement for future nuptials at the end of the two-week Commonwealth Trade and Economic Conference opening here tomorrow.
President Eisenhower was described yesterday by one of his former aides as "a man of not only deep intelligence but very great wisdom."
A senior vice president has resigned at Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., and an executive vice president has been named.

The Regional Plan Association has invited officials and citizens of 550 communities in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan area to a conference on regional problems. The meeting will be held Oct. 8 in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Despite great scientific and industrial advances in the last century, the keystone of Roman Catholic dogma remains that "all-values, even life itself must be weighed solely upon the scale of the Cross," the Rev. William R. O'Brien said yesterday.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 14 -- The father and son combination Oswald Jacoby and James Jacoby, both of Dallas, were top qualifiers last night in the 1958 Lone Star Open Pairs Championship.

Mrs. Charles Ulrick Bay's 3-year-old filly Idun regained her status as the Miss America of the equine world yesterday with a four-and-a-half length victory in Belmont's $29,750 Gazelle Handicap.

The Brooklyn Public Library reported yesterday that the circulation of its books in the past year had reached a twenty-five-year high of 9,058,171.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Between angry shouting bouts with Senate investigators, James R. Hoffa congratulated himself today on "an excellent job" of cleaning up the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The establishment by a railroad pioneering family of an annual space travel award was announced today.

Public offering of $50,000,000 of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company first mortgage pipeline bonds is being made today by an investment banking group managed jointly by Stone Webster Securities Corporation, White, Weld Co., and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

Such tongue-in-check flippancies brought only frowns to the furrowed brow of Charles Dillon Stengel.

BAYONNE, N. J.. Sept. 15 -- A vast armada of rescue craft rushed to the disaster scene here today, but it was a rescue operation that was over nearly as soon as it had begun.

In setting priorities for use of limited city borrowing power in the 1959 capital budget Mayor Wagner puts school construction first. He thus agrees with his Budget Director, Abraham D. Beame. Frederick W. Richmond, New York financier and industrialist, has purchased a substantial block of stock in the Houston Oil Fields Material Company, Inc., and has been named chairman.

PORT SAID, United Arab Republic, Sept. 15 (UPI) -- A 3 per cent surcharge went into effect on Suez Canal tolls today to pay for the United Nations operation that cleared the waterway. There was some doubt whether all ships would honor it.

Net assets of the nation's mutual funds continue to rise, with the Aug. 31 total reaching a new high of $11,315,342,000, the National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Passenger car production has begun to move up as customary production difficulties with new model assemblies are ironed out. Meanwhile, Automotive News said yesterday that stocks of unsold new cars reached the year's lowest point on Sept. 1.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 15 -- Neil H. McElroy indicated today that next year's defense budget might go as high as $42,000,000,000.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 15 -- What happens when the only high school in an American county of 15,000 closes to avoid the admission of twenty-two Negroes?
Mayor Wagner officiated yesterday at ceremonies dedicating the new headquarters of the American Theatre Wing at 161 West Ninety-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Set. 15 -- Sherman Adams returned to his White House desk today as No.1 assistant to President Eisenhower after a ten-day Canadian fishing holiday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today invited private United States concerns to help it determine which type of nuclear reactor held the most promise for economical nuclear power.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 15 -- This city's four high schools, which were scheduled to begin their fall term today, remained closed under orders from Gov. Orval E. Faubus.

" The Politics of Despair," a new book by Hadley Cantril, former chairman of the Department of Psychology at Princeton University, will be published Oct. 9 by Basic Books. MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 15 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Marion S. Boyd turned down today Negro requests to enroll at all-white Memphis State University.

ROME, Sept. 15 -- Pope Pius XII has declared that neither artificial insemination nor voluntary adultery may be resorted to by married couples if a partner is sterile or if they fear they may transmit a hereditary defect to their offspring.
TOKYO, Sept. 15 -- The Leftist - inclined Japan Teachers Union called its long-threatened walkout of public school teachers today, but it was only partly successful.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 -- The Republic of Mexico is in the midst of its most solemn holiday period. It is the anniversary of the call for rebellion against Spanish rule.

Today's new film is "Premier May," a French drama with English titles, starring Yves Montand and Nicole Berger, at the Baronet, Third Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street. Luis Saslavsky, who directed, adapted the screen play with Claude Heymann.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- August figures show G. I. home loan activity may be leveling off again.
The Central Railroad of New Jersey has been operating under severe financial strain in the last year. It has lost money in every month since last November and in that month it cleared only $2,388.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A Federal mediator is scheduled to meet Thursday with representatives of the Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company and its striking workers to try to settle differences over a new contract.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover protested today that the National Probation and Parole Association had misinterpreted his recent address before the American Bar Association on the gravity of juvenile crime.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The stock market closed the day on a rising note with widespread small gains. After a cautious start, the industrials made a modest response to the announcement that restrictions on installment buying would be eased.
LONDON, Sept. 15. -- (UPI) -- Britain eased credit restrictions today, indicating a lessening of Government fears of inflation.

Attorneys for Edward M. Gilbert said yesterday that his group held a majority of E. L. Bruce shares. In the market, the apparent corner in Bruce stock began to melt away. No demand came from Mr. Gilbert that short sellers deliver stock to him.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 15 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, a four-time winner, and Terry Logan of Essex Fells tied for the qualifying medal today in the thirty-third annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association match play championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Those citizens whose remedy for everything they disapprove of in American life is "There ought to be a law" will find comfort in the statistics of the Eighty-fifth Congress published in its official Record today. The legislative crop of the two sessions was 5,126 measures, including bills and resolutions, and only 224 of the items reported by committees to the House or the Senate were killed by inaction.

THOSE in this city who take wine and food seriously listen with respect when Mrs. Jeanne Owen speaks. She is executive secretary of the New York chapter of the Wine and Food Society. She also is the author of four excellent cookbooks, including "A Wine Lover's Cook Book" (M. Barrows, 1940) and "Jeanne Owen's Book of Sauces" (M. Barrows, 1941).

Adam Consolidated Industries, Inc., is moving to diversify further with the acquisition of Tire Mart, Inc., national distributor of auto and truck tires and accessories. Harold N. Leitman, president of Adam, in announcing the agreement by the boards of both concerns yesterday, said the price would be 300,000 shares of Adam for Tire Mart.
Steel production continued to rise last week. It exceeded the scheduled output anal was at the highest level so far this year. A continued, although smaller, gain was expected this week.

Once more, it is the Yankees who are. pennant winners in the American League. There was nothing especially electrifying about the victory itself. By mid-season the Yankees had spread-eagled the league to such an extent that even a sorry August slump hardly cut into their lead. It was obvious that they could coast in. But they didn't back in. They won the clincher decisively, as champions should.
ATLANTA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A Negro was shot and killed by a policeman, one trolley was shot at and another was stoned during a series of week-end disturbances in Atlanta's northwest section.
Fifteen young singers will make their debuts with the New York City Opera, which opens its six-week season at the City Center on Oct. 7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply again this week after a one-week lapse, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on the sale of $1,800,000,000 of 91-day discount bills was 2.605 per cent, compared with 2.359 per cent last week.
Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, warned yesterday of a "dangerous drift" in the United States toward mediocrity as the normal work standard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 15 -- Mikhail A. Menshikov, Soviet Ambassador to this country, is expected to arrive here tomorrow night, according to the Motion Picture Association of America. AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Allen Russell, president of the Austin Senators, said today that his Texas League team would not play in any series where any of his players were excluded. The team has four Negroes.

BORDEAUX, France, Sept. 15 -- Rare is the man in this placid coastal city who doubts that France will accept Gen. Charles de Gaulle's new Constitution in the Sept. 28 referendum. Even rarer is the man who has read the Constitution.

Consolidated net income of the Central Fibre Products Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended June 28 amounted to $3,182,684, against $3,571,512 in the preceding fiscal year, the annual report showed yesterday.

WARSAW, Sept. 15--United States and Chinese Communist diplomats met for almost three hours here today to discuss the Far Eastern crisis. They then decided to take two days off to consult their governments on the next move in the negotiations.

BAYONNE, N. J., Tuesday, Sept. 16 -- A commuter train of the Central Railroad of New Jersey plunged through an open liftbridge into Newark Bay at 10 A. M. yesterday. Synagogues over the city were crowded yesterday as Rosh ha - Shanah worshipers marked in solemn prayer and meditation the Jewish New Year 5719.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in net income for August and for the eight and twelve months ended on Aug. 31. This continued the trend of reaching new highs each month this year, despite the recession.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, who has supported the controversial cancer drug krebiozen, took some himself today.

DETROIT, Sept. 15 -- For a manaager who had just won his ninth pennant in ten years and this last by the widest margin of all, Casey Stengel today was far from the calm, cool and collected skipper one might expect under the circumstances.

" Assassinio nella cattedrale," the Ildebrando Pizzetti opera based on T. S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," will have its first performance in this country at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30 under the auspices of the Empire State Music Festival.
The president of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network declared yesterday that those who say television is all quizzes and Westerns "don't know what they are reporting."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 16 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus clashed today with Presbyterian ministers and the Little Rock School Board as public pressure mounted against his refusal to allow the city's four high schools to open.
GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- Addressing a guard at the Palais des Nations, a visitor asked the way to the GATT. The guard looked puzzled and asked, "What is a gatt?"

Financing a college education in the future may become a sixty-year task involving both the family and the student. This belief was voiced yesterday by Dr. Seymour Harris, chairman of Harvard University's Economics Department.
Officials investigating the murder of Dr. Melvin A. Nimer and his wife Lujean yesterday considered, but decided against, changing the police alarm for their slayer.

The O. A. Sutton Corporation of Wichita, Kan., announced yesterday that it had suspended manufacturing and was liquidating inventories to pay off bank debts. The company is a maker of automobile and home air-conditioning equipment.

WHEN Wolcott Gibbs died last month The New Yorker magazine lost its most reliable and regular contributor and the American literary scene one of its most urbane writers. He died at his summer home on the Fire Island he loved and had ironically celebrated in numerous short stories, a novel and a play.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Since the end of World War II, West Pakistan has added 1,000,000 acres to her cultivated area, but total agricultural production has continued to slump.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 16 -- Bolivia's President has appealed to Washington for help to avert a Communist victory in South America's heartland.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Sept. 17 -- The Nationalist Chinese, in conjunction with United States air and sea forces, again pierced the Communist blockade of the Quemoy Islands yesterday.
TOKYO, Sept. 16 -- The Soviet Union warned Japan today against allowing the United States to use her territory for "aggression" against Communist China.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Harry Oppenheimer, South African mining leader, signed an agreement here today for a loan by the Deutsche Bank of 50,000,000 marks (about $12,500,000).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Government halted today an emergency $1,000,000,000 program to spur housing activity through buying mortgages, five and one-half months after it started, because the entire $1,000,000,000 has already been committed.

Custom smelters raised the price of refined copper 1/8 cent a pound yesterday to 26 3/8 cents. Demand was reported to have improved, reflecting firmer prices abroad, a strike in the copper mining belt of Northern Rhodesia and the threat of a walkout at a major Canadian copper and nickel property.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- Finance Minister H. J. Hofstra announced today that the Government planned to build 80,000 homes -- half of them for workers -- and to cut defense costs slightly in 1959.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16 -- Some Soviet-bloc nations are cutting down on imports from Yugoslavia, apparently because of the renewed hostility between President Tito and the Kremlin.

BEN METIR, Tunisia, Sept. 15 -- President Habib Bourguiba, the Arab leader who is closest to the United States in his foreign policy, recognized the growing authoritarianism of his regime today and defended it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that cash dividend payments by corporations issuing public reports totaled $302,000,000 in August, a 4 per cent drop below the total paid in August, 1957.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Arthur J. Longsjo Jr., 26 years old, of Fitchburg, Mass., who competed for the United States in the 1956 Olmpic Games as an ice skater and bicyclist, was fatally injured in an automobile accident today.
Firemen rescued three workmen yesterday who had been trapped upstairs when a three-story building they were demolishing collapsed at Third Avenue and Fifteenth Street.
On top of months of deficit operations, the Central Railroad of New Jersey now is faced with the possibility of large personal liability claims as a result of Monday's train wreck at Bayonne.

Robert Briscoe, Dublin's first Jewish Lord Mayor, has written the story of his life in collaboration with Alden Hatch. To be called "For the Life of Me," it will be issued Oct. 6 by Little, Brown. The story covers the sixty-three years that preceded Mr. Briscoe's election as Lord Mayor.

ROME, Sept. 16 -- An American's warning against the "political naivete" of the space age's scientists was applauded here today by an international gathering of political experts. Prof. James K. Pollock of the University of Michigan said that "foreign and military policy is hardly the task of the nuclear physicist."

There used to be two delegates named Malik around the United Nations. One of these, not Russian, used to be called, in a not too ill-natured distinction, "the good Malik." Yesterday Foreign Minister Charles Malik of Lebanon, "the good Malik," won the presidency of the General Assembly, a one-session job, over Foreign Minister Mohammed Mahgoub of the Sudan by a vote of 45 to 31.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 16 -- The Navy tried to launch a Vanguard satellite today, but ran into trouble just as the main engine ignited.

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- World production on natural rubber exceeded consumption during July by about 22,500 long tons, the secretariat of the international rubber Study Group reported today. A long ton is 2,240 pounds.
The broad powers of the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission will again be contested in dual actions in State Supreme Court today.

MARKING the tenth anniversary of the Fulbright program, administered by the Institute of International Education, a show of paintings by sixty artists who have worked abroad under grants will open to the public today at the Whitney Museum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today offered banks and other private lenders higher interest rates for helping to provide money to carry out price support loans to growers on crop surpluses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A package pay increase of 10 per cent for 20,000 mechanical and ground crew employes of six major airlines was recommended today by an emergency board appointed by President Eisenhower.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 16 -- Close-aboard observation of Sceptre under sail today left observers with the impression that the British 12-meter sloop will make a formidable bid for the America's Cup.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Gary Bell, a rookie, pitched a two-hitter tonight and the Cleveland Indians defeated the Washington Senators, 5 -- 1. Rocky Colavito hit his thirty-eight homer of the season for Cleveland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The grain futures market which has become increasingly hard to budge recently met some scattered, if not enthusiastic, support today and most prices on the Board of Trade scored small gains.

The cooperative ownership plan for Cumberland House, a seventeen - story apartment building nearing completion on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-second Street, has been declared effective with the sales of half the building's 101 apartments.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 -- The United Steelworkers of America served notice today that it would insist on "substantail" improvement in wages, hours and all other major contract provisions in its pattern-setting negotiations with the steel industry next year.
Burlington Industries, Inc., a leading textile organization, has awarded a large portion of its advertising account to J. M. Mathes, Inc.
In their sermons on the second day of Rosh ha-Shanah yesterday rabbis stressed that a new and peaceful world could be built with man's spiritual resources.

The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will hold its annual celebration of Constitution Day today at the Federal Court in Brooklyn. Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers will preside.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 (UPI) -- Willie Hartack, who rode his first winner less than six years ago, moved to within one victory of the 2,000 mark today when he booted Miss Royal to a popular triumph in the fourth race here.
Investors yesterday heeded the "signal" of the Dow-Jones industrial average, delivered Monday when it surpassed its former historic high of 521.
The blouse industry is doing just fine. Manufacturers are putting in long hours to keep production and shipments up to the level of orders.
DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- Frank Lary, a 27-year-old right-hander, today became the first pitcher in forty-two years to win seven games from the Yankees in a single season.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for United States Senator, accused Governor Harriman last night of supporting free spending as a policy for curing national economic troubles.
THE sounds of crunching, munching, gnawing, nibbling and sipping heard daily at Pelham Parkway in the Bronx come from a group of boarders who have the beastliest table manners in town.
A collection of fourteen space ships that should please even the most imaginative youngsters will go on display at the Hayden Planetarium today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- The legendary ballyhoo of P. T. Barnum will be the basis of the first production for Paramount Pictures of the new independent film unit headed by Martin Jurow and Richard Shepherd. They have a twelve-picture commitment with the studio for the next six years.
ALGIERS, Sept. 16 -Algeria's Moslem women, who have never voted, are the most earnestly courted prospective voters in the campaign here for the referendum on the French Constitution Sept. 28.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Herbert Hoover and Harry S. Truman have accepted $25,000 pensions and other benefits enacted for former Presidents during the last session of Congress.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- The Soviet press said today that the United Nations General Assembly had to consider six major planks of standard Soviet foreign policy if there was to be progress toward a stable peace.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 16 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. said today he had "no estimate" of when the Warren County High School at Front Royal might reopen.
MONTREAL, Sept. 16 -- Canada called upon Britain today to end her discrimination against dollar imports.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 -- Dr. Charles Malik, the pro-Western Foreign Minister of Lebanon, was elected president of the General Assembly as to opened its 1958 session today. He defeated Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub, Foreign Minister of the Sudan.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. E. M. Burke Jr. of Somerset Hills, who never has won a state title, scored the biggest upset in the thirty-third annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play tournament today.
TAIPEI, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Premier Chen Cheng said today that if the Chinese Communists persisted in sealing off the Que moy Islands, "it would mean extending the war."
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Stock market prices advanced today in all principal sections.

Both the Socialist and Radical parties in France held national congresses last week-end on the de Gaulle Constitution. The results were one more split in the Socialist party and a close vote among the Radicals, but with a majority in both groups supporting the Constitution. This division in the two main national Left-Wing democratic parties is typical of French anxieties as the Sept. 28 referendum approaches.
American Airlines announced yesterday it had set a domestic airfreight record for one month in August. It also reported an increase in its passenger traffic last month above that in August, 1957.

FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 16 -- Resistance in this community to outside interference in its school problems grew faint-hearted today with the news of what it will cost to open Warren County High School without help from the State of Virginia.

WASHINGTON , Sept. 16 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower told eight members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today he would give "thoughtful attention" to their request for more emphasis on economic foreign aid and less on military assistance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The Federal highway program faces sharp cut-backs unless additional funds are provided, Russell E. Singer, executive vice president of the American Automobile Association, said today.

THE first gala opening of the fall season took place last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a premiere performance by the American Ballet Theatre. A benefit fashion show and dinner in Sherry's preceded the ballet.
CARLSTADT, N. J., Sept. 16 -- Two Dutch reclamation engineers got a close look today at the Hackensack Meadows from a boat of the Bergen County Mosquito Extermination Commission.
A new kind of lumberjack is making his mark in Canadian logging operations.

New York's two labor federations charged yesterday that changes proposed by the Department of Health in the regulations covering milk and ice cream would result in a "drastic and substantial weakening" of sanitary standards.

BAY CITY, Mich., Sept. 16 (AP) -- For lack of new evidence, United States District Judge Frank A. Picard dismissed indictments today against six top Michigan Communists accused of conspiring to advocate violent overthrow of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Arthur G. Trudeau, the Army's research chief, said today that the Soviet Union's rapid military advances reflected successful espionage more than Soviet scientific prowess.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized freight forwarders to increase rates and charges on traffic to and from New York City by 20 cents a 100 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -Sherman Adams' resignation as No. 1 assistant to President Eisenhower within a matter of hours -- or at most a couple of days -- was forecast tonight by a highly qualified Republican Congressional source.

Seafaring men and maritime industry leaders joined yesterday to honor Capt. Paul R. Jones Jr., master of the freighter Limon, for his part in rescuing thirteen seamen from their sinking vessel in a Pacific Ocean storm last year.
An imposing roster of performers is being lined up for the William Saroyan Pulitzer Prize-winning play, "The Time of Your Life," which is to be done at the Brussels World's Fair.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Norman Manley, Chief Minister of Jamaica, advised the West Indians today not to emigrate to Britain until there were greater opportunities for employment.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 16 -- Physics, Plato and psychology can wait. Passing the pigskin, it seems, is more pressing in Little Rock.

The ban on birth control therapy in city hospitals was lifted yesterday by an 8-to-2 vote of the Board of Hospitals. The decision was announced by Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs, who had set forth the ban in July. The prohibition has always been unwritten.

"Recessions begin and end in the minds of men," says Charles G. Mortimer, president of the General Foods Corporation. The truth of this can't be proved by statistics. But the "Confidence in a Growing America Campaign" of the Advertising Council has furnished circumstantial evidence of it, at least as to the downswing's end -evidence which Mr. Mortimer appraised in his provocative address yesterday at the Hearst Magazines luncheon.
The State Education Commissioner has declined to intervene in the Harlem school controversy, except under certain conditions.

A blend of American ingenuity and pioneering spirit made possible the first United States-flag air service in South America thirty years ago this month. On that occasion Pan AmericanGrace Airways, commonly known as Panagra, flew a single-engine, four-passenger aircraft on a 600-mile flight between Lima and Talara, Peru. The flight originated from a race track and landed on a soccer field.

The Jersey Central commuter train that plunged into Newark Bay Monday was running at "an abnormal rate of speed," according to an official inquiry yesterday. However, a check of the cab of the recovered Diesel early this morning' indicated that full braking power had been applied before the train dropped from the open liftbridge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Though the long and bitter struggle over racial integration of the public schools is far from over, a glance at today's news as compared with last September shows some fundamental differences.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 17 (AP) -- An Austrian who played a leading role in screening volunteers for West Germany's armed forces went on trial here today on the charge he was a fraud.
Domenico Modugno will sing with an orchestra conducted by Lothar Peri at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30.

The price of lead was advanced 1/4 cent a pound by a leading custom smelter yesterday, to 11 cents. Copper custom smelters raised their price of refined metal 1/8 cent a pound to 26 1/2 cents, the second such increase in two days.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 14 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes appears to have sought and obtained a break with the Left-wing Revolutionary party, after months of a tacit understanding of no open warfare.
MAYWOOD, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Production-line methods that accelerated the manufacture of antibiotics can be applied to cancer research, an executive of Charles Pfizer Co., said today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- China's official Communist party organ rejected today the idea of a cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait while United States and Chinese Communist Ambassadors confer in Warsaw on the crisis.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that two major deficiencies of United States foreign policy were "lack of effective bipartisan action and lack of adequate marshaling of public support."

Railroads initiated a new service fee of 6 cents a 100 pounds Monday for handling freight for export or import. But already some of the carriers have decided they don't want it after all and have dropped it, despite an estimate that it would afford their industry $12,600,000 more a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Senate rackets investigators disclosed today that Ohio Teamsters had paid former Senator George H. Bender $1,000 eight days before he was appointed to a Teamster clean-up commission.
MIAMI, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Dade County school board rejected today fourteen Negro children seeking to enter an allwhite elementary school in a direct challenge of Florida's pupil assignment law.
In a past generation in sport, two strong personalities stood out not only for greatness in their field, but also for an irascibility that, when provoked, threatened mayhem.

Three executives of Gimbels, New York, were among a group of forty employes who were honored for long service last night at the annual banquet of the Gimbel Quarter Century Club in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A Firestone Tire Rubber Company executive has told a Federal Trade Commission hearing the company would stop using the names deluxe, super and super deluxe on its lower lines of tires.

Although a spokesman for Edward M. Gilbert refused to talk about it yesterday, it was reported in Wall Street that a compromise was brewing between his group and the management of the E. L. Bruce Company. Mr. Gilbert and his associates have been engaged since early spring in buying stock of the Memphis, Ten., hardwood flooring concern.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Following is the text of the speech by Attorney General William P. Rogers today before the annual meeting of the National Conference on Citizenship:

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Northeast winds of thirty miles an hour, with gusts up to forty miles an hour, deferred the completion of the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy series for the men's North American sailing championship at the American Y. C. today.

Following are the texts of statements on birth control by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn, the Protestant Council of New York, and the Commission on Law and Social Action of the American Jewish Congress:

PIERRE CARDIN, French designer, has given women the lowdown on how to wear the new high-waisted styles. The main criticism heard against the Empire, or Directoire, fashions is that they are so young looking and hard to wear. True, said M. Cardin, but women need not look like a bunch of leggy colts or overgrown adolescents.
The Waterfront Commission moved last night to smash alleged widespread union-management collusion that had been forcing the employment of union-selected longshore workers.

Seamen sailing from West Coast ports for the Taiwan area will get double pay and bonuses under the terms of a new contract signed with the Pacific Maritime Association, a spokesman for the Seafarers International Union announced yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 17 -Checks and balances provided by a dual system of banks -both Federal and state-chartered -- offer the best safeguards against a monopolization of credit by a few large banking groups, or a probable Federalization of control.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 17 -- Signs of frustration have begun to appear in this community over its inability to fill the void created when the Warren County High School here was shut down.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The British film industry has been hurt by the country's rising standard of living, according to Lord Rank, a leading figure in the motion-picture field here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The United States will presently make available to the United Arab Republic about $5,000,000 in foreign aid, frozen when Egypt nationalized the Universal Suez Canal Company in July, 1956.
PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 17 -- Virginia's Governor and Attorney General drove fifty miles in 95-degree weather today to emphasize their continued faith in "massive resistance" to racial integration.

TORQUAY, England, Sept. 17 -- Members of Britain's Liberal party, wearing an air of somewhat bewildered enthusiasm, pushed their way into Torquay today for the start of a particularly hectic twelve months of British politics.

Shop meetings have been suspended by members of United Scenic Artists, Local 829, and they returned to work yesterday afternoon, pending the outcome of further negotiations for a new contract. The concession was granted at the request of Commissioner J. R. Mandelbaum of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, who is attempting to adjust the wage dispute between the union and the employers, Scenery Suppliers Association.
TEEN-AGERS account for about half of the women now getting married for the first time.

W. . Grace Co., engaged in shipping, trading, manufacturing, chemical; banking, paper and outdoor advertising activities, showed a 5 per cent decline in sales for the first half of this year. Earnings fell 48 per cent below those for the first six months of 1957.

GAME law violations settled in July ran about the usual sorry course except that an unusual number of fishermen from other states traveled considerable distances to help New Yorkers break their own laws.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 -In a special report today on Westchester and Rockland Counties, the State Department of Commerce said that the two-county region was growing twice as rapidly as the state as a whole.
Only one American steamship company is willing to stake at least $4,141,818 on the future of roll-on, roll-off shipping on the high seas.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 17 -Behind-the-scenes negotiations were going on today over the new Lebanese Cabinet, which will take charge next week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Attorney General William P. Rogers challenged tonight the Southern argument that the Supreme Court's school decision might legally be evaded or disobeyed.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 (AP) -A fourth known copy of the first edition printing of the United States Constitution has been discovered in a bundle of badly charred paped in the State Education Building. The Constitution was signed 171 years ago today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) up to 6 points (30 cents a bale) off yesterday.

The International Mining Corporation of New York, formerly the National Department Stores Corporation, announced yesterday the purchase of Waterford Oil Company's 25 per cent interest in 275,000 acres of gas lands in southern Louisiana.
SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The giant bomber plane that crashed in flames near here had broken apart in the air, an Air Force general said today.

"A WORLD OF STRANGERS"* is the second novel by Nadine Gordimer to reach these shores. 'Like an earlier book, "The Lying Days," and the two volumes of short stories that established her American reputation, it suggests that life in her native South Africa today can be a stultifying business for men of goodwill.
Two public housing projects on the lower East Side that had been planned for low-income families will be built instead as middle-income housing.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 17 -- Six citizens obtained a charter today for "The Little Rock Private School Corporation." The group apparently will seek to operate the four high schools here as state-supported, private institutions.
A memorial meeting for Herbert Bayard Swope as a founder of Freedom House was held there last night. Mr. Swope died June 20.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

An end to the serious teacher shortage in the city's public schools was in sight last night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Government reported today that farm income during the first three quarters of this year was 19 per cent above that in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The peaceful legal conflict between the sovereignties of the states and the Federal Government over racial segregation in the public schools by compulsory state laws is being prolonged by the Southern resort to state courts in which Virginia is leading the way.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (UPI) -Gene Green drove in two runs with a homer and a triple to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.

For the second night of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the American Ballet Theatre last night relied entirely upon old favorites for its program. As a matter of course, Anthony Tudor's "Pillar of Fire," with Nora Kaye in the role that no other dancer has ever danced, was its high spot.

"Between Seasons" has been bought by Louis d'Almeida, Milton Greene's associate in the impending presentation of "Far Away the Train-Birds Cry." Asked if the independent offering might indicate a rift, Mr. d'Almeida denied the possibility yesterday, saying his partner did not have full time to devote to the latest acquisition.

Greenwich Villagers seeking to close Washington Square Park to all but emergency and bus traffic plan to gather "hundreds of New Yorkers" to demonstrate at City Hall today. Included, they said yesterday, will be both Democratic and Republican politicians.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 17 -- How does the personality of the psychiatrist affect the recovery of his patient? And how can such an apparent imponderable be measured?
DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- Bob Turley today failed in a bid for his twenty-second mound victory of the season despite a titanic home run by Mickey Mantle.
TOULOUSE, France, Sept. 17 -- Voters in southwestern France are following the constitutional referendum campaign like a mystery fan who has already read the last page of his thriller.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Army announced today the cancellation of its Dart anti-tank-missile program.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, attacked the justices of the United States Supreme Court today. He said they had a "lust for power" that had been delegated to other branches of government.
AFTER many trials and heartbreaks, Ildebrando Pizzetti's new opera, "Assassinio nella Cattedrale," was finally seen by an American audience.

The real estate concern of Ely, Schwier Walthers, Inc., of Sea Girt, N. J., has been reorganized under the new partnership of Thomas C. Ely and Kenneth D. Twynam and is now doing business under the name of Ely Twynam.
Architectural plans have been completed for an office building to be erected in Los Angeles by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., of New York.
By means of a certain crystal ball, railroad analysts believe the outlook for freight traffic in the fourth quarter is fine.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- The Steering Committee of the General Assembly today postponed until tomorrow consideration of the issue of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

PARIS, Sept. 17 -- The five Cardinals of France told French Roman Catholics today that the "painful" absence of any reference to God in the proposed Constitution and its description of the Republic as a secular state were not sufficient reasons for voting against it.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined by 1,610,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 172,891,000 barrels, compared with 174,501,000 a week earlier, and 173,805,000 a year ago.
HUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller said today that he would support Republican candidates for the Legislature and local office despite differences of opinion on some issues.
I have read with interest the article concerning the slow-up of both pedestrian and vehicular traffic due to the anti-jaywalking measures adopted since the first week of August.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Sept. 18 -- The Nationalist Chinese put two supply ships through the curtain of Communist shellfire around beleaguered Quemoy Island yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 16 -- Experts here foresee a conference on an almost world-wide scale as a result of the clash between the European Economic Community, or common market, andI nations that contend this cus- toms union threatens their exports.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. l7 -- Calls for a closer working relationship between governments and news media were made today at the final session of the National Municipal League's four-day annual meeting.

JERICHO, L. I., Sept. 17 -Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., Piping Rock, three-time winner of the tournament, eliminated Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, Cherry Valley, six-time winner, 5 and 4, in the quarter-finals of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today,
