WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 -A new plan for transferring the Westchester parkways to the state for redevelopment and operation is being devised, County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian reported today.

A prediction of fewer large newspapers but more smaller, specialized ones was made yesterday by Edward W. Barrett, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. Dean Barrett gave his views in the September issue of Newsprint Facts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Savings and loan associations granted mortgage loans totaling $1,157,000,000 in July, a monthly record.

In the fiscal year ended on Aug. 2, Artloom Carpet Company reduced its losses, despite lower sales. The deficit was $237,798, compared with $496,594 in the previous fiscal year. Sales for the latest period amounted to $8,294,800, against $9,354,115 a year ago.

EATON, N. H., Sept 17 -Twelve Protestant Episcopalians, concerned over racial tensions, drew up today an appeal to the forthcoming general convention of their church. They called for a statement of continued support of "embattled" clergy and laymen in critical areas.

The tragic deadlock in the Middle East reminds us of the wisdom of the predictions of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, who called for fundamental agrarian reforms in Iraq and Iran as an indispensable condition for the peaceful development of these countries.

Many Northern university professors are severely condemning Southern educators for their pro-segregation activities. Yet some of these very professors and their universities are engaged in similar pro-segregation in their own neighborhoods. Despite their public utterances with reference to racial brotherhood they do not wish their families to live on kindly terms with Negroes.

Cocoa futures opened lower yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Commission house liquidation wakened prices early in the session. Later in the day, short covering, buying by European and trade interests and stop-loss purchasing sent the near-by months soaring.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Government is making financial amends to more than 110,000 persons of Japanese ancestry who suffered losses due to hasty evacuation during World War II.

Twenty thousand homewardbound persons were delayed during last evening's rush hour after a switch failure had developed on the northbound express tracks of the Sixth Avenue IND Subway at Thirtyfourth Street.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 17 -- The Soviet Union was officially reported today to have agreed in principle to the sale of 200,000 tons of rice to Indonesia. The rice would come from Communist China and would be on a long term credit basis.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -Soybeans attracted the most interest today on the Board of Trade. The September contract gained 3 1/8 cents a bushel, the sharpest advance for that commodity in many weeks.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Alfred M. Edelson of New Rochelle, N. Y., said today that he had been expelled from Haiti after being imprisoned and interrogated for twenty hours on suspicion that he planned to assassinate Francois Duvalier, Haitian President.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- A short-range Redstone, the most reliable known ballistic missile in the nation's arsenal, streaked up over the Atlantic today in a successful flight that the Army said would aid development of future missiles.
For fifty years William Huntington worked on the statistical tables of The New York Times. For thirty-three years his son Howard did likewise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A court-appointed board of monitors petitioned today for a stronger hand to deal with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- The American - Marietta Company's sales and net income set high records in the quarter and nine months ended Aug. 31, the company reported today.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers reached a three-year labor agreement today.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 (P) -The Joint Legislative Committee on the Publication and Dissemination of Obscene Material said it would conduct public hearings in November on what it termed "the motion picture problem."

The season has passed for planting herbs outdoors, but it is just about time to start a window box that will provide fresh herbs for the kitchen all winter. Directions for preparing an "indoor living spice box" are included in an informative, well-arranged booklet, "Handbook of Herbs," published by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Don Jordan of Los Angeles, counterpunching deftly, won an upset split decision over Gaspar Ortega in a ten-round welterweight fight tonight. Jordan weighed 141 1/2 pounds, to 145 1/2 for Ortega of Tia Juana, Mexico.

TOKYO, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -The Japanese Government said today it could not prevent the United States from using its bases in Japan to supply troops in the Taiwan area if fighting should break out there.

Among the many matters to be discussed by the United Nations General Assembly, now in session, one of the most important is the projected creation of a permanent United Nations police force. Such a force, organized on a standby basis, has been urged upon the Assembly by President Eisenhower and has been endorsed by Congress. It is finding increasing support within the United Nations itself.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Chief Judge Simon E. Sobeloff of the Fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals refused today to postpone integration in two Charlottesville, Va., public schools.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 -Former President Harry S. Truman charged today that the Eisenhower Administration had deliberately caused the recession to "big business" help undermine unions.
OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Canada conversion loan has been an 88 per cent success.

THE Columbia Broadcasting. System offered last night an interim report on the school integration crisis over Channel 2. The thirty-minute telecast, entitled "Integration: Battle in the Courts," emphasized the legal aspects of the issues between Federal and state authorities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- A Miami insurance agency executive denied today that there was any connection between insurance profits and the vote of former Federal Communications Commissioner Richard A. Mack in the disputed Miami Channel 10 television case.

Governor Harriman announced last night that he had asked Francis W. H. Adams, a former Police Commissioner, to become District Attorney of New York County if Frank S. Hogan were elected to the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to interfere with suspension of freight forwarder volume rates between the East and West. The commission affirmed an order of its Board of Suspension which suspended the operation of forwarder volume rates from Aug. 13 to March 14, 1959.
Morgan Stanley Co. and associates are offering today $200,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent Standard Oil Company (Indiana) debentures due in 1983 and priced at 99 to yield 4.57 per cent.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 -- The expected shifts in the management of National Theaters, Inc., were announced today after a meeting here of the board of directors.

With the Federal Government expecting a record peacetime budgetary deficit of $12,200,000,000 in the current fiscal year, and with the national debt estimated to climb in the next nine months to a record $284,000,000,000, it would seem reasonable to hope that the American Automobile Association might show a little realism on the question of higher gasoline taxes to pay for the gigantic highway construction program.
Mail orders, and mail orders only, will be accepted immediately by the New York Yankees for tickets for the world series games at the Yankee Stadium.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) -The Army displayed tonight a Jupiter missile nose cone the size of an automobile, scarred by a 1,500-mile flight through air and space to a mid-Atlantic target last May.

ROME, Sept. 17 -- In a message broadcast today to Roman Catholic pilgrims in Lourdes, Pope Pius XII expressed the certainty that "the restoration of the kingdom of Christ through Mary cannot fail to be brought about."
BROADWAY has begun a new season with a cheerful, machine-stitched comedy entitled "Howie," which opened at the Forty-Sixth Street Theatre last evening.

PARIS, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- A message of tribute from President Eisenhower was read tonight at a dinner given for Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery by brother officers on his retirement as Deputy Supreme Commander of Allied Powers in Europe.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 -The Federal grant will be used by Westchester County to help pay for a $15,000,000 sewage system, including a $10,500,000 treatment plant at the Hudson River in South Yonkers. The system serves the western part of the county.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 17 -- The Vanguard satellite rocket the Navy tried unsuccessfully to launch yesterday came within a thousandth of a second of destruction.

Oregon sold $20,000,000 of veterans welfare bonds yesterday to an investment banking group headed by Halsey Stuart Co., Inc.; Smith, Barney Co., C. J. Devine Co. and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. The .bonds fall due from 1963 to 1972.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 17 -- The Democratic National Chairman sought today President Eisenhower's condemnation of Joseph P. Kamp "and his scurrilous writings."
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Bill Hartack, threetime national riding champion, scored the 2,000th victory of his career in the fifth race here today.

The metropolitan open golf championship isn't what it used to be, but it is doing well as a rejuvenated event, Some thirty years ago, it ranked close to the national open in the matter of prestige for the winner. Then after an eight-year lapse, it was revived by a group of ardent officials in 1949.

The annual ball of the Polish Immigration Committee will take place Saturday in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Proceeds of the event will aid in resettling and rehabilitating Polish war victims and new refugees from many European countries.
RUMSON, AT. J., Sept. 17 -Four boys whose father is missing in the Jersey Central Railroad disaster lost their mother last night. Ill of cancer, she died soon after hearing the news of her husband.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -High Administration officials conferred today on a White House staff reorganization to follow the resignation of Sherman Adams as No. 1 Presidential assistant.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- The Secretary General's report to the eighty-one member General Assembly on his recent Middle East negotiations will be made sometime after Sept. 24, a United Nations official said today.
Strong endorsement has been given by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards to a proposal that real estate salesmen serve a five-year apprenticeship before applying for a broker's license.
Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that he had been reliably informed the Democrat were going to "whip hell out of the Republicans" in the fall election, especially in New York State.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that the Russians probably would be forced to resume nuclear weapons tests. It declared "the Western powers are simply forcing the Soviet Union to take back its word."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Milton (Babe) Lichardus, a 30-year-old professional from Grossinger, N. Y., was the only player to break par today as the forty-third metropolitan open golf championship began at the Metropolis Country Club.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Chris Crawford of Piedmont, Calif., who trounced Ashley Cooper of Australia yesterday, continued his victory march today in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.
CAIRO, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The Algerian National Liberation Front hinted tonight that it might declare itself the government of a free Algeria tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- Secretary of State Dulles will tell the General Assembly tomorrow that debate on the Taiwan and QuemoyMatsu dispute should be postponed pending the outcome of negotiations in Warsaw between the United States and Communist China.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 17 -- When Columbia sails forth Saturday to meet the America's Cup challenge of Britain's Sceptre, she will have the same crew that put her in yachting's world series.

Sir Leslie Knox Munro leaves the United Nations and the diplomatic corps in Washington at the height of his fame and usefulness. His term as president of the U. N. General Assembly ended on Tuesday and he has resigned as New Zealand's Ambassador to the United States.
New Jersey industry is failing to do its share to lessen water pollution in New York Harbor, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, this city's Commissioner of Public Works, charged yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Three Arab nations were reported today to have accepted a plan to establish a "United Nations presence" in the Middle East.

An attempt to improve methods of handling food in Puerto Rico has been undertaken by Associated Food Stores, Inc., of Jamaica, Queens; and Puerto Rico's Economic Development Administration, it was announced yesterday.
This summer there has not been a rumble or a youth homicide involving any of the 120 teen-age gangs with which the city's Youth Board works, Mayor Wagner reported last night.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 -- The convention of the United Steelworkers of America rejected overwhelmingly today an insurgent faction's plea that union organizers be elected, not appointed.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today told the Federal Government to give two tractors back to a farmer who had been penalized for growing too much wheat.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 17 -- Federal District Judge Albert V. Bryan today ordered four Negro children admitted to the seventh grade at all-white Stratford Junior High School in Arlington County. But he postponed the effective date of the order until the beginning of the next school semester in January.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- The United States and British delegations, observing diplomatic amenities to be sure, will be wishing each other ill luck next Saturday at an international event not included in the United Nations agenda.

A three-for-one split of common stock of Prentice-Hall, Inc., publishing concern, was approved yesterday by the directors. The proposal, which must be approved by stockholders, would change the par value of the stock from $2.50 to $1.
The nation's railroads rolled up their second-best passenger safety record in history last year, James G. Lyne, chairman of the E. H. Harriman Memorial Awards, announced last night.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Harry Chiti stole the spotlight from the American League's three leading hitters with a grand-slam homer as the Boston Red Sox and Kansas City split a double-header today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The State Department maintained today its refusal to discuss its negotiations on the future of the five United States bases in Morocco.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld deplored yesterday the "shocking" attacks by judges of high courts who "have joined in the pack" in criticizing recent decisions of the Supreme Court.
The appointment of Frank Schiff as chairman of the New York City United Service Organizations Committee was announced yesterday.

Bertha 2d, the only live whale to be exhibited here since 1897, is dead because, like many females, she deceived men about her age. The pride of the Aquarium had led exhibitors to think she was a yearling. It became known yesterday after her death that she was just a calf.
The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will benefit from the world premiere of "The Roots of Heaven" on Oct. 15 at the Palace Theatre.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells, the defender, lost on the nineteenth hole today to Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge in the thirty-third annual Women's New Jersey match-play golf championship.
Can a golf ball remain suspended in a glass of water? It can if Carbopol is present.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 17 -Franz Josef Strauss, Minister of Defense, was rebuffed again today in his campaign to drive a traffic policeman off his strongpoint in front of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's offices.
Stocks extended their gains early yesterday but the list ran into persistent profit taking in the last hour or so and close down.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- There were further sharp rises in almost all sections of the stock market at the outset today, but activity tended to slacken and some prices closed below their day's best.
The first of four one-hour "preview" concerts by the New York Philharmonic will be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Sunday, Nov. 30, at 5 P. M.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, yesterday struck at critics who hold that labor leaders are too interested in international affairs.

Gene C. Brewer was elected president of the United States Plywood Corporation at a meeting of the directors here yesterday. He succeeds S. W. Antoville, president since 1953. Mr. Antoville was elected chairman and chief executive officer.

"Antarctic Assault," an account of modern exploration by Comdr. Paul W. Frazier, U. S. N., will be published Monday by Dodd, Mead. This personal story begins in 1947 with Operation Windmill to establish ground control points. It continues through Operations Deep Freeze I and II to the planning of Operation Deep Freeze III in 1957, when the scientists were already at work.

Electric power production last week rose to 12,248,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,025,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Sept. 14, 1957, the output was 11,947,000,000 kilowatt hours.

Underwriters led by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., are offering today to the public 1,200,000 common shares, 1 (South African) nominal value, of American-South African Investment Company, Ltd., at $28 a share.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Business circles here welcomed the announcement made in Montreal. A spokesman for the National Union of Manufacturers said:

Patience on the part of Trainer Johnny Nerud enabled him to send out the winner of the $29,200 Nassau County Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The winner was the 5-year-old horse named Eddie Schmidt, who campaigns in the silks of Leroy Burns.
HAVANA, Sept. 17 -- Fidel Castro, Cuban rebel leader, was reported today to have begun his announced offensive against Government troops.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -Fred Hutchinson today was dropped as manager of the sagging St. Louis Cardinals. His dismissal confirmed reports rampant for two weeks that he was through.
A group of investors has purchased the property of Lane's department store on the east side of Fifth Avenue between Thirteenth and Fourteenth Streets.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- Komsomolskaya Pravda, the Young Communist newspaper, today "exposed" Mark Bernes, a crooner and Soviet movie hero, as a "hooligan" who menaced pedestrians while driving an automobile.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A new device with which the blind can read print and typewritten letters was demonstrated today at the National Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Manufacturers sales and profits rose in volume in the second quarter of the year for the first time since late 1956, according to a report by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission. The greatest improvements occurred among the smaller companies, the report said.

WHEN the New York Football Giants named Phil King of Vanderbilt as their No. 1 draft choice, they were a mite puzzled as to where they would play him. Not only did he lead the Commodores in ground-gaining and pass-catching, but he also was their leading defender with most tackles and most interceptions. King was puzzled, too. So he sought advice of Herb Rich, the ex-Giant.

A SMALL, inexpensive and worth-while book on wine and food is now available to the public at many of the nation's newsstands and book counters. Titled "The Art of French Cooking" (Bantam), its retail price is 35 cents; for many home cooks, it may prove worth its weight in louis d'or.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The International Brotherhood of Teamster, several of its locals and a group of transportation companies have been named defendants in a $605,454 damage suit filed in Federal District Court here.
Christmas spirits programs were disclosed yesterday by two major distillers, Hiram Walker, Inc., and Schenley Industries, Inc.

One of the reasons man isn't farther along than he is lies in the very instrument that has brought him as far as he is -- the brain. It's a great instrument in some ways: it has excellent storage facilities for information (room for 10 billion items, according to one scientific estimate), a good filing system and it is open for business every day including Sundays and holidays.

The carnival of beef, better known as the professional wrestling circus, took over Madison Square Garden last night. Perhaps due to the rainy weather or the midweek date, there was no sellout crowd as in most of the previous shows, which were staged on Saturday nights.

ORIENT POINT, L. I., Sept. 17 -- The appearance of thirteen Wood Ibises has been reported here. It is the third recorded visit of the stork-like, blackand-white birds on Long Island in sixty-eight years.
Two films will open at first-run theatres this morning. The programs follow:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17 -- John Usher Monro was named today as Dean of Harvard College effective Dec. 1.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17 -- Britain opened her doors a little wider today to dollar imports. Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade, said the doors would be flung wide open later on, when the danger of a drain on the pound was less acute.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 17 -- No one has been paying Maryland much mind this year. The North Carolina Tar Heels, the Clemson Tigers and the Duke Blue Devils have caught most of the fancy in the Atlantic Coast Conference.

ROCKLEIGH, N. J., Sept. 17 -- An abrupt rise in the population of this little borough in the northeastern corner of Bergen County occurred this afternoon. Forty-two boys from St. Joseph's School in Englewood Cliff became the first residents at St. Joseph's Village.

A WOMAN in her middle fifties who has sung thousands of concerts and traveled millions of miles might well consider sitting quietly and letting the world pass by. But not Marian Anderson, the celebrated Negro contralto, who finds herself in a small office at 2 Park Avenue as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- House investigators said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission seemed to be "dragging its feet" in its investigation of Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- Widespread reports of a free-for-all among the Yankees caught up with the club today as the American League champions headed east for a day off in New York.

The appointments of Robert A. Bivins and Norwell F. Burgess as vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank were announced yesterday by George Champion, president. Both were formerly assistant vice presidents at the head office, 18 Pine Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 -- Following is the text of a resolution adopted today by the United Steelworkers of America calling for the expulsion of rebel leaders:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 18 (Reuters) -- Eugene O'Neill's one-act play "Hughie," given by the American playwright's widow to the Royal Dramatic Theatre here, had its world premiere tonight before an audience that included King Gustaf Adolf and Queen Louise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Quemoy campaign has passed its first crisis but the future of the offshore islands is still dim.
NEWARK, Sept. 18 -- New Jersey's application for a permanent injunction against the abandonment of ferry service by the New York Central and Erie Railroads will be heard Nov. 3.
MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 18 -- The police charged three youths today with setting fire to the South Orange-Maplewood Junior High School Feb. 2. The fire caused $160,000 damage to the school.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Albert V. Bryan granted today a motion by twenty-nine oil companies under indictment on charges of price-fixing to move their trial to Tulsa, Okla.

ATHENS, Sept. 18 -- The fate of national parks, wildernesses and refuges has been the most important topic discussed privately here at the congress of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources.

Holders of common stock in Tropical Gas Company, Inc., are being offered rights to subscribe for 25,674 shares of 6 per cent convertible $100 par preferred stock at par on the basis of one preferred share for each twenty-seven common shares held of record of Sept. 9.

IF the American Ballet Theatre does nothing else during its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, it will have put us in its debt by its presentation last night of Birgit Cullberg's ballet "Miss Julie." It is one of the most distinguished ballets in the contemporary European theatre, and Miss Cullberg is by the same token one of the most distinguished choreographers.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday made a hand-shaking tour in downtown Brooklyn.

For several weeks past persons interested in the Middle East have been puzzled by the phrase "U. N. presence," which cropped up at about the time of the special session of the General Assembly in August and which has reappeared occasionally during and since Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's recent trip to the Middle East.
SOME loud and not necessarily temperate argument on the subject of deer conservation is likely to be heard at 8:30 P. M. on Oct. 14 in the State of New Jersey.
A woman strolling in the southeast Bronx was shot last night in what the police described as a teen-aged gang fight.
The longshore industry's joint union-management labor relations committee held an emergency session last night to consider problems growing out of a Waterfront Commission drive on forced hiring.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- The Soviet bloc got the jump on the United States today with a request to the General Assembly that 1960 be designated as International Public Health and Medical Research Year.
The Board of Estimate has set next Friday for a public hearing on the Brooklyn approach to the proposed Narrows Bridge.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Secretary of State Dulles expressed the hope today that negotiations between the United States and Communist China would lead to a cease-fire in the Quemoy and Matsu area.
WARSAW, Sept. 18 -- Communist China's formal answer to the United States proposals for a cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait is expected to be delivered here Sunday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Sept. 19 -- Nationalist China will support a discussion of the Taiwan Strait crisis in the United Nations only in connection with a charge against the Soviet Union of aggression through aid to the Chinese Communists, Dr. Kiang Yi-shen, Nationalist Foreign Ministry spokesman, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The auto labor settlement reached in Detroit yesterday was widely viewed here today as the least costly for the companies since World War II.

The decision by the Board of Hospitals, accepted by the Commissioner of Hospitals, to lift the prohibition against birth control therapy in New York's municipal hospitals is a satisfyingly right decision. It sustains the freedom to practice medicine. It is scrupulously tolerant of the religious beliefs of those who oppose birth control as immoral, but it does not impose the effect of such beliefs upon those who do not agree with them.
THE voice of French fashion said yesterday that its future was brighter than ever.
WARSAW, Sept. 18 -- Poland, which says it has the highest traffic accident rate in the world, tried hard today to have one day, just one day, without a smashup.
CAIRO, Sept. 18 -- Al Shaab, a Cairo newspaper, reported today that Ferhat Abbas would be named Premier of Algeria in a rebel government in exile to be established tomorrow.
HOUSTON, Tex., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Federal authorities charged two Texans today with violating copyright laws by reproducing oil survey maps valued at $7,000,000.

The Thermometer Corporation of America of Springfield, Ohio, has completed arrangements to purchase the Springfield Metallic Casket Company, Inc., according to Henry C. Greene, president of Thermometer.

JERICHO, L. I. Sept. 18 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood, the 1955 champion, defeated Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock a three-time winner, 2 up, in the semi-finals of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's match-play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WALTER Lacey Pate knows more about tennis balls than perhaps any man in town. He weighs and measures them; he bounces them, squeezes them and drops them from heights; he cuts them open and inspects them. In short, he tests tennis balls.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 18 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus declared tonight that a private school system appeared "to be the only answer to the Federal Government's order to integrate at any price."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18 -- Eddie Erdelatz takes a skeptical, if not dim, view of the high appraisal put on the Navy football team. The coach of the Crab-town Tars finds it easy to lift an eyebrow askance in a clinical discussion of his team, though no one is more fun-loving when the inquisition ends.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Sept. 19 -- Chinese Nationalist fighter planes shot down five Communist MIG-17's and sank three Communist torpedo boats in Taiwan Strait yesterday afternoon, according to a communique here.

A Federal law designed to restore the confidence of prospective new-car buyers in pricing procedure will go into effect today. It becomes effective with the placing on the market of the new Buicks, the first 1959 models to go on sale.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 -- The commander of Lebanon's southern defenses was under close arrest in his home today on charges of plotting against the Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- George T. Baker, president of National Airlines, charged today that Senator George D. Smathers, Democrat of Florida had lied to the Harris subcommittee last spring.
The Cities Service Company sought yesterday to divest itself of the Arkansas Fuel Oil Corporation under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18 -- Residents of this town's "back country" area joined battle last night with the United Aircraft Corporation over its plan to establish an industrial plant in their midst.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Herb Elliott, the fastest miler in the world, tonight denied a promoter's claim he was ready to turn professional.
The Israel Bond Organization opened a campaign yesterday to sell $50,000,000 in bonds by the end of this year:
A group managed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. was awarded issues totaling $30,000,000 of Ohio major thoroughface revenue bonds.
The Seventh-Day Adventists have purchased the two-story commercial structure at 1416 Boston Road, the Bronx from David E. Levy for $27,500. Ernest E. Carolee was the broker in the transaction.
A group of Yale students returned yesterday from the Soviet Union, where they held a series of street-corner meetings.

The editorial "Gaps in Health Insurance" in The New York Times for Sept. 15 is very interesting. And the news item "22.3 Per Cent Blue Cross Rise Will Take Effect Today" in interesting -- in a painful way.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said last night that Revlon, Inc., New York City cosmetics manufacturer, had denied charges of restraining trade through illegal agreements with seven other concerns.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 18 (UPI) -- The Eastman Kodak Company announced today the awarding of sixty-one grants and thirty-nine fellowships as part of its aid-to-education program. This year's benefits amounted to more than $600,000.
Cotton futures declined 3 to 20 points yesterday, with July contracts the weakest. The drop equaled 15 cents to $1 a bale.

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States rose $9,731,000 in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $1,858,000 in July and a rise of $227,286,000 in August, 1957.

A set of keys to the home rented by the late Dr. Melvin A. Nimer had been at the United States Public Health Service Hospital before his murder, the police said yesterday. The owner of the house at 242 Vanderbilt Avenue, Clifton, S. I., had left the keys, the police said.

YONKERS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Belle Acton, one of the greatest mares in harness racing history, scored a thrilling nose victory over Gold Worthy in the $10,000 Merkel free-for-all handicap pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The time for the mile was 2:01 1/5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, was advised by top industrialists today that the nation's business recovery appeared to be general, strong and capable of continuing into 1959.
ROSLYN, L. I., Sept. 18 -- A $2,825,000 construction program for the Roslyn School District was recommended today to meet the needs of this growing community.

Nearly every New Yorker and most of the city's visitors know that "North River" is another name for the Hudson. But it usually takes yachtsman or other student of American history to learn that "South River" once was the name applied to the Delaware River.
A Unitarian church in New York has acquired a portion of the Dead Sea Scrolls containing what is believed to be the earliest copy of the Ten Commandments in Hebrew.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Union workers at the General Electric Company's main plant have voted 5,561 to 4,746 against striking next month.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Del Flanagan of St. Paul gained a unanimous decision over Virgil Akins, the world welterweight champion, in a bitter ten-round non-title bout tonight. Flanagan weighed 149 3/4 pounds and Akins 148.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield urged 2,500 United States postmasters today to work for "next-day mail service anywhere in America."

It is indeed gratifying to note that Governor Harriman has pledged that no residency requirements would be imposed upon people seeking relief as long as he is in office. This follows upon the equally gratifying deletion of a suggested residence requirement plank from the Republican state platform.

A BRIDE or any one else who wants to cook but cannot cook probably has a lack of self confidence. That, at least, is the well-considered opinion of James A. Beard, whose cooking school will open for its autumn session on Sept. 30.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 18 -- President Eisenhower's daily round of golf ended abruptly in a heavy rain today.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 18 -- An American vice consul was seriously wounded by gunmen this afternoon in a new outbreak of terror on Cyprus.

A Jersey Central railroad executive revealed yesterday that some portions of the railroad had been equipped since 1925 with devices that -- if functioning correctly -- would automatically prevent such accidents as the Newark Bay disaster.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) House Investigators passed up any study today of last year's spectacular proxy battle involving control of the Penn-Texas Corporation and Fairbanks, Morse Co.
New York was host to between four and five million summer visitors this year, Joseph P. Binns said yesterday in reporting on the success of the 1958 campaign, New York Is a Summer Festival.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Government is expected to announce new curbs on the importation of lead and zinc that may set a precedent in trade policy.

The New York Knickerbockers yesterday released their 1958-59 National Basketball Association home schedule The local quintet, coached by Fuzzy Levane, will play twenty-seven games, five more than last season, at Madison Square Garden.

Price cuts in heavy fuel oil ranging up to 36 cents a barrel were made yesterday by the Esso Standard Oil Company along the Atlantic Seaboard from Charleston, S. C., to Maine. The company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), ascribed the cut to ample supplies and slackened demand which it said had led to price cutting.

Local 50 of the American Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union broke off negotiations yesterday with five major producers of packaged bread in the New York metropolitan area and threatened to strike next Thursday at midnight.
UNFORTUNATELY, this column cannot report on the story-line of the last act of "The Young Provincials," which opened last evening at the Cricket, Second Avenue at Tenth Street.
Three new films open at first-run theatres today.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will collect blood today at Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L. I., and at the Veterans Administration, 252 Seventh Avenue.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A gynecologist said yesterday that a 50-cent pill to prevent pregnancy had proved 100 percent effective in a two-and-one-half-year test.
MONTREAL, Sept. 18 -- Canada is prepared to consider seriously the establishment of a world food bank, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The world price of tin dropped more than 12 per cent today, when the international support system collapsed. Trading in tin was suspended for several hours on the London Metal Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The White House has a mystery on its hands -- whatever happened to that Harding china ?

The island of Cuba has been enveloped for many months in a "fog of war," thanks to the complete censorship that President Batista has imposed. Even when things happen like the rebel offensive now under way one has to learn of it indirectly, without details and without any means of gauging its real importance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Japan has told the International Monetary Fund that she intends to repay by the end of 1958, the $125,000,000 drawn last year.
In an effort to speed the construction of off-street parking facilities in midtown, the Board of Estimate approved a $95,000 fee yesterday for the services of a consulting engineer.
The M. W. Kellogg Company announced yesterday that it had been appointed exclusive sales and licensing agent for a new process, developed in Mexico, for producing sponge iron directly from iron ore.

AT 10 A. M. Monday, a small but stunning parade will take place on one block of Fifth Avenue. A contingent of Scots Guards Pipers, in full dress and with bagpipes skirling, will march from Thirty-ninth to Thirty-eighth Street, wheel around and enter the doors of Lord Taylor.

Cocoa futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The decline more than wiped out Wednesday's gains. There was selling prior to the issuance of the first Ghana crop estimate, which is expected soon. One notice was issued and it circulated most of the day.
A $6,000,000 answer to the question of what airlines will do with obsolescent but still serviceable aircraft as the jets replace them was provided here yesterday.
" I WILL tell you about Wang Ping-nan," said the foreign diplomat in Warsaw. "He is very Chinese."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 665,999 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
" One heads east an one heads west, Though ever the same wind blows; For it's not the gale, but the set of the sail That determines the way she goes."
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Walter E. Hoffman issued an order today that in effect upheld a Federal court decision calling for integration of Norfolk schools.

MOTION pictures provide the greatest and most continuous fashion show in the world. The man who makes this pronouncement has the sweet sound of success in his voice. He is Charles LeMaire, executive designer for Twentieth Century-Fox in Hollywood and chief coordinator of every phase of its vast wardrobe department.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Victor Boushouyev, 25-year-old Russian electrician, today won the world lightweight weight - lifting championship with a record performance.
HAVANA, Sept. 18 -- The Cuban Government has increased its military operations as Fidel Castro's rebels have launched their announced offensive in the eastern end of the island.

KITZBUEHEL. Austria, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Most of the scientists from twenty-one countries from both sides of the Iron Curtain meeting here believe that there can be no effective international control of nuclear weapons, according to reliable reports emerging today from their closed sessions.
The attorney for a group of Negro parents who have been boycotting public schools in Harlem has requested a meeting with Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.
PARIS, Sept. 18 -- French officials sought today to minimize the importance of the projected formation of an Algerian rebel government in exile.
DETROIT, Sept. 18 -- The United Automobile Workers turned its attention to the General Motors and Chrysler Corporations today.
Fire Lieut. Thomas J. O'Leary produced visible proof yesterday that the $1,172-a-year pay rise accompanying his promotion to captain was most welcome.
A steel unit weighing more than forty tons was gently lowered 100 feet below street level yesterday in a downtown Manhattan excavation.
CHARLESTON, Ill, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- The Civil War might have been prevented had Stephen A. Douglas been nominated and elected President in 1856, Senator Paul H. Douglas said today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Vic Seixas and Ham Richardson gained the semi-finals of the Pacific Southwest tennis championships today.

Average member bank reserves showed little change in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. At $124,000,000, net free reserves -- excess reserves less borrowings -- were down $17,000,000 from a revised figure of $141,000,000 for the week before.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Dr. Fred L. Whipple, director of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Laboratories, said today he had been given a "run-a-round" in the Soviet Union when he tried to get a look at satellite computing centers or equipment.
An electronic aerial road map is being tested in the cockpits of New York Airways helicopters.

Major reassignments in the top management of the Continental Can Company have been announced by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman and chief executive officer. The company is a leading producer of metal, glass and paper packaging materials.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Robert A. (Bobby) Mosbacher captured the seventh men's North American sailing championship today. The victor, a former Long Island Sound sailor, now represents the Texas Corinthian Y.C. at Kemah, Tex.
DALLAS, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Two Texas pilots set a record for continuous flight by a light plane today. They planned to stay aloft three more days.

ROME, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating of Rochester, Republican candidate for Senator, ridiculed former President Harry S. Truman's campaign statements today. Mr. Truman recently spoke in support of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York, Mr. Keating's Democratic opponent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Democratic and Republican National Committees spent more than $200,000 each during the three months ended Aug. 31.
The current golden boy of popular music, Domenico Modugno, made his American concert debut last night at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, ruled today that teamsters union officials, even with credentials from other unions, were barred from holding office in A. F. L.-C. I. O state and city organizations.

NO self-respecting expert would dare debark for Newport and the America's Cup races without making careful preparations. He will stow in his duffel bag such gear as a sou'wester, sea boots, hardtack, a pannikin of grog, a copy of Moby Dick, water wings and pills for seasickness.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- Following is the text of the address by Secretary of State Dulles and of excerpts form the speech by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, before the General Assembly today:
Greenwich Village residents who have been battling the proposal to run two lanes of traffic through Washington Square Park scored heavily yesterday.
Performances of "A Swim in the Sea" on Oct. 28 and Nov. 4 will benefit the Hamilton-Madison House. The new Jess Gregg play starring Fay Bainter is scheduled to open at the Lyceum Theatre on Sept. 30.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The stock market moved firmly ahead on a wide front today. Trading was brisk and the mood buoyant, and there was a steady stream of investment buying for both Government issues and industrials.
Three agencies in France concerned with cultural ties with the United States will benefit from the performances of French plays here.

TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- American motorists will soon be confronted by a network of new interstate freeways that will bear new numbers even though they are meant to be relocations of existing United States routes.

L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, accused Governor Harriman yesterday of "hypothetical hogwash" in announcing a possible successor to Frank S. Hogan as District Attorney of New York County.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The end of railroad passenger service by 1970 was predicted today by an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner.
THIRTY years ago, a young Southern decorator drawled his way into the decorating department of W J Sloane. Last Monday, still drawling, he became the store's vice president.

Everybody seems to be interested exclusively in the political and strategic problems involved in our pledge to defend Formosa. There is more at stake, however, than the security of this far-away island.
A forceful, comprehensive report on the situation in Quemoy and Taiwan was televised last night by the National Broadcasting Company.

Robert Webb, independent producer, has purchased "Meeting at the Summit," an original screen play by Joseph Petraca. The story line is somewhat unusual for these days, for the producer's representatives report Soviet Russia is depicted in a more favorable light than might be expected.
Increased services to help the blind be self-supporting were described yesterday at the opening of a conference of the New York State Federation of Workers for the Blind.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- International class skippers from Bermuda recaptured the Amorita Cup in races off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

The man whose portrait appears on two new postage stamps today in Washington is one of about a dozen persons not citizens of the United States to be so honored. Until 1957 the formal compliment of a commemorative stamp had been extended to soldiers, statesmen and explorers of other nations whose exploits [were directly related to American history, with two notable, exceptions: Johann Gutenberg and Dr. Sun Yati sen.

There was considerable activity yesterday in the "tel and tel" stocks-American Telephone and Telegraph Company and International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Both made the list of the fifteen most heavily traded issues on the New York Stock Exchange, but for different reasons.
MONTEMOGGIO, Italy, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Four sons and two daughters of Giuseppe Costa were married today in a mass ceremony he arranged to reduce expenses.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The United States has rushed some $90,000,000 worth of military supplies to Taiwan in the three weeks since the Quemoy crisis began.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18, (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The inevitable showdown has now come between Provisional President Hoffa of the Teamsters Union and the Board of Monitors appointed by Federal Judge Letts to oversee the union's reform. Several basic issues are involved which are set forth in a petition to the court from the board -- with the usual teamster representative's dissent.
The president of City College urged yesterday that nonresidents of New York be admitted to its municipal colleges in return for increased state aid.

Opening the debate in the United Nations General Assembly against a background of continued gunfire in the Taiwan Strait, Secretary Dulles has denounced Communist China for its policy of force and called for a cease-fire as the prerequisite to a peaceful settlement. He cited Communist China's present policy as further demonstration that this is not a "peace-loving" government within the meaning of the United Nations Charter, entitled to sit in the United Nations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 -- The convention of the United Steelworkers of America issued orders today to expel the "ringleaders" of a rebel faction that polled nearly a quarter-million votes in the union's election last year.

Two views of the world of television are presented in two first novels to be published shortly. One is "The Hot Half Hour," by Robert L. Foreman, which Criterion Books will publish next Friday. It is a story about the rise and fall of a television quiz show and of the people who rose and fell with it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Air Force disclosed today plans for building a worldwide communications control system for its Strategic Air Command bombers. The total cost may run to about $150,000,000.
Corporate planners need a thick skin, and the courage to disrupt standard company practices, a business executive said here yesterday.

THE party season is on and Tiffany's, not to be left out, has decorated eleven buffet tables that are sure to make entertaining more gala than ever this fall. These party tables, which can be seen on the second and third floors, offer many imaginative ideas that can be duplicated at home.

Music events tonight include a concert by the Manhattan Brass Quintet and the Metropolitan Wind Ensemble under the direction of Lorenz Segall at Theatre East, 211 East Sixtieth Street; a folk-song concert by Pete Seeger and others at Carnegie Hall, and a Dixieland jazz concert at Central Plaza, 111 Second Avenue, all at 8:30 o'clock.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, announced yesterday that the 1959 March of Dimes campaign would seek $65,000,000 to combat arthritis, birth defects and poliomyelitis.

IT'S a long time now since critics arid readers thought that part of the novelist's function was to teach a sound moral lesson. Nevertheless, moral lessons continue to turn up in fiction. They are bound to, because no novelist can conceal his personal point of view, his approval or disapproval of the motives and conduct of his characters.

A study of the effect of strontium 90 on mice has convinced the experimenter that the present fall-out will not produce a case of bone cancer or leukemia. The study was under the auspices of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Miss Bardahl became the boat to beat in the President's Cup regatta this week-end with the announcement today that Maverick, the season's leading hydroplane, would not compete.

A French language course will be presented by the Metropolitan Educational Television Association over station WPIX (Channel 11) beginning Monday. It will be televised from 12:30 to 1 P. M., Mondays through Fridays.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 18 -- Harmonious and hopeful Western Democrats ended a two-day meeting here today with a three-pronged objective.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- Harry S. Truman provided eight hours of intensive whistle-stop treatment today for Governor Harriman, who is seeking re-election, and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who is running for the United States Senate.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six major cities in the nation in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $23,953,422,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Traders were more eager to sell soybean futures on the Board of Trade today than they were to buy them yesterday when all interests were bidding hard for every soybean offering in sight.
FREEPORT, L. I. Sept. 18 -- A 77-year-old man who was pronounced dead today turned out to be very much alive almost two hours later.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Friday, Sept. 19 -- The people of Warren County failed last night to agree on a course of action by which they might get their only high school reopened.
Every important group on the stock market but motors and rails showed a loss at yesterday's close, but the over-as decline was moderate.

Arthur Vining Davis, former chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, announced yesterday that he was placing almost all of his extensive real estate holdings in Florida into a new operating corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An account of offers and counter-offers made in the United States-Communist China talks at Warsaw was broadcast tonight by David Brinkley, National Broadcasting Company news commentator.
Harry Golden has been in the news twice -- once as a stockbroker and once as the author of the current best-seller, "Only in America." Now his earlier career has come back to haunt him.

The crisis over the Formosa Strait brings us once again to the brink of global war. But it also presents us with a challenge to exercise our resourcefulness and imagination by using those institutions which have been created for the purpose of avoiding the very jeopardy in which the world now finds itself.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 18 -- It was dark and rainy in Newport today. But fair weather and southwest breezes in the moderate range are in prospect for Saturday's opening race of the America's Cup series between Columbia and Sceptre.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- A record-equalling 64 sent Bob Watson of Ardsley into the lead for the metropolitan open golf championship today. At the Metropolis Country Club, where Jack Burke Jr., established a competitive course mark in the 1949 tourney, Watson produced his spectacular score in fog and a drizzle.

The Columbia football team ran through a defensive drill against Brown University's passing and running attack yesterday afternoon in the Lions' first workout at Baker Field. The Light Blue eleven had been training at Camp Columbia in Lakeside, Conn.
Garvin, Bantel Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was under investigation by the board of governors of the exchange last night. The inquiry was held after the close of trading yesterday.

American Export Lines is attempting to find out whether Great Lakes ports offer a sufficient traffic potential to warrant a four-ship service during the St. Lawrence Seaway navigation season. This was disclosed yesterday by Frazer A. Bailey, managing director of the company.

TORQUAY, England, Sept. 18 -- England, a young speaker said, must "teach the nations how to live." This quotation from John Milton's "Doctrine and Discipline of Divorce" and the sharp burst of applause that followed it told a good deal about the Liberal party.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 18 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is ready to start tomorrow what could be the nation's last atomic bomb tests.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- A report of a division in the Yugoslav Communist party over its relations with the Soviet Government has been brought to the West by an English journalist who is widely considered an authority on Eastern European politics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, announced today that House investigators would hold public sessions next week in their inquiry into the award of a television channel in Pittsburgh.
A man who fell or jumped to his death in front of a BMT subway train in Queens and a derailment on the IRT Pelham Bay line in the Bronx disrupted travel yesterday for thousands of riders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service said today that tests in nine key areas had shown that the presence of radioactivity in milk was well within recommended safety levels.

A three-year contract was signed here yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute and the Radio Officers Union. The contract, which goes into effect Oct. 1, replaces a three-year pact expiring on that date.
The decision of the Board of Hospitals to institute a program of contraceptive therapy in municipal hospitals was widely praised yesterday.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 18 -- An Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile, the first scheduled to travel its full range of 6,325 statute miles, blew up eighty seconds after take-off today.

Just short of a year ago, George D. Widener's Jester won the Futurity Stakes at Belmont Park. Yesterday at the same place, the son of Tom Fool won again, but his victory did not occur in any monumental competition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Leaders of the teamsters plan to seek the removal of Godfrey P. Schmidt as a monitor of the union on a charge of conflict of interest.

The City Housing Authority has abandoned one of two low-rent projects planned for the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. William Reid, chairman of the authority, said yesterday that the decision had been made in deference to Orthodox Jewish groups who opposed additional public housing in the area.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 18 -- The Governor of Virginia challenged the Eisenhower Administration today to seek a constitutional amendment to settle the school segregation issue.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Cultural exchanges between the Soviet Union and the United States are helping crumble the barriers of fear, Soviet Ambassador Mikhail Menshikov said today.

The Real Estate Board of New York will sponsor eight lectures between Oct. 6 and Dec. 8 on "How to Apply Your Know-How." The series will be conducted on Monday evening at 5:15 o'clock in the Commodore Hotel.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Shadow Wave, who did not race as a 2-year-old, flashed a pair of 2:01 miles today to capture the country's No. 1 event for 3-year-old pacers, the Little Brown Jug.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange receded somewhat in the month ended Monday. A short interest results when speculators sell borrowed stock in the expectation of repurchasing it at a lower price. The Big Board announced yesterday that the short interest at the close on Sept. 15 was 5,646,414 shares, or one-tenth of 1 per cent of all shares listed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18 -- After five years of privacy, the United Nations has opened its formal gardens to the public.

When measured in terms of the original demands of Mr. Reuther the concessions made to the auto workers by the Ford Company are comparatively modest. LONDON, Sept. 18 -- "The Heart's a Wonder," a musical version of John Millington Synge's "Playboy of the Western World" opened at the West-minister Theatre tonight. The audience received it warmly.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 18 -- Negotiations to put teeth into Bolivia's economic stabilization plan were reported progressing satisfactorily today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 18 -- Dissident factions within two locals of the Petroleum Workers Union won elections last night for control of the locals. The winning groups are considered to the left of the leadership they replaced.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The Soviet Embassy has delivered to the Foreign Office a photo copy of another document purporting to be an anonymous letter from a United States airman threatening to drop nuclear bombs on the Soviet Union and Poland.
Directors of the Fruehauf Trailer Company have elected Roy Fruehauf as chairman and chief executive officer. William E. Grace succeeds him as president and chief operating officer.

It is clear from present developments that the attempt of the Supreme Court to change the national mores by a sociological interpretation of the Constitution is fraught with disaster. Generations will not allay the strife or heal the wounds caused by the court's action.
ROME, Sept. 18 -- Immediate plans to link the United States and Italy by jet airliner have run into trouble.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation in its fiscal year ended July 31, according to the results disclosed yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Several of the top roles in "The Wonderful Country," the film version of Tom Lea's novel of life in the post-Civil War Southwestern frontier, have been filled.

Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., producers of typewriters, cash registers and office equipment, is expanding its foreign operations with the purchase of the Hamann division of the German Telephone Works and Cable Industry, Inc.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Military leaders of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) ended a three-day conference today with agreement on strengthening existing plans for defense of the treaty area in the light of the Taiwan Strait crisis.
" The Disenchanted," the Budd Schulberg-Harvey Breit collaboration, based on Mr. Schulberg's popular novel, has found a co-sponsor and is now moving full speed ahead.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 18 -- Today is the tenth anniversary of a bloody event that President Sukarno then termed a "national tragedy." It was the rising by Indonesia's Communists against the President and nation in armed revolt, a revolt that failed.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The Norwalk Housing Authority is seeking a ninety-unit housing project for older people. The project would cost $800,000.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks rose $202,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase was ascribed chiefly to borrowings for tax payments due last Monday.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored a 9-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight with a thirteen-hit attack.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The $80 billion plus appropriated for Government spending by the Eighty-fifth Congress has renewed calls for reform of the legislative fiscal system as well as for "economy." Former President Truman, using the figure to deride Republican claims that huge Federal budgets are exclusively Democratic products, was the latest personage to cite this figure and view it with alarm.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 18 -- Negro and white students in Little Rock will be hearing the same teachers beginning on Monday -- but they will be hearing them in their homes, while watching television.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 18 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. announced today the closing of two schools at Charlottesville in accordance with Virginia's anti-integration laws.

The Texas Railroad Commission has ordered the state's producing oil wells to go on an eleven-day production basis in October. The order, announced yesterday, fixes the state's allowable production next month at 2,957,936 barrels a day. The September schedule is twelve days.
Sales and earnings of the United States Shoe Company in the nine months ended Aug. 31 gained from the level in the corresponding period last year, the company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- A former Republican Governor of Kansas urged today defeat of candidates of either party who favored right-to-work laws.

The meeeting on Sept. 14 in Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises between General de Gaulle and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer raises for the first time since the end of World War II real hopes for the future of Europe.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Parents arranged tonight with the approval of the local government to reopen schools next week by holding classes in private homes, lodge halls and churches.

THE big deal in pheasant dog trials will open at the New York State Three Rivers Game Management Area, near Syracuse, on Oct. 2 and continue through Oct. 15. This is the one that separates the small-trial flashes from the champions.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 19 -- Atomic Energy Commission scientists racing a diplomatic deadline fired the first of a new series of experimental nuclear explosions at the commission's desert test reservation today.
Car buyers and dealers met on more equitable ground yesterday as the new "truth-in-labeling" Federal price law went into effect.
Prices of cotton futures advanced 4 to 10 points yesterday, in slack trading. The rise equaled 20 cents to 50 cents a bale.

The appointments of Ralph P. Schaberg and Frederick W. Lohm as vice presidents of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company were announced yesterday by Thomas E. Lovejoy Jr., president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Dr. Herbert F. York, the Pentagon's chief scientist, said today that man might have to make his first leap into space from rocket bases at the North or South Pole.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Bob Watson, the Ardsley club professional who learned to play golf in Texas, became the metropolitan open champion today.

KIEL, Germany, Sept. 19 -- Soviet overtures for settling world issues, apparently based on controlled disarmament, are a sign that "we are moving toward better times," Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union asked the General Assembly today to "recommend" that the United States, Britain and France join it in slashing their military budgets by at least 10 to 15 per cent.
HAVANA, Sept 19 -- President Fulgencio Batista said tonight that the importance given to the entry of rebels into Camaguey Province has been highly exaggerated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Lawrence G. Derthick, Commissioner of Education, called on the Council of Chief State School Officers today to speed implementation of the National Defense Education Act.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 -- The Lebanese were working today toward a compromise on their new Cabinet.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 19 -- Tomorrow in Britain small groups of sailing folk will be meeting around the nearest radio to hear the result of the first race between Sceptre and Columbia. Five P. M. local time at Newport is 10 P. M. in England and because of quaint liquor laws the bars and other places where seafaring men gather may be near to closing.

A two-foot square chunk of pavement in East Tenth Street, near Fifth Avenue, dropped into a crevice at 2 P. M. yesterday. Peering into the opening, the police and utility workers saw a hole, 8 feet wide, 5 feet long and 8 feet deep.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Ireland's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Frank Aiken, proposed today to the General Assembly that by international agreement nuclear weapons be restricted to what he termed "the nuclear club."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- The Friends of Raynham Hall will offer the sixth annual series of lectures on American architecture, furnishings and history. The series will be held on six successive Mondays, starting Oct. 6, in the parish hall of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union monitors decided today to go ahead with their hearings and investigations of alleged union corruption despite an ouster threat against one of their three members.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Poliomyelitis cases totaled 399 last week, 193 of them paralytic. Both were the highest weekly counts reported this year.

Industrial executives, appraising the 1959 sales outlook yesterday, forecast that the automobile volume would be at least 20 per cent larger than this year's, and steel output would rise about a fourth.

State Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit refused yesterday to bar Paul E. Bragdon, insurgent Democratic nominee, from appearing on the ballot in the Nov. 4 election for Assemblyman in the Eighth Assembly District.

The action was the result of alleged failure to remit premiums totaling $83,000 to the St. Louis Fire and Marine Insurance Company.
