FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 19 -- The patience and calm urged on this community by its school board and by Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. appeared today to have worn thin.
Reports that the Government would impose limitations on imports of lead and zinc set off a wave of speculative buying yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.
The Manhattan Brass Quintet and the Metropolitan Wind Ensemble presented a joint concert entitled "Music in the Round" last night at Theatre East, 211 East Sixtieth Street.
Reports that freight carloadings were hitting their best 1958 marks sent the railroads thundering ahead in yesterday's stock market. There were 1958 highs for the combined and rail averages.
Continued delay by the city in approving the Brooklyn approach to the proposed $260,000,000 Narrows Bridge will mean an end to the bridge project, Robert Moses said yesterday.

Those who fear that the large decline in United States gold reserves in the first half of this year indicates that there might be international speculation or a change in the American gold price got some reassuring news yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Dr. George K. C. Yeh, Chinese Nationalist Ambassador, said today that his Government should order air strikes against Chinese Communist gun emplacements opposite Quemoy as soon as it had enough planes.
Columbia University announced yesterday that accommodations had been found for its courses in the creative and practicing arts.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Jerry Lynch, the hottest-hitting Redleg of the moment, fattened his average to .313 tonight, leading an explosion of power that sank Milwaukee's Braves, 7 -- 1.
For the first time in nine weeks unemployment insurance claims in New York State increased last week.

The appeal of the Communist party of Cuba for a "united front" against Batista, reported in The Times of Aug. 29, proves conclusively two facts that deserve to be underlined. First, that the Communist party has no connection whatsoever with any of the groups engaged in active opposition against Batista's regime; and, second, that Juan Marinello and Blas Roca, the two main leaders of the party, have been in Cuba all along, unmolested.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Britain's plans to ease restrictions on dollar imports have bolstered the pound sterling and prompted speculation that sterling will be fully convertible next year.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The mobility of jet age international criminals has stimulated an Interpol study of the use of television to flash "wanted" descriptions throughout whole regions faster than a sheriff can tack a poster up on a post office veranda.
LA PAZ, Sept. 12 -- Bolivia's dream of an oil outlet to the sea should become a reality next month.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- The stock market tended to pause in its advance today in the face of week-end profit-taking and Wall Street's opening hesitancy. However, the undertone remained firm, volume was maintained and a late rally enabled most sections to close with more gains than losses.
MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 19 -- The elimination of junior drivers licenses and the raising of speed limits were urged today at the first of three public hearings on proposed state traffic legislation.
FULTON, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating of Rochester, Republican candidate for the Senate, asked election today on the basis of "experience versus experiment."
NEWARK, Sept. 19 (AP) -- It takes girls to bring out the boys for athletics.

A dozen plaster sculptures said to be the work of Frederick William MacMonnies turned up yesterday in the cellar of a building in Greenwich Village that is being torn down. Workmen had placed the pieces -- mostly busts -- on the sidewalk and invited passers-by to help themselves, but an art lover called the police, who then took the sculptures into protective custody.

THE room settings now on view at the National Home-furnishing Show at the Coliseum are, for the most part, livable. At least, this is the consensus gleaned from a random survey conducted between 4 and 6 P. M. on Wednesday.
Activity in the new capital market will be at a somewhat reduced pace in the week ahead, but only in comparison with the abnormally heavy schedules of the last two weeks.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Tommy Kono of Honolulu set two world records tonight and beat Fedor Bogdanovsky of the Soviet Union to win the middleweight title in the world weightlifting championships.

The American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers announced yesterday the election of Howard C. Pyle of Los Angeles as president. His one-year term will start next February at the annual meeting in San Francisco. He will succeed Dr. Augustus B. Kinzel, vice president for research of the Union Carbide Corporation.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- Grants totaling nearly $1,000,000 for educational television programs and experiments were announced today by Dr. Henry T. Heald, president of the Ford Foundation.
BALTIMORE, Sept 19 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman, stumping into Maryland tonight to lend Democratic candidates a hand, attributed a Republican tight money policy for inflation and unemployment.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Raw wool production in the free world in the 1958-1959 season is expected to decline for the second season in succession.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- A high-ranking United Nations official will go to Jordan for consultations with King Hussein's Government.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 -- Yankee world series stock climbed a few points tonight despite the fact that Paul Richards' Orioles upended the Bombers with a Garrison finish. Scoring all five runs with one out in the ninth, the Birds tripped the Yanks, 5 -- 4, before a jubilant gathering of 12,731.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 19 -- Nearly two years ago a Roman Catholic layman in Milwaukee personally airlifted a planeload of seventy-three Hungarian refugees to his home city.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The powerful Steering Committee of the General Assembly voted today to defer for another year consideration of Communist China's admission to the United Nations.
ALBANY, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Board of Regents granted a provisional charter today to a high school that will take its students on a tour around the world.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 18 -- No self-respecting Indian woman here would think of going out without a bowler hat.

The seven-story office building at 188-90 Montague Street, Brooklyn, which also has an entrance at 165 Remsen Street, has been purchased by the Josal Realty Corporation from a client of Milbank, Tweed, Hope Hadley.
ROME, Sept. 19 -- All police-authorized brothels went out of business tonight when prostitution became illegal in Italy, one of the last countries in Europe where it still had been licensed.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 19 -- The United States vice consul who was shot yesterday by a Cypriote terrorist was apparently mistaken for a British civilian, a United States official said here today.
The New York Stock Exchange suspended a broker, fined his firm $25,000 and censured his eleven partners yesterday.

A new $125,000 organ will be dedicated at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, 207 East Sixteenth Street, at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. In place of the regular sermon, the Rev. Edward O. Miller, the rector, will lead the congregation in a litany of dedication.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 19 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower spent today fishing and playing bridge with three friends on a secluded farm in northwest Rhode Island.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 19 -- The two telephones in the old frame house of Harry L. Golden, a cigar-chewing, cracker-barrel philosopher out of New York's Lower East Side, seldom stopped ringing today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Princeton and Rutgers, the teams that started the autumnal madness in the first game of intercollegiate football in 1869, open tneir season in Palmer Stadium on Saturday, Sept. 27, and it could be one of the best scraps of the opening day in the East.

A member of the British cabinet strongly urged yesterday the establishment of an European free trade area. Reginald Maudling, Paymaster-General in the Macmillan Government, backed the proposal at a luncheon meeting of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce the the Plaza Hotel.

A sitdown strike of American Airlines cargo workers began here yesterday and by nightfall had spread to Newark, Albany, Philadelphia and Hartford, causing flight delays and cancellations. A total of 1,500 workers were reported out.

WILTON, Conn., Sept. 19 -- Some residents of this small commuter town are seeking to legalize the sale of liquor in Wilton, which has been dry under local option since its founding in 1802. A petition favoring the move has attracted 250 signatures and needs only 100 more to force a town-wide referendum.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19 -- The Rev. Robert P. Murray has been appointed Roman Catholic chaplain at Princeton University to succeed the Rev. Hugh Halton.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The September corn future came in for the usual contract-ending flurry of trading today but other expiring September deliveries finished in relatively calm dealings with small price shifts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- (UPI) -- President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon paid tribute today to Lajos Kossuth, Hungarian patriot of the 1800's. The tributes were in connection with a new Champion of Liberty postage stamp issued in his honor by the United States.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- Pravda complained in strong terms today of a "crude anti-Soviet introduction" to an interview given by Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, on the American television program "Youth Wants to Know" last Sunday.

LITTLE ASHTON, England, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Harry Weetman, long-driving British Ryder Cup player, today moved into a six-stroke lead at the end of the third round in the 72-hole British Masters golf tournament.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Air Force fired another Snark today. This is the intercontinental guided missile that soon may be deployed with the Strategic Air Command.

It is true, as Mary Lewis suggests in her letter printed on Sept. 17, that good use can be made of native speakers of out-of-the-way languages now domiciled here. However, not all these people have either the aptitude or the desire to do actual teaching.

Whether the United Steelworkers' insurgents have used methods prohibited by the union's constitution in their opposition to President McDonald we are in no position to judge, nor do we know whether the present union administration has overstepped the bounds of propriety in high-pressure propaganda for their side. But the Steelworkers' constitution, as summarized in the resolution to oust the rebels, is surely "a model of union democracy," as Senator Kennedy has said.
A new seven-part series on American politics will start on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network Sept. 28.
Governor Harriman told a Harlem audience last night that President Eisenhower's position on school integration had encouraged bigots and demagogues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, declared tonight that the United States was militarily superior to the Soviet Union. He added that the United States could remain so in the Nineteen Sixties.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Bruce Maher tonight set up all three of Detroit's touchdowns and added a pair of conversions to lead the Titans to a 21-6 football victory over George Washington.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States last month rose above the 1957 level for the first time in fourteen months, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Sceptre slid ever so slowly down the ways into the water today as her skipper traded banter with Columbia's captain, Briggs Cunningham, who watched from a near-by dock.
Minority stockholders in the Arkansas Fuel Oil Corporation expressed dissatisfaction yesterday with the Cities Service Company's plan to split their company in two.
FATIMA, Portugal, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Cardinal Spellman celebrated mass here today at this sanctuary for 600 American pilgrims touring the shrines of Europe with him.
TURKU, Finland, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Dan Waern, Sweden's sub-four-minute miler, broke another middle distance record today when he sped 1,000 meters in 2 minutes 18.1 seconds.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A group of white students here adopted a resolution today declaring that they want their high school reopened even if it means admitting Negroes.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 19 -- The William Volker fountain, the last work of the Swedish sculptor, Carl Milles, will be unveiled at 3 P. M. tomorrow in the Kansas City Cultural Center. It will be dedicated to the memory of a German immigrant who came to this community in 1882 at the age of 23.

A strike of 600 lightermen was called off last night following a conference with their employers' representative, the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York. The men had been away from their jobs at loading or unloading lighters one day.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, Sept. 20 -- Powerful United States forces deployed in the Taiwan area facing Communist China have been grouped under a new unified operational command in Taipei, apparently in ultimate preparation for combat, if necessary.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- The United Steelworkers of America took the first step today toward setting up a chain of hospitals and medical centers to meet the health needs of its 1,250,000 members.

The emergency brakes on the Jersey Central commuter train that fell into Newark Bay last Monday were applied only when the train had reached the very lip of the open lift bridge, it was revealed yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange ticker ended its fourth biggest week of the year yesterday, with 18,111,266 shares changing hands in the five trading days. At midweek the widely followed Dow-Jones industrial average posted a record high.
CAIRO, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Cabinet as announced today is as follows:
The hangover from last year's boom is causing the indigestion in today's bond market, a New York University economist suggested yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Six major airlines agreed today to accept recommendations of a Presidential emergency board for settlement of a dispute with the machinists union.

Millions of Americans who probably don't know a spinnaker from a marlinspike will thrill today to the renewal of one of the world's outstanding international sports classics, the races for the America's Cup. Yachting is in a world of its own, but this competition has achieved a tradition that places it in the category of the "great" events.

Once again the week-end is to be highly respected. During the summer it lost a certain amount of caste, was overshadowed by thoughts of the whole fortnight of vacation. Now it has returned to its own.

Of more than two thousand nominations that were submitted before the deadline of Jan. 16, 1956, ten colts have met all requirements and conditions to participate in the $116,390 Futurity at Belmont Park today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A Swedish expert in the art of secret writing received a patent this week for a coder that fits in the pocket of the diplomat's cutaway.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 19 -- Yachting's world series begins tomorrow. Weather permitting, the first race of the seventeenth challenge match for the America's Cup will start at 12:10 P. M. The scene of action will be the broad Atlantic, some ten miles to sea of this teeming port.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged Nichols Associates, Inc., Chicago, a seller of real estate advertising, with obtaining property listings through misrepresentation.
Mayor Wagner said last night that dates were "being worked out" for him to speak for the Democratic-Liberal ticket both in the city and upstate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The index of average primary market prices remained unchanged at 119 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices rose on average for processed foods, but declined for farm products and for other commodities.

President Eisenhower's speech of Sept. 11 about the American-Chinese crisis does not, in my opinion, make any more plausible or less reckless United States military intervention at Quemoy on behalf of the aging and brutal dictator Chiang Kai-shek.

Mississippi, Clemson, Texas and North Carolina, football teams that generally are ranked in the top twenty among the nation's collegiate elevens, swing into action today. Some 130 contests are on the schedule, which lists a number of attractive intersectional games, topped by Pittsburgh at the University of California at Los Angeles and Penn State at Nebraska.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union has denied shooting down a United States Air Force plane that crashed near the Soviet-Turkish frontier Sept. 2.

A volume of poems and drawings about New York called "The Tune of the Calliope" will be published next Friday by Thomas Yoseloff. The poems, by Aaron Kramer, represent a twenty-year span of work and include excerpts from eight of his earlier books.

DURING the last several months, Macy's expert tasters have covered a long list of countries for outstanding and representative food products. The store will bring its selections to the city's connoisseurs on Monday, when it opens its centennial food festival.
An on-again, off-again railroad service fee for handling export or import cargoes was on again yesterday.
NEARLY 3,000 people went to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to talk about Paris clothes, see Paris clothes and hear all about Paris clothes.

One of the most persistently recurring monetary proposals advanced since the end of World War II has been the proposal that steps be taken to improve the "liquidity" of nations for purposes of their international trade relations by increasing their gold and exchange reserves. That end would be achieved by the familiar process of general currency devaluation, though its authors prefer to use the phrase "raising the price of gold."

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Sixteen-year-old Bruce Zator, accused of slaying a classmate in the Massapequa High School April 30, pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter charges in Nassau County Court today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Tuscarora Indians petitioned the Supreme Court today to review a decision that permits condemnation of tribal lands for the Niagara Falls power project.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, reported yesterday that New York State's school enrollment had reached another high, but that the growth was uneven.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Sept. 19 -- A Federal judge placed the community of Van Buren, Ark., on its honor today to resume racial integration in its high school.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Consumer prices fell last month for the first time in two years.

As a Palestine Arab refugee who is directly affected by the "Plan on Arab Refugees" offered by the newly formed Institute for Mediterranean Affairs, The New York Times, Sept. 11, I have carefully scrutinized the proposals to find out to what extent they merit consideration.

THE premiere of Herbert Ross' "Paean" and Nora Kaye's appearance in the season's first "Giselle" made last night's program of the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House of double interest. That neither item altogether came off, is another matter.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Marketing and cooking problems will be eased for forty of this town's aged next month.
EVER since bricks were created, architects and builders have been trying to find and use more and better prefabricated parts in home design and construction.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Norfolk school board postponed today the opening of all junior and senior high schools until Sept. 29. In the interim, it will ask an appellate court to stay a lower court's desegregation order.

The New York Central Railroad expects to hold its passenger service deficit this year to about $37,000,000, or $15,000,000 below the record total of $52,200,000 lost in 1957, according to Alfred E. Perlman, president.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev warned President Eisenhower today that the United States troops and ships faced expulsion by the Chinese Communists from Taiwan and the surrounding seas unless they were withdrawn "now."

Carlebach, Galleries, Inc., which has a large collection of primitive art from Europe, Africa, Asia and South America, has signed a long-term lease for the store and basement at 1040 Madison Avenue at the northwest corner of Seventy-ninth Street.

Arthur Austin's letter in your Sept. 16 issue challenging the status of the Supreme Court's 1954 school desegregation decision as the law of the land echoes a similar observation by Governor Faubus on "Face the Nation" on Aug. 31.

HONG KONG, Sept. 19 -- The Peiping Foreign Ministry issued tonight its seventh "serious warning" against the United States Seventh Fleet for its "invasion" of Communist China's territorial waters in disputed Taiwan Strait.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Willie Mays banged three hits, moving within 2 points of Richie Ashburn in the National League batting race, as the San Francisco Giants clipped St. Louis tonight, 8 -- 1. Stu Miller tossed a five-hitter for the Giants.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers served notice tonight that they would strike at General Motors and Chrysler Corporation. But they held out hopes that contract settlements could be reached to avert the walkout.
Nine thousand Americans of German descent, living in New York State, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania, will take part in a German-American Steuben Parade here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce urged the nation's businessmen today to "get into politics" if they wanted to match the political power wielded by unions.
An art exhibition and sale at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel Art Gallery Dec. 1 through Dec. 6 will benefit the Grand Street Settlement House.

In his address before the United Nations General Assembly Foreign Minister Gromyko spoke of the recent Soviet campaign for a new summit meeting and blamed the West for delaying it. What he neglected to say is that the West has been prodding the Soviets to resume the Moscow preparatory talks for such a meeting and that it is Mr. Gromyko himself who broke them off.

PARIS, Sept. 19 -- The French Government termed the new Algerian Provisional Government "artificial" today and accused it of having no other means of action than assassination and terrorism.

OMAHA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A Strategic Air Command jet tanker smashed two Russian jet transport speed records and set seven additional world marks in a single flight Wednesday, S. A. C. headquarters disclosed today.

BOB HOPE'S ninety-minute version of "Roberta" on Channel 4 last night turned out to be almost two shows: First, except for Anna Maria Alberghetti, a rather dispirited hour. Second, a half-hour of lively fun and nonsense.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals ruled today that defendants before general courts-martial may no longer be represented by persons who are not lawyers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Secretary of State Dulles described the Far Eastern situation today as "extremely serious." However, he said he continued to hope that the talks in Warsaw with the Chinese Communists would yield at least some positive results.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Sept. 20 -- Norman Snead, a rangy sophomore quarterback, threw three touchdown passes today as Wake Forest routed favored Maryland, 34 -- 0. The victors snapped a twelve-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Officials here were agreed today that, whatever else might be said about Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's intemperate letter yesterday to President Eisenhower, it at least provided a classic example of Soviet debasement of the language and uses of diplomacy.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Sept. 20 -- The North Carolina State eleven capitalized on a wave of fumbles to upset the Tar Heels, 21 -- 14, before 41,000 fans today.

MISSOULA, Mont., Sept. 20 -- Criticism of the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs was coupled here this week with determination to speed tribal self-help.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -- The prosecution called today for the death penalty for Fadhil al-Jamali, former Iraqi Premier charged with conspiring against Syria to bring about overthrow of the Government in Damascus with imperialist backing.

Inflation is the big threat to the economy today, according to what business men are being told by the Federal Reserve Board. It is on this premise that the board has begun to tighten the screws on credit by raising its lending (discount) rates to member banks.
The meaning of penitence during the Jewish High Holy Days provided the theme for several sermons in temples and synagogues yesterday.

* * * Obviously Frank O'Connor is at the opposite end of the stick from the Joyce fanatics. This is as it should be; one would not argue with Mr. O'Connor's right to his opinion on the work of Joyce. But, is Mr. O'Connor becoming the new Sainte-Beuve in his identification of the man with the artist?

ABOARD U. S. C. G. C. WILLIAM J. DUANE AT SEA OFF NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 -- As many British critics had feared, Sceptre proved herself inferior to Columbia to windward in the first race of the seventeenth America's Cup series.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 -- Hoyt Wilhelm, a 35-year-old knuckle-balling right-hander, a relief man for most of his career and regarded as virtually a washout at the beginning of this season tossed a no-hitter today.

SINCE nothing more quickly subverts an evening on the town than to be reminded, by sudden fevers, of life's harrowing transience, the major Broadway theatres always have physicians waiting to rush in with healing balms.

A wave of "sickness" among the unlicensed personnel of the Grace liner Santa Rosa delayed the departure of the vessel about twenty-two hours. The ship left the company's West Fifteenth Street terminal at 2 P. M. yesterday with a capacity list of 295 passengers on a twelve-day Caribbean and South American cruise.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The consensus among inflation fighters here seems to be that the Ford wage settlement has served the cause of stabilization about as well as could be expected.

AT the time of his death in August, Wolcott Gibbs had been on the staff of The New Yorker magazine thirty - one years, and he had, so he says, contributed more words to that publication than any other person. Nominally its drama critic, he actually contributed pieces in nearly every form the magazine was accustomed to use, and he probably regarded his official position as more or less an accident.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 20 -- Sixty-one Little Rock lawyers declared their opinion tonight that the four closed Little Rock high schools could not be legally reopened as segregated private schools.
The National Park Service has been urged to establish a maritime museum and a marine restaurant at the site of Castle Garden and the old Aquarium in Battery Park.

Mr. Crowther feels that dubbing robs the film of the "natural flavor" communicated by the original native language. But how does the viewer with no knowledge of the language secure this "natural flavor"? The inadequate subtitles, coupled with unintelligible dialogue, can hardly perform this function.

USING as the title for her latest volume of memoirs the second line of Robert Browning's poem about seeing Shelley plain, G. B. Stern introduces us gaily and informally to some more of her celebrated friends. Her sketches are vigorous, entertaining rather than revealing, and the main character to emerge from a welter of anecdotage is the author herself.

AT the moment, a couple of determined and energetic young New Yorkers named Radley Metzger and William Kyriakis are polishing for theatrical release a ninety-six-minute feature called "Dark Odyssey," shot on the local streets on their own initiative and capital.
NEWARK, Sept. 20 -- A 14year-Old boy was charged by the police today with the beating and burning of a 9-year-old girl last night.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Communist Hungary today accused the United States of discriminating against it, protested alleged spying and appealed for better relations.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Sept. 13 were 4 per cent above volume for the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve board has reported. A week earlier there was a rise of 2 per cent.

As a prelude to the introduction of educational television into the city schools tomorrow, Assistant Superintendent Maurice U. Ames outlined the assets and liabilities of the project yesterday. He warned against expecting perfection
HONOLULU, Sept. 20 -- The political campaign has started in Hawaii. For the first time, members of a third party are adding their voices from the speaking platform.
The first foreign flag raised in the city of Tokyo after the opening of Japan has been found in the attic of an old brownstone building at 280 Convent Avenue, just north of the City College campus.

CLEMSON, S. C., Sept. 20 -- Lowndes Shingler, a second-half substitute, sparked Clemson to two rallies today as the favored Tigers gained a 20-15 football victory over the Virginia Cavaliers before 20,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A number of Latin-American Republics will announce at the Pan-American Sanitary conference a major stride forward in public health -- eradication of the mosquito that carries urban yellow fever. The conference opens tomorrow in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

THE American home, not so long ago swept clean of decoration, is now getting dressier all the time. Ornamental furniture of past periods is the overwhelming first choice today. A strong minority trend: built-in furniture, which purists cherish.

Almost as soon as the Assembly had disposed of its opening formalities, two other major issues emerged: the Middle East and disarmament. The Nov. 13 evening performance of The Girls in 509," starring Imogene Coca and Peggy Wood at the Belasco Theatre, will benefit the Society of St. Johnland.

Elaboration is the keynote. It takes over in fabrics, flooring, wall coverings and other decorative niceties that complete the picture of the 1958-59 room. Stripes have streaked to the top as the first choice in pattern, with the runners-up, filigree and scroll designs, playing a curvilinear counterpoint.

WINTER-flowering sweet peas, ranunculus and anemones are fine for fall planting in areas where winters are mild. Planted early enough, they will bloom in the winter. Later sowings mature in early spring.

Mild profit-taking at mid-week finally slammed the brakes on the stock market's upward drive -- but not for long. Prices resumed their upward course in the final trading session last week and soared to new peaks for the year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 12 -- Congressional and Gubernatorial elections will be held in Brazil Oct. 3. They present a baffling contest of fuzzy issues, crossed party lines and personal ambitions.
NEWARK, Sept. 20 -- The City Council has under consideration major revisions in the air-pollution and smoke-abatement-control ordinance to tighten enforcement.
ALGIERS, Sept. 20 -- Algeria is going through an experiment that may well be unique in history: A popular and supposedly democratic vote is being organized by a fighting army in a country at war.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Administration is drawing up plans to combat the Soviet blocs economic offensive with a long-range, multi-billion-dollar loan program in less developed areas.
It's been a bumpy, downhill road for the automobile industry so far in 1958. Production and sales have declined in a generally disappointing year.

A 250-foot unmanned balloon containing 7,000,000 cubic feet of helium gas -- twice the volume ever used before -- will be launched by University of Chicago physicists next winter to take pictures of cosmic rays 130,000 feet above the earth.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 -- The General Motors and Chrysler Corporations made similar contract offers to the United Automobile Workers today in bids for a speedy settlement of labor disputes.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 19 -- President Francois Duvalier observes the first anniversary of his six-year mandate Monday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 20 -- Another Swedish election campaign has ended, with the nation's leaders in a debate on television. But the posters argue on.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 20 -- A formidable generating capacity in cerebral energy got under way this week with the turn of a mental switch on an isolated hilltop overlooking the Stanford University campus.

The first week of the U. N. General Assembly's thirteenth regular session has produced the expected controversies, including the basic one between the United States and Russia.

New elements of impasse and tension were injected into the integration controversy last week. For the first time, schools in the South were shut down over the issue of admitting Negroes to white classrooms. The development set in motion conflicting pressures whose ultimate impact on the integration struggle still could not be gauged.

THE Post Office Department has nothing on the American Ballet Theatre for valor. Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom -- not to speak of flood and fire -- have been able to stay these hardy troupers from the punctual fulfillment of their contract for a season at the Met.

IN this picture-postcard village facing Switzerland's highest and mightiest peaks, Walt Disney is waging an Alpine invasion rivaling Hannibal's for ingenuity. Using pack mules instead of elephants and such random devices as cograils, cable lifts and helicopters, 170 Disney moviemakers are shooting "Third Man on the Mountain" among summits considered impregnable.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 -- Columbia's victory today in the first America's Cup race was called inconclusive by Olin Stephens, the designer of the slippery yacht.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Invitations have been issued for the seventieth annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball, to be held Oct. 18 at the Tuxedo Club. Ten debutantes will be introduced to society.

IN the Nineteen Twenties William King, 14-year-old war widow's son, was enrolled as a cadet in the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth. From this famous nursery of British naval officers he emerged just in time to serve as submarine commander for six grueling years during World War II.

THERE are many reasons why Dr. Edward Robinson Squibb (1819-1900) merits such a well-documented biography as Lawrence G. Blochman has written. Ironically, both the least important and most important of these reasons derive from events occurring after Dr. Squibb's death.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Texas Christian rolled to a 42-0, victory over the University of Kansas today on the flashy running, of Merlin Priddy and accurate passing by Glen Dawson and Hunter Enis, quarterbacks.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- The Florida Quadricentennial Commission at a recent meeting here began shaping plans for the seven-year quadricentennial to be held at various places in the state starting in 1959 at Pensacola and winding up in 1965 at St. Augustine.

Teaching by television, which has both its evangelists and skeptics, will get its first nation-wide test this school year in a college physics course on a coast-to-coast network program. The program, originating in New York City, will be offered for full credit by approximately 300 colleges this semester.

Governor Harriman and Carmine G. De Sapio ridiculed reports of disunity within the Democratic party yesterday. They appeared together at a political conference at the Park Royal Hotel, 23 West Seventy-third Street.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 18 -- Calvin W. Rawlings, Democratic national committeeman for Utah, welcomed party leaders from eleven Western states and Hawaii here this week with an apology.

Intentionally broke First Landing's streak and almost broke the track record while winning the $114,390 Futurity at Belmont Park yesterday. The son of Intent, running in the silks of Harry Isaacs' Brookfield Farms, beat Christopher Chenery's hitherto undefeated First Landing by a length in the sixty-ninth running of the important event for 2-year-olds.

YONKERS, Sept. 20 -- Charming Barbara, piloted by William Haughton, and Willis L., driven by William Myer, finished in a dead heat in the $6,000 Monitor junior free-for-all trot headlining the Yonkers Raceway program tonight.
Kim Il Sung, North Korean Premier, has unveiled an ambitious program apparently aimed at making his country the most industrialized in Asia relative to population by 1965.

IN 1945 at San Francisco, after a generation of unprecedented collective insecurity, the world turned to the United Nations as a cure for the diseases of international society. Today, almost half a generation later, the need for a rudimentary world order grows ever more apparent. Yet it is asked: Is the U. N. adequate to its purpose? Is it doomed to futility?

CAIRO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The newly formed provisional Algerian Government assured President Nasser today of its support for a policy of strong Arab solidarity.
WARSAW, Sept. 20 -- The United States and Communist China agreed today to take an extra twenty-nine hours to consider each other's proposals for a cease-fire in the Strait of Taiwan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- The United Nations will soon show the taxpayers of many countries a sample of what their Governments' contributions are accomplishing in underdeveloped areas.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- A new use has been found for Boston's narrow streets. Two side streets, Temple Place and West Street, have blossomed into gay, traffic-free shopping plazas.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 20 -- The North Shore Horticultural Society will open its fiftyfourth annual benefit flower show on Oct. 31 in the indoor tennis court of the former George Dubont Pratt estate on Dosoris Lane.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 18 -- The head of the Air Force Academy's new department of astronautics says that his objective will be to "turn out future commanders of ballistic missiles squadrons -- not space cadets."

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 -- If modern yacht designers were to follow that ancient and wonderful custom of putting figure-heads on their creations, there is not much question as to whose might well be on the beautiful bow of the glamorous Columbia.
Dedication ceremonies for a new $3,500,000 Queens College gymnasium, said to be one of the nation's largest, will be held Tuesday at the college's Flushing campus.

WHAT will the 1958-59 music season offer the New York concertgoer? Since nearly every season has its surprises, unexpected events (like the emergence of Van Cliburn last season) cannot be anticipated.
Soviet explorers are preparing for an Antarctic tractor journey 600 miles longer than any polar trek yet undertaken.
Ottawa, Sept. 20 -- A mounting wave of labor unrest is worrying Canadians.
COLOMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20 -- The migration from city to suburbs was declared here today to be demanding a radical change in the traditional work pattern of social welfare agencies.

PATHOS as a property of the nude body, expressed without any rhetorical gestures or facial grimaces, belongs to the sculpture of Saul Baizerman (1889-1957) to a degree not found in the work of any other contemporary artist.

THE recent decline in book selling in Chile indicates that inflation can be as disastrous in the literary world as it is in the market place. When the price of a novel triples, as it has recently in Santiago, and the average wage earner has difficulties in balancing his food budget, it is not surprising that literature is regarded as a marginal luxury and that the book industry feels the sharp effects of home economies.

WHAT might be called an electronic lonely hearts club will be established by the American Broadcasting Company on Oct. 13 when it starts presenting "Chance for Romance." According to Irving Mansfield, co-producer, it will be a "romantic participation show."

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 20 -Ch. Westhay Fiona of Harham, Airedale terrier from the kennels of Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago, was named best in show at the twenty-second Ox Ridge Kennel Club fixture today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 -- Pittsburgh's pro-type offense, executed with all the skill of the play-for-pay performers, today spoiled the debut of George Dickerson as coach of the University of California at Los Angeles by defeating the Bruins, 27 -- 6.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who organized the Negro bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., in 1956, was stabbed by a Negro woman in a Harlem department store yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Library of Congress announced today acquisition of the first installment of the papers of Theodore Roosevelt Jr. The papers were placed there by the widow of the twenty-sixth President's son.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The controversial question of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations comes up here on Monday before the General Assembly.
The officers and directors of the George Junior Republic are sponsoring a preview performance on Oct. 9 of "The World of Suzie Wong." The play opens at the Broadhurst Theatre on Oct. 14.
TORQUAY, England, Sept. 20 -- Jo Grimond, leader of the Liberal party, bitterly denounced the Establishment today and called for "political reform and true democracy" in Britain.

HONG KONG, Sept. 20 -- The potential and actual but unvoiced differences between Communist China and the Soviet Union doubtless exist, but present relations between the two big Communist powers are close and their policies are effectively coordinated.

CLINT LANE'S fourth year at West Point is no less exciting than his first three, described in "West Point Plebe" and two other volumes. Now he is acting commander of Beast Detail (indoctrination of new cadets), is caught in a forest fire, wins his stripes as cadet captain and faces Navy in both football and baseball.

MIAMI BEACH -- Unable to do anything about the weather last winter, when continuing cold and rain, plus the spreading national recession, served to end a decade of boom seasons for Miami Beach, this resort's hotelmen are casting about for the key to revival.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 20 -- Morris County's first county park was dedicated and opened today with dignitaries and some 200 county residents attending.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 20 -- Nine months after the defeat of dictatorship here, Venezuela is fighting her way to effective democracy and constitutional government along thorny uphill path.

WASHINGTONG, Sept 20 -- The Communist attacks upon Quemoy, though intense and determined, are still limited and localized, and intelligence reports give no indications of additional eruptions in the Far East.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The eyes, ears, noses and squeaky shoes of some newly arrived diplomats are being carefully noted by a group of United Nations security officers. The officers are trying to distinguish between the diplomatic corps and the nondiplomatic corps at the current session of the General Assembly.
A record grain crop is producing a huge harvest of dollars for farmers across the Great Plains. More than $5,500,000,000 is expected to be paid out to farmers in the peak period -- Aug. 1 to Oct. 31.
Scofflaw hunting has become so successful that the Chief Magistrate's Term Court is expanding to handle increased business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -Lieut. Col. Theodore Macklin Ball, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Ball of Washington and Spalding's West Shore, Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Frances Ball, to Richard Edward Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Baldwin of Burlington. An autumn wedding is planned.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- The annual Election Day Fair of the Scarsdale Congregational Church on Nov. 4 will be of special interest to gourmets.

RECORDINGS of the Bach B minor Mass do not turn up too often, as might be expected of a very long work that demands orchestra, continuo, chorus and soloists. Thus when a new version appears, one turns to it with eagerness.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18 -- Informed Yugoslavs predicted today that the crisis in the Taiwan Strait would die soon. But they foresaw the Chinese Communists fomenting a succession of similar conflicts for an indefinite time.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A man who said he had killed Serge Rubinstein in 1955 was arrested here tonight.
The 16,844-ton luxury liner Oslofjord sailed yesterday after the Norwegian America Line Agency, Inc., had posted a $500,000 bond ensuring her return.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 -- Proud Columbia struck a mighty blow in defense of the America's Cup today.
Harold Oldak's Windborne II was the winner of the eleventh annual day race staged by the Stuyvesant Yacht Club of City Island yesterday.
Dr. Seymour Harris, chairman of Harvard University's Economics Department, last week brought closer a debate on a coming issue in higher education: How are its increasing costs to be paid?

THE introduction of another small-leaved rhododendron hybrid this fall shows the response of plant breeders to modern home landscaping needs. The newcomer is Pioneer, a dwarf rhododendron of extraordinary quality.

IN his fifth book of short stories, Jesse Stuart turns again to the scenes of his boyhood and youth in eastern Kentucky, a land of rugged hills and rugged individualism. Mr. Stuart is a poet, and one of the secrets of his charm as a storyteller is a certain poetic touch in his description.

RAIN dripping off a roof which has no gutters will soak down into the ground near the foundation walls, causing dampness in the basement. It can also stain the house walls and ruin foundation plantings.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 20 -- This city's dreams of becoming a "university city" moved a step nearer reality this week when it was chosen site of the proposed Florida Presbyterian College.

She will be seen as the benevolent but confused Veta Louise Simmons in a ninety-minute telecast of Mary Chase's comedy hit, "Harvey," on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

COMPOSERS do not often have parties thrown for them, and when three composers are the recipients, the occasion is triply rare. Thus a goodly number of persons turned out last week to say good-by to Roy Harris, Roger Sessions and Ulysses Kay -- and, in absentia, Peter Mennin -- on the occasion of their thirty-day trip to the Soviet Union.

An auction in the Bronx these days offers new merchandise at prices to amaze the most skilled bargain seekers. It takes place every Thursday morning in the shadow of the Triborough Bridge, in a dingy little building that belongs to the Harlem River Yards of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
PARIS, Sept. 20 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle began today a quick tour of four provincial cities to whip up support for his Constitution to be voted on Sept. 28.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20 -- Indonesia's "civil war" is no longer Indonesia's biggest news, as it was only a few months ago. The conflict is pretty much a page three affair in Jakarta's four-page newspapers these days.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- There may be enough drama around the world to fill the newspapers, and the Soviet press is going at the assorted crises with the usual zest, but Moscow itself is simply preparing for a busy winter.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 -- The United States Government formally rejected today the message on the Taiwan crisis sent to President Eisenhower yesterday by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

FOR the third consecutive season, Max Pollikoff, violinist turned concert manager, is presenting his Chamber Music Reading Series at Barnard College. The series is being sponsored by the Alice M. Ditson Fund of Columbia University in cooperation with Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, and the Music Performance Trust Fund of the Recording Industry.

MONTAUK, L. I. -- A new season in the sun is booming this resort area through a period that ordinarily would be used for boarding up against wintery Atlantic gales. An unvarying low pollen count is the golden key. While the metropolitan New York area wheezes through the scientifically recorded hay fever season, Montauk's rolling hills are swept by crisp, pollenfree winds off the ocean.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- It would be most difficult, perhaps impossible, for cities with schools closed over the racial segregation issue to replace them with a constitutional system of "private" segregated schools.

A luncheon and fashion show to be held at the Plaza on Oct. 14 will benefit the Special Research Division of the Manhattan Society for Mental Health.

A sitdown strike of American Airlines cargo workers that began Friday night ended here at 3:45 P.M. yesterday.

AT stake in the North Atlantic "fish war" between Iceland and Britain are parts of the world's richest fishing banks, on the submerged coastal shelf of Iceland.
