BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 -- An around-the-clock curfew went into effect here today. Beirut remained tense and uneasy, with rival political groups still holding hostages and threatening further violence.

Nine days ago President Eisenhower wrote that he could not detect in Premier Khrushchev's letter of Sept. 7 "any effort to find that common language which could indeed facilitate the removal of the danger existing in the current situation in the Taiwan area."
The Braves clinched the National League pennant yesterday by defeating the Redlegs, 6 to 5, at Cincinnati. It was Milwaukee's second championship in a row.
Slum redevelopers are finding private housing for dislocated relief families at rents much lower than those for which the Department of Welfare has been footing the bill.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 -- Probably no queen, whether from Sheba or Hollywood, ever had such a coterie of handmaids as an America's Cup defender.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Howard Seymour sailed Mutiny to Resolute Class honors today in the interclub sailing conducted in a driving rain by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 21 -Three native Ohioans were honored here today for their contributions to aviation and the nation as a $3,500,000 terminal, part of a $12,000,000 facility, was dedicated at Port Columbus Airport.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Federal Mediator Eric G. Taylor announced tonight that an agreement has been reached to end the crippling month-old British Columbia longshoremen's strike.
SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr. warned here tonight that the state must increase financial support of education.
Where can man register his horror lest the fate of Quemoy, that small, insignificant far-away isle in the Pacific, precipitate us into the holocaust of total war?
GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 21 -- On a day on which a water spaniel might have been expected to thrive, an Airedale terrier, Ch. Westhay Fiona of Harham, captured best-in-show honors.

The national executive council of the Zionist Organization of America voted yesterday to recommend to the coming Zionist convention that Emanuel Neumann be drafted for a third consecutive term as president.

FALL is often a good time to redecorate the house. And the hall is a good starting point, since it can set the atmosphere for the entire home. One reader with this in mind inquired about glamorizing a square-shaped hall in her formal home.

Agnes de Mille's new book, "And Promenade Home," which had originally been planned for November publication, will now be issued on Oct. 9 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. In her first book, "Dance to the Piper," Miss de Mille told of her childhood and the heartbreaking early years of her career.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 21 -- The clergy in this community is standing aside in the controversy over whether Negro and white children may go to public schools together.
Final plans have been made for the Blue Grass Ball, a dinner dance to be held Thursday in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Proceeds will go to the Travelers Aid Society of New York.

The memory of Lajos Kossuth, exiled Hungarian liberator of a century ago, was honored in a service yesterday at the First Hungarian Reformed Church, 344 East Sixty-ninth Street. He had helped to establish the church.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 21 -- Several ministers called here today for the defeat of segregation in next Saturday's special school election.
The arrival of "A Swim in the Sea" at the Lyceum on Sept. 30 is off. Now in Philadelphia, where it opened last Monday night, Jess Gregg's drama will continue there until Saturday night.

PEPPERIDGE Farm bread is one food product with a trade name that has real meaning. There IS a Pepperidge Farm. It is a lovely, rambling Englishstyle country house set in the midst of 300 acres of rolling farmland in Fairfield, Conn. On the second floor.

AT the head of Long Island Sound, beyond the East River, there is a little-known island. In late summer, field asters spread a blanket of blue across its treeless north-eastern tip. In winter, it lies shrouded in fog or swept by icy winds.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 21 -- A Roman Catholic leader cautioned church-goers today against condemning communism until they had put their own house in order.
The Soviet Minister of Culture conceded one Soviet cultural shortcoming in a broadcast televised yesterday. He said the Soviet Union had "not learned to make many good comedies" for television.

The five-story apartment house at 685 East 183d Street has been sold by Lomar Realty Company to Louis Willinger. The building, on a plot 83 by 100 feet, contains forty-three apartments. The deal was made for cash over mortgages of $122,500.
Store oweners who open on Sunday and turn "this special day into just another business day" were criticized yesterday by Msgr. Harry J. Wolff.

During the past few weeks thes columns have published many letters on the question of United State relations with China. Many of the letters have expressed points view differing with our Government's official position of refusing to appease Red China through the abandonment of Quemoy and Matsu.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Sept. 22 -- There has been an accumulation of evidence in recent hours of an increasing build-up of United States military power in the Taiwan Strait area.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, Sept. 22 -- A continued decline of the Liberal party marked yesterday's local elections in Sweden.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Hank Aaron, whose homer clinched the 1957 pennant, led the Milwaukee Braves to their second straight National League championship today. He drove in four runs in a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
A committee of One Hundred Housewives in New York State will campaign in their communities against consumer frauds, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

ROME, Sept. 21 -- A call for a national crusade to smash the Sicilian Mafia was sounded by a prominent member of the Government coalition today. Giuseppe Saragat, leader of Italy's Democratic Socialists, urged that the people get rid of the "repulsive scourge" of crime on the largest island in the Mediterranean.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman expressed gratification yesterday over the announcement by Governor Harriman that he would offer the New York County District Attorneyship to Francis W. H. Adams in the event that Frank S. Hogan is elected to the Senate.

Sometimes as we hear the arguments of the critics against selling the city subway system's power plants we wonder whether these critics are basing their attack on the same seventy-seven-page report of the Mayor's committee that was delivered to us on April 8, 1958. We publish on this page today a letter from such a critic, Martin Gerber.

A settlement has been reached in the wage dispute between the United Scenic Artists Union, Local 829, and the Scenery Suppliers Association. A three-year agreement, retroactive to June 22, was agreed upon, according to Erwin Feldman, lawyer for the union.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Labor party leader, affirmed tonight in stronger terms his party's opposition to Britain's becoming involved in a war over the Chinese offshore islands.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Princeton University opened its 212th academic year today with traditional exercises attended by 2,000 persons in the University Chapel.
The Christian church is more deeply entrenched in the Soviet Union than it was a quarter of a century ago, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday.

ERWINE AND LOUIS LAVERNE are pioneering again, this time at Altman's. The sophisticated furniture and accessory imports these brothers introduced at their through decorator showroom earlier this year make their appearance at the store today.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek said last night she hoped the current Warsaw talks would be a success, but she implied that a decision there would not necessarily be binding on the Chinese Nationalist Government.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev declared tonight that the "danger of fascism" had arisen in France with Premier Charles de Gaulle in power.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 -- Delegates to the Commonwealth Trade and Economic Conference spent the week-end taking stock of its accomplishments. The consensus was that the first week had been fruitful and that further achievements might be expected in the second week's session opening tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Twenty-six of forty major locals have instructed their delegates to support a strike vote against General Electric, Westinghouse and General Motors, a spokesman for the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers said today.
Grain represented the only sign of life last week in a listless steamship charter market.

" Striking gains" in employment opportunities for Negroes, Jews and other minority groups in banks in the state during the last thirteen years was reported yesterday by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 21 (AP)--After a five-day mountain trip by pony, mule and yak, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru opened talks today with the Maharaja of the Himalayan state of Bhutan.

UNQUESTIONABLY Melissa Hayden's first New York performance of "Swan Lake" Saturday afternoon with the New York City Ballet at the City Center was the high-point of the ballet week-end, as it would have been of practically any week-end you could name.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- Elizabeth Taylor has been signed for the film version of "Two for the Seesaw," William Gibson's successful Broadway comedy.

CITY and farm families still rely on the home oven for a good share of their baked goods. In a Department of Agriculture survey, 67 per cent of the city families and 93 per cent of the farm families were found to have at least one home-baked product a week, with quick breads, cakes and pies leading in popularity.
AUGSBURG, Germany, Sept. 21 (AP) -- West German athletes today scored 115 -- 105 upset over the highly rated Soviet team in a two-day track and field meet.
Fordham University's radio station will start broadcasting stereophonic programs on Oct. 1 using a relatively new technique called multiplexing.
ROME, Sept. 21 -- Landing rights for Boeing 707 Jet Clippers at Rome's International Airport will be discussed by Italian and American experts in talks due to open here tomorrow.
NATIONALIST China's new Ambassador to the United States, who said yesterday his Government could "hold out forever" against the Communists, is no stranger to America.
IZMIR, Turkey, Sept. 21 -- Premier Adnan Menderes vigorously defended today his huge spending programs and the use of United States and other foreign aid to support them.

George S. Horton, a vice president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, has been nominated for the presidency of the board to succeed John B. Swift. Nominees for that and other offices will be presented at the annual meeting of the board on Sept. 30 in Michel's Restaurant, 346 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The United States and Britain will discuss mutual problems of defense in the Middle East and the Far East in Cabinet-level talks due to begin tomorrow. The talks will be led by Duncan Sandys, British Minister of Defense, and Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, at meetings at the Pentagon.
BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Paul Robeson said here tonight that he would make his future home in London.

In your encouraging remarks on Sept. 11 about the recently published Report on the Palestine Refugee Problem you ask whether the solution proposed therein is practical and whether there is a chance that it be carried into effect. As a co-author of the report permit me to say that two additional provisions which could not be inserted into the text of the report, but which are entirely compatible with it, will answer your questions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- A State Department official said today that the United States might decide "after another week or so" to place the critical Taiwan Strait situation before the United Nations.
Development of a new type of pulp for use in making cotton-content paper has been announced by the Buckeye Cellulose Corporation, a subsidiary of the Proctor Gamble Company.

LLOYD NECK, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Two sisters from Jericho, L. I., took the top hunter honors at the Long Island Professional Horsemen's Association junior horse show on the Marshall Field estate today. Kathy Norden's Crutchfield won the championship, with Patricia Norden's Brilliant Lass taking reserve.
NEWPORT, R. L., Sept. 21 -- If the weather predictions materialize, both sides will have their wish tomorrow when the match for the America's Cup resumes.

The National Association of Investment Companies announced over the week-end the election of Herbert R. Anderson as president. This trade group consists of 146 open - end (mutual funds) and twenty-four closed - end investment companies.

Despite the effects of a waning recession and some adverse weather from time to time, New York City's Summer Festival was again a success in attracting tourist business. The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has made its annual report on its promotion of the vacation attractions here, addressed to people throughout the country. A million and a half folders went out, publicizing special events, hotels, restaurants, stores and things to see.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- George K. C. Yeh, Chinese Nationalist Ambassador to the United States, declared in an interview today that the Nationalist forces on Quemoy "could hold out forever."
Billions of crisp, swirling leaves may be symbols of invigorating autumn weather to some but not to the Department of Sanitation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman differed widely tonight with Chicago drama critics over his daughter Margaret's acting ability.
Four new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

FALLSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Frank S. Hogan, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, spoke out tonight for the first time on charges that his nomination had been dictated by Carmine G. De Sapio.
The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has protested to the Controller General against bearing "the tremendous burden" of a recent retroactive wage increase for Federal employes.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 -- The White House said today that the State Department would issue later this week a "sharp rebuttal" to Soviet criticisms of United States policy in the Taiwan area.

The Jewish Board of Guardians has purchased the twelve-story structure at 120 West Fifty-seventh Street. Purchase of the building, which is between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, was made possible by a grant from the estate of the late Edwin B. Elson, after whom the building will be renamed.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The United Auto Workers was expected to present a counteroffer to the General Motors and Chrysler Corporations tomorrow in contract negotiations.
Two hundred and seventy-five infants and toddlers will move next Monday into the New York Foundling Hospital's new home at Third Avenue and Sixty-Eighth Street.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 21--Sir Hugh Foot, Governor of Cyprus, issued a blunt answer today to Greek allegations of ill treatment by British troops. The allegations concerned searches in the Paphos area last week-end.

By long-standing tradition, people from Missouri want to be shown just how things stand, so it is not surprising that Missouri's state university was the first institution of higher learning in the world to provide formal training for gathering and editing the news.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Robert F. Kennedy said today that the Teamsters Union should be put in receivership by court order so that its "corrupt leadership" could be removed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Net working capital of United States corporations expanded by $1,700,000,000 in the second quarter of 1958 to a new high of $116,600,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21 -- Having successfully completed its huge Conversion Loan campaign, the Canadian Government is preparing to raise more money by a savings bonds issue. The bonds will be placed on the market from Oct. 14 to Nov. 14 for maturity in 1973, with an average yield to maturity of 4.19 per cent.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The Soviet Union declared tonight that President Eisenhower had Shown he was unwilling to "listen to the voice of reason" by rejecting Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's latest message on the Taiwan crisis.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said here tonight that, "more than anything else, America needs men and women who will fight corruption wherever they find it."

STRATFORD, Ont., Sept. 21 -- After a half-dozen years' absence, Sir John Gielgud returned to this continent last night to open a tour of his first solo offering, a Shakespearean anthology called "The Ages of Man."
IT would be to your advantage to tune in "Harvey" at 9:30 o'clock this evening on Channel 2; the revival of Mary Chase's comedy about the invisible rabbit is a warm and hilarious delight.

An increase of the city's retail sales tax to 4 per cent is being seriously considered by the Board of Estimate. The present 3 per cent rate is the maximum permitted by the state law authorizing the city to levy the tax.
Most business books lack the literary touch. But these two have refreshing style. An ex-newspaperman, Mr. Keats has chosen an enticing title for a witty and bitter attack on the auto industry.
MIAMI, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- A leading authority on cancer research said today that "excessive cigarette smoking has been conclusively proven to produce cancer of the lungs."
An entirely new type of tramp steamer is scheduled to complete loading and sail from the Port of New York today.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Joseph P. Kamp, pamphleteer who calls Walter P. Reuther a would-be dictator, made a conditional offer tonight to stop distribution of the pamphlets.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- The Executive Committee of the European common market said today that "good progress" had been made in the first nine months of the new community's existence.
HONOLULU, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- Four men and a dog landed on the island of Maui last night after having drifted sixty-nine days in a raft from California.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- The United States appealed to the Soviet Government on humanitarian grounds today for some information about eleven fliers missing since their transport crashed near the Soviet-Turkish frontier nineteen days ago.
The incentive system remains "the backbone" of the Soviet economy, the head of an American tourist delegation reported yesterday on his return to this country.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating declared yesterday that the defense of Quemoy and Matsu was primarily a military decision.
American ship lines handling passenger runs in the Pacific will be able to meet competition from jet planes and foreign-flag shipping, Randolph Sevier, president of Matson Lines said in Honolulu.
ALGIERS, Sept. 21 -- The formation of a government by the insurgent National Liberation Front appears to be a moderately successful operation from the point of view of internal Moslem opinion.
CAIRO, Sept. 21 -- Saudi Arabia recognized the Provisional Government of Algeria today and the Amman radio announced Jordan's intention to do so.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's Alexei Medvedev defeated America's Dave Ashman for the world heavyweight weight - lifting championship today to give the Russians five of the seven titles.
Viewers of WCBS-TV's "Eye on New York" got a big surprise yesterday when the station put the wrong video tape recording on the air.

HAVANA, Sept. 21--Army authorities are reported to have seized a large quantity of arms and ammunition hidden by youthful revolutionists in a cemetery in Santiago de Cuba, capital of Oriente Province.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week. They tended to firm at the outset but wavered later and closed with net mixed changes. At the end of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 8 to up 21 points. During the preceding week the market had been up 9 to 30 points.

CAIRO, Sept. 21 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser is reported planning a sweeping reorganization of the United Arab Republic's Government. It would be designed to bring affairs under closer central control and achieve greater unity between the Egyptian and Syrian regions.

WHEN the members of Ten Platoon of the Second Rifles of Canadian Infantry went under fire for the first time in Sicily in July, 1943, most of the men were more exhilarated than frightened. They were well-trained and competent. They trusted their leaders. Sergeant Mitchell was a good soldier and so was Lieutenant Adams.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 21 -- The key to a better steel operating rate rests now with the automotive industry. Consumers of steel, other than car makers, already have stepped up their orders. Full-scale support from the automotive industry could be a deciding factor in a steel rate increase.
A Norwegian tanker rescued the crew of a United States Navy plane late Saturday after the craft had been forced down by engine trouble in the Atlantic Ocean 180 miles north of Bermuda.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Investigating James R. Hoffa for a time can give a Senator a liberal education.
CAIRO, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- Observers here viewed the reported reshaping of the governmental set-up as the most important development since the union of Egypt and Syria Feb. 1.
A small group of friends of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia stood in the driving rain yesterday in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx to pay graveside homage to the former Mayor.

Fourteen newspapers in the city and on Long Island have agreed voluntarily to reject real estate advertising that identifies the properties involved as "inter-racial," the Commission on Intergroup Relations announced yesterday.

New York's first city-owned whirly floating derrick lacks a name, but Marine and Aviation Commissioner Vincent A. G. O'Connor hopes that one of the department's 1,500 employes can come up with one. The successful namer will win a $100 United States savings bond.
WITH the opening today of the Design Center for Interiors, consumers are invited for the first time to stand in the doorway of the "through decorator" world without an interior designer in tow.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 -The United States and Israel are dedicated to help the Middle Eastern states keep their independence, the Israeli Ambassador said today.
Three sizable accounts have found new agency homes.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 -At least it was a healthy, outdoorsy sort of day, spiced by the tonic tang of the salt sea air. But the one inescapable fact that emerged from yesterday's festivities was that an America's Cup race does not supply the thrills of the Kentucky Derby. Takes longer, too.

ORANGE, Tex., Sept. 21 (AP) -- A cloudburst dumped fourteen inches of rain in nine hours on this southeastern Texas city today, flooded 200 houses and blocked highways. National guardsmen evacuated an estimated 150 persons.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 -- With the crews of Columbia and Sceptre resting from competition today, the yachtsmen from the 1,000 power and sail boats in the spectator fleet here also took the day off.

The United Parents Associations reported yesterday that both Governor Harriman and his Republican campaign opponent, Nelson A. Rockefeller, favored a $500,000,000 school construction bond issue for New York City to be exempt from the debt limit.
Yom Kippur, the most sacred day of the Jewish religious calendar, will begin at sundown tomorrow.
A 37-year-old patrolman, who rescued three persons in an apartment house fire last May 11, will receive one of the Police Department's highest honors, the honorable mention award.
GARDEN CITY, L. I. Sept. 21 -- Governor Harriman told Nassau County today that it might "very well swing the state one way or the other" in the coming election.
The proposed sale of the city's transit power plants raises a number ber of questions of municipal policy which have received scant attention.
LOUISVILLE, Sept. 21 (AP) -- John Unitas passed for two touchdowns today as the Baltimore Colts routed the New York Giants, 42 -- 21. It was the Giants' fifth straight exhibition loss.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- A crew of workers toiled overtime in the rain today in an effort to complete by Tuesday the installation of a $40,000 steel fence designed to "safety-proof" a hazardous section of the Cross County Parkway.

VIENNA, Sept. 21 (Reuters) -- The International Atomic Energy Agency -- the sixty-nine-member United Nations body charged with speeding practical cooperation in atomic affairs -- begins its second general assembly here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The United States Information Agency is increasing cultural programs in a long-range effort toward creating better understanding of this country overseas.

Discussing the deterioration of the Government bond market that set in shortly after the Treasury's financing operations of June 15, a highly influential monthly review published by a leading New York bank recently indulged in this passing observation:
Southern workers are moving "gradually, but steadily, toward an effectively integrated labor movement."
PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Latest reports by the Ministry of Labor show a reduction of working hours in France.
The city has retained private consultants to design an all-purpose lighting pole to replace the sixty-four varieties now in use on its streets.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (AP) -It became increasingly clear to grain futures traders last week that prices had become tightly wedged in a narrow range between the extremes of bullish and bearish influences.

VIENNA, Sept. 21 (AP) -Dr. Linus Pauling, California scientist and foe of nuclear weapons tests, said tonight that Britain had given him permission to return there after a dispute over how long he could stay.
MERCURY, Nev., Sept. 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission briefly lifted today the secrecy surrounding one of its most important activities: making sure atomic bombs do not go off accidentally.
The railroad dismissed Fred for drunkenness. He became a bum, a petty thief. He went to jail. His six children were ashamed. His wife was broken-hearted and destitute.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Government said today foreign countries added more than one billion dollars to their gold and dollar holdings as a result of dealings with the United States in the second quarter of this year.
The membership of the Fair Housing Practice Panel authorized by the Sharkey-Brown-Isaacs Law was announced by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

Now that the Eighty-fifth Congress has adjourned without taking action on any of the bills introduced to widen coverage of the Fair Labor Standards Act, renewed efforts to gain these improvements in the law must begin as soon as Congress reconvenes.
BORDENTOWN, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Two persons were killed on the rain-drenched Jersey Turnpike near here today when their car crashed head-on into a bus.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Don Mackenzie won the closest International Class race of the season on Long Island Sound today.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The stock "boomlet" here continued in a firm and confident market last week. Share and bond indexes set new highs for the year.

LILLE, France, Sept. 21 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle said here this evening that a massive majority vote in favor of the proposed new national Constitution was needed to demonstrate French unity to the world.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 21 -Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas disputed today the declaration of sixty-one Little Rock lawyers that his private-school plan was illegal.

BRITISH pageantry was the attraction at Madison Square Garden Saturday evening. The Regimental Band of the Grenadier Guards and the massed pipers and Highland dancers of the Scots Guards appeared here as part of a tour that will take them to fifty-five cities of the United States and Canada.

BEVERLY SOMACH, violinist who made her debut in 1947 as a 12-year-old prodigy, and who has played numerous concert performances and solo recitals since, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

READY-TO-WEAR clothes never meant more to a woman than right now. One day, the temperature soars to midsummer level; the next day, it is overcast, with threatening storm clouds. Even though it is fall by the calendar, the feeling is one of transition and what to wear right now, instead of two months from now, can be a problem.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile has said today to be on the verge of a success that might put the United States ahead of the Soviet Union in the race for missile superiority.
BOSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Ted Williams added a chapter to his stormy baseball career today when he hurled his bat into the box seats and it struck a woman on the head.

PARIS, Sept. 21 -- Widespread and apparently reliable reports that Premier de Gaulle had dismissed independence and integration as equally impossible solutions of the Algerian problem created new interest here today in the Premier's plans.

BELFAST, Sept. 21 -- The Irish linen industry, despite its world-famous product, is in a bad slump. Factories are closing, and about 17 per cent of the labor force is idle. Production of linen cloth is at only 56 per cent of the pre-1939 level.

Increased expenses pushed the gross margins of food chains up to 20.4 per cent of the sales dollar for 1957, while net profit remained stable at 1.4 per cent. In 1956, the gross margin was 19.5 per cent and in 1955, 18.1 per cent.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- Acting on urgent instructions from home, the United States Embassy tried virtually at dawn today to return to the Russians the letter that Premier Khrushchev sent President Eisenhower on Friday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)--William A. McDonnell, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, urged today that big industrial unions, such as the United Auto Workers, be broken up.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The National League pennant - winning Milwaukee Braves arrived home tonight to the cheers of a crowd of 20,000. It was wild confusion at General Mitchell airport when the Braves' chartered four-engined plane touched down on the flight from Cincinnati, where they had clinched their second straight pennant a few hours before.
A 72-year-old Bronx woman was killed in a four-car accident on the Major Deegan Expressway yesterday. Three other persons were injured.
The Negro woman who stabbed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a Harlem department store Saturday was sent to Bellevue Hospital yestreday for mental observation.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 21 -- The 1959 budget introduced here last week discloses a record expenditure of 9,027,000,000 guilders against 8,552,000,000 far 1958. Revenues are put at 7,430,000,000 against 7,412,000,000, leaving a record deficit of 1,597,000,000 guilders.
A city survey has found that Manhattan's new private rental apartments continue to be designed for small, well-to-do families.
LITTLE FALLS, N. J., Sept. 21 -- Unlike some hobbyists, Anthony Wester finds materials for his craftsmanship easy to get. All he needs is a discarded bottle.
SAMMY KAYE and his orchestra began a new weekly series of television programs Saturday night over Channel 7.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 21 -- If Casey Stengel is a trifle bewildered by the manner in which his Yankees are preparing themselves for the world series, it must be conceded that the Bombers are pursuing a novel course.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- If he is successful in ousting the mutual savings banks from the American Bankers Association, his next target will be New England commercial banks "controlled" by the savings banks, Arthur T. Roth said here today. Mr. Roth is president of the Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Franklin Square, L. I.
The Police Athletic League awarded a desk set yesterday to an 11-year-old boy from Queens Village who risked his life last year to thrust a girl from the path of an automobile.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- Herman D. Kenin, president of the American Federation of Musicians, warned today that his organization would take action against "unfair movies, unfair records or the sponsors of unfair television or radio shows."
Professional jockeys get into race-riding in many ways. In the case of Lawrence (Larry) Adams, the break-in involved a switch from steaks to stakes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Republican National Committee issued today its official speaker's handbook for the fall Congressional campaign.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21--Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev told the Soviet people today that their school system would be completely overhauled to teach youngsters respect for physical labor and to prepare them from the first grade for "useful work."
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Late selling clipped away about half of a broad general advance in soybean prices today on the Board of Trade. Most of the grains moved along within narrow price ranges.

Tin from Communist China is behind the recent Soviet success in disorganizing the London tin market, newly published Soviet foreign trade statistics indicate. The data appear to make clear that the Soviet Union would have experienced a tin deficit rather than being able to export the metal if it had not been for rapidly growing Chinese tin exports to the Soviet Union in recent years.

PASSAIC, N. J., Sept. 22 -- A special citizens' committee studying the public school curriculum here resigned today. The group of thirteen civic and professional leaders cited the "creation of a climate in which we cannot function effectively."
The 1959 DeSoto has been face-lifted enough to distinguish it from last year's models.
PARIS, Sept. 22 -- Paris airport authorities have given conditional authorization for Pan American World Airways to begin trans-Atlantic jet service next month.
The Department of Hospitals specified yesterday that two physicians would have to certify the need before birth control therapy could be given in any case.

A cold front that passed out to sea with unexpected speed (twenty-five to thirty miles an hour) caused the light airs that made yesterday's America's Cup match an unsatisfactory drift. It also set the wind forecasts of the United States Weather Bureau to naught.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers appeared today to be making progress toward a new agreement covering the company's 70,000 workers.
Investors in Government securities are playing a waiting game this week. They ponder what the Treasury will do to raise from $3,000,000,000 to $4,000,000,000 in its first cash borrowing of the fall.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee accused former President Harry S. Truman today of what it called five distortions and falsehoods in three campaign speeches last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Johnny Lee, a former Yale basketball star, today decided against taking a fling at professional basketball with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association.

JOHN KEATS (no pseudonym) is a former Washington newspaper man with a lively style and a penchant for seizing on questions of intense public interest and writing breezy, fact-packed, opinionated books about them. His "The Crack in the Picture Window" exposed the less-than-Utopian life of our mushrooming suburban housing developments.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 22 -- A program to start a two-year community college in Suffolk County next September was proposed here today. The school would have an initial enrollment of 500. an initial enrollment of 500.
Station WCBS-TV has rescheduled an interview with Leopold Stokowski for tonight at 10:30 o'clock.
HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Dartmouth was bolstered by the return of five backs today as Coach Bob Blackman began preprations for Saturday's opener against Lafayette.
Nelson A. Rockefeller suggested yesterday that Governor Harriman was doing public penance for an earlier show of independence from Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany.
Steel production dipped slightly last week, not quite reaching the amount scheduled. This week, however, it is expected to climb again to a new high for the year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A sheaf of hotel bills, an oriental rug and other gifts from a fellow New Englander toppled Sherman Adams from the second most powerful post in the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Thurman A. Whiteside, a Miami lawyer, testified today that he had turned down a $10,000 fee from National Airlines in the Miami TV Channel 10 case because it might cause "embarrassment" to himself and his friend Richard A. Mack.

J. Weingarten, Inc., is planning to raise $6,500,000 through a public sale of sinking fund debentures to be managed in mid-October by underwriters headed by White, Weld Co., and Moroney, Beissner Co. The transaction would mark the first national distribution of the company's securities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Communist party should still be required to register with the Government as a tool of Moscow, in the opinion of Francis A. Cherry of the Subversive Activities Control Board.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Israel is beginning to receive a small but steady flow of weapons from Britain, France and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Miss U. S. I, a Detroit hydroplane, today won the President's Cup Regatta by turning on the brakes instead of the gas. Loafing safely to last place in the final heat, she collected enough points to take home the trophy.
Full-scale educational television became a reality here yesterday. Five hours and twenty minutes of special programs were beamed to schools and homes in the metropolitan area.

Directors of Stop Shop, Inc., yesterday voted a five-for-four split of the common stock to be effected by issuing one additional share for each four held. The distribution will be made on Nov. 24 to holders of record of Nov. 3.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 22 -- Premier Djuanda announced today the postponement of Indonesia's parliamentary elections, scheduled for next September, for a maximum of a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- In his dignified resignation from the White House tonight, Sherman Adams said he would remain on the job long enough to permit an orderly transition of his duties to somebody else.

An exhibit of British imports, both modern and antique, was opened yesterday with the rousing music of bagpipes and a tea. During Lord Taylor's "British Fortnight" English merchandise will be offered in forty - six departments of the store and its six suburban branches.

South Carolina is planning to borrow $13,000,000 in the public market to finance the construction of public schools. The offering is slated for Oct. 15. The bonds will be full-faith-and-credit obligations of the state.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- A University of Chicago gynecologist said today that tests had been developed that could practically eliminate cervical uterine cancer.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 -- Beirut, now living under an around - the - clock curfew that went into effect yesterday, was virtually a dead city today, except for feverish defense preparations being made in some sectors.
Mayor Wagner agreed yesterday with the contention of Robert Moses that the city was committed to construct a $260,000,000 bridge between Brooklyn and Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations reached an agreement today with a union of its organizers. The signing was set for tomorrow.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 22 -- A bid by a young Israeli farmer for legal recognition as heir to the fortune of Nuri as-Said, late Premier of Iraq, received a setback in a Tel Aviv court today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Officials of two large gas distributors backed today a proposed merger of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating shook scores of hands on the sidewalks of Harlem yesterday afternoon in his campaign for United States Senator.
MONTREAL, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and Australia protested the United States import restrictions today.

George Abbott has found a new collaborator. He is John Allen, who doubles as actor and assistant stage manager of "Drink to Me Only," which Mr. Abbott is directing for a Broadway premiere on Oct. 8 at the Fifty-fourth Street (Adelphi) Theatre.
ROSYTH, Scotland, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The fish war between British fishermen and Iceland has settled down to a fairly pleasant routine, with time out for tea and fraternization with the enemy frequent.

The foreign ministers of all twenty-one American republics begin a two-day conference in Washington today. It fits into the new picture of a general review and reappraisal of hemispheric policies in which the United States is taking an active part. The realization of the need for new policies came as a result of Vice President Nixon's experiences on his South American trip in May.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Arthur S. Flemming deplored today the closing of some public schools in the integration crisis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Mrs. Sherman Adams sat alone at home tonight and watched her husband tell the nation on television he was quitting as President Eisenhower's chief assistant.
FASHION may accomplish what force failed to do in Ireland; that is, abolish the wearin' o' the green.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Sol Lesser Productions is looking for a new athletic type of actor to succeed Gordon Scott as hero of the Tarzan adventures.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The United States and Britain signed an agreement here today to prolong the Fulbright exchange fellowships for another ten years.
AUBURN, Ala., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- A 60-year-old retired Air Force general swapped his star for a freshman's beanie today as he registered at Alabama Polytechnic Institute to study farming.
WASHINGTON Sept. 22 -- President Eisenhower imposed quotas today cutting lead and zinc imports by one-third.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Ted Williams was fined a nominal $50 today by the American League president, Will Harridge, for letting his bat get out of hand along with his temper.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, was reported today to have negotiated a tentative agreement calling for a wage increase of $1.20 a day for about 180,000 soft coal miners, plus 10 cents a ton increase in the welfare fund royalty and other improvements. The welfare fund royalty is now 40 cents a ton.

In 1955 I was one of three Senators who voted against the Formosan Resolution under whose terms our Government now claims a commitment to defend Quemoy and Matsu. In 1955, when this resolution was before the Senate, the Administration denied that there was such a commitment.

The Board of Elections rejected yesterday an independent nominating petition for Benjamin J. Davis, former Communist City Councilman. Mr. Davis had sought to run for State Senate in the Twenty-first District (Harlem) as the Peoples' Rights candidate.

Two men experienced in real estate and administration were appointed yesterday to top posts in the Bureau of Real Estate. The bureau is under going reorganization as the result of disclosures and a wave of criticism several months ago.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 22 -- Two Soviet engineers inspected American voting machines at the Brussels World's Fair after Marshal Kliment Y, Voroshilov, Soviet President, had manifested suspicion that the machines were rigged, it was disclosed today.

The Grand Union Company, the nation's second largest food chain, operating 434 stores, plans to acquire the Sunrise Supermarket Corporation, which operates twenty-eight food markets in Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

The problem facing youth today, said the gentleman on the train (a man who had the courage of his generalizations), is whether or not one should be a specialist. Everyone knows that it is more fun and more intellectually bracing to be a generalist, using the word to mean a man who takes the universe as his field and doesn't burrow into a tunnel.
GENEVA, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Japan demanded a revision today of the International Sugar Agreement to make it more beneficial to the sugar-importing nations.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 22 -- Little Rock teenagers attended class today in haircurlers and pajamas.

The New York Exchange for Woman's Work will benefit from the Jan. 6 performance of "The Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Jessie Lanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
Two hundred and fifty Columbia and Barnard College freshmen lent a hand yesterday in the city's hospitals and community centers.
A major Liberian-flag ship operator appears to have turned the tables on British critics of "flags of convenience."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Sherman Adams resigned his White House post today under heavy political pressure.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -- Time ran out on Columbia today before the United States defender could put a second victory over the British challenger Sceptre into the official record of their match for the America's Cup.

The "Harvey" in public performance last night and in the press preview on Sunday afternoon were so similar that further comment would only be redundant. Reviewing in advance of a program obviously has passed a first tentative test and must be considered seriously.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The State Department made public today the note the United States Embassy delivered to Soviet authorities in Moscow yesterday seeking information of the fate of American airmen whose plane crashed in Soviet territory Sept. 2.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 22 -- The Communist party in Venezuela has achieved a degree of respectability and influence unmatched in the Western Hemisphere. But prospects that communism will dominate this oil-rich country in any foreseeable future appear remote.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 22 -- Charitable gifts exceeding $2,970,000 were made by the will of Mrs. Frieda Schiff Warburg. The will was filed for probate here today in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. The estate was valued at $9,100,000.

A water main break south of Washington Square knocked out 600 telephone subscriber lines yesterday. The break threatened thirty-four trunk cables connecting the New York telephone company's central offices in lower Manhattan.
Dr. Bernard Schwartz, the man who started the Sherman Adams controversy, said yesterday that the case showed the need for a far-reaching investigation of Government agencies.

A Queens civic leader charged yesterday that Long Island Rail Road stations on the Ozone Park spur had become "stamping grounds for vandals and hoodlums, lovers' lanes, criminal hangouts and battlegrounds for teen-age gang wars."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- At a farewell luncheon for White House aide Maxwell M. Rabb a few months ago, Sherman Adams sat by Mr. Rabb as the latter told the audience how wrong the observers were who had found Mr. Adams lacking in warmth.
Governor Harriman said emphatically yesterday that New York State had kept pace in the competition with other states for new business.
YONKERS, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Solid South won the feature pace by one length over Adios Senator tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Time for the mile was 2:03. Frisco Rebel was third.

WHETHER hunters like it or not, the shooting preserve is going to figure more in their plans this year than last, and more next year than this year. As the number of hunters increases the amount of open hunting land decreases. The preserve is taking up some of the slack.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The R-N Corporation said today that a new method of reducing iron ore that might cut steel production costs drastically was ready for commercial developments.
The eighteen-story east wall of the Pierre Hotel was raised one sixty-fourth of an inch yesterday without disturbing guests in the 700-room hotel.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Ernest Green, lone Negro graduate of Little Rock's Central High School last spring, began his college career quietly today.
BOTH as play and performance, "Jackknife," which opened at the Royale Playhouse last evening, is generally unfinished. It does not need polishing so much as it needs sandblasting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today it wanted to hear from all United States concerns that had been unable to transfer to this country dollars received in payment for merchandise shipped to Turkey.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 22 -- The Argentine peso tumbled on the free market today. When the exchange houses closed it took fifty-one pesos to buy a United States dollar. This was the lowest quotation reached by the peso in its steady decline of recent months.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The man who was replaced as the professional captain of the Sceptre, Britain's hope in the America's Cup Yachting races, said today he would be surprised if the trim, white craft won a single race from the United States yacht Columbia.

In August, 1939, Nazi Foreign Minister Ribbentrop flew to Moscow and on the night of Aug. 23 signed the Hitler-Stalin pact which sounded the signal for the second World War. Initiated by Stalin this pact not only partitioned Poland and other East European countries between the two war conspirators but also made certain, after the British-French guarantees to Poland, that Hitler's attack on Poland would mean war between him and Britain and France.

NEWARK, Sept. 22 -- Two employes of the Central Railroad of New Jersey testiifed today that they had tested the mechanical equipment on the train that plunged into Newark Bay. They reported that they had found no defects in the inspection before the run.

With two exceptions, a woman should never prefix her signature by Mrs. or Miss. Her Proper signature, whether married or single, is Joan Williams. Underneath this or to the left, she may sign Mrs. Harold Williams in parentheses, if she is married.
VIENIA, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- The International Atomic Energy Agency opened its second general assembly today amid reports if might become the "police force" for any ban on nuclear weapons tests.

The Hanover Bank will move a large part of its operations from the Wall Street area to the new thirty-story building to be constructed at 350 Park Avenue by Uris Brothers. The structure will be known as the Hanover Bank building.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- The United States charged today that the Chinese Communists were "rapidly shooting themselves and shooting the world" out of a chance to settle the situation in the Taiwan Strait "as it should be settled."
ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- The Independent-Socialist party will have a double opportunity to defend its right to a place on the ballot in the November election.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 22 (Reuters) -- British officials today released 130 political prisoners -- eighty-nine Greek men, eleven Greek women and thirty Turkish men -- it was learned authoritatively tonight.
The Husky Oil Company set a record of $29,404,662 in sales and operating revenues for the fiscal year ended June 30, but earnings declined sharply, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

There are many reasons why retail toy volume has jumped from $196,000,000 to $1,250,000,000 in the last twenty years. The more than sixfold increase is attributed to population gains, increased incomes and improvements in quality.

We greet with enthusiasm the first large-scale public-supported program, in this area, for using television as a medium of instruction. There is a big opportunity here to put television to work to aid in education and in so doing to justify itself. It can be a medium of immense good and has often been just that. It can also be prostituted into an instrument that can undermine our most important social values.
State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan yesterday postponed until Thursday a hearing on the addition of six dockers to a hiring list.

Cornell and Utah, St. Joseph's of Philadelphia and Syracuse, Dayton and Niagara and Holy Cross and St. John's have been paired in first-round games for the Eastern College Athletic Conference's seventh annual Holiday Basketball Festival.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 22 (AP) -- O. A. Knight of Denver, president of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union, was greeted with a demand for his impeachment as the union opened its national convention today.

Two college football coaches disagreed yesterday with one official's thought -- or was it his hope? -- that the administration of the changed rules would not prove too difficult for the referees, umpires, field judges, etc.
The rumored settlement of the fight for control of E. L. Bruce Company was confirmed yesterday.

A move was made in the Kings County Surrogate's Court yesterday to have a $13,163 Brooklyn estate turned over to two New York State charities instead of being bequeathed to the State Bank of the Soviet Union.

The New York Life Insurance Company, in its largest single mortgage commitment of this year, signed contracts yesterday for a $12,650,000 loan for the construction of a nineteen-story interchurch center. The center will be the first national Protestant interdenominational headquarters building in the country.
BOSTON, Sept. 22 -- The nuclear submarine Skate received her first American plaudits today for her exploits under the Arctic ice pack.

A man surprised a burglar in a neighbor's apartment yesterday and was critically injured when he and the burglar rolled out a third-floor window during a struggle. The thief saved himself by grabbing a fire escape, and fled.
BEN METIR, Tunisia, Sept. 22. (AP). -- President Habib Bourguiba declared today that Tunisia recognized the Government of rebel Algeria as a means of holding on to it for the West.
Many persons prominent in the social and diplomatic worlds will attend the gala opening night Oct. 2 of the New York Philharmonic's 1958-59 season in Carnegie Hall.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 22 -- Roman Catholic charitable organizations were called upon today to help salvage the "forsaken poor" who are living out their lives on the "skid rows" of America.

Stockholders of Gulf States Land and Industries, Inc., approved at a special meeting yesterday a proposal to sell the sugar company's production and by-products facilities at Raceland, La., to the South Coast Corporation. They also approved a proposal under which Gulf States would acquire 80 per cent of the Capital stock of Colmar Oil Company, Ltd.
PROVIDENCE, Sept. 22 -- Alva Kelley took the telephone call in his office and a wry smile crossed his face as he listened.

The Securities and Exchange Commission moved yesterday to block a Florida real estate stock promotion led by Arthur Vining Davis, retired head of the Aluminum Company of America. But the effort quickly ran into a snag.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Julius H. Miner dismissed today action against most of the defendants in a $4,000,000 libel suit brought by Samuel Insull Jr., son of the late utilities leader.
Employes of concerns at 380 Madison Avenue will give blood today at the Biltmore Hotel, Forty-third Street and Madison Avenue, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- British music critics today praised the vitality of William Steinberg's first concert as conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra.
Mrs. Mary Roberts Rinehart, the novelist, died in her sleep last night in her apartment at 635 Park Avenue. She was 82 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

Commuter groups appeared before the Public Service Commission yesterday to protest plans of the New York Central Railroad to close its station at Valhalla, N. Y. They also protested the curtailment of Central facilities at Purdy's, near North Salem, N. Y.
While freight traffic of the nation's railroads during July lagged well below the 1957 level by 21 per cent, truck loadings were almost as high as they were a year ago.
MONTREAL, Sept. 22 -- Canada and Britain announced plans today for increased aid to under-developed members of the British Commonwealth. Both countries had increased trade in mind.

ALBANY, Sept. 22 -- Assemblyman Malcolm Wilson declared tonight that he was the principal campaign target of Governor Harriman because he had forced the Governor to accept retroactivity as a principle of Social Security coverage for public employes.

SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 20 -- El Salvador is preparing to export coffee withheld from shipment during the last crop year. An accord reached at Mexico City by the seven major Latin American producing nations, which went into effect Nov. 1, expires at the end of this month.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, Sept. 23 -- Chinese Nationalist leaders conferring here with United States military commanders were reported yesterday to have argued for United States acquiescence in a Nationalist air attack on Communist coastal guns blockading Quemoy Island.
The condition of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took a sudden turn for the worse yesterday when he developed pneumonia.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Unless banks can attract additional capital, other financial institutions will continue to outpace them in growth, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned here today.
SPECULATING on the nature of the universe is not only the province of philosophers. Painters and poets also often key their imagining powers to the search for an image of the universe.

A new style in men's clothing and lighter-weight fabrics and medium shades for spring and summer of 1959 could make the coming season one of the best for the industry. This was indicated yesterday by Michael Daroff, president of H. Daroff Sons, Inc., and the House of Worsted-tex, Inc., producers of men's clothing.
Whether the city administration will seek a tax on off-track betting on horse races is likely to depend in part on the public's reaction to the proposal.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- American schools will never again be left so completely to educators as they have been, Roman Catholic teaching leaders predicted tonight.

A RECIPE for last-of-the-season corn and fresh tomatoes has been contributed by Mrs. Otto F. Delitsch of Brooklawn, N. J. Mrs. Delitsch writes that it is a favorite formula that she herself "compounded."
Signs of an upturn in advertising are continuing.

A stringent set of rules for the conduct of legalized bingo was announced yesterday by the State Lottery Control Commission. The regulations are designed to keep the game out of the hands of racketeers.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 22 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today expressed "a feeling of alarm because our country's recreational facilities are lagging far behind the needs of the people.''
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 22 -- Gov. LeRoy Collins announced today a plan to speed school integration where feasible and protect against "improvident, forced desegregation."

The resignation of Sherman Adams from his post as Assistant to the President comes in belated deference to the fact that he failed to meet the highest standards of official conduct demanded by the American public and frequently proclaimed by both the President and himself.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Peiping radio charged that a United States plane "intruded over the Chinese mainland" today.

WARSAW, Sept. 22 -- United States and Chinese Communist diplomats held another negotiating session today without reaching any decision on fixing a cease-fire in the Strait of Taiwan. However, the talks have not reached the stage where either side is ready to suspend them as a lost cause.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Some weeks after the Conference of the Chief Justices of State Courts heard, and by a vote of 36 to 8 approved, a report on Federal-state relations as affected by judicial decisions Attorney General Rogers addressed the National Conference on Citizenship.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 24 points (15 cents to $1.20 a bale) yesterday, with old crop months showing the most strength.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The foreign ministers of the Latin-American republics arrived here tonight for two days of informal talks on improving inter-American political and economic cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Director of the United States Information Agency told a House subcommittee today that this country was being "out-gunned" by the radio propaganda facilities of the Soviet Union and its satellites and friends.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -- If today's course had been windward-leeward instead of triangular, Columbia might well have won.
The Seafarers International Union announced yesterday that it was planning legal action against the McCormick Shipping Corporation of Miami, operators of the Yarmouth, Panamanian-flag cruise ship.

The Soviet bloc arose in its blustering majesty yesterday to object to a single item in the seventy-two which were proposed in the General Assembly's agenda. Hungary did not, of course, care for this item, for it called for a discussion of the butchery of Hungarian patriots and the suppression of Hungarian liberties by foreign troops called in by Hungarian traitors.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -- Mr. Adams came to the temporary office of President Eisenhower here today obviously determined on the course he was about to take.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 -- Governor Harriman named Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner under former Republican Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, to a $15,000-a-year post on the State Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board today.

Your article in The Times of Sept. 7 quoting Robert Moses' statement that Title I projects were not meant to provide housing for middle-income groups suggests the question that both municipal officials and others have skirted up to this point.

Bowling brings out the "killer instinct" in some persons when they first pick up a ball. As a result, the first lessons for new bowlers often must be spent on attempts to slow the approach.

Sports as an influence for goodwill in a troubled world was the theme of a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Given by the People-to-People Sports Committee, the dinner was attended by about 800 leaders of sport, including more than a score of past and present champions.

ONCE upon a time there was a roughneck umpire named Bill Guthrie, a salty character whose language was laced with such low-life pronunciations as "dese, does and dem." One day he called out Babe Ruth on strikes. The Babe ordinarily showed little emotion at such misdemeanors but this time he impetuously tossed his bat up in the air.
PARIS, Sept. 22 -- The French Government protested today to the Governments of Morocco, Tunisia and Libya against their recognition of the new Algerian rebel Government.
DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The auto industry's 1959 models are coming out in increasing volume.

Sintering facilities with an output of 2,400 tons a day have been placed into operation by the Armco Steel Corporation at a plant in Ashland, Ky. Through the sintering process iron ore and other raw materials are formed into a solid mass.
BILSTON, England, Sept. 22 (AP) -The girls played a man-sized game of soccer here over the week-end. When it was over, the teams vowed never to play each other again.

The fourteen-story apartment house at 300 West End Avenue has been resold by Klausner Associates, operators and investors, who purchased the property recently. The sale was made to a syndicate organized by Chambers Kantrowitz, attorneys.
The first of a series of events celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary year of the Academy American Poets will be a theatre benefit on the evening Oct. 22.

ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER DUANE OFF NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -There was one spectator at sea for the second race of the America's Cup series today who could not lose no matter how the race came out. He was Capt. Franklin Ratsey, chairman of the board of Ratsey and Lapthorn, Ltd., of Gosport, England.
Strength developed briefly and then subsided on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, intimated today that the union might call a strike against the General Electric Company before the Oct. 1 contract deadline.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept 22 -- Two unreconciled groups of parents began today to register their children for makeshift private instruction starting Wednesday in the basement of homes, in lodges, in an old schoolhouse and other places they have yet to find.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Two major league strikeout records were set by Philadelphia pitchers tonight as the Phillies swept a twilight-night double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The school integration dispute generated a new drive today to change Senate rules so that anti-civil rights filibusters can be prohibited

The treasurer of a credit union active among railway mail clerks shot himself dead yesterday morning in Pennsylvania Station. The credit union's books were being audited by the State Banking Department.

THE New York State Education Department appeared to be off to an auspicious start in television' yesterday. Its initial day of educational video, running from 9:50 A. M. to 3:30 P. M. over Channel 11, reflected remarkable production aplomb for a project put together in only a few weeks.
