The advertising business is the subject of at least four novels published this season and written by authors who have had experience in that field. Two weeks ago Simon Schuster published "The Admen," by Shepherd Mead, which dealt with the personalities in an agency.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Top Republicans, led by Vice President Richard M. Nixon, called the resignation of Sherman Adams tonight a tragic loss to the Government.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A New York University doctor who pioneered in treatment of palsy today described an operation in which the patient spends twenty-four hours with a needle in his brain.
United Air Lines has removed United Nations emblems from its planes in response to protests of various individuals and organized groups.

VAN BUREN, Ark., Sept. 22 -- Eight Negro students returned today to Van Buren High School. Threats of a walkout by white students were not carried out. There were only minor taunts and hard looks as the Negroes went to school for the first time in more than two weeks.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The Soviet Government sharpened today the tone of its reaction to President Eisenhower's rejection of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's letter to him about the Far East crisis.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Stock market prices advanced briskly in active trading early today but a late reaction cut many gains.

FORT LEE, N. J., Sept. 22 -- This community's Mayor and Council decided today to levy assessments against those parts of lands held by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission and the Port of New York Authority not actually used by them.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Senate-Rackets Committee "never found any crooks in our union," the president of the United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum and Plastic Workers of America said today.
ROME, Sept. 22 -- Pope Pius XII told a group of philosophers from many countries today that there was no incompatibility or conflict between philosophy and religion.
Gallant Man, one of the candidates for horse - of - the - year honors, has popped a splint in his left foreleg and will not start in Saturday's $100,000 added Woodward Stakes.

SARANAC, N. Y., Sept. 22. -- The New York State Educational Conference Board recommended today that the 1959 Legislature work to decentralize school districts in New York City and other metropolitan centers.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 22 -- Political posters, bearing the ever-smiling image of this or that popular hero, are the public opinion poll in the bazaars of Baghdad.

New orders for machine tools rose last month from the July level. With two exceptions, in April and July, orders have increased in every month of this year. The volume of new orders, however, remains well below that of 1957.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made its first loan in the Federation of Malaya yesterday.

Directors of the A. IV[. 13yers Company, producev oZ wrought iron, declared the first dividend on the common stock n more than four years yesterday. They voted a quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share and a fiscal yearend extra of 40 cents a hare.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 22 -- A political scandal engulfed the West German Chancellery today with the announcement that Hans Kilb, former personal secretary to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, had been arrested on suspicion of being involved in bribery.

The autumn color in the trees reaches its climax in areas that have clear, sunny days, such as those typical of New England in September and October. The sugars and acids left in the leaves by the retreat of the sap need a degree of oxidation to achieve full brilliance.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The number of states and territories with programs for mentally retarded children has grown from four to forty- four in the last three years.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- There was an uproar in Parliament today on the issue of fair play for the Communists under circumstances in which they happen to be suspected of foul play on a grand scale.

Cocoa futures were lower early in the session on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot September position fell almost 1 cent a pound. Early liquidation was induced by the issuance of 141 notices, most of which circulated until about 1 P. M.
THERE can be no ifs, ands or buts about it: The high waistline must be here to stay.
Two ominous warnings on taxation made Page 1 news for New Yorkers yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will ask the General Assembly to authorize an increase in the working capital fund from $22,000,000 to $30,000,000. His budget message on 1959 requirements, circulated today, says the increase is "needed urgently."

URBANA, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Although Gov. Orval E. Faubus views outside accrediting of schools in Arkansas as unimportant, a North Central Association official today indicated that the loss of accreditation could be serious.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, and Duncan Sandys, British Minister of Defense, today opened three days of discussions of military topics of mutual interest to Britain and the United States.

As a resident of New York City I am disturbed at the reports that the Metropolitan Regional Council is being considered as the appropriate agency to undertake a solution of the metropolitan region's commuter rail problem.
Darien, Conn., will be on view historically on Oct. 4 when the community is host to the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Larger Federal, state and local budgets to protect the public from radiation hazards were advocated today by the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -The post-mortem on today's uncompleted America's Cup race showed that both skippers were in there slugging to keep up the good fight even when they were sure it was hopeless to think that they could finish within the time limit.

Columbia University's 1958 Loubat Prizes have been awarded to the late Douglas Southall Freeman for "George Washington, a Biography," and to Henry A. Pochmann for "German Culture in America, 1600-1900."
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22 -- Sceptre had the benefit of some race practice in light weather with Columbia today.
TIZI OUZOU, Algeria, Sept. 22 -- The French Army said today it had discovered mass graves containing the bodies of 400 nationalist fighters killed by order of their own commander.

Following are the texts of an address by Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, from Washington, as recorded by The New York Times, and a letter by President Eisenhower to Mr. Adams from Newport, R. I:

The White House "request" for free television and radio time for Sherman Adams to announce his resignation as Presidential Assistant was decidedly ill - advised. The privilege of commandeering the nation's broadcast facilities should be employed only in matters of major national urgency, not for the Administration's houseeking difficulties.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Five major sporting goods companies and six of their officers were fined in United States District Court today after pleading no contest to Government antitrust charges.
A Children's Court order remanding Melvin Nimer Jr. to Bellevue Hospital for mental examination was terminated yesterday.
An 18-year-old girl was found raped and strangled to death yesterday when a collie dog being walked at 8:30 A. M. began barking in a lot near Sutphin Boulevard and 116th Road, South Jamaica, Queens.

The recent manifestations of hostility to the United States in various Latin-American countries call for certain measures to improve our relations with the peoples of the Southern Hemisphere. Among them are the following:
Barry Sullivan has notified the producers of "Goldilocks" of his desire to withdraw from the show because he "feels uncomfortable" in his first musical stage assignment.
Motors, steels and American Telephone yesterday led the stock market to a new high for more than a year. The New York Times railroad and combined averages set peaks since Aug. 5, 1957.
Thirty days hath September, except on Sabena Belgian World Airlines' 1958 calendar, where it has thirty-one.

The Inauguration yesterday of Gen. Fouad Chehab as President of Lebanon was accompanied by fervent hopes as well as good wishes. If he can restore order and stability to that strife-torn country and set Lebanon on an independent and peaceful path, nearly everyone in and out of Lebanon will be happy.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 23 -- The Little Rock School Board asked a Federal court today to rule whether it could legally lease the city's four high schools to a private corporation.

SOMEWHERE IN ALGERIA, Sept. 20 -- Last night, after formation of the Provisional Government of Algeria was announced, the Algerian army struck out on a march for what was announced as its biggest offensive against the French.

Mary Martin has requested a postponement of the special television show that was planned for the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Dec. 12 from 10 to 11 P. M. It was to be produced by Leland Hayward and sponsored by Pontiac.

The first school days after a vacation are periods of adjustment for students and teachers alike. The former, accustomed during the summer to freedom from set routines, face the certainty of assignments taking time both in and out of school.

A store on the lobby floor of the new office building at 575 Lexington Avenue, corner of Fifty-first Street, has been leased by Men's Town and Country, clothier and haberdasher. The lessee, now using about 2,000 square feet at 594 Lexington Avenue at Fifty-second Street, will occupy 4,000 square feet of space at the new location, which has a store frontage of thirty-one feet on the avenue.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey announced yesterday a net profit for August of $659,616, after recording a credit of $752,799 in back mail pay. Without this award, the road said, it would have registered a net loss for the month of $93,183.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23 -- Ivy coaches are agreed that there will be better balance in the league this year in the strengthening of the second division teams, though Princeton, Dartmouth and Yale continue to stand out with Penn.

VIENNA, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The International Atomic Energy Agency rejected today a Soviet move to seat a Chinese Communist delegate in place of the Chinese Nationalist delegate at the organization's second general conference.
Following is the text of an address delivered in Washington last night by Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Paul M. Butler charged tonight that Sherman Adams' resignation as No. 1 assistant to President Eisenhower reflected "political expediency" arising from election fears of Republican candidates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- About 140 cases of paralytic polio were reported this year through Sept. 12 in persons who had received three Salk vaccine shots. Theodore J. Bauer, Assistant United States Surgeon General, said tonight.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Ed Bouchee broke a 4-4 tie with a two-run single in the seventh inning tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies gained a 6-5 victory over the newly-crowned Milwaukee Braves. It was the first major league triumph for Jim Owens.

The Titan intercontinental ballistic missile, the supersonic Convair B-58 bomber, and the Navy's Seamaster patrol plane face possible cancellation or curtailment in the 1960 fiscal year, beginning next July 1.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -Two Roman Catholic leaders -a Minnesota mother of ten and a Wisconsin high school teacher -- assailed American newspapers today for printing too much crime news. It corrupts the nation's youth, they declared.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 23 -- The nattily dressed young man, who was about to model suits, hats and topcoats, said he wouldn't fight Eddie Machen.

GEORGE GOBEL'S seasonal premiere, which occurred on Channel 4 last night, was rather conventional television variety relieved by scattered touches of engaging nonsense and a pleasant visit with Keeley Smith, the songstress of the husky voice and priceless dead pan.

The near-by cocoa positions were sharply lower in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The September contract went off the board very weak following the issuance of 164 notices. The October futures dropped the daily limit of 1 cent a pound.

THE three attributes that make for the success of a public dining room are much in evidence at the Envoy Restaurant, which opened a few months ago in the Socony-Vacuum Building, near Grand Central Terminal.

A state-wide referendum on a proposal to legalize and tax off-track betting on horse races was requested in a resolution adopted yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 22 to 2, with one abstention.

IT was apparent even before spring training that the Milwaukee Braves were far and away the best team in the National League. The logical assumption was that they would spread-eagle the field and clinch the pennant early, perhaps as early as the Yankees in the other league. The target date for both was in the neighborhood of Labor Day, a rather exclusive neighborhood for pennant clinching.

Two new films will open today at local theatres. "The Defiant Ones," a United Artists drama co-starring Tony Curtis and Sidney Poitier, is at the Victoria. Stanley Kramer directed and produced, from a screen play by Nathan E. Douglas and Harold Jacob Smith.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Thurman A. Whiteside contradicted today testimony given by Richard A. Mack, former Federal Communications Commissioner, to House investigators last spring.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- James R. Hoffa and two lieutenants railed against Senate rackets investigators and leaders of organized labor today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Federal courts face the biggest backlog in their history -- more than 75,000 cases. This gloomy report was given today by Warren Oiney 3d, director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. It was his first annual report on the state of the courts since he took office last January.
Soviet scientists say they have ground bone sawed from the skulls of live animals, mixed the powder with a penicillin solution to form a thick paste and used this to fill the skull holes.
The Johns-Manville Corporation plans a merger with the L-O-F Glass Fibers Company in an exchange of one share of its common stock for two and one-half shares of L-O-F.

YONKERS, Sept. 23 -- Holding off a stout bid by Meadow Lands in the stretch, Adie Rainbow, driven by Stanley Dancer, scored a nose victory in 2:02 3/5 in the $13,100 Dan Patch pace before 21,774 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

As the colleges and universities throughout the nation reopen this month, the acute problem of their expansion looms ever larger. In the past six years alone college enrollment has jumped 45 per cent, while in the next decade this heavy figure is expected to double.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Britain will not be deflected from her plan for administering Cyprus during the next seven years by the proposal from Archbishop Makarios, a qualified source said today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 23 -- Weather permitting -- and in the light of recent developments who is to say that it will -- Columbia and Sceptre will resume their contest for the America's Cup today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Nick Perry of Harrison and Mario Laureti, Darin (Conn.) professional, won the Westchester County Golf Association's amateur-pro team competition today at the Metropolis Country Club.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint in Federal District Court here yesterday charging Canadian Javelin, Ltd., and twenty-two other defendants with fraud and evasion of rules requiring registration of securities.

Stockholders of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Raiload will vote at a special meeting Oct. 17 on two proposed capital changes. The meeting will consider a plan to modify the preferred stock and a proposal to increase the authorized common stock as the last major step in clearing $114,214,673 of arreas on the 7 per cent preferred stock.
An irresistible "headache ball" and a voracious clam shovel are making a path through Washington Heights for the approach to the projected lower deck of the George Washington Bridge.
The runner-up for the most important pair title at stake in United States tournament bridge yesterday challenged the right of Charles H. Goren and Mrs. Helen Sobel to the title.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 22 -In a certain country district of Iraq, a traveler reports, the farmers are neglecting their autumnal tasks upon the soil.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation contended today that its earnings had "declined dangerously" since 1954.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The General Assembly decided today not to consider any proposal during the 1958 session to seat Communist China in the United Nations.

An experiment in diet that proved carrots superior to lobster is making the flamingo flock at the Bronx Zoo one of the most colorful in captivity. Since early this year, Dr. William G. Conway, curator of birds at the zoo, has been trying to prevent the process of fading that overtakes flamingos in zoos.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 -- A stay was denied today, pending appeal, of a lower court integration order for seventeen Negroes to enter the secondary schools of Norfolk, Va., next Monday.

You have published various worthwhile letters concerning the Far East crisis. There is, however, one element which I believe has not been discussed sufficiently -- bipartisan participation in decisions.

Prayers and sermons yesterday marked the beginning of Yom Kippur, the most sacred day of the Jewish year. Throughout the city Yom Kippur Eve services were held in synagogues and temples on the start of the High Holy Day, known as the Day of Atonement.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -The 400,000-member International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers resolved today to redouble its efforts to demolish its rival, the United Electrical Workers, independent.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Top seeded performers in both the men's and women's division in the sixty-ninth annual Pacific Coast tennis championships advanced today.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 24 -- Objections to Virginia's "massive resistance" to school integration were voiced here tonight by the local chapter of the League of Women Voters.

Bell Telephone Laboratories has announced the election of Dr. Hendrik W. Bode and Jack A. Morton as vice presidents, effective next Wednesday. The company conducts research and devolpment work for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company, Inc., a subsidiary of A.T. T.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 23 -- An insect that has defied extermination is destroying thousands of Red Pine trees surrounding reservoirs here and in Bridgeport.

A "sleeper" bill in the City Council that would permit the Mayor to delegate most of his document-signing power to subordinates was assailed yesterday as "preposterous" by the Council's Minority Leader, Stanley M. Isaacs.
SARANAC, N. Y., Sept. 23 -The Council of New York State School Superintendents voted unanimously today to condemn racial segregation in the schools of the South.
The Dec. 4 performance of "Goldilocks" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre will be a benefit for the Fountain House Foundation.
BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- Ted Williams again wielded his bat with devastating force tonight, but this time he did not let it leave the playing field. Instead, he used it exclusively on the Yankees.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 23 -- While most yatchsmen can undoubtedly tell a spinnaker from a Genoa jib, none of them here for the America's Cup race seemed to have any idea how the terms originated.

Directors of the Di Giorgio Fruit Corporation, at a meeting held yesterday in San Francisco, recommended a split in both Class A and B common stock and an extension of voting rights, now confined to the Class A stock, to Class B.

UNLESS you want to wake up some day to find your home mortgaged twice, your children living on peanut butter sandwiches and your husband drilling for oil in the backyard, stay away from the Emeric Partos fur collection at Bergdorf Goodman.

Sir David Eccles, President of Britain's Board of Trade, has announced that his country is planning a further reduction in its remaining barriers against dollar imports. Assured by the United States that the latter intended to pursue monetary policies that would reduce the possibility of further "runs" on sterling, Sir David declared that his country is prepared to make dollars available for more North American products than at any time since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -House investigators made public today allegations that a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission had been offered and had solicited bribes in a television channel case.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Paul C. Downs, a Springdale (Ark.) farmer bayonetted in an arm during last year's integration violence at Central High School, sued the Federal Government today for $5,000 damages for his wound.
CHANNEL 2 (Station WCBS-TV) made amends last night for an embarrassing error of omission.
Allegheny Airlines announced yesterday that it was ready to start affixing the United Nations emblem to its twenty-three aircraft.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 23 -- This city's oldest Roman Catholic charitable institution today is gaining national renown in the field of juvenile delinquency.

Directors of the Reading Company, a major carrier of anthracite and bituminous coal, took no action yesterday on declaring a dividend on the common stock. This was the first time in forty-five years that the board had not ordered a quarterly dividend.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The United States announcement had only a mild effect on London Metal Exchange prices today. The reaction among dealers and brokers was mixed.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 -Mexico did not know today just how much it was going to be affected by the United States quota, but there was general agreement that the result would be bad.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 23 -- A movement is under way to organize into a single group 75,000 railroad commuters from eleven counties west of the Hudson River.

The Josal Realty Corporation, represented by Edward H. Freiberger, attorney, has taken title to the ten-story office building at 188 Montague Street, running through to Remsen Street, in downtown Brooklyn. The ground floor, occupied until about two years ago by the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank, is vacant and will be modernized for store tenants.

TIZI-OUZOU, Algeria, Sept. 22 -- Great Kabylia, a mountainous department on the Algerian coast, where women go unveiled and men have a tradition of independence older than Algerian nationalism, presents a major problem for the authorities who are conducting the French constitutional referendum.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 23 -Governors of key Deep South states discounted today the possibility that a third party would be formed in the 1960 election campaign.
DETROIT Sept. 23 (AP) -Suits for $4,000,000 in damages were filed today against Robert F. Kennedy, the rackets committee counsel, by William Bufalino, president of Teamsters Local 985, and the local.

A new issue of $17,500,000 of bonds of Norway, payable in in United States dollars, is being offered for public subscription today by a syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., Kuhn, Loeb Co., Lazard Freres Co. and Smith, Barney Co.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -British missile experts have reported here on their progress in developing a long-range missile, powered with a solid fuel. This program is said to be far more advanced than projects in the United States for the ship-based Polaris and the land-based Minuteman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Pablo Casals, worldfamous 'cellist, who has not performed in the United States since 1928, agreed today to play in the General Assembly hall Oct. 24, United Nations Day.
GLOBE-TROTTING buyers at Gimbels have found that it is a small world. Some of the most exciting imports at this store come in infants' sizes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -An Assistant Secretary of State sought support from the mining industry today for President Eisenhower's move imposing import quotas on lead and zinc.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Austria appealed to her neighbor, Hungary, today to free the prisoners taken in the anti-Communist revolt of 1956.

Harold Annis of Chappaqua, N. Y., an executive of the Oxford Paper Company of New York, has a penchant for acquiring extra jobs, most of them full time, none of them with pay, but all of them interesting.
Corporate bonds of recent issue took the leadership in the bond market yesterday with the successful sale of $40,000,000 of first mortgage obligations of the Consumers Power Company.
SHENANDOAH, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP) -- About 150 students and five teachers defied their school board today and held classes in the legally closed West Mahanoy Township High School.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Three Princeton football players, including Capt. Fred Tiley, returned from the side-lines for light contact work today.

The thirty-fifth annual benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild of America will take place at the Nov. 4 performance at the Longacre Theatre of "The Pleasure of His Company," which is scheduled to open Oct. 22.
Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, disclosed yesterday that her department's policy on birth-control therapy was "similar to that recently recommended by the Board of Hospitals."
SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 23 -A group of war veterans went to court today to fight racial discrimination in the American Legion's 40 and 8 society.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23 -- The Fair Campaign Practices Committee rejected today a request by Joseph P. Kamp of Westport, Conn., that the committee grant him a hearing on charges of defamation made against him by some political leaders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Meade Alcorn said today that aggressive advocacy of "right-to-work laws" could hurt the Republican party.

Harvey Sorkin and Lawrence Herman, realty operators, have sold the building at 660 West 180th Street containing forty apartments and seven stores. The structure is at the southeast corner of Broadway. The buyer was a client of Duff Brown. The sellers acquired the building a year ago. It is assessed at $325,000.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- British anxieties about the Far East crisis appeared today to be focused increasingly upon the possible use of nuclear weapons by the United States against the Chinese Communist forces bombarding Quemoy.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was stabbed by a Negro woman Saturday, showed improvement yesterday at Harlem Hospital, where he has been recuperating.
The decision of the United States Government to impose quotas on imports of lead and zinc touched off world-wide protests yesterday. The reaction in this country was less emphalic.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 23 -- Steering clear of controversial issues and seeking identification with popular causes, Venezuela's Communist party is trying to sell itself as a respectable force in the national political life.
Queens College dedicated the new $3,500,000 Maurice Fitzgerald Gymnasium on its Flushing campus yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Dr. Florence Wilhelmina van Straten, the woman who has made clouds grow and vanish, was saved from the penurious fate of authors with a riddle put by her Dutch father.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 -- Minster of Trade Gordon Churchill told a news conference today that Canada regarded the quota system as "basically contrary to the principles of the trade agreement between Canada and the United States."

BATAVIA, N. Y., Sept. 23 -Nelson A. Rockefeller, Republican candidate for Governor, warned New York State's farmers tonight that they "can expect no help" from the present Democratic Administration. He said it was "subservient to Tammany interests."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Two physicians in Kansas City used electronic equipment today to diagnose heart conditions of three patients in Bethesda, Md.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 23 -- Leading Peruvians condemned the United States quotas today.

THE little Boston mackerel has been a lifesaver this season, not only for the bluefish fleet but also for the Long Island rowboat fishermen. Mackerel are all over the near-by ocean, and in many of the harbors, sounds and inlets of the North Shore.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles stressed to Latin-American foreign ministers today the measure of United States concern for inter-American relations. This concern, they said, is backed by "new initiatives" this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A Commerce Department analysis reveals only a slow rise in Government purchases of goods and services -- the part of Government spending that helps business activity most directly.
PARIS, Sept. 23 -- The following varied events took place in France today. They helped to picture the country's divided nature as Sunday's referendum on the proposed new Constitution approaches:
Touring Canadians pose an economic problem. The Bank of Montreal has found that every year since 1950, Canadians have spent more money traveling outside Canada than visitors have spent inside it.

The Soviet Union and its satellites spent a record total of $500,000,000 to $750,000,000 last year on propaganda aimed at the non-Communist world, an American official asserted last night.
TORONTO, Sept. 23 -- The United States decision drew sharp criticism from some Canadian producers today, but failed to appreciably disturb prices on the Toronto stock market.

This letter is prompted by you Sept. 18 editorial "Pay Later and Pay More," in which you criticizes the American Automobile Association for opposing a new Federal gasoline tax increase to make up an anticipated $900 million deficit in the highway trust fund for fiscal 1960.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 23 -- Gen. Fouad Chehab became President of Lebanon today. His capital was under a strict twentyfour-hour curfew and was heavily patrolled by troops.
A group of stockholders in the Wilson Jones Company filed suit yesterday in Federal Court against the company and its president and chairman.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The stock market lost some of its buoyancy today and in many sections prices slipped back gently all day. This was ascribed, in part, to the Far East situation and yesterday's relapse on Wall Street.

DESIGNERS of Steuben crystal are preoccupied again with achieving as much movement in design as is possible. In a group of eight pieces that will be introduced today, this characteristic is evident in the softened flowing lines and the applied decoration.
The State Education Department's new educational television program was given a passing grade yesterday by many teachers, pupils, school officials and parents.
WARREN, Mich., Sept. 23 -- The 1959 Chevrolets will move more forcefully into the medium-priced field, leaving room at the bottom for a smaller economy car next year.
MANY designs in Ann Cox' fall collection of fashions echo the Paris trends.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The shades of Little Red Riding Hood, her grandmother, and the late Senator Carter Glass were evoked today as bankers debated a proposal to expel mutual savings banks from the American Bankers Association.
A farmers' market, retailing vegetables grown by school children at eight "miracle gardens" in Brooklyn, Harlem and the Bronx, did $10.55 worth of business in City Hall Plaza yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23 -- Indonesia's Communist party made it clear tonight it would go along reluctantly with the cabinet's decision to postpone next September's general elections for a maximum period of one year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The Navy announced today that it had successfully used carbon black to create and dissipate clouds at will in a series of tests over the coast of Georgia.

HAVANA, Sept. 23 -- Fidel Castro, Cuban rebel leader, declared last night that he would accept neither a military junta to replace the Government of President Fulgencio Batista nor "false elections." Elections are to be held Nov. 30.

After a heated debate, dominated by the Taiwan Strait conflict, the United Nations General Assembly has passed a first, if indirect, verdict on the issues involved by refusing to put the question of any change in Chinese representation on its agenda.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- The Screen Actors Guild today appeared to have abandoned efforts to reach a friendly settlement of a controversy with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists over jurisdiction of performers employed in production of taped TV commercials.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Institutional investors have an important responsibility to "aggressively assist" the Treasury in solving its financing problems, Secretary of the Treasury Robert B. Anderson told the nation's bankers here today.
ONEONTA, N. Y., Sept. 23 -The Democratic party will begin a house-by-house, voter-byvoter campaign census in all the upstate counties this week.
An off-duty detective was arrested early yesterday in the shooting of a 17-year-old boy in a Queens diner. The bullet was removed from the youth's neck later in the day.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday the appointment of two regional directors in its overseas development program.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- An unfamiliar figure gave a Brooklyn baseball tinge to the New York Football Giants.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The choice by Pope Pius XII of a successor to the late Samuel Cardinal Stritch as Archbishop of Chicago will be announced tomorrow.

PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for United States Senator, opened a four-day campaign tour of the north country today. He promised action on Federal legislation to prevent a recurrence of the "unfortunate episode of Sherman Adams."
Sales and earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the six months ended July 31 were lower than those of a year earlier, reflecting the pattern of the general economy," the company reported yesterday.
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Eighteen nen and two sledge dogs at the South Pole celebrated the first day of spring today and saw the sun for the first time in six months.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation worked today to resolve non-economic differences and to reach a new national agreement.
LILLE, France, Sept. 23 -The question of a new French Constitution seems hardly to have stirred the sluggish political climate in the northernmost French department.

NEWARK, Sept. 23 -- A speedometer tape taken from the wrecked Diesel engine indicated that the Jersey Central train had been going forty-five to forty-six miles an hour before plunging into Newark Bay last week, an expert said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday, to close 4 points lower to 10 higher than on Monday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 -- (Canadian Press) -- Canada pledged today not to increase tariffs on $150,000,000 worth of United Kingdom products, including aircraft and automobiles, in return for Britain's reduction in import controls on Canadian goods.

A Delaware, Ohio, woman, Mrs. Donald deVault, won top prize of $25,000 yesterday in Pillsbury's tenth Grand National Bake-off. Her prize-winning recipe was for a rather simple dessert -- spicy apple twists.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP) -There is little likelihood that Asian influenza or its allied viruses will strike a major blow at New York State this winter, Health Commissioner Herman E. Hilleboe said today.
ATHENS, Sept. 23 (Reuters) A new plan for Cyprus' independence was announced here last night by Archbishop Makarios, exiled leader of the Greek Cypriote community.

THE pas de deux provided the special features of last night's program by the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House. One of them was Herbert Ross" "Tristan" in its first presentation anywhere; the other was the tried-and-true "Black Swan" pas de deux with Alicia Alonso and Igor Youskevitch making their debuts as guest artists.
The Board of Elections is starting a postcard check today to discover how many of New York City's 2,431,000 registered voters changed their addresses since last year.

Julius Helfand, the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that he was "hopeful" that a heavyweight championship fight would be held in Madison Square Garden early in December.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A German scientist who was captured in World War II arrived in Washington today on his way to a job provided by the United States Coast Guard officer who was his captor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Government today officially certified the Boeing 707 jet transport as airworthy and ready to start regular passenger service between New York and Europe on Oct. 26 as scheduled.

A junior committee has been formed to work for the success of the Oct. 23 performance of the musical "Goldilocks," which is scheduled to open Oct. 11 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre. The Bargain Box, a thrift shop at 1579 Third Avenue, will benefit.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 23 -About 300 Norfolk high school seniors signed up for the Tidewater Educational Foundation private school program today as it became apparent that the city's white secondary schools would not open Monday as scheduled.

The city and county of San Francisco are planning to borrow $26,425,000 in the bond market on Oct. 27 to finance public improvements. The bonds will be general obligations dated next Dec. 1 and due serially on Dec. 1 from 1959 to 1978.

The long-delayed arbitration of the dispute between the Grace Line and the International Longshoremen's Association over the size of dock gangs to handle cargo for the company's new liner Santa Rosa got under way yesterday.
The housing committee of the Riverside Democratic Club appealed to city officials yesterday to enforce building codes and sanitary laws on West 103d Street.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 24 -J. Russel Sprague made known tonight that Robert Moses had resigned from Hofstra College's Board of Trustees because, according to Mr. Moses, faculty members used the college's name in political activity. Mr. Sprague is the Republican leader of Nassau.
The Celanese Corporation of America and Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., of Britain have formed a joint subsidiary to produce in this country a polyester fiber similar to Dacron.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -The Government's chief statistician pointed out today that there were many gaps in economic statistics available to government policy makers.
The Catholic Teachers Association of the Diocese of Brooklyn called upon Mayor Wagner yesterday to investigate charges of religious bias at Queens College.

NEWARK, Sept. 24 -- The New Jersey Public Utilities Commission sought a clue today to the cause of last week's Jersey Central train disaster in the health record of Lloyd F. Wilburn, the locomotive engineer.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Scheduled rate increases for private-line teletypewriter services were put off until Jan. 1 by the Federal Communications Commission today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Following is a communique issued today by the Foreign Ministers of the American republics meeting here:
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 24 -Virginia is seeking an immediate hearing by the full Fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals on the Warren County and Norfolk school integration cases.

The Assembly of Captive European Nations has called for a special session of the General Assembly to consider the expulsion of the Soviet Union and Hungary from the United Nations for their defiance of United Nations resolution on Hungary.
CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- The American Bankers Association has turned down a proposal to oust mutual savings banks.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the victim of a stabbing last Saturday, continued to improve yesterday despite a touch of pneumonia, Harlem Hospital said.
The first steps in a campaign to improve and promote the long idle piers in Staten Island were taken yesterday.
Manufacturers of high fidelity equipment for the home will spend a record of about $11,000,000 for advertising in 1959.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 24 -- The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, announced today that a center for philosophical research would be established here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The foreign ministers of the twenty Latin-American republics and the United States established machinery today for a new inter-American economic development institution and for pushing other moves in the economic field.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 24 -- Pessimism is increasing here over the possibility of a peaceful settlement of the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

The Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads broke into the black last month. The Pennsy, No. 1 in the industry, reported net income of $3,288,600, its first profit since last October, when it had earnings of $1,710,365.

NEARLY 150 food editors from the United States and Canada are on a gastronomic carousal here this week. The occasion is the sixteenth annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference, which is sponsored by the American Association of Newspaper Representatives.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 -Archbishop Meyer received the news while here today for the consecration of Bishop Michael William Hyle of Baltimore.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 24 -The winds blew hard enough today to scatter all except a few lingering doubts as to the outcome of the seventeenth challenge match for the America's Cup.
CHICAGO Sept. 24. (AP). -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

On the site of the Collyer brownstone home at 128th Street and Fifth Avenue a group of youngsters yesterday cleared the now empty lot of rubbish and stones. They were preparing to plant flowers there as part of the coming Salute to Fall.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 24 -- Boston College alumni have been coming back to the campus to have a look at the beautiful new gymnasium and hockey rink that are the pride of John Curley, and they are prepared to fill the reconstructed football stadium in expectation of a big year for the Eagles.

The junior members of the Smith, Wellesley, Radcliffe and Mount Holyoke Clubs of New York will sponsor a benefit dance on Oct. 23 in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza. Proceeds will aid the individual scholarship funds of each of the four women's colleges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today tentatively ordered two schools in the Pacific Northwest to stop using "deceptive offers of employment and other misrepresentation" in selling courses in airlines training.
ALGIERS, Sept. 24 -- With the voting starting here Friday French Army officers have shifted their attention from the political to the military problem of the "battle of the referendum."
A subscription committee has been formed to work for the success of "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evening of Nov. 8.

PARIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -Sven Davidson, top-seeded Swedish player, was upset today in the second round of a tennis tournament by Ladislav Legenstein, a virtually unknown exile from eastern Europe. The score was 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.
A hillside in Central Park that became a man-made hole is now acquiring a concrete floor to support bronze figures from "Alice in Wonderland."

The democratically elected delegates of the 1,300,000 members of the United Steelworkers Union voted overwhelmingly at last week's convention to direct the international executive board -- which had been elected by the referendum vote of the membership -- and also the various locals to "take prompt and vigorous action to eliminate" a small minority who had opposed President McDonald and an increase in union dues.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 24 -- The pupils and teachers of Venable Elementary School went back to class this morning amid unaccustomed settings of washing machines, work benches and pine-paneled bars.
The Catholic Teachers Association of the Diocese of Brooklyn adopted a resolution yesterday praising Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs for his opposition to birth-control therapy in municipal hospitals.
Robert Fulton Cutting 2d, a Wall Street broker and scion of one of the city's most prominent families, committed suicide with an Army pistol yesterday in his home at 15 East Eightyeighth Street.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The bodies of six United States airmen whose unarmed transport crashed in Soviet Armenia Sept. 2 were turned over to the United States at a Soviet border town today.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 24--The Westchester Presbytery, composed of ministers and elders of thirty-five Presbyterian churches in the county, protested today against an increasing number of political events on Sundays.

In his letter published Sept. 19 Paul Mocsanyi, former art critic of The United Press, expressed the hope that action be taken to preserve the priceless works of art which had been evacuated to Taiwan prior to the Communist occupation of the Chinese mainland.

Your editorial of Sept. 11 "StateAid Tempest" is content to take at face value the spurious Republican explanation for excising from Governor Harriman's budget $2.2 million earmarked for adult education. This explanation was that an additional $53 million was voted in state aid for general education, $36 million of which would go upstate and $17 million to New York City, and that the localities could use some of this money for adult education.
The nation's crude oil production increased 77,850 barrels to 7,087,085 a day in the week ended last Friday, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Things are beginning to hum again at the Paramount studio, where stages had been idle for five weeks after completion of the Jerry Lewis comedy, "The Geisha Boy."
BY taking the theatre on its highest level, James Forsyth has written the first major play of the season, "Heloise," acted last evening at the Gate Theatre, Second Avenue and Tenth Street.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, the nation's largest brokerage house, hopes to switch from a partnership to a corporation early next year.
WARSAW, Sept. 24 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka accused the Roman Catholic Church in Poland today of working "openly and secretly" against the Government.

The Nov. 10 performance of "Once More, With Feeling" at the National Theatre will be a benefit for the Child Study Association of America, Inc. Tickets may be obtained at the office of the beneficiary, 132 East Seventy-fourth Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Harry S. Truman primed California Democrats tonight with this message:

Edward Goodell, Liberal party candidate for Attorney General, opened his party's campaign with a radio address last night in which he described himself as "the symbol of protest against machine politics."

SOMEWHERE IN ALGERIA, Sept. 21 -- Algerian rebel forces opened their first general offensive against the French last night. By this evening they were in control of the countryside from the Tunisian frontier to a line running south from the sea at La Calle to just east of Souk-Ahras, then southeast to the mining town of Ouenza and south to Tebessa.
ALGIERS, Sept. 25 -- "I put the white ballot in the envelope, I swallow the purple ballot," said the dark-eyed Moslem youth this morning.

Levittown, L. I., is the scene of the oddly entitled "Ariadne and the Concrete Duck," which has been earmarked for a Jan. 28 opening here. Ernest Kinoy is the author of the romantic comedy, dealing with a New England boy who weds a European girl and moves with her to the suburban community.
ROME, Sept. 25 -- The Supreme Defense Council is believed to have discussed at its meeting today the forthcoming delivery of United States Jupiter missiles to the Italian Air Force.
TOKYO, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Jose Gallicchio, 76-year-old millionaire rancher from Argentina, who has seven children and ten grandchildren, took a Japanese bride today after a three-hour courtship.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 25 -- The first legal test of the new Connecticut statute permitting public transportation for pupils of nonprofit private schools was announced today.
The semi-annual report of the Cannon Mills Company showed lower sales but higher earnings for the six months ended June 30 compared with the same period a year ago.

Immediately after the first World War D'Annunzio declared with flaming eloquence that we must support his holding Trieste. Otherwise, through that crucial gap would pour Asian hordes bent on the destruction of the Western World. It was America's first line of defense.
ROME, Sept. 25 -- In the face of Communist opposition the city council authorized today the construction of an American-owned hotel in Rome.

MIAMI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Hurricane Helene, with ninety-mile-an-hour squall winds and gales spanning a 350-mile path, swirled in the direction of the coast of the Carolinas today. But a 50-50 chance remained that the storm would swerve and miss the mainland.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Sept. 26 -- A Chinese Nationalist convoy landed supplies on blockaded Quemoy Island today through heavy fire from near-by Communist batteries on the mainland, the Nationalist Defense Ministry announced.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would soon appoint a small committee of "outstanding citizens" to study and report on the feasibility of legalizing off-track betting on horse races.

WENTWORTH BY THE SEA, N. H., Sept. 25 -- Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, chairman of the special Senate subcommittee investigating problems of the textile industry, spoke here today at the 104th annual meeting of the Northern Textile Association. He declared:
FORT SMITH, Ark., Sept. 25 -- A Federal judge declined today to interfere with the proposed leasing of Little Rock schools to a private corporation. Segregationists were heartened by the decision.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, said yesterday that modern education was emphasizing Western civilization to this nation's detriment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Following are texts of a communication to President Eisenhower from J. Albert Rolston, chairman of the Charlottesville (Va.) Committee for Public Education and the President's reply:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Richard A. Mack, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission, and Thurman A. Whiteside, a Miami lawyer, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States.
The Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday confirmed that it had adopted a new amendment to its athletic recruiting code that would limit pre-college and post-graduate aid to student athletes.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- The state's school districts will receive about $88,000,000 more in education aid during the school year now opening than they did in 1957-58, the State Education Department estimated today.

The eleventh annual Blue Grass Ball for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society of New York was held last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. The dinner dance was sponsored, for the fifth time, by Elizabeth Arden.

Casey Stengel, the Yankees' manager, is looking ahead to an important engagement with the Braves in Milwaukee next Wednesday. But he also has a keen interest in the three final games with the Orioles.
An automatic changer that will accept dollar bills and provide change in quarters, dimes and nickels was demonstrated here yesterday. The electronic device works only with clean bills.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Lane High School's displaced senior and junior classes will begin classwork Monday at five locations under an emergency schooling program.

THE Museum of Contemporary Crafts is celebrating its second birthday with an exhibition of colorful Finnish rug designs and a selection of contemporary craft objects on loan from various art museums. Tiles by David Weinrib and applique wall hangings by Jettie Penraat also are being shown.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25 -- Tom Greene has been called the T-formation quarterback of the year, and Capt. Jim Healy and Vin Promuto have been proclaimed the best pair of guards in college football.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan asked "the whole international community" tonight to oppose the use of force in the settlement of the dispute over Quemoy.

When will we enjoy toll-free passage through the bridges and tunnels that are operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and by the Port Authority? Why aren't we enjoying this privilege right now?

Van Cliburn donated the $1,250 he won in the Moscow Tchaikovsky Competition to the city yesterday. He said that it was his wish the prize money be used to help all peoples find common understanding through "the universal language of the arts."

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 -- New Jersey School Superintendents today endorsed the conclusions of Dr. James B. Conant, president Emeritus of Harvard University, that the comprehensive high school could fill the needs of American secondary education.

Chicago borrowed $20,000,000 in the bond market yesterday. Issues of serial obligations, maturing from 1960 to 1977, were sold at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by Chicago's major banks at an interest cost of 3.58809 per cent.

Jack Resnick and Raymond Ziplow, realty investors, who bought the building at the southwest corner of Eighty-sixth Street and Third Avenue six years ago, have purchased the adjoining property at the northwest corner of Eighty-fifth Street and the avenue.
BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, asserted today that Sherman Adams had been "politically assassinated."
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board admitted today it erred in seeking an injunction in a labor dispute without having conducted an investigation.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Ch. Merriedip Duke George is an Old English Sheepdog who looks like a large, occasionally animated mop, weighs 100 pounds and sleeps in the kitchen. His owner, Mrs. Marvin H. Kucker, is a young, blonde exurbanite housewife.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- British Government securities maintained their recent strength in the stock market today. Industrials joined in the advance on selective demand with most interest in shares offering bigger yields.
Juvenile crime in the city schools has declined steadily since reaching a peak last January, Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald reported yesterday.

It would certainly seem like good business to effect a long-term saving of $4,000 a year in relief rental payments by making a "one-shot" expenditure of $2,240 for relocation expenses. This is the example cited by Charles Grutzner in his article in The Times of Sept. 22.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A $6,000,000 section of Route 17, designed to bypass Bloomingburg, will be opened Oct. 23, the State Public Works Department announced today.
The summer hiatus in marketing speech-making gave way to a volley of words at three meetings here yesterday.

ALGIERS, Sept. 25 -- Antagonism toward Premier Charles de Gaulle and doubt about his "orthodoxy" on the Algerian question are mounting among European settlers and apparently in some influential military circles here.

TODAY, when the knowledgeable shopper looks for a porterhouse or sirloin steak for broiling, she selects the cut with streaks of fat marbled through the lean muscle meat. She knows that a generous quantity of fat in beef denotes tenderness, the most desirable quality in meat for broiling or roasting.

Hurricane Helene, now moving up the Atlantic coast, is giving the Weather Bureau its first chance to experiment with a new device which promises greater precision in hurricane tracking and more efficient warnings -- with consequent savings in life and property.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 -- Rashid Karami, the new Premier of Lebanon, thinks of Gamal Abdel Nasser as a "superman." This attitude toward the President of the United Arab Republic is the tell-tale thread of Arab nationalism that runs through the warp and woof of Mr. Ka rami's complex political career.
Donelli Son is not the title of a current best seller. Nor is it the name of a thriving business concern, even though Donelli pere et Donelli fils are together in business -- the football business.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- Sam Jaffe, a leader in the talent agency business for twenty-five years before his retirement last month as the president of the Famous Artists Associates, will re-enter the field of motion-picture production as an independent operator.

A State Supreme Court Justice late yesterday denied a motion seeking to restrain the Board of Estimate from taking action today on the proposed Seventh Avenue approach to the projected Narrows Bridge between Brooklyn and Staten Island.
The Weather Bureau found yesterday that its emergency warning service worked better than it had dared to hope.

State Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz reserved decision yesterday on a move to block the Waterfront Commission from access to the books and records of the International Longshoremen's Association's welfare fund.
The Transport Workers Union contended yesterday that the proposed sale of the city's transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company was specifically barred by law.
The Police Department has a new rule for pickets: bring your signs but leave your sticks at home.
A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., manufacturer of carpets, will occupy a large warehouse and office building to be erected to its specifications in Milltown, Middlesex County, N. J.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- T. S. Eliot, the poet and playwright, will be 70 years old tomorrow and acknowledges that he looks at life more genially than in the days of his youth.
A United Nations Day concert featuring Pablo Casals, world-famous 'cellist, has been scheduled for presentation next month by two national networks and two independent stations here.
Three categories of lucky souls go cruising on Chesapeake Bay and its rivers and creeks:

Governor Harriman said yesterday that he avoided purely political rallies on Sunday, but that he saw no harm in attending clambakes and picnics. Sundays, he said, are the best time for people to gather to discuss politics and community life.

Burdick Becker, Inc., an advertising agency specializing in the medical and pharmaceutical fields, leased a floor in the new building at 630 Third Avenue at Forty-first Street. The broker was Joseph B. Rogers and Jerry L. Cohen of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers. Collins, Tuttle Co. is agent for the building.

The election of Paul A. Gorman as president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company was announced yesterday. The company is one of the largest operating companies of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Secretary of State Dulles asserted here last night that the United States would not retreat in the face of armed force but otherwise was prepared to settle the Quemoy dispute by peaceful means.
The Army gave a public showing yesterday of its Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missile, said to be this country's most effective anti-aircraft defense weapon.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 25 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. ruled out the possibility today of leasing Virginia schools to private operators to avoid racial integration.
Strong Republican opposition to raising New York City's sales tax from 3 to 4 per cent was voiced yesterday by party and legistlative spokesmen.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 25 -- The United States Pavilion Theatre at the World's Fair was host tonight to talented young amateurs in a variety show. The production was "A Day at the Fair" with a cast of sixty-five.

One hundred and eight cowboys and cowgirls in Western garb, with two bands blaring, invaded City Hall Plaza at noon yesterday. The Mayor greeted the contingent headed by Roy Rogers, who is called the "King of the Cowboys."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 667,277 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
A strike in the five bakeries that produce 75 per cent of the city's normal supply of packaged white bread was called here at midnight, but it will not affect grocers' supplies until tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- The 100-member General Electric Conference Board of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers unanimously decided tonight to ask the General Electric Company to resume contract negotiations in October.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for United States Senator, ended a three-day campaign tour of the north country tonight with predictions of an upstate sweep for the Rockefeller-Keating ticket.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Dr. John Cranford Adams, president of Hofstra College, said today that he did not believe there had been a breach of academic conduct by Hofstra faculty members.

The man who will command the world's first nuclear-powered merchant ship, and the sixteen engineers who will control the vessel's 74,000,000-watt power plant, put on their new atomic - age insigne for the first time yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Fred Haney hinted strongly today that Warren Spahn, the Braves' left-handed ace, will hurl the opening game of the 1958 world series against the New York Yankees here next Wednesday.

With a pat on the head that clearly indicated, "Well, boy, we made it," Jimmy Hobales guided My Last Try across the finish line well in advance of the others in the $8,675 Bushwick Hurdie Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -Mail to members of Congress on the Far Eastern crisis, while light, is running generally against President Eisenhower's decision to defend the offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu.
Eddies of uncertainty swirled over the stock market yesterday. Prices moved erratically and closed lower on average in the year's heaviest trading.

The International Garden Club is sponsoring a fall festival to be held tomorrow afternoon at the Bartow Mansion Museum in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. Proceeds from the fete, which will commemorate the forty-fourth year of the founding of the club and the restoration of Bartow Mansion, will go toward the maintenance fund of the museum.
A threat that the United States' Far Eastern policy "can only lead to the most terrible disaster for the people of the United States" has been voiced by the Chinese Communist party.
DINA KEVLES, in her second one-man show at the Roko Gallery, 925 Madison Avenue, exhibits a group of abstractions, some based on visual experiences.
YONKERS, Sept. 25 -- No one took a vote, but it appeared tonight that the United Nations was split on how to pick a winner at Yonkers Raceway.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 25 -There was a rather pleasant bit of whimsy here tonight -and there was need for whimsy.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Jack Ahern, a 63-year-old Buffalo golfer, won the New York State Seniors Golf Association fall tournament today. Over the West course of the Winged Foot Golf Club, Ahern tallied a 77 for a 36-hole total of 154. Yesterday he had a 77 over the club's East course.

KAISERSLAUTERN, Germany, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Maj. Leonard V. Bailey of Salt Lake City, who has sixteen years of service in the United States Army, went on trial before a court-martial today and pleaded not guilty to beating up Timmie Rogers, a touring Negro entertainer.
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, pointed to Sherman Adams' resignation today as an example of "corruption in American upper circles."
Last night while most of the city went about its business, civil defense officials held simultaneous rescue exercises in the five boroughs.

TERRY BRENNAN learned something last spring -- or did he? At least the youthful Notre Dame football coach confirmed his suspicions that the new rule on conversions after touchdowns was a booby trap. It is a singularly unpredictable one, too. The sideline strategist never knows when it will explode in his face or when it will prove a complete dud.

A solemn stillness has returned to mountain, farm and seashore, save where a roadside vegetable stand lures the week-end tripper, or the changing hues of early autumn foliage attract the color photographer.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 25 -- Columbia, a yacht that obviously has all the answers, responded authoritatively today to the chief open question pertaining to the seventeenth challenge for the America's Cup.

PREMIER NIKITA S. KHRUSHCHEV of the Soviet Union was depicted in a television play last night as having denied Josef Stalin prompt medical aid after the dictator purportedly had suffered a stroke before his death in March, 1953.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Latin-American coffee producing countries reached an agreement today to control coffee exports and curb the oversupply on world markets that has been depressing prices.

The two situations are not truly analogous, however. Disobedience to the law by nonconformance is an ancient technique of man.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a drop in its net income for August to $8,459,477 from $9,145,893 in the like 1957 month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Air Force said today its new Bomarc long-range interceptor missile had "destroyed" a 1,000-mile-an-hour target missile flying seventy-five miles away at a height of 48,000 feet.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The newspaper Sovietsky Sport disclosed today that in the last three months thirty players had been ousted from Soviet soccer teams and 100 other athletes had received warnings for misbehavior.
DUNKIRK, N. Y., Sept. 25 -Soft - sell campaigning today gave Nelson A. Rockefeller a 3-to-1 edge over Governor Harriman in campaign buttons on a Democratic steel worker's shirt.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Britain and France told the General Assembly today that they still hoped that the negotiations in Warsaw between the United States and Communist China would succeed.

THE latest novelty in the season of the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was added to the repertory last night in the form of Anton Dolin's "Variations for Four." It is a short piece of no pretensions beyond exhibition, and, as presented on this occasion, of scant distinction indeed.
VIENNA, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- The International Atomic Energy Agency learned today that the United States was prepared to pay for a world-wide research program into peaceful uses for atomic energy.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 25 -An accident at sea marred the America's Cup races off here late this afternoon.

BLUE Concord grapes are beginning to appear in markets across the nation and soon will be ripening in suburban backyards in the New York area. Homemade jellies long have been the housewife's answer to what to do with this perishable fruit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today there was "a complete agreement between the Post Office Department and the Public Health Service on the importance of protecting the public health."
DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- The Chrysler Corporation said today it had been forced to postpone the introduction of four car lines because of the erratic labor situation.
The Flintkote Company, which produces the broadest line of building materials in the country, has arranged to purchase the Orangeburg Manufacturing Company, Inc. The price exceeds $12,000,000.
Three baby sea lions, just arrived from the West Coast, made a fighting debut at the Bronx Zoo yesterday and won the right to frolic in peace at the zoo's main pool.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower warned today that closing of schools over the racial issue could have "disastrous" consequences for the children involved and for the country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The British called today for a tripartite solution of the Cyprus problem by Turkey, Greece and the United Kingdom.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Dr. Don Paarlberg, a chief architect of Administration farm policy, is slated for appointment as President Eisenhower's principal economic adviser.

THERE was, perhaps, an unnecessary amount of sentimentality in "The Ed Wynn Show," which began on Channel 4 last night. Some of its situations were farfetched and there was a rather unconvincing ending in which everyone lived happily -- presumably forever.

Joseph J. Cella was nominated last night as the Democratic candidate for Municipal Court Justice in the First District of Manhattan. He was selected by Democratic committeemen of the district at a meeting at the Tamawa Club, 88 Seventh Avenue.

Members of the committee planning a benefit theatre party for the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women were entertained at a tea yesterday afternoon in the Palm Court of the Plaza by Mrs. Frederick Lee Liebolt and Mrs. Lowell Wadmond.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 25 -- The trial of Dr. Fadhil Jamali, former Premier of Iraq, on charges of plotting against the Government, was concluded today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Treasury offered two short-term securities today to raise $3,500,000,000 to finance part of its heavy deficit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- United States forces will be out of Lebanon by the end of October, Administration sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Individuals set a post-war record for cash savings in the second quarter of this year, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

With the close of the stock market today, the thirteen trading weeks of the third quarter will have passed. A look backward shows that much of the activity centered around two auto stocks, American Motors and Studebaker-Packard.
WARSAW, Sept. 25 -- The United States and Communist China decided today to keep their negotiations here alive at least five more days.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Dixie Series, a post-season baseball play-off between the winners of the Texas League and the Southern Association was saved last night when a club owner agreed to abide by a segregation law.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said tonight that there were ominous signs that public patience with many conditions in the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area was wearing thin.
Dr. Clinton A. Clauson, Democratic Governor-elect of Maine, visited this city yesterday to talk politics and receive an award from the Chiropractic Association of New York.

BRIAN BISHOP long has designed glittering chandelier earrings for Lena Horne and ropes of "crystals" for Rosalind Russell, as well as showering many New York stores with his glamorous jewelry. Now, with the addition of his new associate, Eugenio de Berrayarza, an interior decorator, these same beads are dangling all over the house.

The Vienna Octet will open the Sunday Concert Society series of eight programs at Carnegie Recital Hall on Oct. 26. The first concert will include a G major Divertimento by Michael Haydn, Brahms' Clarinet Quintet and Dvorak's String Quintet, Op. 77.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission renewed the broadcast licenses of the Storer Broadcasting Company and Westinghouse Broadcasting Company today after it had reprimanded both companies for having violated the commission's rules.

Today's new film is "Damn Yankees," Warner Brothers' color version of the Broadway musical comedy, with Tab Hunter, Gwen Verdon and Ray Walston, at the Roxy Theatre. George Abbott and Stanley Donen directed and produced, from a screen play by Mr. Abbott. Russ Brown and Shannon Bolin are in the supporting cast.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A hearing scheduled for today in the fight for control of the E. L. Bruce Company, a Memphis, Tenn., flooring concern, was canceled when counsel for both factions filed stipulations requesting that the case be dismissed.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 25 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. criticized tonight President Eisenhower's attack on public school closings. In a statement, Mr. Almond said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Some Western diplomats here felt that Secretary of State Dulles, in his New York speech tonight, had sometwhat "softened" the United States position on the Taiwan Strait crisis.

Confidence in the outlook for the national economy was reported by several industry leaders yesterday. They were interviewed by phone as a feature of a marketing conference held by the American Management Association at the Statler-Hilton Hotel here. The executives indicated that 1959 would be a good business year and that the recession was rapidly becoming a thing of the past.
Money is only as good as the paper it is printed on. A single type of paper, produced by one company, distinguishes genuine United States currency from counterfeit.
NEWARK, Sept. 25 -- The possibility of a malfunction in a signal less than 500 feet from where a Jersey Central train plunged into Newark Bay last week was raised today at an investigation.
The Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, founded by Jeremiah Milbank in 1917, entered an affiliation agreement yesterday with New York University.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 -- Appeals will be heard here Saturday in two and possibly three Virginia school cases in which stays of lower court integration orders have been denied.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Grain futures prices had little to show after the close of the Board of Trade today for all the bullishness of the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Representative Oren Harris said today that Mayor David L. Lawrence of Pittsburgh and Senator George A. Smathers of Florida had not done anything "improper" in a Pittsburgh TV channel case now under investigation.

THE American toy industry has long been at work making dolls that would walk, talk, crawl, wink, cry, blow bubbles, and do everything, but cheat at stud poker. Nearly every fall new dolls have appeared -- some who said, "Mamma," and some whose flirtatious eyes said much more.
WERNER LANDSHOFF, 'cellist, and George Bennette, pianist, presented a joint program of piano-'cello works last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

ANYONE who has wandered among the ruins of Paestum, the ancient Greek city on the Italian coast some sixty miles south of Naples, knows that they possess an extraordinary capacity to stimulate the sense of the past and the historical imagination. The two great temples to Hera and Poseidon are fairly well preserved.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Iceland, supported by Denmark, urged the General Assembly today to settle at this session the "life-and-death matter" of fishing rights within territorial waters.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Eddie Stanky today was named "assistant on player personnel" by General Mariager Bing Devine of the St. Louis Cardinals.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 -- Lebanon's new Premier said today that his Government would ask immediately for withdrawal of United States troops from his country.

QUITE a number of new works appeared on last night's Carnegie Hall program of the Contemporary Music Society, but the evening was Leopold Stokowski's. He conducted the music, received congratulatory messages from President Eisenhower and Mayor Wagner, made a speech and indulged in repartee with the Mayor.
Cotton futures declined 1 to 11 points yesterday. There was liquidation in old October, and also in the far months through commission houses. The drop equaled 5 cents to 55 cents a bale.
A LATE September survey of metropolitan galleries finds them warming up in the mild weather, preparing the public for more memorable things to come.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- The Central Conference of Teamsters, most powerful regional unit within the truck drivers' union, unanimously reaffirmed its faith in James R. Hoffa today. It voted him and his chief helpers a blank check to spend conference funds.
Comdr. James F. Calvert, skipper of the nuclear-powered submarine Skate, disclosed yesterday that it had taken him and his crew less than an hour to qualify for the Circumnavigators Club.

A CHILD growing up in a large family tends to field the line drives of emotional crises with the assurance of a New York Yankee on the opening day of a world series. The child's insouciance, although less unnerving, may be traced to the same source as the ballplayer's: a fairly good idea of what to expect, based upon a familiarity with the setting and a great deal of experience.
Check transactions in the twenty-six major cities of the nation in the week ended Wednesday totaled $23,530,584,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday.
Canadian Javelin, Ltd., consented yesterday to a permanent injunction against boiler room operations, or high-pressure telephone selling of stock.
TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today there appeared to be "considerable sentiment" in New Jersey for raising revenue through the taxation of legalized off-track betting.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, described the Eisenhower Administration's domestic and foreign policies tonight as a "colossal and costly failure."

Your editorial of Sept. 15 calling for the "widest possible support" of the shop fire warden plan sponsored jointly by the Fire Department and the I. L. G. W. U. notes that the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union "has taken the lead in demanding an end to the risks that still exist in spite of today's safety laws."
An investigation into charges of discrimination against Roman Catholic faculty members at Queens College was ordered yesterday by the State Commission Against Discrimination.
An international art festival featuring fine art and folk art from thirty-seven countries will be staged here next month as a tribute to the United Nations.

FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 25 -- This community will set up a program of emergency private instruction to provide for 1,044 pupils who have been shut out of Warren County High School since the beginning of last week.

President, Eisenhower's special aviation assistant called yesterday for a new policy to penalize defense contractors who fall short on promises. This policy would increase rewards for those who "actually perform miracles."
Prof. Gerhard Loewenberg's letter published Sept. 14 on France's new Constitution prompts me to offer certain comments about the objections which it voices.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- There was good news for newspapermen today. A Soviet spokesman hastily called a news conference and said, among other things, that in the future Russian diplomats would talk more to the press. Newsmen decided to test the pledge.
Cocoa futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange fell the daily limit of 1-cent-a-pound on all contracts yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Export-Import Bank reported today unusually heavy activity in the fiscal year 1958 and expected an even bigger year in fiscal 1959.
Despite unprofitable results so far, Furness, Withy Co. will expand its Great Lakes and Bermuda runs.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 25 -- A committee of citizens sought in State Supreme Court today to prove that a Nativity creche, on the lawn of a high school tended to teach religion but not history.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Eisenhower agreed today to a heavy schedule of personal campaigning for Republican candidates in the November elections.
