PARIS, Sept. 25 -- A proliferation of poster art is a feature of the campaign for the referendum on a new French Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The next legal step in the Little Rock case will be an appeal from District Judge John E. Miller to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover warned today that the nation was headed toward a record for major crimes. He said they were up 12.3 per cent over the corresponding period last year.
THE National Broadcasting Company televised an absorbing half-hour study of James R. Hoffa last night.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Hubert Beuve-Mery, publisher of the newspaper, Le Monde, gave his conditional yes today to Premier de Gaulle and his proposed new Constitution.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers hammered four Chicago White Sox pitchers for thirteen hits and a 7-to-1 victory today, but temporarily lost the services of Al Kaline.

Loans to business by the large New York banks fell $92,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $108,000,000 in the like week a year ago.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 25 -- Governor Faubus said late today that he wanted to study the ruling of a Federal district judge in the Little Rock school case before making any comment.
The week ahead should see only moderate activity in new offerings, since the recent strength in bond prices seems to have unsettled the capital market.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service -- the biggest shipping "enterprise" in the world -- will start its tenth year Wednesday.
DALLIS, Tex., Sept. 26--The commander of the Strategic Air Command said today the nuclear striking force was "ready to go."
William B. Shearer, the man who achieved world-wide notoriety after he had been charged with scuttling the Geneva disarmament conference in 1927, died in obscurity last week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States met here today to discuss the situation in the Taiwan Strait.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Sept. 26 -- A $3,000,000 mosque, the most imposing in Southeast Asia, was opened today by the Sultan of Brunei in his capital in Northwest Borneo.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Indications are that Western Europe's trade with the Soviet Union has declined during 1958 and that its imports from Eastern Europe have "continued to stagnate," according to the Economic Commission for Europe.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 26 -- Briggs Cunningham, who sailed the yacht Columbia in her successful defense of the America's Cup, classifies himself as a man who gets his greatest satisfaction out of doing things with his hands.

HAVANA, Sept. 26 -- Sabotage of railway and highway communications by insurgents is gradually bringing traffic to a halt in the three eastern provinces of Cuba, according to travelers arriving in Havana.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 1 point (5 cents a bale) up on the old October contract and 2 to 20 points (10 cents to $1 a bale) off on other months.

Another former contestant on the television quiz show "Twenty-One" charged yesterday that he had been given answers to questions before going on the air. He also asserted that he had been told when to miss a question and drop out of the show.

The recently published illustrated booklet "We Open the Gates," written by Harry Fleischman and James Rorty, is a refreshing antidote to the poisonous diet of racial prejudice which the public has to take in the news these days. It is a collection of moving stories about advances in the fight of organized labor on racial and religious discrimination -- in factories and hotels, on farms and railroads, in stores and telephone centrals.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been published recently:
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- President Arturo Frondizi asked the Argentine people tonight to work in order and tranquillity for the nation's economic recovery.

ALICIA MARKOVA made her second guest appearance last night with the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Fokine's "Les Sylphides" as her vehicle this time. What she did may have had little relation to the essential Fokine style, but it managed in its own right to be the purest of theatrical magic.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The British don't often blow their own horn, but when Harold Macmillan gives it a toot it's a beaut. The Prime Minister declared today that Britons had "a lot to be proud of."
ATLANTA, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Florida State, fighting for a spot in big-time football, threw a scare as into Georgia Tech tonight before bowing to the Engineers, 17 -- 3.
A Broadway opening after the first of the year is being planned for "The Gay Felons," the new Joseph Carole comedy, which H. Clay Blaney and Geoffrey Jones are producing.
TORONTO, Sept. 26 -- A spectacular design by a Finnish architect was chosen today as the winner of an international competition for Toronto's new City Hall.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 26 -- Columbia, the yacht-racing Gem of the Ocean, today completed a magnificent defense of the America's Cup by sailing away from Britain's challenger, Sceptre, for the fourth time in a row.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The British Labor party, in an official policy statement, asked today that the Chinese Nationalists evacuate Quemoy and Matsu.

Helped by a subsidy from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad succeeded in cutting its loss to $195,677 last month from the $759,188 loss sustained in July. In August of 1957 the road had earnings of $314,475.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Sept. 26--The Navy fired a full-sized twenty-inch Vanguard satellite into space today. But there appeared to be only an outside chance that it had been successfully guided into an orbit around the earth.
Wage negotiations between the American Merchant Marine Institute and the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots were recessed in a stalemate yesterday.

While Columbia and Sceptre struggled to the defender's one-sided decision at sea off Newport, the prize for which they vied so earnestly rested on a pedestal at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. Yesterday Columbia made certain it would remain there.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Grain futures traders finished writing off today the gains in most contracts that were chalked up in Wednesday's bullish market.

Round Table of the Kerr Stables would like to pick up $71,730 today, and he has a better than even chance of doing so. The 4-year-old colt will compete in the $110,200 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park and first money in that event figures to be the above-named sum.
BUFFALO, Sept. 26 -- Governor Harriman said today that he was opposed to off-track betting on horse racing.
President Eisenhower has called on all Americans, of whatever faith, to set aside Wednesday as a National Day of Prayer for the United States "and for all mankind."
LAST night "The Further Adventures of Ellery Queen" started on Channel 4. The program sported a live one-hour format and a good production of a routine murder tale.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -The International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers adopted a constitutional change today designed to strengthen the union's bargaining position by requiring fewer votes for strike approval.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette won twenty games in a season for the first time in his career tonight. He finally turned the trick after seven full years in the majors with a 2-1 victory for the Milwaukee Braves over the Cincinnati Redlegs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Committee on Political Education, an arm of organized labor, says Vice President Richard M. Nixon is seeking to revive the "trickle-down" tax theory.

Don Paarlberg, who will assume the role shortly to be vacated by Gabriel Hauge as principal economic adviser to the President, is taking on a job that, as he no doubt is fully aware, is not exactly a sinecure. One reason for this is that he enters the picture at a time when, from the standpoint of the country's economic position, conditions are not too auspicious.
The Times editorial of Sept. 16 on the city's school construction program is notable for its thoroughness, but strangely omits a cardinal, if not the most important, consideration.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The president of Associated Industries of New York State asserted today that hostility to business and industry was reflected in the administration of state government by both major parties.
A strike against five major bakeries was called off early yesterday when an agreement was reached on a new contract.

When Sceptre finally edged across the finish line after receiving its fourth and final thrashing from Columbia in the America's Cup series yesterday, a message of condolence was signaled to the blue-jacketed and downhearted British yachtsmen.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26 -- The South increased its industrial output by almost $4,000,000,000 during the last year and added 1,330 new plants while the nation was suffering one of its worst economic slumps in years. (The recession generally is believed to have started in the middle of last year and to have begun to ease in the middle of this year.

The Hartford County, Conn., Metropolitan District borrowed $4,400,000 in the bond market yesterday on three issues of serial securities. The money raised will be used to finance water supply and sewerage improvements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 118.9 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The United States has agreed to sell India $238,800,000 worth of surplus grains for rupees, the State Department announced today.
Nelson A. Rockefeller will make his first state-wide television appeal for votes as the Republican candidate for Governor on Monday evening.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced yesterday that it had arranged with fifteen local banks for a $100,000,000 credit from Oct. 7, 1958, until Oct. 6, 1959. This is the thirteenth credit arrangement of this type made by the giant utility for its expansion and construction programs.
Representatives of two rival United States Maritime trade unions met last month behind the Iron Curtain to pay their last respects to a crew member who died in Danzig, Poland.
Three young men, described as leaders in a neighborhood gang, were indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury in the murder of a 22-year-old clerk, allegedly because he would not join the gang.

NOT since the Nineteen Thirties has Ritter Brothers produced a sea otter coat, and that one was for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. This rare fur -- it is of a soft, deep brown color with silvery top hairs -- made its appearance again this week in an oval shaped, seven - eighths - length coat that formed part of the fall and spring custom collection of the Ritter concern.

HEWLETT, L. I., Sept. 26 -- A collection of paintings by Goya, Turner and Reynolds and more than 500 rare oriental ivory carvings escaped destruction today in a fire in the home of Albert J. Rosen here.

An affiliation of unusual importance to the handicapped was announced yesterday. One of New York's most honored institutions, the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, will join its forces with the work of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- A 47-year-old economist who takes no stock in the "beat generation" idea was inaugurated today as head of one of the world's largest educational institutions.
The teacher shortage here apparently has been solved, numerically.
The Treasury's decision to raise $3,500,000,000 on short-term securities priced far below the market caused a sharp decline yesterday in Government obligations of all kinds.
SNAPPY days are here again. Countering fall's first chill gusts, New Yorkers already have begun to unearth thicker clothes from the mothballs.
NEWARK, Sept. 26 -- The state Public Utilities Commission lifted its restrictions today on Jersey Central train operations across the Newark Bay bridge.
HONG KONG, Sept. 26 --The Peiping radio reiterated tonight Communist China's rejection of a United States proposal in the Warsaw talks for a cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait.
The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, will hold a dinner dance on Nov. 19 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Proceeds will further The Lighthouse's work with the blind.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Premier de Gaulle and his Government were silent tonight on the subject of the Cairo statement by Premier Abbas of the Provisional Algerian Government. Mr. Abbas said the rebel Government would carry on the fight against French rule until France indicated willingness to negotiate on the basis of recognition of the Algerians' "right to independence."

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for United States Senator, toured recession-blighted industrial towns in the lower Mohawk Valley today. He promised to work for tariff relief for the stricken glove and carpet industries.

A preview of "The Pleasure of His Company" on Oct. 21 at the Longacre Theatre will benefit the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled. The play by Samuel Taylor and Cornelia Otis Skinner opens the next night with a cast including Miss Skinner, Cyril Ritchard, Charles Ruggles and Walter Abel.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 26 -- It's all over, but the shouting from England and Scotland is almost audible without electronics. Those of us who watched the burial of Sceptre's hopes today had realized that Columbia's victory in the last race of this seventeenth America's Cup series was inevitable.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh confirmed yesterday a report that he had refused since last Monday to approve bail bonds written by the Public Service Mutual Insurance Company.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Saturday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Hurricane Helene, taking a slight turn northward, bore down on the Carolinas' coastline early today.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Evening of positions prior to the weekend accounted for most of the volume.
Contraceptive therapy can be provided to city welfare patients as far as the State Department of Social Welfare is concerned, Raymond W. Houston, the state commissioner, said yesterday.
Directors of the Reynolds Metals Company yesterday declared a 2 per cent stock dividend on the common stock, payable Oct. 31.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Chamber of Representatives voted today to file criminal charges before the Senate against Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, former Colombian dictator, for "abuse of power" and obstructing the "due process of law."
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy assured pickets yesterday that they could carry signs attached to handles of "light wood and similar light substances."
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 26 -- Well, what exactly was wrong with the beautiful Sceptre?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The AFL-CIO asserted today that inflation was the result of "arbitrary and artificial" price levels set by big business and not higher wages won by industrial unions.

A group of prominent American medical authorities met in a classroom here yesterday and planned what they hope will soon be a constant flow of privately sponsored United States medical aid to the major underprivileged areas of the world.
Specialists in diabetes reported favorably yesterday on the use of a new oral drug against the disease.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (AP) -- "Arti!" said the critics. "Manufactured metal," said Uncle Sam. And he slapped a 19 per cent duty today on four pieces of abstract sculpture by Jorge Oteiza, a Spaniard.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Willie Mays of San Francisco, hitless in three appearances, dropped a shade behind Richie Ashburn of Philadelphia in their tight battle for the National League batting title as the Giants beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3, tonight.

"Desegregation: Resistance and Readiness," by Melvin M. Tumin, will be published Oct. 27 by Princeton University Press. Based on a study of adult white male citizens of Guilford County, N. C., the book describes the attitudes toward desegregation and the factors that influence those views. The author is an associate professor of anthropology and sociology at Princeton University.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -Joe Quong, 58 years old, was seized by Federal agents today on a warrant issued by the United States District Court in Memphis, Tenn., that charges him with possession of contraband goods made in Communist China.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Mrs. Mary Tenison-Woods of Australia retired today as chief of the Status of Women Section of the United Nations, a post she had held since 1950. She will leave Tuesday for her home in Sydney.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 26 -- In its efforts to guide the country to effective democracy, Venezuela's junta is looking to the United States for moral support.
NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 26 -- Sceptre came close to quitting the final race of the America's Cup match today.

A special program of short documentary films on Africa will be shown free to the public, starting on Tuesday and continuing through October, at the World Affairs Center for the United States, United Nations Plaza and Forty-seventh Street.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 26 -- The first full week of high school television classes in Little Rock seemed today to have settled one thing: in teaching, there is no substitute for personal give and take.
RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 26--The army seized power tonight in Burma. Gen. Ne Win, Commander in Chief of the armed forces, was asked by Premier Nu to head a new Government and he agreed.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Frank S. Hogan, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, declared here tonight that "modern Republicanism" was being used as a vote-catching expedient by the G. O. P.

In your issue of Sept 9 you stated that Sceptre's builders are Alex Robertson Son, Clydebank. Many great ships were built at Clydebank -- the two Cunard "Queens," Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth, for example. But not Sceptre.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Generalissimo Rafael Trujillo is out to purge the United States Congress this fall of men he dislikes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -Edgar W. Holtz, associate general counsel for the Federal Communications Commission, said today that Commissioner T. A. M. Craven had not participated in the award of Miami television Channel 10.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Attorney General Edward J. McCormack ruled today that Charles Gibbons had been "duly nominated" to run as the Republican candidate for Governor of Massachusetts, and that his name must be on the ballot.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -The National Federation of Republican Women adopted resolutions today favoring immediate statehood for Hawaii and for Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Ted Williams moved into a virtual tie for the American League batting lead tonight as the Boston Red Sox swept a twilight-night bill from Washington, 6 -- 4 and 3 -- 1. The Senators' losing streak is now eleven games.
Total unemployment insurance claims in New York State dropped last week. However, new applications for jobless benefits rose.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The committee has struck out and yesterday's heroes have virtually been forgotten.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The Foreign Minister of the Netherlands declared today that Indonesia's expulsion of 40,000 Dutchmen and her expropriation of $1,250,000,000 of their holdings might adversely affect under developed nations.
John Barnett, new director of the National Orchestral Association, will hold the first rehearsal of the season next Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Civil Rights Commission named members of state advisory committees for Kansas and Colorado today.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle asked Frenchmen tonight to get the Fifth Republic off to a running start with a massive approval of the new Constitution in the referendum Sunday.
MONTREAL, Sept. 26 -- The British Commonwealth Economic Conference ended today with expressions of praise from several chiefs of delegations for the unanimity that prevailed.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -A United States Army major was convicted today of disorderly conduct and was fined $1,000 for having struck a Negro civilian entertainer in an officers' club.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 26 -- The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals will be asked to block the proposed leasing of this city's four high schools to a private corporation.
UPTON, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Dr. Eugene C. Ogden jabbed a hypodermic needle into the stem of a ragweed plant at the Brookhaven National Laboratory here today in an effort to conquer hay fever.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Fifteen Latin-American coffee producing countries agreed today to sign an export control agreement.
An article by Herbert Hoover, "Myth of the Fourth Horseman," appears in last week's issue of The Saturday Review.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National League champion Milwaukee Braves voted tonight to split their world series money into thirty-four full shares.

Van Cliburn will play the Rachmaninoff Piano Concerto No. 3 with the New York Philharmonic instead of the Prokofieff and Mozart concertos originally announced for Oct. 16, 17, 18 and 19. The entire program also has been changed by Leonard Bernstein.

QUEMOY, China, Sept. 26 -It appeared today after a twoday tour of this offshore island that its garrison, which the Chinese Nationalists say is 100,000 strong, feels able to withstand sustained Communist artillery bombardment for some time.

BEACH plums, the wild fruit that grows on sandy dunes from New England to Virginia, are ripening now to a rich purple. Although the beach plum is a regional food, it is fairly well known in this country because so much of it is prepared in a jelly that is sold in delicacy shops from coast to coast.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Following is a transcript of President Eisenhower's remarks here on the bicentenary of Fort Ligonier:

ROME, Sept. 26 -- The Vatican condemned racial intolerance today as a reason for world tension. A broadcast in several languages believed to have been inspired by Pope Pius XII deplored recent incidents caused by racial discrimination "in Europe, America and Africa."
LIGONIER, Pa., Sept. 26 -- President Eisenhower helped celebrate the 200th anniversary of Fort Ligonier here today. The British-built stockade fort has been restored as a national monument.
The nation's savings bankers moved swiftly yesterday to try to patch up "any differences" with commercial bankers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- High tariff sentiment here and abroad is threatening the growth of the aluminum industry, whose world markets already have been disrupted by Russian exports, a leading aluminum producer said today.

Dollars, cents, hours and other such routine issues of collective bargaining were swept aside yesterday while a $320,000,000 airline and a 285,000-member union tore into each other over these basic problems:
YONKERS, Sept. 26 -- Speedy Pick drew the No. 1 post position today for the $50,000 Trans-America Pace final at Yonkers Raceway Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Neil McElroy, Secretary of Defense, said today he would be astonished if any proposal came to him for cutbacks in the Air Force's Titan intercontinental ballistic missile or B-58 supersonic bomber programs.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, Sept. 27 -- Six newsmen, five Chinese and one Japanese, were missing today after an amphibious landing craft overturned yesterday in the Taiwan Strait.

The members of the British Commonwealth have agreed upon a significant new development in international communications. They propose to establish a telephone cable link around the world. Some new cables will be laid. Some existing lines will be used and tied in. The project is expected to cost about a quarter of a billion dollars and may take ten years to complete.

What a pleasure to hear a violinist who not only is a real musician, with a flair for his instrument, but who also has the intelligence to venture outside the miserably limited standard repertory for the violin.
VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- A Soviet delegate voiced strong criticism today of the results achieved by the International Atomic Energy Agency during the first year of its existence.

PUERTO RICO and North Carolina are now engaged in a polite dispute over the primacy of the Western world in abundance of blue marlin. The matter may yet have to be settled by the Senate, sitting as a court.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Long Island retained the Myra D. Patterson Trophy by defeating Westchester and New Jersey contingents in their thirtieth triangular team match for the cup at the Apawamis Club today.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Ch. Licken Run's Rock and Roll, frisky black-and-tan 2 1/2-year-old terrier purchased by Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago at Madison Square Garden last winter, scored an important specialty victory today.

In your editorial of Sept. 20, commenting on the formation of the Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic, you stated that: "Now a serious situation has to be faced by all powers as well as France."
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 26 -- Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher reserved decision today in a suit to prevent the installation of a Nativity creche on the lawn of Ossining High School.
The privilege of attending the seventy-fourth opening night of the Metropolitan Opera on Oct. 27 will be more expensive than last season's.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Justice Department will fight the refusal of Judge John E. Miller to pass on the legality of a "private-school" plan in Little Rock, Ark.
The Yankees returned to the Stadium last night for their final world series tune-up -- a three-game brush with the Orioles -- and regaled a gathering of 14,668 with a show of utter futility.
HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 26 -- In three years under Bob Blackman, Dartmouth has come from the depths to rank with the top Ivy football powers.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has offered a helping hand to the virtually inaccessible Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan to end its isolation from India and the modern world beyond.
Over a tumult of Bay Ridge boos and catcalls, Robert Moses warned the Board of Estimate yesterday that the city must make an immediate decision on the proposed Narrows bridge.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman ruled yesterday that the Ford Motor Company and Caswell Motor Company, a Ford dealer, had infringed a patent owned by the International Nickel Company.

In August of 1937, when Ranger had swept ahead of Endeavour II in much the way that Columbia walked away from Sceptre, Harold S. Vanderbilt, the successful defending skipper, relaxed his usual reserve. Almost jubilantly he said, in answer to a question about what had made Ranger so fast:

Stocks made small gains yesterday, closing a wobbly week in which more stocks rose than fell, but in which the standard issues represented in the averages had moved lower. The week's volume was the heaviest of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals ruled today that retired officers were part of the nation's national defense effort and therefore subject to court-martial, the same as officers on active duty.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The advance in British Government securities was checked on the Stock Exchange today and prices moved into reverse.

MIAMI, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Dale Hackbart, operating behind a hard - charging line, sparked Wisconsin's football team to a 20-0 victory over Miami tonight before a record season-opening crowd of about 60,000 in the Orange Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Government will support the price of corn grown in violation of Federal planting allotments this year at a national average of $1.06 a bushel, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A nest where a succulent young Blue Point oyster is safe from the predatory snail was patented this week. The inventor uses a thousand of the oyster nests on his underwater farm in Long Island's Great South Bay.

I should like to point out an error in Topics of The Times for Sept. 22, which engrossingly outlined the history of American journalism education while recognizing the University of Missouri's pioneering role.

Earnings of Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., in the quarter to end Sept. 30 will be substantially higher than those of the two preceding quarters, Mortimor S. Gordon, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
A Bronx girl who broke her tooth on a metal object found in a can of salmon is entitled to collect damages from the retailer even though she did not purchase the salmon.
MIAMI, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Joe Hall, Dade County's School Superintendent, has admitted that race was involved in the barring of four Negro children from a white school.

The three-year settlement between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Workers presents a most important challenge to the entire management of the motor industry, the U. A. W. and to the public as a whole.
CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- An offer to stop the killing and terror and negotiate a peaceful settlement with France was made today by the Provisional Government of Algeria.

State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan yesterday postponed a hearing on a show -cause order obtained a week ago by the Waterfront Commission. Commission counsel requested a delay until Thursday to permit additional study of papers in the case.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- New England railroads served notice today that they planned to raise first class passenger and coach fares by 5 per cent on Dec. 1.

GLASSMAKING, the oldest industry in the New World, is celebrating its 350th birthday this year. The anniversary was marked yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Home Fashions League at the Roosevelt Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -Former President Harry S. Truman happily collected $28 in the North Beach sector of San Francisco today to kick off a Dollars for Democrats drive in northern California. He finished the job in less than a half hour.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- With officials agreeing that tensions in the Middle East have "generally eased," prospects brightened today for an early withdrawal of British troops from Jordan and United States forces from Lebanon.

Performances of "The World of Suzie Wong" on the evenings of Dec. 2 and Dec. 10 will benefit the Play Schools Association. The Paul Osborn comedy starring France Nuyen is scheduled to open at the Broadhurst Theatre on Oct. 14.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -The Argentine Government has again put off a settlement of the American and Foreign Power Company's claim for its expropriated properties here.
In the late Nineteen Thirties "liberals" had an answer for those who asked "Why war over Danzig?" But today it is the "liberals" who are asking the deceiving question: "Why war over Quemoy?"

ALBANY, Sept. 26 (UPI)--Tomorrow will be American Indian Day in New York State. Governor Harriman, proclaiming the observance, said everyone should "join in paying tribute to our Indian friends and neighbors." He noted that thirty-seven tribes were represented in the state.

On the front page of your issue of Sept. 17 it is reported that Eisenhower is awaiting the "outcome of public demands for a reopening of public schools before taking legal action to that end." And on Page 26 it is reported that in Front Royal resistance grew "faint hearted" when parents learned what the cost would be to run the schools without state aid.
HILL 904, Algeria, Sept. 26 -About 2,000 Moslem men and women came to this mountain top on the edge of Kabylia today to vote in army tents serving as polling places.
OF all the gamblers at the wheel of fashion in Paris this summer, few played for bigger stakes than Sears Roebuck and Montgomery Ward.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 26 -- A tentative timetable and an operation plan have been issued for the withdrawal of United States troops from Lebanon, a responsible source said today.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 26--Members of the Nassau County Ophthalmological Society will conduct free eye examinations at ten Long Island hospitals tomorrow. The examinations are to prevent blindness through the early detection of glaucoma, a disorder resulting from increased pressure of fluids within the eyeball.
More than 5,000 pedestrians have received summonses in the first six weeks of enforcement of the city's anti-jaywalking law. The campaign began on Aug. 8, after several months of educational effort.

NAZILLI, Turkey, Sept. 25 -Premier Adnan Menderes pulled a switch today to open a dam that gives Turkey one of the largest hydroelectric power plants in Europe. He said the coursing waters that started the huge turbines spinning provided the best answer to critics of his expansive and expensive public works program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Public mail to the State Department on the Quemoy situation has been steadily increasing and is running heavily against the Administration's decision to help the Chinese Nationalists retain the offshore islands.
The Dec. 19 performance of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, "The Flower Drum Song," at the St. James Theatre will benefit Woman's Hospital.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Jimmy Wilson, the Negro sentenced to die after robbing a white woman of $1.95, meet Gov. James E. Folsom today while his attorney pleaded for clemency. The Governor took the case under advisement.

Now that the major share of this summer's scanty heat appears to have passed away another season of bowling will be upon us. Men, women and children, twenty-five million strong, will fill once again the many bowling alleys in pursuit of exercise, entertainment and on occasion a dollar or two.

SOUMA, Algeria, Sept. 26 -- Tiny communities scattered all over Algeria voted today in the first round of the three-day referendum on a new French Constitution. Other rural communities will vote tomorrow and the cities will vote Sunday.
MONTREAL, Sept. 26 (UPI) -The communique of the Commonwealth Economic Conference sounded the theme of assistance to under-developed countries and the lifting of trade barriers wherever possible.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Communist Hungarian Parliament today dissolved itself and set Nov. 16 as the date for the first general election in the country since 1953. Municipal elections will be held at the same time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -John W. Gwynne, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, declared today that Congressional investigating committees had failed to assure witnesses fair treatment.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Strikes and wildcat stoppages continue to curtail automobile production today as negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation reached the critical stage.

True early lines on most of the teams that figured prominently in pre-season football polls will be available after today's contests as Army, Navy, Notre Dame, Oklahoma and Ohio State swing into action for the first time this season.
The National Fair Campaign Practices Committee said here yesterday it was looking into a complaint concerning the Iowa Gubernatorial campaign.

The Communist party of the United States celebrated its thirty-ninth anniversary last night by echoing the Communist world's demand that the United States withdraw its military forces from the Taiwan area.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- There were sorrow and shame in some of the page one headlines today. "Sad, Sad, Sceptre," cried the nationalist, Empire - minded Daily Express in seven columns. "Final Shame -- Beaten by a Mile."

THE Broadway theatre, that incalculable mixture of carnival and art, has roused itself to a new season, as any sharp-eared producer can tell by the flutter of checks from anxious angels rushing into the footlighted world where fools fear to tread. For the nation's theatre capital is supported mainly by men and women immersed in self-deception so profound they could persuade themselves that the watery orange drink sold in theatres is champagne.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 27 -- Syracuse spotted Boston College a two-touchdown lead, then defeated the Eagles, 24 -- 14, before an Archbold Stadium crowd of 15,000 today.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Northwestern, a Big Ten weakling that failed to win a game last year, opened its season today with a 29-28 victory over Washington State, one of the leading contenders for the Pacific Coast Conference title.

AFTER his graduation from a concentration camp, Alfred Andersch, young West German writer, spent his formative years in the German Army, from which he deserted in 1944. He continued his formal education in an American prison camp, was released a year later, started writing after the war.
BALBOA, C. Z., Sept. 27 -Another "battle of the levels" such as marked the building of the Panama Canal may be ahead on decisions about its future.

IN this candid and engaging book Father John LaFarge, author of "The Manner Is Ordinary," remarks truly that the general public (including the non-religious and the anti-religious part) is more interested today than it was a generation ago in what churches and churchmen have to say.
Pretty girls and air travel seem to go well together. Passenger airlines early took advantage of this situation in hiring hostesses. This kept male passengers from being frightened.

" IT HE feeling that each one of us is encircled by a dark secret leaves me no peace. I feel that, though we love each other so much, we barricade ourselves against each other as we would against enemies," Valeria writes in her diary in late February, 1951.
DALLAS, Sept. 27 -- James H. Douglas, Secretary of the Air Force, warned tonight of the United States' readiness to use nuclear weapons in the China crisis.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 -- The future defense role of the National Guard will be the major issue at the eightieth general conference of the National Guard Association of the United States. The conference opens here Monday.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Sept. 27 -- The Atomic Energy Commission said yesterday it was ready to sell uranium enriched to more than 99.97 per cent in the uranium 238 isotope. This form is not available from any commercial sources.

GREENWICH, N. J. -- Colonial patriots disguised as Indians will again burn English tea here in old Greenwich, in south Jersey's Cumberland County, next Friday evening. The burning will be part of a two-day celebration of events in the village's colonial and revolutionary history, which is being sponsored by the county historical society, the Board of Freeholders and the Township of Greenwich.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 27 -- The South's growing atomic development was underscored here this week by approval of a plan to create the nation's first regional nuclear energy agreement.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 23 -One of the least-publicized stakes in the continuing war between the Nationalist and Communist Chinese is a collection of 242,590 paintings, woodcuts, tapestries and pieces of jade and porcelain. It is considered the largest, most valuable collection of Oriental art in the world.
The Jewish Festival of Tabernacles will begin at sundown today.

I am grateful to Miss Schleier and Mr. Gerras for their good letters on the past two Sundays relative to the problem of the wheel chair patron in the theatre, a matter which happens to affect me personally.

OFTEN of spectacular variety, New York exhibitions rarely show fourteenth and fifteenth century frescoes, more rarely still those of the quality now at Duveen's. Foremost here are two fragments containing flying angels to which the mighty name of Giotto has been attached.

TO THE SPORTS EDITOR: In last Sunday's Times you had a small article on Hoyt Wilhelm following his no-hitter. You mentioned some of his unusual distinctions as a pitcher. Everything you mentioned was fine and yet you neglected to write of one of Wilhelm's most unusual distinctions.
NORTHERN gardens will be more colorful in winter if they are wisely planted m fall. Many trees and shrubs can be selected to provide showy fruits, foliage, bark and, in a few cases, flowers.
James and Allegra Mertz of the American Yacht Club had the best over-all record for the second straight season in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship competition.

" A TOUCH OF THE POET," which opens at the Helen Hayes Theatre on Thursday, is almost certain to be the last new full-length play by Eugene O'Neill that will ever be produced. It has been awaiting production since O'Neill revised it into final form in November, 1942 -- a Friday, the 13th.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27 -- Revenues of the Tennessee Valley Authority from the power program during the fiscal year 1958 totaled $233,600,000, according to a 600-word financial statement released today. Net income was reported at $55,000,000.
A gangling 18-year-old lost his job last week. He was doing pretty well, but he missed a day he couldn't explain at the time.

The merits of cooperative education will be examined in a nationwide study supported by the Fund for the Advancement of Education. The program was announced last week by Dr. Ralph W. Tyler, director of the Center for Advanced Study in Behavioral Sciences, Palo Alto, Calif., and chairman of the Study Committee on Cooperative Education.

FOR the past three summers the big news in men's clothing has been the improvement -- and acceptance -- of the hot-weather suit known as wash-and-wear. The news now is that pioneers in the clothing and chemical industries have developed a fall-weight (winter-season) suit that will be as scrubbable, rinsable and dryable as its fly-weight summer cousin.

BOGNOR REGIS, England, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Fifty school girls braved exploding firecrackers today and marched through this English resort with banners denouncing plans to make them go to school with boys.

WITH the ladies going from the sack to the trapeze to the Empire in the course of one short season, it is almost reassuring to report that men contemplate no radical change in their appearance this fall and winter.

GREENLAWN, L. I., Sept. 27 -- On a day on which only a hardy-type dog might be expected to excel, a hardy-type did, as the Suffolk County Kennel Club's twentieth annual all-breed event sloshed through a long program.

The Seaman's Church Institute of New York has chosen the Dec. 4 performance of "The Man in the Dog Suit" for its annual autumn theatre benefit. The Albert Beich and William H. Wright comedy, starring Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn, is scheduled to open at the Coronet Theatre on Oct. 30.

The Yankees' final tune-up program for the world series was slightly disrupted yesterday when rain wiped out the second encounter of the three-game series with the Orioles at the Stadium. The postponed game will be played as part of a double-header today as the regular season closes.

MICHAEL TODD PRODUCTIONS plans to bring something new to the screen scene provided the entire human race does not become permanently afflicted with head colds. Last week it was learned that the independent company was preparing to make a feature that not only would be in color and in the new Todd 70-mm.

The layout editor for George Barrett's delightful and perceptive article missed a rare opportunity. He showed three paintings of Aphrodite which the author did not mention, but no picture of the statue which was second in his list, though, alas, he devoted to her only these words: "Rome's tender, radiant Aphrodite of Cyrene."

HERBERT L. MATTHEWS' recent review of the novel "Reapers of the Storm" by Lyttleton and Sturz gives an inaccurate impresson of life in Spain. It seems to come from the book, not the reviewer, though he does not question the statement that "The material * * * was smuggled out in small notebooks to Gibraltar."

Just a note of appreciation to thank The New York Times Magazine for printing the two superb articles which appeared in the issues of Sept. 7 and 14. In refer to Mr. Nehru's article on the "Paradox of Our Age" and Senator Fulbright's article concerning complacency.

NEXT Friday, many residents of the Netherlands -- and especially those who live in the university town of Leiden -- will feast on hutspot met klapstuck literally hodgepodge with beef. Historians say that this flavorful and substantial combination of potatoes, carrots and meat has been served on that date for nearly 400 years.

Resident buyers' offices report increasing delivery problems in ready-to-wear departments. There were heavy Paris promotions this year, which preempted some production facilities, and recent holidays have slowed the output of normal fall merchandise.

IN the Northwest, the accent is on the English hollies. Part of the emphasis is due to the extensive cut holly industry in Oregon and Washington. Commercial growers continually search for the best heavy-berried and colorful types of English holly for decorative purposes.

AS the seasons progress, several insects mature and become "noisemakers." Their sounds are known to everyone who lives outside the city and they often become disconcertingly familiar to vacationers who are accustomed to the noises of subways and taxis.

NO rock garden would be complete without one or two plants of Phlox subulata. This perennial, probably because it is so well liked, has several common names -- moss pink, mountain pink, ground pink, creeping phlox and flowering moss.

THE poet and journalist, Harry Roskolenko, has had the audacity to go around the world on a scooter and return to tell us about it. He has thereby put us in his debt. "Poet on a Scooter" is a fascinating example of American escapist-discovery literature.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles is now engaged in the biggest gamble of his long diplomatic career. He is playing poker in China with nothing better than a pair of deuces in his hand and a forty-five in his pocket, and he is playing it against Chou En-lai and Mao Tse-tung, two of the roughest international card sharks in the world.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Frank S. Hogan, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, said here tonight that state Democrats had patched up their differences and were united behind the ticket.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff proposed today the establishment of a state-supported mental health community center in cooperation with the Yale University Medical School.

We give our warm congratulatory salute to the designers, builders and sailors of the yacht Columbia. They have done a magnificent job in their defense of the America's Cup and we are rightly proud of them. What they showed was exactly the right combination of skill, persistence, boldness and imagination that makes for great triumphs in sport.

An expanded program of travel films and lectures, and courses in opera, music appreciation and singing is planned for Town Hall's new season opening next month. Town Hall became an integral part of New York University last February and now operates under its Division of General Education and Extension Services.

FIVE events of major interest to photographers will be held this week and next. Most important is the international exhibition "Photokina 1958" in Cologne, Germany, which opened yesterday and will continue through next Sunday.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Virginia Military Institute, unbeaten since 1956, struck at every opportunity today to defeat Villanova, 33 -- 6, in the rain before 6,800 at Villanova Stadium.

The talk along Madison Avenue about fast plays these days may have nothing to do with the volatile nature of the advertising business. The football season is here and few areas can claim more fervent adherents.
OTTAWA, Sept. 27 -- Canada decisively relinquished the airplane as a defense instrument this week and turned to the missile as the weapon of the future.

BY the Twenties the novel, which in the hands of our greatest writers had been a superb moral instrument, became morally diffident and much of its energy was turned upon itself in the form of technical experimentation.

Your editorial of Sept. 15 "The Atom at Geneva" ably summarized the significance of the recently concluded International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy. You are also to be congratulated for your thorough daily coverage of that gathering of scientists.

EAST ORANGE, N. J. Sept. 27 -- A large committee has been named to aid the second annual Ball of the Oranges, which will be held here on Nov. 28 at the Suburban Hotel. The announcement was made by Calvin A. Agar Jr. of Llewellyn Park and James Linen Macwithey of East Orange, co-chairmen of the event, which will benefit the East Orange General Hospital laundry renovation fund.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Nick Bottini, a rangy end, converted a blocked punt in the third period into a touchdown and enabled little Buffalo to upset Harvard to day, 6 -- 3. It was the football season opener for both teams at rain-drenched Harvard Stadium.

BOYS and girls never seem to tire of reading about Abraham Lincoln or about animals; and, naturally, the two together make an unbeatable combination. Here, Mrs. Randall, wife of the late James G. Randall, an authority on Lincoln, writes of the great man's friendships with dogs, cats, goats, pigs and horses.

Apparel exhibits have been scheduled in Chicago for a week beginning last Friday. Two women's apparel groups postponed their showings from earlier dates because of a convention conflict. These were Style Exhibitors, Inc., at the Morrison Hotel, and the Chicago National Women's Apparel Show at the Palmer House.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics' consumer price index, which started rising in March, 1956, and which was to rise or remain unchanged in twenty-eight of the twenty-nine months that ensued, took its second backward step in the month of August, the thirtieth month.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Fifteen Latin-American countries today signed an agreement that probably means coffee prices in the United States will remain at current levels.
The Treasury has started an intensive study of all phases of debt management, Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, disclosed last week.

EVERY once in while the reading public is offered a historical novel so gigantic in its concept and so cycloramic in its effect that it is like a glacier calving. Great waves rush out in all directions on the hitherto calm sea.

SHORTLY after the announced starting time for a jazz concert at Town Hall early this month, Al Collins, a disk jockey, walked out on the stage and told the audience that although the concert was already more than ten minutes late, he had been sent out to talk to them for a while. The reason for this, Mr. Collins explained, was that none of the musicians had arrived yet.
TRENTON, Sept. 27 -- The Republican State Committee will convene here on Wednesday to name Senator H. Alexander Smith as the party's state chairman for ninety days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that its Vanguard satellite had not ascended to the orbital path at which it was aimed yesterday. Instead, it made one or perhaps more low-altitude trips around the world and then burned up from atmospheric friction.
A former queen of the American coastal passenger fleet is headed for the scrap yard.

THE calendar may say September but, to listen to talk among human relations specialists this month, it might as well be spring. Not since the last song writers' convention has there been so much serious -- and businesslike -- discussion of love as went on at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association.
A total of 11,169,536 patrons wagered $804,699,260 at New York State horse race tracks last year. From these pari-mutuel transactions, the state collected a record $73,998,563 in taxes.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27 -- River tow traffic on the 650-mile Tennessee River, which amounted to an estimated 12,740,000 tones last year, will be speeded up by a new lock under construction at Wilson Dam, Muscle Shoals, Ala.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- It is the judgment of many competent observers here that no error of commission or omission by President Eisenhower since he has been in office has wrought more political havoc inside the Republican party than his handling of the Sherman Adams affair.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept 27 -- Voters turned down today a proposal to open this city's four high schools on a desegregated basis by a majority of almost three to one.
MY adventure with growing the true mandrake of Biblical and literary fame began three summers ago when I saw a number of young Mandragora officinarum plants at Mrs. Mortimer J. Fox's garden.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Joe Barbagallo, the 60-year-old chief barber at the United Nations, has continued to coexist happily with the East and West by following a policy of no debating, no chopping and no waiting.

WHEN I first encountered Philip Larkin's work in this grouping of young poets and almost poets, I felt as if my glasses had been wiped miraculously clean. Not one of Housman's tests (the shiver up the spine, the tightened throat, the watering eye), but I have no doubt that Mr. Larkin is the real thing.

THE recent flurry of concern over purity of television quiz shows the latest chapter in the electronic evolution of one of man's primitive methods of diversion and self-analysis. The game of finding out who knows the answers has been a flourishing social institution ever since Eve made Adam guess in which hand she held the apple. Television merely improved upon its economic features.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Fourteen Monmouth County communities will decide seventeen local questions by referendum at the Nov. 4 general election. The dealline for filing municipal questions for inclusion on the ballots ended Thursday.

BASEBALL is a sport of infinite variety and swiftly changing patterns. And never more so than at its summit, the world series, which is with us again this week in a rematch of last year's rivals -- the National League's Milwaukee Braves and the American League's New York Yankees.
The hotel industry expects to capitalize on the commercial jet age, scheduled to start in this country next month.

IT is not often that a book gives us the Egyptian side of the Near East mess. James Aldridge, an Australian novelist who wrote "Signed With Their Honor," seems, like his principal character, to "prefer the Egyptians to the English."

DIRECTOR JOHN HUSTON flew here last week from his home in Ireland to help Twentieth Century-Fox sweat out one of the heaviest gambling parlays involving one studio and the talents of a single director in many a year.

Specialists from six nations met last week in Rye, N. Y., to discuss the delicate and illuminating art of making laboratory specimens take their own pictures. The technique, called autoradiography, has already made clearer some of the basic biochemical processes of life.

Senator Fulbright in his very interesting and valuable article expresses apprehension that he will be criticized for the views expressed in this article. I am afraid he will be criticized not for these very sensible views but for failure to apply them to the very important events of our domestic policy.
THE central point of my review related not to the genuineness or falsity of the documents with which Dr. Possony's researches are concerned.

TO see a deciduous holly glowing in the autumn sunlight with its red berries on leafless branches is to gain a greater appreciation for this cousin of the American holly. The deciduous holly, which deserves wider usage on home properties, provides a long season of color in the shrub border.

BERKELEY, CALIF., Sept. 27 -- Two women and two men, including a former New Yorker, are to receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws here on Monday during inaugural ceremonies of Dr. Clark Kerr as twelfth president of the University of California.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector) (Reuters) Sept. 25 -- Moves to improve the lot of about 20,000 repatriated Arab refugees are being made by the Israeli authorities.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 18 ---- Jim Johnson, a son of "Ching" Johnson, the former New York Rangers' all-star defenseman, is just about Bolivia's coach of the year.
Problems of administering employe benefit plans will be greatly increased under some provisions of the new social security and disclosure acts, which will become effective next Jan. 1.

A LOT of people around lunch rooms and milk-shake joints have suddenly started talking about how to teach a boy to use a gun, as they do every year around this time. Thousands of words are wasted; the thing is very simple.

THE fall concert season is here. On Thursday the New York Philharmonic opens its first season under the musical direction of Leonard Bernstein. On Tuesday, Oct. 7, the Philadelphia Orchestra, under the direction of Eugene Ormandy, will make the first of its Tuesday evening visits to Carnegie Hall.

In the natural emphasis that was given to what Secretary Dulles had to say on Thursday night about the problem of Quemoy and Matsu sight may have been lost of some other aspects of his address. His summary of how we are helping Asia to remain free and to attain a better life was brief but comprehensive and telling. It presents the constructive side of the picture, and is well worth recapitulation.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 27 -- Despite the competitive fiasco that dimmed the luster of the seventeenth challenge for the America's Cup, it seemed likely today that there would be future calls on the United States to defend its yachting honors.
STUTTGART, Germany, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Two-wheel vehicles have proved faster than cars in a novel race through Stuttgart's traffic.

The Three Harbors Garden Club will hold a flower show Oct. 8 from 2 to 8 P. M. at Fort Hill, home of Mrs. Willis D. Wood of Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L. I. Mrs. Wood is honorary chairman of the flower show committee.

WITH the same skill that he has shown in three previous fictional journeys into ancient Britain, Henry Treece, a gifted English novelist, ventures back into the mists and forests. In "Red Queen, White Queen," he comes up with a novel that has all of the merits (and some of the limitations) of its predecessors.

MODERN astronomy is hard to popularize above the sky travelogue level. The subject is inherently difficult, and if it is made too easy for the reader, most of the interest is lost. Some astronomers try to educate their non scientific readers by giving brief lessons in physics as the book proceeds.

IN 1953, Lois and Herb ("Cris") Crisler spent eighteen months in Alaska's Brooks Range, "northernmost mountains on the North American mainland, largely unknown to anybody." There, Mr. Crisler was filming the life and migrations of caribou and "their wild shepherds, the wolves."

THE Biblical injunction "Physician, heal thyself" is apt advice for the tranquilizer-pill industry as mirrored in this fast-paced, suspenseful novel. An account of the gestation of a new tranquilizer -- naturally called "Pax" -- it has a hardboiled realism, an obviously intimate knowledge of the milieu by the authors ("Middleton Kiefer" is the joint pseudonym of two former public-relations men in the drug industry).
The big question on Wall Street last week was: "What's with Telephone?"

The First French Republic was proclaimed on Sept. 21, 1792, just a day after the French artillery at Valmy sent invading Prussians racing home across the Rhine. The Fifth French Republic is probably coming into being today as millions of French citizens in metropolitan France, in Algiers and in French territories beyond the seas vote on the latest proposed Constitution.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Suffolk farm hands, skillfully wielding sabre-like knives, harvested 9,675 crates of early cauliflower for the fresh markets this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Eisenhower last Monday clamped import restrictions on lead and zinc that could cost about half a dozen nations that export these metals around $70,000,000 a year in dollar earnings.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The world four-mile relay record of 16 minutes 41 seconds was cut more than 10 second today by a British team composed of Mike Blagrove, Peter Clark, Derek Ibbotson and Brian Hewson.

More than 2,500 letterpress printers from thirty-two states and several foreign countries attended an all-day demonstration here yesterday of the latest electronic and photographic developments in their field. Letterpress, dating back to the Gutenberg Bible, is the most common method of printing.

THE interesting article by Hal Bridges ("Roundup Time on the Western Range") did not mention the most successful of all writers of "Westerns." I call Mr. Bridges' attention to Karl May. The omission is understandable because May wrote in German, and, until recently, none of his books has been done in English.
NORWALK, Conn., Sept 27 -City officials are planning to draw on the talents of professionally skilled citizens to obtain a public band shell.

IN Marc Slonim's "Talk With Ignazio Silone," it is noted that Silone took a train to "Frosinone, in the Abruzzi." Frosinone, capital of the province, is located in Lazio (Latium). * * * This pleasant section of Lazio is rich in historical materials and is a paradise for the sociologist - anthropologist.

IN ITS terse career of five performances, "Howie" made one pertinent entry into the theatre's time sheet. When the head of the house wanted to unhand an F. B. I. man, he did not offer him a pair to "My Fair Lady." He offered him a pair to "The :Music Man."

THE night he was made a Koshare brave, Charlie Nickerson became a true Coloradan. A few months before, he had been a lonely eighth-grade boy, newly arrived from Cape Cod, and very unhappy with the town of La Junta.

A new type of gasoline service station, completely built and equipped in a factory and assembled at the site is being constructed in New Jersey for the American Oil Company. T. A. Aldridge, vice president of Amoco, said it was developed by Petro Merchandising of Linden, N. J., and was being built by Paramount Diners, Inc., in Haledon, N. J.

OF all the Great Lakes, Lake Superior certainly is the wildest and loveliest, just as it is the largest fresh-water lake in the world. Never can you forget even a few days spent along those cold, windswept, wave-dashed shores.

THE talented young French writer, Amaury de Riencourt, has set himself the task of producing an "all-inclusive philosophy of history." Like his earlier book, "The Coming Caesars,'' "The Soul of China" is designed to be a fragment of this larger study.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- A bitter controversy with religious and racial overtones raged this week over a vast urban renewal project that was designed primarily to protect the University of Chicago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- The Attorney General's office began this week to try to force California public utilities to pass on gains from tax write-offs to customers in the form of rate reductions.
A pamphlet explaining the various referendums being conducted in connection with this year's state election is being distributed by the League of Women Voters.

New York State has always been in the vanguard in its provisions for the education of its citizens. Its tax pattern for school support has been recognized as outstanding among the states, and its average expenditure per pupil, about $460, is the highest in the nation, far above the national average of $275.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 27 -- The Turkish Government has selected its adviser to the British Governor of Cyprus. He will go to Nicosia in the next few days to assume his duties under the new British administrative plan for the island, which goes into effect Wednesday.
SOMETHING new will be taking place when "Playhouse 90" presents William Saroyan's comedy, "The Time of Your Life," on Oct. 9 over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
WARSAW, Sept. 27 -- There were fifty-four women at a banquet table in a Warsaw hotel today. There was some chatter, a bit of laughter, and an outsider could never have known.

Last Thursday, in appropriate ceremonies, two of the nation's and the world's best known rehabilitation agencies announced an affiliation whereby they will join forces in rehabilitation research, teaching, and services to the handicapped.

Theatre parties to "The Flower Drum Song" on Dec 10 and Jan. 2 will benefit the Museum of the City of New York. The new Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical is scheduled to open at the St. James Theatre on Nov. 27.

ANDOVER, N. J., Sept. 27 -- The big cities of the United States are being rediscovered as the new frontiers of America, according to Charles Abrams, chairman of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- The new conversion rule paid off for Yale's football team in the Bowl today. The Elis struck for a touchdown early in the first quarter, added 2 points on an end run and checked a fighting University of Connecticut eleven, 8 to 6.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Maj. Gen. Wilton B. Persons and Sherman Adams are as different as the climates of their respective states -- Alabama and New Hampshire.

Clem finished 'way ahead of Round Table in the $111,200 Woodward at Belmont Park yesterday. The persistent colt who competes in the colors of Mrs. Adele Rand won the mile-and-a-quarter event by a half-length, but at the finish Round Table was completely out of it.

THIS excellent novel introduces to America a writer already well known in France. "The Law," Roger Vailland's seventh novel, received the important Prix Goncourt last year, and is a Book-of-the-Month dual selection for October. It is not Vailland's first book to be honored.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- Health officials here say that Detroit's polio epidemic has demonstrated once again the effectiveness of Salk polio vaccine shots and at the same time has accentuated the tragedy of those victims who failed to have the shots.

IT is often argued -- I have maintained it myself -- that one of the main differences between the Victorian novel and the modern novel is that the former is solidly grounded in society, taking public values for granted, while the latter, having lost that common sense of public and externally manifested values, becomes increasingly preoccupied with the difficulties of communication, the inevitable isolation of the individual, the unreality of society.

NEW do-it-yourself repair kits and patching materials have made it possible for home handymen to mend, repair or rebuild almost any broken object around the house. Adhering to just about any material that will be found in the home. these versatile patching materials set without heat or pressure, and will not rot, rust or deteriorate -- indoors or out.

DURING the early Eighteen Hundreds stout, barge-like keelboats plied the muddy Missouri, rowed, poled or pulled along by their rugged crewmen. Many hazardous miles upriver was the untouched wealth of the Oregon Territory, jealously protected hunting ground of the Blackfeet.
Two years ago, at Amsterdam, the Netherlands, ten competed in the challengers' tournament which determined the candidate to meet Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia for the world championship at chess.

CAIRO, Sept. 27 -- On Wednesday it will be eight months since the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria was proclaimed from the balcony of the seldom-used old Presidential offices across the street from the Parliament Building, which has since suffered a similar state of desuetude.

Expense accounts in this country are estimated at five to ten billion dollars a year. Losses to the Treasury from their abuse are estimated at one to two billion a year in an article by V. Henry Rothschild and Rudolf Sobernheim, published last week by The Yale Law Journal.
HARTFORD, Sept. 27 -- Gov. Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, who was elected to the Senate this month, is coming to Connecticut to help Thomas J. Dodd, the Democratic nominee for the Senate.
A strike against Youth House in the Bronx will begin as scheduled at 12:01 A. M. Monday, Youth House Local 1457, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, said last night.

LIKE every other genius, St. Francis of Assisi belongs to everyone, is part of the total human inheritance. But also (like every other genius) he was intensely of his own age, was supremely a thirteenth-century Umbrian merchant's son, of that time and of that place alone, and of none other.

STALIN, Rumania, Sept. 12 -- The director took his small black notebook from his corduroy jacket, spread it carefully on his desk and began telling a visitor about the economy of a Rumanian collective farm.

The Saturday evening performance of Eugene O'Neill's "A Touch of the Poet" will benefit the Greater New York chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy (ANTA). The play opens Thursday at the Helen Hayes Theatre.
An "acute" shortage of teachers here in the junior high school division was attributed yesterday to the city's failure to offer higher salaries to attract specialists.

NOT a single novel but a grouping of three novelettes, intimately related in theme, "Three Who Ventured" is a remarkably unified book. Its unity rises not out of character or action or structure or style -- but simply out of a view of life that informs each of these three quite separate yet somehow fused narratives.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Burrna's new strong man said tonight that he had accepted a call from Premier Nu to form an interim government because the nation was in a state of "grave disturbance."

The Triangle Circle, a women's club, will hold an afternoon bridge party on Oct. 27 at the Colony Club. Proceeds of the fete will go to the college scholarship fund of St. Christopher's School, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

ASCHOLAR of international note, Sabatino Moscati, is Professor of Semitic Philology at the University of Rome, and in earlier years also taught the history of religions. With such a background it is natural that he should approach the ancient civilizations of the Middle East mainly in terms of their linguistic connection, and of the literature, so much of which is religious in inspiration, through which this connection can be traced.
LOUISVILLE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Winsome Winner survived a stretch drive by Pilot and won the $25,000 added Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs today.

Philip Pollack is doubtless correct when in your Drama Mailbag he predicts that "some day there will be a play about Franklin D. Roosevelt based, not on mannerisms, but on the man and on the social forces that molded him."

This is the time when the annual confusion starts over the ending of Daylight Saving Time. In some places it has ended. Wisconsin turned the clock back one hour at midnight, while California reverted to standard time at 2 A. M. today. Other states where many communities will go back to standard time today include Illinois and Indiana. New York remains on daylight time.

MT. KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Rose Stradner, a former motion picture actress and the wife of Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Hollywood writer, producer and director, was found dead here this afternoon in their summer home.

THE current exhibition at the National Academy of Design, organized to mark the centennial of Henry Ward Ranger who was both artist and art patron, is of much greater interest to the visitor on two other counts.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 27 -The United States offered full support today to the new Cabinet of Premier Rashid Karami.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Southern California fought Michigan almost to a stand-off today before the Wolverines escaped with a 20-19 triumph in their football opener, witnessed by 77,000 fans.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Warren Spahn posted his twenty-second victory of the season today as the Milwaukee Braves, the champions of the National League, whipped the Cincinnati Redlegs, 6 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Urban expansion was seen in a Department of Agriculture document today as laying the groundwork for a possible collapse in land values.

Barring some spectacular change in the positions taken thus far by the United States and Communist China in the Warsaw negotiations, the crisis over Taiwan Strait seems to be headed for the United Nations.
CAIRO, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser introduced land reform laws for the Syrian Region of the United Arab Republic today.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Royalty, that ever-fresh staple of British news, was recruited today by three London newspapers to revive circulations.
MIDDLE-ATLANTIC gardeners are discovering that many kinds of evergreen holly tolerate subzero winters. Thus these handsome plants are steadily gaining popularity for use in the home landscape.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Ted Williams, gunning for his second straight American League batting championship and the sixth of his career, took over the lead from Pete Runnels today when he had three hits in the Boston Red Sox's 9-5 victory over the Senators.
WASHINGTON -- The Government is taking a travel tip from the nation's gasoline stations: A traveler, whether by sea or land, likes a map he can handle.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- French and French-ruled voters around the world -- 47,000,000 of them -- will be asked tomorrow to approve or reject revolutionary changes in their institutions and, inferentially, the leadership of Premier Charles de Gaulle.

ROME, Sept. 27. (UPI) -- A simple safety device for sleepy motorists may be the answer to the growing problem of Italy's road accidents. Truck drivers who recently tested the device enthusiastically dubbed it a "Guardian Halo."

THIS is a German physician's book about two solitary small-boat trips across the Atlantic, one in an African dugout canoe, the other in a seventeen-foot folding boat. Hannes Lindemann writes that while he was employed at a United States air base in Morocco he "met a man who as a voluntary castaway, had studied the problems of survival at sea.
WARSAW, Sept. 26 -- In a dim corridor of Warsaw's Ministry of Education, delegations of Polish mothers waited patiently for their chance to speak their piece to the official behind the door.
A pair of highly versatile new radio-telescope "ears" for the young science of radio astronomy is being made ready at an observatory operated by the California Institute of Technology.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Sam Barton sailed Aries to a 78-second victory today in the third race of the International Class post-season series for the deCoppet Trophy.

I have just read, with great pleasure, the article by Max Frankel, "Q A On a Moscow Street Corner" (Aug. 31). Having just returned from Europe and spending ten days in Russia, I can wholeheartedly agree with all that was written.

The Cantonese words "mon lei" mean "ten thousand miles." Yesterday a 40-year-old Chinese junk that had been abandoned and restored a number of times cast off her moorings for a cruise down the inland waterway to Florida.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The eighth annual House Tour of the Mount Holyoke Club of Westchester will be held here the afternoon of Oct. 7, from 1 to 5 o'clock. Proceeds of the tour will provide scholarship funds for qualified Westchester girls attending the college in South Hadley, Mass.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Lehigh University upset heavily favored Delaware, 8 -- 7, this afternoon on the strength of a third-period touchdown and two-point conversion.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Cornell beat Colgate in football for the first time in five years today. A rain-soaked crowd of 12,000 at Schoellkopf Field saw the Big Red score in each of the last two periods for a 13-0 victory.

HOLLY was a doll, in a red dress, red shoes, with a green petticoat and socks, and, like all the dolls in the toyshop, she wanted a little girl for Christmas. Ivy, 6 years old, (green coat, red gloves), was an orphan in search of a non- existent grandmother, and she was wishing for a doll too.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Two-thirds of the voters in continental France are expected to approve tomorrow a constitution giving General Charles de Gaulle more power than any French peacetime leader has exercised since the fall of Emperor Napoleon III in 1870.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- "God save me from my friends, I can take care of my enemies." This proverb must be much in the mind of Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, as he surveys the fractious ranks of Labor today.

In Texas, railroad promoters still think big -- well, pretty big. While Eastern carriers are doing their best to curtail plant and reduce operations, down in Dallas and Fort Worth twelve forward-looking investors have laid out $1,200,000 to build a seventeen-mile railroad.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 27 -- Notre Dame's vaunted football machine had to pull out all the stops for an 18-0 victory today over Indiana's inspired Hoosiers before 49,347 fans.
