With October designated as National Science Youth Month, a group of thirty-five youngsters in the metropolitan area is embarking on a stepped-up program in science education and participation.

IN "Flash and Filigree." a first novel by Terry Southern, two nightmares run parallel through the Southern California landscape. One is the situation of Babs Minter, pretty but puerile nurse at the Hauptmann Clinic. The other is the predicament of Dr. Frederick Eichner. "the world's foremost dermatologist."

IN this mature, moving account of the rise, fall and partial recovery of a Hollywood "personality," Robert Carson, as a sort of bonus, has left the reader the task of determining who are the romantic parties referred to in the title. Kit McClaren is plainly one of the lovers.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- A community chest type of agency that has just come into legal being hopes by next year to end signs of a "revolt" against charity in northern Westchester.
WILMINGTON, N. C., Sept. 27 -- Winds of 135 miles an hour, twenty-five-foot waves and torrential rains from Hurricane Helene broke across North Carolina's coast today and wrought widespread damage.

TASSAFT, Algeria, Sept. 27. -- The second day of the referendum in Algeria ended in apparent calm. There was no violence at the polls and no unusual military activity by the nationalist rebel army, French authorities reported tonight.
PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The French Government has burst into song on the eve of the constitutional referendum. The melody has a calypso flavor and the lyrics are decidedly political.
Plans have been completed for the annual autumn theatre party sponsored by Chapter Number One Auxiliary of the Berkshire Industrial Farm.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 27 (AP) -- A 98-yard scoring run of a pass interception by Phil Parslow, a second-string halfback, today touched off an 18-14 victory for the University of California at Los Angeles over Illinois.

THE world peace appeals by Dr. Albert Schweitzer which were broadcast in April from Oslo, Norway, are published this week under the title, "Peace or Atomic War?" (Holt, $1.50). The three addresses call for an end to nuclear bomb testing, outline the dangers of atomic war and urge a summit conference on disarmament.

THE most surprising headline in a long time on the subject of motion pictures recently appeared in a weekly film trade paper here. NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- Chinese Communist goods at cut-rate prices and on easy credit terms are pushing Indian exports out of many traditional markets in Asia.
CLEMSON. S. C., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Clemson surmounted a major obstacle in its drive for national and Atlantic Coast Conference football honors today with a stirring 26-21 victory over North Carolina.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation worked against a Tuesday strike deadline today to resolve bargaining differences reported to center on what the union called wage inequities.

The art season steps up its pace this week with many group and one-man exhibitions, including work by well known European and American artists. Two of the shows will be devoted to work by the late Arthur Dove and two others to work by Picasso.

AMANI, Tanganyika, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Most persons do their best to avoid mosquitos. But here, on the top of a 3,000-foot mountain that juts up from the steaming jungle, a handful of scientists regularly offer their arms and legs to be bitten by the insects.

The Industrial College of the Armed Forces will conduct a series of twelve lectures on national defense at Town Hall this fall and winter. The talks will be open to civilians, as well as to reserve officers.

NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Oklahoma's new rapid-fire multiple offense sputtered in the early minutes, but eventually proved effective as the Sooners raced to a 47-14 opening football game victory over the West Virginia Mountaineers today.

THE eighth annual Fall Conference of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., will open this afternoon at the Lake Placid Club, Lake Placid, N. Y. Registration for the three-day program will be taken from 3 to 8 P. M.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Iowa tossed a versatile football offensive, triggered by the passing of Randy Duncan, at Texas Christian University for a 17-0 victory today.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 27 -- A statistical study of whistlers, strange signals that travel from earth to space and back again, has shown that they occur in marked cycles.
VIENNA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- East and West fought again today as the International Atomic Energy Agency ended the first week of its second general conference.

IT is good that a generous disposition prevails among serious movie fans to go all out in touting unusual and exotic films that do possess uncommon merits, though perhaps not as many as the touting implies.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- An international approach to the problem of displaced persons in the form of a world refugee year will be proposed to the General Assembly by Auguste R. Lindt, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, it was learned here today.

ST. JOHN, American Virgin Islands - This small island, so quiet Utah one bright-lights addict described it as "the place old people go to visit their parents," is excited these days. Not since the opening of the twenty-ninth National Park here (on which occasion one authority reported an outbreak of hypertension among the natives) has there been such a stir.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -President Eisenhower today selected Maj. Gen. Wilton B. Persons, a friend of twenty-five years, to succeed Sherman Adams as the Assistant to the President.

ADD to National Prune Week, National LoveThy-Neighbor Week and National Oyster Week a new one -- Stereo High Fidelity Week. This newcomer has been proclaimed by Mayor Wagner, as of next Tuesday, and it will continue through Saturday. By a not unexpected coincidence, those five days will also be the period when the annual New York High Fidelity Music Show is being held at the New York Trade Show Building.

NEWARK, Sept. 27 -- Ten thousand persons braved today's showers to help the Port of New York Authority celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of Newark Airport. The two-day program, which continues tomorrow, commemorates the establishing of the airfield on Oct. 1, 1928.

THE old gag about holding a Democrat caucus in the hall closet is no longer funny up here in the wilds of Maine. As Marty Manter said when he found his mare sitting in the buggy seat, the situation has changed. Even the Republicans can find more members than that.

WASHINGTON -- The great summer hegira is over. Family automobiles are back in their home garages, and children, back in school are telling teachers and classmates of the wonders they saw, including the glimpses of history and national grandeur they encountered during their summer travels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Supreme Court will meet at noon Monday to hand down its opinion in the case in which it denied Little Rock, Ark., further delay in integrating Schools.

TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 28 -The casualty toll from typhoon Ida mounted today as reports trickled in from flooded areas of central Japan. The police listed 303 persons dead, 696 injured and 1,230 missing.

WHAT a red cloak is to a Spanish bull, so is an auctioneer's red flag to people who rush headlong to bid and buy. Park Commissioner Robert Moses has refused aid in selling underwater lots owned by the city to expand a private beach club at Clason Point in the Bronx. Mr. Moses said he would renew his efforts to oust the club in favor of a public park.
BERGEN, Germany, Sept. 27 -- The consensus of Allied military observers after a mock battle of West German brigade formations is that the 105,000-man Bundeswehr has arrived as an army in being.
Big business is giving more of its philanthropic dollar to education than ever before, according to a survey announced last week by the Council for Financial Aid to Education.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Mobile County Sheriff Ray D. Bridges said today seven men had been arrested, including the Saraland Police Chief, N. W. (Pat) Patrick, in connection with cross-burnings there.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 27 -- Life on Taiwan which, except for a few tiny islands like Quemoy is all that is left of free China, goes on as usual despite the almost daily threats of the Communist Government in Peiping to "liberate" the 9,000,000 Taiwanese and about 2,000,000 mainlanders here.
The long-sought goal of $1,000,000,000 a year in gifts for American education may not be too far away if current philanthropic trends continue.

Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund, Inc., has reported net assets of $185,362,515, equal to $11.09 each on 16,715,023 shares outstanding Aug. 31. This compared with $136,538,456, or $10.61 each on 12,865,656 shares a year earlier.

Energetic and voluble Edward M. Gilbert, a 34-year-old New York lumber executive, bounded into prominence recently in a role usually associated with flinty-eyed Wall Street stock operators. He fought for a company and almost cornered its stock in the process.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Starfish -- arch enemy of Long Island Sound's oysters -continue to defy man's best efforts to eradicate them. The main reason, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service said today, is the pest's ability to move six or eight inches a minute.

THE first Nassau County section of the 90-mile Long Island Expressway will open Tuesday. The new stretch runs from the Queens-Nassau line to Willis (Mineola) Avenue in Roslyn. On the west it connects with a 2.5-mile completed section of the Expressway in Queens so that a contiunous new 7.5 miles of concrete will be available from Springfield Boulevard, Queens, to five miles into Nassau County.

TAIPEI, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Soviet-supplied Chinese Air Force has met its master in the Chinese Nationalist Air Force and its American-trained pilots, United States authorities said today. The Reds are being out-fought and out-thought in aerial combat.

THE Republic of Turkey, newest nation of the West, has created ten endowed playhouses as a part of its break with Oriental tradition. Three are supported by the municipality of Istanbul. Four are the State Theatres of Ankara, which send their productions to playhouses in three provincial capitals.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 27 -- A United States delegation headed by C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, arrived here by air this evening.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Led by a brilliant halfback, Bill Austin, a spirited Rutgers football team set back Princeton in surprising fashion today.
Harry Brown has a nickname -- "the fastest gun on Fourteenth Street."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Hopes had been running high on the University of Pennsylvania campus that things would be looking up for the Quakers' football team this season because of a strengthened line, particularly in the inner portion.

SINCE completing his monumental ten-volume "A Study of History," Arnold Toynbee has mellowed considerably. In that work he viewed very calmly the probable collapse of our Western civilization, as of all other surviving civilizations, and concluded that none of them had any real excuse for their existence, since in their mortal sickness none gave signs of producing a Universial Church -- the only justification he could see for a civilization.

LAST autumn, at a time when Washington's relations with the South were low, John Singleton Mosby galloped full tilt across home screens with his Confederate Rangers, leaving in his wake swaths of beaten, sullen Yankees.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Diplomatic probings are in active progress here in an attempt to find a way out of the current deadlock over the Chinese offshore islands and Taiwan.
AN oriental mystic has argued somewhere that any intelligent Chinese who studied the signatures of Chiang Kai-shek and Mao Tse-tung would have no doubt which one would conquer the other.

ABINGDON, Va. -- Fall, when flaming foliage covers the Blue Ridge Mountains, is a good season for making a scenic tour of the Skyline Drive and the Blue Ridge Parkway. From New York City it is about a 600-mile trip down the Drive and Parkway and U. S. 11 to Abingdon here in the southwest corner of Virginia.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -President Arturo Frondizi is being pushed by powerful forces toward changes in the policies and the top personnel of his Administration.

NO ONE knows for sure just how many choruses there are in the United States. A conservative estimate is 3,000, but there are some who think the number should be as high as 10,000. And the guess work covers so wide a range because no accurate survey of the nation's choral resources has ever been made.
Ten courses in astronomy, meteorology and navigation start this week at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West and Eighty-first Street.

Although Senator Fulbright's admonitions are indeed most timely, he has tactfully avoided emphasis on the most serious source of our deterioration. For is it not the manifest lack of intellectual health so rampant in high public office that has fortified the Madison Avenue technique for political aspirants?
OTTAWA, ILL., Sept. 27 -On Oct. 15, sixty trucks will start going around in circles. They will keep it up eighteen hours a day, six days a week, for two years.

TAIPEI, Taiwan Sunday, Sept. 28 -- A fierce artillery duel raged between Nationalist batteries on Quemoy and massed Communist coastal guns last night while thousands of Chinese here celebrated the "moon festival" with firecrackers and skyrockets.
